HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Black Eye Didn't Stop Crimson Star

BYLINE: By DOUG SCANCARELLA 

 BODY:
Harvard Coach Tim Murphy has seen again and again what a tough, hard-nosed running back Eion Hu is. Hu, a junior tailback, is his leading rusher this season, with four 100-yard games, a bright spot for a Crimson team with a 1-4 record.
"Whether it's the last play of the the fourth quarter or just a routine drill in practice, he's giving it 100 percent," Murphy said. "He doesn't know any other way." 
 So Murphy wasn't the least bit surprised when he heard about the first time Hu stepped onto the football field.
Hu was 7 years old at the time. While attending summer camp in the Passaic County town of Wanaque, N.J., he was mistakenly put into a game with players who were almost twice his age.
The mistake occurred because Hu was big for his age, but it didn't deter him. In the heat of the game, he caught an elbow in the right eye, which resulted in a black eye.
"We were so excited to see him go to camp and learn to play football and other American sports," said his mother, Kathy Hu, "then the first day he came home with a black eye."
It was a rude introduction to football. Hu's parents didn't know what to expect. They were born in the Sichuan Province of China. In 1949, when Kathy Hu was 6 years old and Eion's father, Ching-Yeh, was 8, their respective families fled the mainland for Taiwan.
"We don't remember too much because we were quite young," said Hu's mother. "It was very dangerous, very scary. My parents told me that the boat that left after us was bombed and that everybody died. That could have been us."
After growing up in Taiwan, the Hu's moved to the United States in 1965. Hu's father is a biology professor at William Paterson College in Wayne, N.J.
The elder Hu convinced his son not to give up after his initial injury.
"He told him that we paid for the week and that he should give it more of a chance," his mother said. "By the end of the week, he didn't want to come home."
There was never any looking back. Hu became a star halfback at DePaul High School in Wayne, N.J., where he compiled almost 2,000 yards in three seasons and was recognized as one of four National Sports Foundation Scholar Athletes of the Year. In his senior season, he led the Spartans to a state championship.
His success has continued at Harvard. Now a junior, Hu has had nine 100-yard days for the Crimson. As a sophomore, Hu was named the Ivy League rookie of the year (freshmen do not play on the varsity) as he ran for 1,123 yards and 11 touchdowns.
This season he has rushed for 100 yards in four of five games, and has 613 yards and 7 touchdowns. In a victory over Colgate, Hu had a career-high 3 touchdowns and 235 yards. It was the best single performance by any Harvard back since 1974.
The leader of the Crimson offense is the second-year starting quarterback Vin Ferrara, who played at DePaul's scholastic conference rival, Delbarton. Before coming together to form the bulk of Harvard's offensive attack, Hu and Ferrara met in high school once a year. They both collected Parochial All-State honors in their senior seasons.
Hu's biggest fans are his parents. In the few years they have been following the game, they have became ardent football fans. They attend every Harvard home game.
In the classroom Hu has a B-plus average in economics. After he graduates in 1997, he wants to "get a job in the business world for three or four years" and then return to Harvard to pursue a master's degree in business administration.
"When I first got here in the spring of 1994, I knew we had a player in Eion," said Coach Murphy, who went to Harvard after being an assistant at Cincinnati University in 1994. "He's a quick, slashing type of runner, with great field vision.
"As time went on, I realized what a great kid he was -- and I don't just mean as a football player. At a school filled with extraordinary kids, he still stands out. He's a good student and a good athlete, and he's very humble about it."
Murphy's point was proved in an early season 28-27 loss to Cornell, in which Hu fumbled. It was only his second fumble in more than 500 career carries.
Harvard hasn't had a winning season since 1987. But with two 1-point losses on a team comprising mostly of underclassmen, Hu and Murphy are optimistic.
"We're young and we have to learn to win," Hu said. "We're really a few plays away from being 5-0. If we practice like heck, we could compete for the Ivy League title. If not this year, next year."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harvard's New Jersey connection: Running back Eion Hu (left) and Vin Ferrara with Coach Tim Murphy. (The Boston Globe)

LENGTH: 341 words

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Budget Cutting Requires Fare Increase

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Save the Subways" (editorial, Oct. 5), on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's proposed financial plan: The M.T.A. will issue half as much fare-box debt during the next five years as it did from 1982 to 1994, not twice as much, as you suggest. Through 1994, $2.6 billion of revenue bonds were issued to pay for the authority's capital program. From 1995 to 1999, we plan to issue $1.3 billion of revenue bonds. 
 The remaining revenue bonds in the plan won't be issued until 2000 to 2003 as projects are completed.
In 1999, debt service for pre-1995 revenue bonds will be almost $200 million, while debt service for the 1995-99 revenue bonds will be $85 million. New York City Transit Authority and commuter rail increases will provide revenues of $314 million in 1999, more than enough to cover the cost of the proposed program.
The M.T.A. announced a new five-year plan when its existing plan unraveled because the Federal, city and state governments reduced mass transit subsidies to close massive budget deficits.
The State Comptroller reported this week that the state's deficit amounts to $7 billion in the next two years. The city faces a reported $3 billion deficit next year. These are the economic realities you ignore. The M.T.A. must address these realities.
Rather than wait for a government bailout unlikely to materialize, we have developed a responsible plan that includes deep budget reductions, increased productivity and increased fare and toll revenues.
The plan will push the M.T.A. to become a more self-sufficient, cost-effective operation. The budget plans announced this week, which will reduce staff by 3,800 positions, are a positive step in this direction.
The plan's $3 billion budget reductions can be achieved, not at the expense of the reliability, safety or quality of service, but by increasing productivity through outsourcing, consolidations and work-rule changes.
 
E. VIRGIL CONWAY
Chairman, Metropolitan
Transportation Authority
New York, Oct. 13, 1995

HEADLINE: A Mixed Trading Session Sees Technology Stocks Rise Again

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Technology stocks extended their advance yesterday but cyclical issues like Caterpillar and Alcoa fell, leaving the market indexes mixed.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index of 500 stocks rose 0.66 point to 587.44, its second consecutive record close. The Nasdaq composite index, which includes many leading technology issues, gained 9.93 points to 1,045.37, adding to Tuesday's advance of 17.31 points. 
 But the Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.42 points, to 4,777.52 after rising 14.82 points earlier in the session. Two rounds of computer-guided orders to sell stocks sliced 14.80 points from the average, according to Birinyi Associates of Greenwich, Conn.
"What we have is a very divergent market," said Don Hays, director of investment strategy at Wheat First Butcher Singer in Richmond.
While technology and financial stocks have led the market higher this year, investors looking at other industries are "starting to get very concerned about the economy, especially Christmas sales and falling car sales," he said.
Earnings drove many of the market movers yesterday.
Shares of the Microsoft Corporation surged after the company reported late on Tuesday that earnings climbed to 78 cents a share, up from 51 cents last year and exceeding analyst estimates of 70 cents a share. Microsoft rose 4 1/2, to 95 5/8.
Confidence in the outlook for Microsoft spilled over to other technology stocks, driving the prices of Intel, Cisco Systems, Oracle and others sharply higher.
Sun Microsystems Inc. jumped a second day after reporting surprisingly strong earnings late Monday. The maker of computer workstations rose 4 3/4 to 72 5/8 after surging 9 1/4 on Tuesday.
The Compaq Computer Corporation climbed 2 3/4 to 54 1/8. The world's biggest maker of personal computers agreed to buy the Thomas-Conrad Corporation to expand its offering of network products.
Concerns of a cyclical slowdown dragged down several blue chips. Caterpillar slid 2 5/8 to 51 1/2 after reporting disappointing earnings on Tuesday, while Alcoa fell 1 to 50 3/4 on concern about rising aluminum production.
Shares of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, dropped 2 1/4 to 66 1/2. While its quarterly earnings climbed 15 percent, they failed to match Wall Street expectations.
Shares of First Interstate Bancorp climbed 32.3 percent after Wells Fargo & Company offered to buy the company in a deal that would create the nation's seventh largest banking company.
First Interstate shares jumped 34 1/4 to 140 1/4, while those of Wells Fargo jumped 15 3/8 to 229. Wells Fargo, of San Francisco, offered 0.625 shares for every First Interstate share, valuing the Southern California bank at $143.125 a share.
Shares in Berkshire Hathaway Inc., which owns 14 percent of Wells Fargo, climbed 150 to 29,700.
The Great Western Financial Corporation, a savings and loan based in Chatsworth, Calif., climbed 1 3/8 to 25 1/2 after it said third-quarter earnings rose to 45 cents a share from 38 cents in the period a year earlier.
H. F. Ahmanson & Company, another California savings institution, jumped 1 1/2 to 27 3/4. Smith Barney raised its ratings on Ahmanson, which is scheduled to release earnings today, and Great Western. Both were raised to "buy" from "outperform."
Thomas O'Donnell, an analyst with Smith Barney, said that whether the Wells Fargo purchase of First Interstate "goes through or not, these companies have been given a higher profile as takeover candidates, especially for anyone who wants to build a presence in California."
The advance in financial stocks was not universal. Citicorp shares slumped 3 5/8 to 69 1/8 after the New York bank was removed from the recommended list at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and Merrill Lynch said it would have a tougher time surpassing analysts' earnings forecasts.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Slip as U.S. Posts Strong Trade Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday in choppy trading after a report on the nation's trade deficit indicated new strength in the economy.
Both the cash and futures markets slipped somewhat after the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit narrowed 21.2 percent, to $8.8 billion, in August. Economists surveyed by Reuters had expected an August deficit of $11 billion. 
 The strong figure led some market participants to raise their estimates of economic growth in the third quarter, increasing the chances that inflation could accelerate as a result and reducing the possibility that the Federal Reserve would lower short-term interest rates at its policy meeting next month.
Despite the fall in prices yesterday, traders remain optimistic. Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the market was simply consolidating the gains achieved in recent days.
"Market sentiment is still bullish," he said. "Skeptical, but over all still bullish." Bond prices are reflecting the lack of much inflationary pressures, and investors are responding by buying the longer maturities, he added.
Yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond fell 19/32 , to 10710/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.33 percent, from 6.28 percent on Tuesday.
The Treasury announced yesterday that next week's note auctions would include $17.75 billion of a new two-year issue and $11.5 billion of a five-year issue.
If the high yield on the two-year note comes in at 5.750 percent to 5.874 percent at auction on Tuesday, the Treasury will reopen an existing five-year note that has two years left to maturity, the agency said. The five-year note carries a 5.75 percent coupon and is due on the same date, Oct. 31, 1997. It is likely that the Treasury wanted to eliminate confusion by not having two securities maturing on the same date.
In when-issued trading ahead of those auctions, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.67 percent and the five-year maturity at a price to yield 5.82 percent.
The battle in Washington over the budget and debt ceiling continues to weigh on the market, bolstering the prices of shorter-maturity issues. With the number of new bills reduced and demand about the same, investors are likely to pay a premium for bills.
In the futures market, the December bond contract bounced in a narrow range, reaching 11717/32 at its high and hitting 11628/32 at its low point, before settling at 117.
Robin Mesch, a fixed-income market analyst with Thomson Research in Boston, said "long term, bonds remain a buy-the-dip market in this quarter, but we could see a pullback to as low as 116 to 11529/32 on the contract without negating the bullish structure of the market."
"Today's consolidation gives us a sense that we will get a deeper pullback," she added.
In the municipal market, prices were steady, as California sold $461 million of general obligation bonds through competitive bidding won by Merrill Lynch.
Rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's, the bonds were priced to yield a maximum 5.80 percent for issues due in 2017 through 2020.
In the corporate bond market, where issuers have rushed to market to take advantage of rates hovering at 20-month lows, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation had the largest sale yesterday.
The finance arm of the large auto maker sold $500 million of noncallable 10-year notes through Merrill Lynch at a price to yield 6.701 percent, or 72.5 basis points more than a comparable Treasury security. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Underwriters said the notes were rated A3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Hopes for U.S.-China Meeting Lift Wheat to 14-Year High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Wheat prices topped $5 a bushel yesterday for the first time in more than 14 years on hopes that China would buy more American wheat.
On other commodity markets, copper and crude oil prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index rose eight-tenths of a point, to 241.30. 
 Wheat prices jumped at the end of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade after Agriculture Secretary Daniel R. Glickman said that President Clinton's scheduled meeting with President Jiang Zemin next Tuesday might lead to more wheat sales.
"I think the reason China hasn't been buying recently was political," Mr. Glickman said. With a meeting set for next week, "I expect them to begin to look more favorably at the market."
In addition, Egypt bought 700,000 metric tons of wheat, and traders expect a sale to the Philippines, which could shrink inventories already expected to reach a 20-year low next spring.
"It's just a bull market, and it showed itself," said Dave Armstrong, an analyst with the Chicago Corporation.
Wheat for December delivery rose as high as $5.01 a bushel yesterday before ending 8.25 cents higher at $4.9975 a bushel. It was the first time an active contract reached $5 a bushel since Jan. 16, 1981, the Chicago Board of Trade said.
Copper prices fell to their lowest level in almost a year on concerns that a slowing economy would reduce copper consumption by manufacturers.
"The economic story is getting somewhat shaky," said Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York.
December copper fell 2.75 cents, to $1.211 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange of New York, the lowest price for an active contract since Oct. 25, 1994.
Despite a drop in crude oil inventories to their lowest level since 1979, November crude oil prices slipped 7 cents, to $17.61 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Then Rebounds On Japan and U.S. Trade Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled in Asian trading yesterday, but rebounded after a report showed that the United States' trade deficit narrowed more than expected in August.
The dollar's rise prompted investors to sell German marks and buy other European currencies that had fallen against the mark recently. Dollar purchases by the Japanese central bank failed to halt the yen's rise during Asian trading. 
 "The market was short on dollars and caught very much off guard by the improvement in the U.S. trade deficit," said Charles Spence, director of Treasury sales at Standard Chartered Bank.
The dollar rose against the mark even though the Bundesbank left its 14-day repurchase rate unchanged during regular weekly money market activities. It was the first time the German central bank had not lowered the rate since Aug. 16. Lower German interest rates typically make the mark less attractive.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 100.76 Japanese yen from 100.41 yen on Tuesday. It edged up to 1.4232 marks from 1.4147 and to 1.1562 Swiss francs from 1.1480.
The early selloff in Asia began with a higher-than-expected Japanese merchandise trade surplus for September -- $11.29 billion, down 5.6 percent from August's surplus of $11.96 billion. But analysts had expected an even lower figure.
The dollar fell below 100 yen, prompting the Bank of Japan and Japan's postal service, which holds huge amounts in savings, to intervene in the market. But this failed to revive the dollar, Mr. Spence of Standard Chartered said. The dollar moved up somewhat during European trading but was still weak before the Commerce Department released the trade report.
The United States trade deficit narrowed to $8.82 billion in August, the smallest imbalance this year. When the news came out, the dollar jumped nearly 1 yen and more than a German pfennig.
"I think the boost took us to the higher end of the range that we've been in for the past several days but wasn't enough to take us over that," Mr. Spence said. "Consequently, the dollar looks ready to settle in again."
Market participants expected coordinated central bank intervention, which never materialized, as the dollar climbed. Such interventions have been most common recently when the dollar was rising. "But I think at this phase the central banks are quite content with the success they've had in turning the dollar around" since it hit post-World War II lows in April, Mr. Spence said.

HEADLINE: SENIOR CLASS;
Wearing the Gray Badge of Courage

BYLINE: By ROBERT W. STOCK 

 BODY:
EVENTUALLY, old age announces itself. Eyes fail, limbs ache, skin wrinkles. But before that happens in a serious way, most of us do some announcing of our own. We line up for senior discounts at subway booths or movie theaters. We dye our hair -- or stop dyeing it. We brag about our grandchildren, admit retirement, even tell people our real age.
Little scientific research has been done on these small moments of truth, these public admissions of our years. But two dozen interviews with experts and a cross section of older people suggest that these decisions are not made lightly and without some soul-searching. 
 Though the image of older people has improved somewhat in recent years, being old still carries heavy social and economic freight. Small wonder that we avoid the label as long as possible. "Coming to grips with age and death is tough," said Harry Moody, the acting director of the Brookdale Center on Aging in New York. "Sometimes denial is a good thing."
And deny we do. Consider David Garth, the 65-year-old New York political consultant, in front of his bathroom mirror. "I have a special angle where I can see myself the way I used to be," he said. "Then you see yourself on television, and you say, 'Who is that old guy?' "
The first time Mr. Garth was offered a discount at the movies, he said, "I was outraged." He still pays full price. "It's as though I'm just not aware of the discounts," he said. "I'm blocking."
Lillian Troll, 80, is a retired psychology professor in Alameda, Calif. "When I first became eligible for a movie discount, I didn't do it," she said. "I felt embarrassed about saying I was that old. It took me about five years. Then I just got used to the idea that people realized I was older."
Depending on your state of mind and the state of your pocketbook, the incentives to declare your age can be powerful, but some admissions are more public than others. Discounted airline tickets, for example, are pretty anonymous. On the other hand, heeding the airline boarding announcement that gives seniors advance seating puts you right out there. Slipping 60 cents into the bus fare box in New York usually attracts no attention, but the Washington Metro Farecard for older people is bright orange, while the regular card is white.
John Hendricks, a professor of sociology at Oregon State University in Corvallis, views such discounts and privileges as a kind of benign ageism -- he calls it the "poor dear syndrome" because it lumps all older people within a stereotype of being frail and destitute and in need of help. "It means that younger people will see you as different from them," he said, "lesser than them, not someone they would be interested in talking to. You get a 10 percent discount, but you are also being depreciated 10 percent."
Mr. Garth puts it this way: "The worst fear people have about getting older is being dependent and out of control. One of the symbols of being dependent is taking advantage of these things. Those who do it feel they're owed something, and I understand that. But I do away with all the symbols of dependency I can."
Of course, there are some people who simply relish discounts. "I'm not a rich person," said Genevieve Burke, a 72-year-old receptionist at the University of Vermont in Burlington. "I enjoy getting a bargain anytime, whether it's at the movies or at a flea market."
Many are the ways older people hide, and reveal, their age. Driving a car is a positive sign that you are part of the mainstream, said Susan A. Eisenhandler, an assistant professor of sociology at the University of Connecticut in Waterbury. And giving up driving is a major acknowledgment of old age. "Even those who do will often keep renewing their license as proof positive that they're not really old," she said.
Some older people cringe when the post office delivers a copy of Modern Maturity, the American Association of Retired Persons magazine. Others determinedly stay away from senior centers and other senior activities.
"Friends tell me about the great trip they had, with all the details," said Elise Maclay, a Westport, Conn., writer. "But when I ask who sponsored it, there's this hesitation to admit it was Elderhostel, followed by assurances of how lively the other people on the trip were. If it had been an Audubon Society or Yale alumni trip, they would have said so in a minute."
Asked to give her own age, Ms. Maclay refused, for what she said was a very practical reason. "The world thinks, and editors think, you're not au courant, you're not 'with it' anymore," she said.
At a certain point, though, many older people take a different tack on that issue. "I don't mind saying how old I am," said Kenneth Lawson, 69, a retired lab technician in North Providence, R.I. "Maybe it has something to do with people thinking I look and act much younger."
Hugh Downs, a host of "20/20" on ABC-TV, makes no bones about acknowledging that he is 74: "Suppose I said I was 55. Then people would say, 'He's not in such good shape.' Now they say, 'You can't be that old.' " In any event, Mr. Downs said, he works in an industry where one's age cannot be hidden. "Lucky for me," he added, "it's an industry where it's not politically correct to discriminate against older people."
The issue of when to 'fess up gets little attention among gerontologists, said Lynne Gershensohn Hodgson, the chairwoman of the sociology and gerontology department at Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn. "Do gerontologists who have spent their whole lives trying to eradicate negative attitudes toward older people put color in their hair?" she said. "We don't talk about it."
Professor Hodgson, who is 45, told of having dinner at a gerontological conference with a group of colleagues, most of whom were considerably older. "The print on the menu was tiny, and we all were having trouble with it," she recalled. "So for the first time in public I pulled out my reading glasses. I was going to show them how I acknowledged my aging. The next thing I knew, they all pulled out their reading glasses."
But times may be changing. Dr. Gene D. Cohen, the director of the Center on Aging, Health and the Humanities at George Washington University, believes that age stereotypes are weakening. "In the past, when you were 65, you were statistically much closer to death than today," he said. "A longer, healthier life span makes older people more comfortable with their age, and that makes them less likely to deny their aging."
The fact that older people are healthier, more active and better educated is also changing attitudes among the younger generations, Dr. Cohen said, because it fudges the differences between young and old that feed stereotypes. In other words, nowadays when you announce your age and a younger person says you don't look it, the chances are it's true. You're part of a historical process that is turning old age into more of a point of pride and less of an embarrassment.

HEADLINE: Clinton Angers Friend and Foe In Tax Remark

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton made an offhand confession on Tuesday night that he had raised taxes "too much" in his first budget in 1993, and the remark drew mockery from Congressional Republicans today. Angry Democrats accused him of repudiating a package they had stuck their necks out to pass without a single Republican vote.
Speaking at a campaign fund raiser in Houston, Mr. Clinton said: "Probably there are people in this room still mad at me at that budget because you think I raised your taxes too much. It might surprise you to know that I think I raised them too much, too." 
 The President, who took office promising both a tax cut for the middle class and higher taxes for the wealthiest Americans, deferred the tax cut in favor of further reducing the Federal budget deficit. In the speech on Tuesday, he seemed to blame both Democrats and Republicans for forcing his hand, although he defended his decision as "the right thing to do." After the remarks caused a small furor on Capitol Hill this morning, the White House complained that they were being taken out of context.
But members of both parties in Congress, debating Republican plans for tax cuts that Mr. Clinton bitterly opposes as too deep, saw no such subtleties. The Republican National Committee faxed copies of the speech around town, and the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Archer of Houston, held a news conference to say that Mr. Clinton "has finally come up with at least a half truth when he says he raised taxes too much; the full truth is he shouldn't have raised taxes at all."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who helped steer Mr. Clinton's proposal through the Senate Finance Committee, was just as harsh, saying that the 1993 budget's deficit reduction had improved the economy and was something to be proud of.
"It just knocked us over when we saw that report this morning," Mr. Moynihan said. "He keeps conceding these things. He doesn't understand that he's conceding the principles." Asked why he thought the President had made the remarks, Mr. Moynihan said: "He's running for re-election, he's raising money in Houston. What he should have said was, 'Is there a man in this room who's not richer than he was two years ago?' "
Mr. Clinton's remarks were made late Tuesday night and drew little notice, but Republicans seized on them this morning after he was quoted in a news service account of the speech.
The President seldom gets in more trouble than when he tries to explain himself too much to an audience he wants to win over, and the speech on Tuesday night seemed a classic example. Clearly tired from a three-day campaign swing, he gave a rambling talk, once referring to Huey Long as "the famous populist Governor and Senator of Kentucky," before correcting himself to say Louisiana.
But as he gears up for his re-election campaign, Mr. Clinton has increasingly sought to portray himself as a lonely paladin whose good ideas are frustrated by the will of both Congressional Democrats and Republicans, and his basic argument on taxes seemed less a slip than a calculated effort to shift blame to them.
His remarks Tuesday night closely echoed comments he made to the Business Council, a group of top corporate executives, in Williamsburg, Va., last Friday, when he said that because no Republicans would support his 1993 budget, "I had to raise your taxes more and cut spending less than I wanted to, which made a lot of you furious."
In fact, in his frantic search for enough Democratic votes to win passage, Mr. Clinton dropped proposed tax increases he favored, like one on energy, and in the end, Vice President Al Gore had to break a tie in the Senate.
"Do you know what we had to do to get those 50 votes?" Senator Moynihan said, recalling the White House arm-twisting.
Speaker Newt Gingrich said the President's analysis "verges on being out of touch with reality," and added: "When you have a President of the United States who is capable of making up whatever fantasies fit his current position, I don't know how as a serious person you can do anything."
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, insisted that too much was being made of Mr. Clinton's remarks. "Nobody likes to raise taxes," Mr. McCurry said. "Everybody would like to cut taxes."
"Every one of those Republicans that voted against the President's deficit reduction package predicted that this would be ruinous for the economy," Mr. McCurry added. "Remember that? And it wasn't, and that's the point the President made last night."
But Senator William V. Roth of Delaware, the chairman of the Finance Committee, which today began deliberating the Republicans' $245 billion tax cut package, said, "I think we can all agree that the President did indeed raise taxes too much." He noted that Mr. Clinton himself had revived his own call for tax breaks for the middle class, albeit smaller and aimed more at lower income families than the Republicans' proposals.
Gene Sperling, a White House economic adviser, suggested the Republicans were simply trying to score oratorical points.
"The Republican Congress is relying on the increased revenue flow from the 1993 tax increase to balance the budget," he said. "Without that, they would not be anywhere near balance. Even though they control both houses of Congress, they have not rolled it back. So if they oppose it, they have an easy solution."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of both parties seized on an offhand comment that President Clinton made on Tuesday night. At a fund-raising dinner in Houston, the President said that he had raised taxes too much in the 1993 budget. (Associated Press) (pg. B13)
 
Chart: "HIGHLIGHTS: Adjusting the Tax Code"
The proposed seven-year tax package now before the Senate Finance Committee includes literally hundreds of adjustments to the Internal Revenue Code, some niggling and some sweeping. Here are the most important ones:
 
Child tax credit -- $500 per-child credit against income taxes for taxpaying households. Would be gradually phased out, according to number of children claimed, starting at taxable incomes of $75,000 for single filers, $110,000 for couples, $55,000 for married filing separately.
 Seven-year cost: $141.4 billion.
 
Adoption tax credit -- $5,000 for each child under 18; not applicable to filers with no tax liability, and phased out at taxable incomes between $60,000 and $100,000.
 Cost: $2 billion
 
Marriage penalty relief -- Gradually increases the $6,550 standard deduction for married joint returns to $8,200 by 2000 and more thereafter.
 Cost: $12.3 billion.
 
Student loan interest credit -- Up to 20 percent of interest payments on student loans, up to $500, applied against income taxes during first five years of repayment. Phased out at higher incomes.
 Cost: $1 billion.
 
Individual retirement accounts -- Gradually raises income limits for IRA contributions to $85,000 for singles, $100,000 for couples; indexes contribution and income levels for inflation. Creates IRA for homemakers.
 Cost: $12.7 billion.
 
Capital gains -- Creates 50 percent deduction on individual capital gains; caps tax rate at 19.8 percent. Cuts corporate rate to 28 percent, from 35 per cent.
 Cost: $40.3 billion.
 
Medical savings accounts -- Creates tax-exempt savings accounts restricted to medical expenses.
 Cost: $1.3 billion.
 
Alternative minimum tax -- Changes depreciation rules and creates tax credits, lowering the tax in many cases.
 Cost: $9.2 billion.
 
Long-term care insurance -- Treats insurance premiums as deductible medical expenses.
 Cost: $9.9 billion
 
Estate tax relief -- Cuts estate taxes for certain businesses; increases credits; other changes.
 Cost: $13.3 billion (pg. B13)

HEADLINE: Privatization Starts Feud In Haiti

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 14

 BODY:
There are just 66,000 telephone lines in all of Haiti, and the Government-run telephone company says it does not have the money to install more. The electric company, airport and harbor, also Government-owned and in need of modernization, complain of the same lack of funds.
Selling a share of those and other state enterprises to private investors might appear to offer a promising way out for a poor, nearly bankrupt country. But a plan to do just that has split the Haitian Government into two bitterly feuding camps and driven a widening wedge between President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and Haiti's foreign aid lenders, led by the United States. 
 Hinging on the outcome of the policy dispute, the most serious the Aristide Government has experienced since being returned to power by American troops a year ago, is the disbursement of nearly half of Haiti's projected $350 million budget for this fiscal year. If Mr. Aristide does not go ahead with the privatization and other reforms he previously promised, the donor nations say they are prepared to hold back much of the aid they have pledged.
"This situation has got to be cleared up by the middle of November if that money is to flow," one foreign official warned. "Without external budget support, this Government is going to have to dramatically ramp down its spending, including job creation and social programs" dear to Mr. Aristide.
The privatization dispute was central to the decision of Smarck Michel, the 58-year-old businessman whom Mr. Aristide appointed as his prime minister last year, to submit his resignation Friday. Mr. Michel has vigorously supported the privatization effort, but has been opposed by Mr. Aristide and some of his fellow Cabinet ministers.
While still in exile last year, the Aristide Government presented lender nations with a privatization plan and in February it signed an agreement with the International Finance Corporation, a branch of the World Bank, to sell off all or part of nine state enterprises, including two banks. But little progress has been made since then, and Haiti's aid donors say Mr. Aristide's unwillingness to commit himself to the program is the main reason.
"The President is not playing straight with us and that means we are on a collision course," said one irritated foreign official. "It is unacceptable for him to give aid and comfort to the international community behind closed doors and then say something completely different to his own people."
Initially, Mr. Aristide referred to privatization as an act of "economic democratization" that would strip the oligarchy of economic power and transfer it to ordinary people. But he has made no concentrated effort to explain the program and its potential benefits to the population in speeches and meetings, a procedure he normally follows when he clearly wants something done.
That ambivalence, in turn, has encouraged Mr. Aristide's supporters in grass- roots groups on the left to organize street demonstrations and paint anti-privatization graffiti everywhere. They have also vehemently attacked Mr. Michel and other proponents of the measures on the Government-owned television, accusing them of betraying the nation.
But the measures are also opposed by some of Haiti's most powerful families, who have formed a temporary alliance with the left. With several of the state companies closed down or crippled, they have been able to make huge profits by controlling imports of items such as generators, flour and cement, and in any case are not eager to face more efficient foreign competitors.
"A few big capitalists don't want it because they are used to having a monopoly," Mr. Michel said while visiting the United States last month.
Chances for further political conflict have only grown with the seating of a new Parliament. Dominated by nationalistic, left-wing members of Mr. Aristide's Lavalas movement, the National Assembly has offered no indication that it is willing to move quickly on the privatization issue in order to meet foreign-imposed conditions.
On Aug. 7, the Government opened bidding for the first two companies, a cement company and a flour mill, both of which have been shuttered since 1972 and were thus considered unlikely to cause controversy. The bids were supposed to have been opened on Oct. 2, but remain "under lock and key, sealed in a safe," as one Haitian official put it.
That does not bode well for the immensely more complicated and contentious process of privatizing the telephone company, which is profitable but notoriously inefficient, or the electric utility, which loses money and is unable to supply power to large parts of the country.

HEADLINE: How World Bank Can Help Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The meeting in Washington of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (news article, Oct. 12) did little to change their model of economic policy reform called structural adjustment. These organizations have the power of reducing government spending, restricting credit, cutting wages and promoting foreign investment in all the countries that borrow from them. This kind of reform has too often failed to benefit the poor, and has widened the gap between rich and poor. 
 In Zimbabwe, with the institution of a World Bank structural adjustment program, real per capita spending on health and education fell by nearly one-third. The majority of African governments under structural adjustment were spending less on health per capita in 1990 than in 1980, and vaccination rates in 24 African nations have fallen since 1990.
More than 1,200 members of Congress and parliaments worldwide are preparing to present a letter to the heads of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The letter urges the institutions to promote strategies that maximize individual capacity, most especially cost-effective, community-based health care, education and access of the poor to credit for self-employment.
New York's Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato have not signed this letter. The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have enormous power. Only through concerted pressure from government and citizens around the world can this power be harnessed to meet the needs of all people.
We will measure the worth of the World Bank and the I.M.F. by their success in efforts to end the poverty afflicting more than a billion people.
 
(Sister) MARY ELIZABETH LLOYD
Morristown, N.J., Oct. 17, 1995
The writer is a pediatric nutritionist.

HEADLINE: President Hints at Budget Compromise

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton held out the possibility today that he and Congressional Republicans could find a way to balance the Federal budget in seven years as the Republicans want but only if they gave ground on cutting programs for health, education and the environment that he wants to protect.
In the clearest statement yet of the extent, and the limits, of his willingness to compromise, Mr. Clinton said, "I think there's a way for me to meet their stated objectives, which is a balanced budget in seven years, with a family tax cut, and I think they want a capital gains tax cut." 
 But he warned the Republicans to "turn back from passing extreme measures that will never become law."
Mr. Clinton also said that when he remarked on Tuesday that he raised taxes "too much" in 1993, he did not mean to suggest that he regretted passage of the economic plan that imposed those tax increases. Republicans had mocked the comment, while Democrats, fearful that the President would compromise too readily in the current budget battle, were outraged that he seemed to be repudiating a plan many supported only reluctantly at the time.
Even as Mr. Clinton sought in an informal news conference this morning to clarify his remarks on the tax increase, he raised new questions by suggesting for the first time that he might accept the Republicans' timetable -- though not their priorities -- for balancing the budget.
Balancing the budget by 2002 has been one of the chief Republican goals, one dismissed by the White House last spring as virtually impossible if not outright dangerous for the economy. More recently, the White House had said it believed the budget could be balanced in nine years; so Mr. Clinton's willingness even to entertain doing so in seven seemed to be a significant olive branch.
Speaker Newt Gingrich praised Mr. Clinton's comments as "a big step in the right direction," but he could not resist adding a dig at the President's reputation for equivocation: "If he says that tomorrow it will be really good, and if he says it all weekend it will be terrific."
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said Mr. Clinton's latest comments "could have been a mistake, too."
In fact, when pressed on his comments about the budget timetable, Mr. Clinton seemed to soften them a bit, saying, "Well, I think we could reach it in seven years, I think we could reach it in eight years, I think we could reach it in nine years."
White House aides later said the important consideration was spending priorities, not the number of years. But they acknowledged that the only way to preserve Mr. Clinton's favored programs and balance the budget in the time the Republicans want would be to compromise on the size of any tax cuts and adopt more optimistic economic forecasts than the Republicans have so far been willing to accept.
The President has threatened to veto half a dozen of the Republicans' major proposals, including cuts in Medicare and Medicaid growth. Aides said he was trying to walk a fine line between such threats and holding out the possibility of compromise on other issues.
"He's been looking for ways to hold the door he said was open open," said one senior White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity. "He's recently become worried that the Republicans have been so frozen into a hard-line position on various points that they won't budge."
White House aides said they were increasingly concerned that the Republicans would try to force a budget showdown by refusing to raise the Federal debt ceiling when the Government's borrowing authority expires early next month and cash runs out. For the first time today they held serious discussions about whether Mr. Clinton would be able to attend a scheduled economic conference in Japan on Nov. 16 if a crisis was unresolved.
Mr. Gingrich said today that he expected to delay any action to increase borrowing authority until after the giant tax and spending bill was finished.
In his news conference, before taking the first question, the President went out of his way to backtrack from his comment at a political dinner in Texas on Tuesday that "I raised your taxes too much" in 1993.
"If I said anything which implies that I think we didn't do what we should have done, given the choices we faced at that time, I shouldn't have said that," Mr. Clinton said. "My mother once said I should never give a talk after 7 at night, especially if I'm tired. And she turned out to be right, is all I can say."
In fact, Mr. Clinton said, "I am very, very proud of what I did."
Mr. Clinton also said he envisioned committing United States troops to police a possible Bosnian peace accord for "in the range of a year," but he said he did not want to decide definitively until the precise goals of any peacekeeping mission were set.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton has raised the possibility of a compromise with Republicans on balancing the budget in seven years. Mr. Clinton answered questions yesterday at a news conference, where he detailed his position. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RESHAPING MEDICARE: THE IMPLICATIONS;
Past All the Talk, Some True Goals

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Beneath the surface, the debate in the House of Representatives today was not so much about the Medicare program itself as it was about partisan politics: about whether the Republican revolution will succeed and about whether Democrats can recapture the glory of the New Deal and the Great Society.
The politicians may agree on little else, but they agree on this: Next year's elections and those for years to come could turn on how the public perceives the votes this year on Medicare. 
 That explains why the speeches today were more tactical than explanatory, concerned more with resonance than with truth. Both sides tailored their arguments to fit the public's view, expressed in opinion polls, that almost nothing the Government does is so important as sustaining Medicare. They had to stretch to do so.
Republicans maintained that their only aim was to save the popular program from bankruptcy. Democrats held, as Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico said this morning, that under the Republican plan, "Medicare will end as we know it today."
But no matter how often Republicans repeated their mantra about preserving and protecting Medicare -- words carefully field-tested by their pollsters -- they cannot escape the fact that their true goal in overhauling the Medicare program is to raise money for their fiscal agenda.
And no matter how much Democrats pledged allegiance to Medicare, the creation of which was the crowning achievement of the last generation of Democratic lawmakers, they cannot escape the fact that fundamental changes are essential if the program is to survive.
Take the Republicans first.
In their Contract With America, the platform on which they won control of Congress last year, Republicans promised to cut taxes for middle- and upper-income Americans and balance the Federal budget in seven years. The contract said nothing about Medicare.
But once they were in the majority in Congress, the Republicans realized that they had to find the money somewhere to offset the lower taxes and balance the budget. With Social Security off the table, the only available pot was Medicare. Less than 12 percent of the budget now, Medicare would account for 30 percent of the lower spending in the Republican budgets over the next seven years.
This was not done for ideological reasons the way, for example, the Republicans want to cut welfare programs and turn them over to the states for administration. Nor was it done because Republicans disapprove of the existing Medicare program the way, say, they object to environmental regulations.
The decisions on Medicare were made purely and simply to raise money, not to preserve and protect anything. The Republicans seized on the report this spring by Medicare trustees that the system would go bankrupt by 2002 unless spending was reduced or more revenue raised. But that was just a convenient excuse. The trustees had made similar reports for years without Republicans expressing anxiety. And the amount of savings the Republicans seek -- $270 billion over seven years -- is many times what would be needed to avert insolvency.
This is how the $270 billion figure was arrived at: First the Republicans decided to balance the budget by 2002. Then they decided to cut taxes by $245 billion. Then they squeezed as much as they could out of all other Government programs. At that point, they were $270 billion short of the money they needed. That is how much they decided to take from Medicare.
But if the Republicans did not face up to the facts today, neither did the Democrats. Not one Democrat alluded to the incontrovertible fact that taxpayers cannot afford to sustain the Medicare system as it exists today.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that unless significant changes are made, the cost of Medicare will rise to $458 billion, or 18.6 percent of the budget, in 2005, from $178 billion, or 11.7 percent of the budget, in 1995. By the second decade of the next century, when those in the baby boom generation begin to retire, Medicare will be swallowing such a large share of the Federal pie that little will be left for anything else.
Today, about four workers pay taxes for each person covered by Medicare. The proportion will fall to 3.1 workers in 2015, to 2.5 workers in 2025 and to 2 workers for each beneficiary in 2050, according to Government estimates.
And consider this: Medical costs in the private economy have leveled off in the last couple of years as more and more workers have turned to -- or been forced into -- cost-efficient managed care systems like health maintenance organizations. Some large employers, like the State of California, have actually reduced their bill for providing medical insurance for their workers. But the cost of Medicare, virtually the last bastion of traditional fee-for-service medicine, has continued to grow by about 10 percent a year.
Rather than address this predicament, the Democrats, bereft of new ideas to counter the Republican offensive, returned to the same well they have relied on for years -- the charge that Republicans are playing fast and loose with the well-being of the elderly.
Democrats are convinced, for instance, that they wrested control of the Senate from Republicans in 1986 by hammering on the theme that Republican senators had voted to lower Social Security benefits.
In the long term, lawmakers in both parties will probably face up to truths they preferred for political reasons to avoid today. If the Republican plan becomes law and down the road insufficient funds are available for high-quality health care for the elderly, Republicans will most likely intervene to provide whatever money is needed.
If, on the other hand, the Republican Medicare plan dies on the vine because of a Presidential veto or for some other reason, it is an equally safe bet that Democrats will ultimately agree to make whatever changes are necessary to keep the program solvent.
But that's the long-range outlook. In the short term, there is one certain prospect: The vote in the House today will be a dominant issue in next year's election.

HEADLINE: Milk Industry Faces Vast Change

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: MIFFLINTOWN, Pa.

 BODY:
For most of the 23 years that Donald C. Everitt has been running a small dairy farm here, few groups have had more power on Capitol Hill than the milk lobby, and few farmers were as assured of help if things went badly.
But no commodity has fared so badly in Congress this year as milk, with the House Agriculture Committee producing a plan to abolish price supports while its Senate counterpart has slashed subsidies in half. 
 For consumers, the changes may trim a few pennies off the price of a gallon of milk. Mr. Everitt worries that the changes could mean that the Everitt family's 270 years of dairy farming may soon end. But Gary L. Anderson, who runs a dairy farm in Cecil, Wis., thinks the cuts are worth the chance to get rid of rules that guarantee higher prices for dairy farmers in Pennsylvania like Mr. Everitt than for those in his region.
The upending of the complex system that has governed milk production for decades shows that even a long-entrenched interest group like dairy farmers can lose its hold on Congress in a year of rapid change.
Part of the industry's power has come from the ubiquity of dairy farmers, who can be found in every state in the nation. But under the pressure of a budget resolution calling for billions of dollars in cuts in farm subsidies, regional differences divided the industry and undermined its influence.
Blunders also played a part: trade groups long used to dealing with a Democratic majority moved ineptly to adjust to Republican control, angering a subcommittee chairman.
And Senator Rick Santorum, the Republican representing Mr. Everitt and other Pennsylvania farmers on the Senate Agriculture Committee, found himself caught between his constituents' interests and his own pledges to reduce the budget.
Already struggling with rising costs, Mr. Everitt and his 37-year-old son, Donald Jr., now keep an extra 30 cows and rise at 4 o'clock every morning, an hour earlier than they did a decade ago, to milk the cows.
"I'm just barely getting by -- my wife works, my son and I have more cows," Mr. Everitt said as his herd ate from a nearby trough. "They say we're supposed to be better managers, but there comes a point where we can't be any better."
Farmers are known for making such complaints, lest someone notice their good fortune and take it away. But economists agree that for small family dairy farms, particularly those in the Northeast, the budget bill now moving through Congress could prove disastrous.
"An 80-cow farm is going to find it hard to be cost competitive" in the Northeast, said Andrew M. Novakovic, chairman of the agricultural economics department at Cornell University. "As a general rule, that isn't going to be enough."
The Senate plan would lower the price that farmers are guaranteed for their milk. The House plan would go further and eliminate the current labyrinth of Federal rules dictating the minimum prices that companies must pay to farmers in each of 34 regions for various grades of milk sold to consumers. Companies would instead be allowed to buy milk from whatever farmer sold it cheapest.
To be sure, Congress has done some favors for dairy farmers. The House plan would make small, fixed payments to dairy farmers to help them weather the transition to a deregulated market. But the overall effect of both plans would be less Federal spending, more competition and probably lower milk prices.
Public-policy experts and consumer groups have long called for these changes. The current system amounts to an indirect tax on milk users, they say, taking as much as $800 million in higher prices each year from milk consumers and giving that money to dairy farmers.
"Government regulations mean that consumers pay more, and taxpayers pay more, than they should," said Harry M. Snyder, an authority on dairy policy at Consumers Union.
Farmers like Mr. Anderson and his neighbors agree. "We see the Federal dairy program as a disadvantage, and if we let market forces determine who produces and at what price, we believe we'd be better off here in the Midwest," he said.
But Mr. Everitt worries about what will happen if milk price supports are eliminated and the industry is suddenly exposed to the ferocious competition of the modern American business world. "It's nice to have that safety net -- if you don't have it, the price could really drop," he said the other day on his farm here in south-central Pennsylvania.
In one sense, the milk industry's troubles began with its remarkable success in past legislative battles. It fought off some of the changes that have limited the cost of other Federal crop subsidies in recent years. So when Republicans went looking for big, expensive farm programs that could yield large budget savings, they immediately began looking at the milk program.
Recognizing the danger, milk lobbyists opened their campaign with a move that quickly backfired. They volunteered for some subsidy cuts provided that complicated new rules be introduced to share the cost among regions of the country. The House and Senate agriculture panels promptly accepted the chance to save money in their deficit reduction efforts, but rejected the new rules.
"What they did was deny us the one thing we had to have in our offer," said James C. Barr, the chief executive of the National Milk Producers Federation, the dairy farmers' lobbying group.
The milk producers also gambled that they could block the deregulation and free-market rules envisioned by Representative Steve Gunderson, the Wisconsin Republican who heads the House Agriculture dairy subcommittee, by rallying representatives from other regions against him.
But the plan backfired when Republicans proved reluctant to challenge Mr. Gunderson and when the subcommittee chairman responded with fury. "It was a cold, calculated, manipulative attempt to try to bring all the regions of the country together to roll the Midwest and keep business as usual," Mr. Gunderson said.
The move so angered him that he then pushed through the Agriculture Committee a sweeping plan for complete deregulation.
Mr. Barr said he wanted a plan that was good for the entire milk industry, not just Wisconsin dairy farmers. Ending regional differences in milk prices "will cause vast regional dislocations," he predicted.
The reshuffling of Congressional committee membership also left the dairy business at a disadvantage. No Republicans serve on the House Agriculture Committee representing Northeastern districts.
The Senate Agriculture Committee is dominated by Southerners and Midwesterners. It has one Northeastern Republican, Mr. Santorum. But the Senator, a freshman with a strong commitment to free-market principles, believes that the days of lavish farm subsidies are numbered, and he has tried to change the nation's costly sugar and peanut programs instead of protecting his state's huge dairy industry.
The dairy industry also used to shield itself from political harm with lavish campaign contributions to both parties. But it showed poor judgment in its political contributions in the last two years. A study of dairy industry contributions by the Center for Responsive Politics, a Washington research group, found that 9 of the top 10 House recipients of dairy industry money in 1993 and 1994 were Democrats. So were 7 of the top 10 Senate recipients.
Political action committees for milk farmers began giving more generously to Republicans in the first half of this year, but the fact remains that few Republicans owe the industry any favors.

HEADLINE: RESHAPING MEDICARE: THE OVERVIEW;
HOUSE VOTES TO CURB COSTS OF MEDICARE BY $270 BILLION; PRESIDENT PROMISES A VETO

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
House Republicans took a giant step today toward dismantling decades of Democratic social policy, passing legislation to curb Medicare spending and encourage the elderly to turn to private managed-care organizations from the traditional Government plan that has served them since 1965.
The vote was 231 to 201, as 4 Democrats joined 227 Republicans in favor of the bill, while 6 Republicans, 194 Democrats and 1 independent voted against it. 
 Speaker Newt Gingrich, appearing weary after hours of hard bargaining, closed the debate before the vote by saying: "We want to solve problems for all Americans. We want no racial division. We want no class warfare. We want no conflict between generations." He added, "We want a solution to preserve and protect Medicare."
But President Clinton renewed his threat to veto the measure, which will become part of the massive budget reconciliation bill going to the floor next week. He told a news conference that the bill amounted to a "$270 billion cut in Medicare that will eviscerate the health system for our older Americans." Addressing his remarks to House Republicans, he declared: "I will not let you destroy Medicare. I will veto this bill."
With the Senate expected to adopt a similar measure, the stage will be set for a definitive political clash over the size, shape and purpose of Federal spending, with Mr. Clinton and the Republicans each blaming the other for risking a Government shutdown or a default on bonds.
The argument on the House floor was less a debate than an exercise in serial speech making, with each side having a few carefully scripted points, made over and over again. Democrats complained about tax cuts and increases in Medicare premiums. Republicans said their bill would keep the system from going bankrupt. When representatives actually responded to each other's remarks, it was usually to offer flat contradiction or insult.
Accusing Democrats of "Medagoguery," Representative Porter J. Goss, Republican of Florida, said, "We're going to pass this bill because we want to save Medicare."
Representative Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana, said: "They are gutting Medicare. Today, Medicare; tomorrow, Social Security, programs they have always opposed and oppose today."
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the bill changed the meaning of G.O.P., from Grand Old Party to "Get Old People."
"There is only one reason this bill is required -- to finance tax cuts for the rich," said Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, who waved the gavel he used to preside over the House when it passed the original Medicare legislation in April 1965.
Representative Martin R. Hoke, Republican of Ohio, said Democrats offered "nothing more than another in a long line of Band-Aid solutions." Representative Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas, the majority whip, called the Democratic alternative "a joke wrapped in fraud and shrouded by farce."
Although none of New York's 14 Republicans voted against the bill, several of its provisions alarm New York health officials. They are concerned that its spending curbs will hit urban hospitals with particular severity because many depend on a variety of Federal subsidies that the bill would reduce or eliminate.
There is particular concern in academic medical centers and hospitals that depend on large numbers of foreign-trained residents, because the bill appears to reduce reimbursements for them.
The Democrats proposed cutting only $90 billion from the program over seven years, or as much as they said was really needed if a $245 billion tax cut plan were not part of the Republican program. The Democratic proposal was defeated, 283 to 149. Many Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, opposed even those cuts. Mr. Gephardt's aides said he did not want to cut Medicare at all until the Republican tax cut proposal had been abandoned.
The Senate Finance Committee approved it today.
The Republican Medicare bill, closely similar to one the Senate is expected to adopt as part of budget reconciliation later this month, would reduce allowances in the future for inflation in Medicare expenditures for hospitals, doctors and other health care providers. According to the Congressional Budget Office, more than half of the $270 billion would come in that way.
Its most innovative section would encourage the elderly to get their health care through health maintenance organizations or other plans with a specific list of providers under the general rubric of managed care. These plans, called Medicareplus, would have to provide at least as much in benefits as the traditional fee-for-service system did.
One element would be medical savings accounts, with which individuals would make tax-free deposits to cover expenses, deductibles on insurance policies, copayments and some items that Medicare does not cover, like prescription drugs.
Though Republicans touted these innovations, the Congressional Budget Office found that only 13 percent of the bill's savings would come from encouraging the elderly to move into managed care. Another 20 percent would come from increases in the monthly premiums Medicare beneficiaries pay for doctor care.
The bill also provides that if the savings expected from the devices do not materialize, the Government must order additional curbs on reimbursements to hospitals and doctors. Democrats asserted this provision would take effect and drive doctors away from treating Medicare patients, and thus bring an end to the fee-for-service system.
Democrats contended that the Republican curbs on projected Medicare spending were really cuts. "These huge Medicare cuts are needed to pay for tax cuts for the rich," said Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia. Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, asserted, "We aren't making cuts, folks, we're slowing the growth."
Not all the complaints came from Democrats. Four New Jersey Republicans defected from their party, saying the bill hit their state too hard. They were: Representatives Frank A. LoBiondo, H. James Saxton, Christopher H. Smith and Dick Zimmer.
Governor Christine Todd Whitman had urged the delegation to fight a part of the bill lowering special Medicare payments to hospitals serving large numbers of indigent patients. The Governor and the delegation also asked Mr. Gingrich to improve language on the reimbursement for international medical graduates.
Another major complaint from the Democrats was that hospitals would suffer. Representative Eva Clayton, Democrat of North Carolina, said: "Many of my hospitals will lose. Several of them may have to close."
Often, after a Republican had finished speaking, a Democrat would get up to announce an estimate of the losses to hospitals in his or her district. For example, Mr. Dingell told Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, that the Texas Medical Center would lose "half a billion dollars."
When they were not snapping at Democrats, Republicans emphasized soothing rhetoric. "Our plan is a long-term solution, a vision, hopes and dreams," Mr. Archer said.
Outside the Capitol, union members protested the Republican proposal. Democrats promised, as Mr. Gephardt told them, that even if today's vote was lost "the fight has just begun." He added, "And we will win."
On the floor, the minority whip, Representative David E. Bonior, Democrat of Michigan, renewed that argument, saying, "The debate in this country is just beginning, and it will continue around the kitchen tables of every home in America, where sons and daughters will scrimp and save to care for their parents."
But the Republicans had their supporters, too. About 100 of them watched the proceedings on a television in a meeting room two floors below the House chamber. After the vote, Mr. Gingrich, smiling broadly and waving, entered the room to sustained applause.
"This is a very, very great victory," the Speaker said. "It is a great victory for courage over fear, it is a great victory for facts over fiction, it's a great victory for being positive over a very nasty and dishonest demagogic attack ads."
 
CHRONOLOGY
What Next for Medicare Legislation:
 
YESTERDAY -- House passes its version of Medicare.
 
OCT. 26 - House is scheduled to pass the reconciliation bill - a piece of legislation that includes welfare revisions, tax cuts, farm subsidies and a Medicaid overhaul. Before the bill is voted on, the House Medicare will be incorporated.
 
BEFORE MONTH'S END -- Senate passes its version of the reconciliation bill, including its Medicare provisions.
 
LATE OCTOBER/EARLY NOVEMBER - House-Senate Conference is held to iron out differences in the two reconciliation bills.
 
SHORTLY AFTERWARD -- House passes compromise bill. Senate passes compromise bill. Bill goes to President Clinton. If President exercises veto, as he has threatened, he and Republican leaders in Congress would have to reach a compromise. Republicans don't have votes to override a veto.

HEADLINE: President's Guru Goes Public;
Back Home, Dick Morris Tells Tales From the Clubhouse

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
President Clinton's latest political guru, Dick Morris, is usually so obsessively low-profile that he might best be known as the stealth strategist.
But not last night, when he stepped far, far back to his political roots to mingle with the remnants of New York's Tammany machine. 
 From the moment Mr. Morris arrived outside Gallagher's Steak House on the West Side, a half hour late and fresh from the Washington shuttle, the flashbulbs popped, the boom mikes dangled, and he was at the center of the media maelstrom usually reserved for the candidates, not the consultants.
"Richard, wrong way, turn left," Bernie Cohen growled into a microphone. He was trying to direct Mr. Morris, the West Side's prodigal son, a Democrat-turned-Republican-turned-Clintonite, who was fighting his way through a drink-toting crowd from the McManus Midtown Democratic Association to a podium in an upstairs sanctum of the steakhouse.
"That," said Mr. Cohen, the association's general counsel, "was not intended as a commentary on your advice."
For an hour, Mr. Morris, 47, was far more revealing of himself than of his strategy to re-elect Mr. Clinton. The small man in the gray suit peremptorily ordered the cameras to the back of the room. He told "one of the all-time great romantic stories of the Western world," the tale of his 85-year-old father, Eugene, who married his high school sweetheart, Blanche, after his first wife died two years ago.
He introduced his high school debate partner, Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried. "The first campaign that I ever ran was his campaign for district leader on the West Side of Manhattan," Mr. Morris said.
"Did you win?" a voice demanded.
"Oh, against Bernie," Mr. Morris said. "I forget. He was also my first opponent."
It turns out that Mr. Secrecy likes an audience.
Mr. Morris's uncharacteristic appearance in this West Side steakhouse would baffle official Washington. But then again, Washington does not know much about the McManus. Four years ago, it hardly knew about Hope, Ark.
New York Democrats, on the other hand, have known the McMani, as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan dubbed them, across the century that the Irish clan has dominated politics in Hell's Kitchen. The legendary Tammany leader, George Washington Plunkitt, once complained: "Ceasar had his Brutus. I've got my 'The' McManus." The McManus in question was the great uncle of James R. McManus, Mr. Morris's host last night.
Mr. McManus and Mr. Morris go way back to the wars between the Reformers and the Regulars that made West Side Democratic politics like a free-fire zone in the 1960's and 70's. Most of the reformers shunned Mr. McManus, the son of Tammany, who won the district leadership in Hell's Kitchen after his father died in 1963. "I was 26 years old and people would curse me out," he recalled. "You carry your father's sins."
But not the West Side kids -- Mr. Morris among them -- the bright boys from Stuyvesant, the city's elite public high school, and Columbia University, who seized control of several reform clubs.
"They saw the weakness of the reform clubs, in the sense that they had complete democracy, you know," said Mr. McManus, a firm believer in clubhouse discipline and in delivering votes in a block. "What they did was pack the clubs and took over the clubs from within."
Across the years, Mr. Morris moved to Connecticut. His politics veered from left to right. Yet when Mr. McManus needed a draw for last night's $60-a-head club fund-raiser -- small potatoes compared to the $1,000-a-plate Presidential galas -- Mr. Morris volunteered.
"For a man who became powerful and deals with senators and Presidents and Governors to call a little district leader on the West Side and offer that, that's a friend and a wonderful person who doesn't forget 25 years ago," Mr. McManus said. "Listen, the politicians forget last week."
Mr. Morris returned the compliment last night. "Just as you never forget the first woman you were intimate with, you never forget the first person you made a political deal with," he said of Mr. McManus.
Mr. McManus is not Mr. Morris's only remaining New York tie. The consultant has already signed up to run a Democratic mayoral race for Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer in 1997, a sign that the Republicans may not prove forgiving of Mr. Morris's defection to President Clinton.
And to some dismay from the Washington political establishment, Mr. Morris has brought a handful of New Yorkers into the White House with him: the media consultant Henry Sheinkopf, a former police officer with a thick New York accent known for his ability to play hardball, and the pollsters Mark Penn and Douglas Schoen, who began as proteges of David Garth. But the two now range so broadly that Mr. Penn worked for Ross Perot in 1992 and Mr. Schoen managed the unsuccessful campaign of Milan Panic, the American businessman who ran for President of Serbia.
Everything about Mr. Morris that now makes Washington fret has been known for years in these New York precincts. His propensity to switch-hit, representing Republicans or Democrats indiscriminately, was foreshadowed in his years as a high school debate team captain during which classmates recall him debating any side of an issue with equal verve and persuasiveness.
Here too they knew, in the vernacular of the Lower East Side, that this was a man with chutzpah. Representative Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan, another West Side kid, remembers the time he read a liberal defense of the cities that Mr. Morris had written for The Village Voice and noticed that Mr. Morris was referred to at the end of the article as an economist.
"I knew Dick had a B.A. from Columbia in government," Mr. Nadler recalled in a phone interview. "I called him up and said, 'Great article" -- which it was. I was curious about one thing, 'How did you become a noted economist?" As Mr. Nadler recounts it, Mr. Morris replied, "One becomes a noted economist the way one becomes a Presidential candidate. One declares it."
Last night, no one was quibbling with Mr. Morris's credentials. "I'd like just to close by giving you a wonderful personal vignette that my wife said I should say," Mr. Morris said. "I was sitting with the President one night and we were working on some speech or other and it was getting kind of late. We were alone. And I looked at him and I said, 'You know Mr. President, ever since I was 8 years old, I dreamed of doing exactly this in exactly this way. And he looked back at me and he smiled and he said, 'So did I.' "
