HEADLINE: 16 City Schools Are Taken Over By Chancellor

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
On his fourth day as Chancellor of the New York City Schools, Dr. Rudy Crew said he was taking direct control of the city's 16 most troubled schools, places where the vast majority of children cannot read at grade level and where some teachers appear preoccupied with discipline rather than with learning.
In some cases the Chancellor would break larger schools into several smaller ones, in other cases he would remove principals and in the worst situations he would replace the entire staff of a school -- its principal, teachers and aides, said his spokesman, David Begel. 
 "I will take no excuses for schools that do not, or have not, over the course of a multiple set of years, been able to make substantial gains for their children," Dr. Crew told reporters yesterday at the Board of Education's headquarters in Brooklyn at an event for student journalists. He allowed only the students to ask questions, and the actual takeover announcement was made later in the day by his spokesman.
The new Chancellor's aggressive action came after the State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, himself only in the job a month, issued detailed reports on the failures of the schools.
Based on inspections by state investigators made last week, the reports showed a list of problems: math-teaching techniques from the 1950's at Erasmus Hall High School in Flatbush; filthy bathrooms with no doors, soap or towels at P.S. 121 in East Harlem; classes in "near chaos" at P.S. 65 in the South Bronx, a school where a third of the teachers were substitutes or uncertified, and insensitivity by teachers at P.S. 62, also in the South Bronx, who asked their students, many of them homeless and poor, "Where did you go on vacation?"
In a news conference in Albany yesterday, Mr. Mills said he was giving New York City's Board of Education until the end of the school year to improve the schools or the state would move in to close them. "I have a legal and moral responsibility to act in the face of these facts," he said.
But his firm threat of takeovers gives Dr. Crew added muscle in intervention. All but the three high schools are run by local school boards, which have blocked intervention by previous chancellors in court actions over the years. The state, however, has the authority to close schools, by removing what is essentially their license to operate. Mr. Mills and Dr. Crew have both said they were working together on intervention plans.
Later in the day, Dr. Crew said that while each school's problems are complex and distinct, the need to take action is critical and overdue. All 16 of the schools have been on the state's list of low-performing schools since the state began tracking them in 1989.
Mr. Begel said the 16 schools -- 3 high schools, 3 junior highs and 10 elementary schools -- would immediately come under the Chancellor's control. A 17th school that Mr. Mills considered as a candidate for takeover under this round of action, James Monroe High School in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, has made enough progress that it will be given more time to improve.
Dr. Crew is arranging meetings with local community school boards and superintendents, who oversee the elementary and junior high schools, to discuss a redesign of the schools, Mr. Begel said. He also will be talking with representatives of the teachers' and principals' unions about the takeovers.
"What's important to emphasize is the collaborative nature of this effort," Mr. Begel said.
It is too soon yet to say what action each school will require, Mr. Begel said. In some of them, principals or teachers might be replaced. At others, the school may be broken up into smaller units.
Carol A. Gresser, the Board of Education president, said she was hopeful that Dr. Crew's effort would make a difference to the long-failing schools because there will be support from all levels.
"This is the state and this board and the Chancellor locking arms, and saying we have to work together," she said. "This is not an adversarial action as far as I'm concerned."
She said the effort to improve the schools began under Dr. Crew's two predecessors, Ramon C. Cortines and Joseph A. Fernandez.
But both chancellors met legal resistance from local boards.
When Mr. Cortines tried to take over Intermediate School 193 in the South Bronx, School District 12 spent more than a year fighting him in court. In August, as Mr. Cortines prepared to leave, a state judge ruled that the Chancellor had the right to bypass the local board and dismiss a principal whom the board had hired.
While the law gives the chancellor the power to intervene when there is an act of wrongdoing, it is less clear when the issue is academic failure.
Mrs. Gresser said the central Board of Education would urge Albany lawmakers to introduce legislation that would clarify those powers -- needed under the state law that decentralized the city system in 1970. A similar bill two years ago died after intense lobbying by unions opposed to giving the chancellor such powers.
The chances of such a bill passing appear better this year because the more aggressive stance is supported by Carl T. Hayden, who was elected last March as the Chancellor of the State Board of Regents, and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker.
Donald Singer, the president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, has said he would not oppose the Chancellor's intervention as long as principals had been given enough time and resources to succeed.
The 16 schools are all on the State Education Department's list of "schools under registration review" created in 1989 under Commissioner Thomas Sobol. Schools are placed on the list based on the percentage of students who do not meet minimum competency requirements on mathematics, reading or writing tests. If the schools do not improve, the Education Commissioner can recommend that the Board of Regents, the governing body for the state's schools and colleges, revoke their registrations.
At P.S. 304 in Bushwick, Brooklyn, Marvene Jones, whose four children have gone to the school, said she has seen fingerpointing for years about whose fault it is that the children are not learning. Only 12 percent of third graders in the school read at or above grade level, according to standardized tests.
"I'm here every day," Ms. Jones said. "I see a lot of children who can't read. That's from way back, seven or eight years ago. Somebody wasn't doing their job."
At his press conference with the student journalists, Dr. Crew said the fingerpointing would end because everyone would have to take some responsibility for the schools' poor performance.
"This is not a case of one person, or two people, or a faculty of people who have done poorly," he said. "This is the case of a school system that has failed these children. And it is that system that's going to have to be given to the art of self-correction."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Fears Over Jobs Have Held Down Wage Growth

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Americans who feel that the economic recovery has not done much for their paychecks had their worries confirmed today by an unlikely official: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Sounding more like his liberal critics than the conservative central banker that he is, Mr. Greenspan said that wage increases had slowed because so many Americans were worried about losing their jobs. 
 "That fear has doubtless played a significant role in the slowdown in the growth of labor compensation," he said in the text of a speech prepared for delivery tonight in Chicago. "Workers have, in effect, sought to preserve their jobs by accepting lesser increases in wages."
Mr. Greenspan went on to predict that workers would not stand for this much longer. "There will eventually come a point," he said, "when workers will perceive that it no longer makes sense to trade off wage progress for incremental gains in expected job security."
But Mr. Greenspan went on to tie stagnant wages firmly to his main concern at the Federal Reserve, which has been to control inflation. The risk is that workers may demand wage increases exceeding the increases in their annual output, possibly pushing up prices, he said.
And while Mr. Greenspan said that subdued wage increases had contributed to smaller price increases over the last 15 years, he stressed that a disciplined monetary policy had been largely responsible for the nation's success in bringing down inflation. The Federal Reserve sets monetary policy, and Mr. Greenspan has run the Fed since 1987, a time of mostly steady growth and falling inflation.

HEADLINE: At 50, U.N. Is Still a Stranger in New York

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
It was Christmastime in New York City. Damon Runyon had died earlier in the week. On Sunday the New York Giants would lose the National Football League championship to the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds. Advertisements for a soon-to-open Frank Capra movie, "It's a Wonderful Life," were appearing in newspapers.
On Dec. 12, 1946, headlines also trumpeted an 11th-hour donation by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the city: a 17-acre tract of slum land on the East River, occupied by slaughterhouses and meatpacking plants, that would finally secure the United Nations headquarters for New York. 
 And from that moment on, the United Nations and its host city were inseparable, locked in a sometimes touching, sometimes tense embrace.
"I've always thought the U.N.'s relationship with the city was like a long, rather positive marriage," said Sir Brian Urquhart, who was a top United Nations official for more than 40 years. "There are tremendous ups and downs and the partners occasionally get tremendously fed up with each other."
On Tuesday the United Nations celebrates the 50th anniversary of the ratification of its charter. It celebrates, too, its long association with New York, a relationship that began in great hope, excitement and pride but has since been tempered by the mundane realities of politics and parking tickets.
In the minds of many New Yorkers, the United Nations today seems to be associated not so much with the city's international standing as with stalled traffic, unruly demonstrations, the threat of terrorism, diplomats who ignore their bills, ineffectual government and the occasional shoe-banging of a Khrushchev or the hoopla of a papal visit.
The semi-centennial gathering, to begin on Saturday night with a gala at the World Financial Center, underscores the ambivalent relationship. As more than 200 world leaders and their delegations descend on the city at once, it means not only financial reward and the glory of world capitalhood, but the inconvenience of heavy traffic, closed streets and heightened security.
Canvassed last week, New Yorkers expressed opinions on the United Nations with their characteristic skepticism or, in some cases, indifference.
John Robles, a musician, thought aloud as he bought a newspaper on Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights: "You know, these diplomats with the special plates who can park their cars anywhere and don't get tickets? It seems to be something like a big fraternity of political people from all over the world and they watch each other's backs."
Peter Bracey, a public health adviser from Brooklyn, said: "One big building that has a lot of foreign dinners. Just one big foreign party."
Part of the image problem, United Nations officials say, is that 80 percent of its work is in economic development in third-world countries, which is rarely reported by news organizations with the fervor of the coverage of more sensitive peacekeeping actions or the more embarrassing budgetary troubles.
 
Location, Location And Limbo
 Another problem is location.
Completed in 1952, the famous edifice -- the monolithic Secretariat (the city's first building with all-glass walls) and the free-form General Assembly building -- is remotely situated on the East River, several long blocks from the nearest subway. Designated an international territory, it isn't officially in New York, or even in the United States, so it has always been symbolically on the outskirts of town. (Inside, it lately has a more foreign feel than ever; the United Nations must be one of the last skyscrapers in the United States where people smoke in the hallways.)
And of course, there is politics. The United Nations has always been a symbol of this nation's argument with itself over the issue of engagement versus isolationism.
In 1956, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin said he would "continue the fight to get the United States out of the U.N. and the U.N. out of the United States."
In 1983, after a Soviet diplomat accused the United States of being a poor host, the American deputy chief delegate, Charles M. Lichtenstein, said that if member nations were unhappy in New York, "we will put no impediment in your way, and we will be at dockside bidding you a farewell as you set off into the sunset," a remark supported by President Ronald Reagan, who declared, "If they chose to leave, goodbye."
It was the previous year that Mayor Edward I. Koch, incensed by the United Nations' anti-Israel stance, called it a "cesspool."
"I've always believed that New York City is the international capital of the world and that the U.N. belongs here," Mr. Koch said recently. "But when the U.N. people said that they'd move, I said, 'Move.' Where else can these guys get such cheap meals in first-class restaurants?"
These days, officials of both New York and the United Nations are at pains to point out that the institution and its host city are well matched, and that their relationship has been, and remains, mutually beneficial.
"Like New York, the U.N. is an English-speaking, multiethnic environment, and there is certainly a sense that the people who work here help make New York what it is," said Shashi Taroor, special assistant to the peacekeeping undersecretary.
Samir Sanbar, assistant secretary general for public information, pointed out the prestige factor: the gathering of world leaders will be the largest ever, anywhere. "This kind of congregation, let alone the money that it brings in, cements New York City's role as the world's central place," Mr. Sanbar said.
 
As City Employer, U.N. Ranks Third
 The prevailing opinion, in fact, is that the city probably gets the better deal, a feeling that has emerged in recent years as several United Nations agencies have been wooed by other cities, including Bonn and New Rochelle, N.Y., to which Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, nearly defected in 1993.
"We needed Unicef to stay where it was for two reasons," said Barry Sullivan, the former Deputy Mayor for finance and development, who offered Unicef a lease extension through 2026, at a reduced rent on its headquarters at 3 United Nations Plaza, after which Unicef would own the building.
"One, the U.N. really anchors the East Side of midtown, and with Unicef leaving we were in danger of creating a hole in the midtown-East Side area. And second, if we kept them, over time we'd continue to have a shot at new agencies."
The United Nations' financial contributions to the city are enormous. According to a study released yesterday by the New York City Commission for the United Nations, Consular Corps and International Business, the United Nations and its related agencies, missions and consulates channeled $3.3 billion into the city in 1994, generating 16,700 jobs directly and the need for 14,300 more, and making the United Nations the city's third biggest nongovernment employer, after Nynex and Chemical Bank.
In return, the city pays for any public schooling for diplomatic corps children, although many go to private schools. About 1,700 diplomats pay no income tax; about 4,000 diplomatic employees hold sales tax exemption cards. The city also provides and pays for routine police work involving the United Nations.
Since the mid-1970's, the Federal Government has reimbursed the city for protecting visiting dignitaries. The annual stipend, now $7 million, was not used up in 1994; the New York City Commission says that if the city is permitted to roll over the surplus, the two-year total will be enough to cover the costs of protecting the Pope on his recent visit (about $4 million) and for the 50th anniversary celebration.
What really irks New Yorkers -- and is probably the United Nations' most lingering local public relations test -- is the idea that the delegates are a bunch of wealthy deadbeats, ignoring parking tickets, rent agreements and other bills for goods and services in the name of diplomatic immunity.
A longtime problem, it has grown worse lately. The State Department estimates debts to local landlords, hotels, hospitals and utilities at $6.6 million to $8.5 million, three to four times what it was five years ago. According to the New York City liaison commission, about 9 percent of the parking tickets issued in the city are to cars with diplomatic license plates; those unpaid tickets added up to nearly $10 million in 1994.
In addition to providing various services like advising diplomats in car-buying, placing their children in local schools and clearing their apartment building vestibules of the homeless, the commission began its own collection agency last February.
Livia S. Sylva, the head of the commission, said it had already settled $396,000 in outstanding debts. In addition, she said, 26 percent of the accounts it is asked to settle involve goods and services that have not been delivered to diplomats. Many delegates, she said, feel that they have all been tarred with the same brush and that there exists, among city landlords, for instance, a widespread discrimination against them.
"A lot of people see the United Nations as an airport hangar," said Jane R. Steiner, the commission's deputy chief. "They don't see its value and they should."
 
Resistance To Europe
 Fifty years ago, on Oct. 24, 1945, the United Nations charter, which was drawn up in San Francisco, was ratified by a majority of the 51 original member nations, bringing into existence what for many in the postwar world was a dream organization that would render the globe free of violent conflict. There was considerable competition among cities in Europe -- Paris, London, Geneva, The Hague -- to be the site of the headquarters, and the first General Assembly meeting took place in London in January 1946.
There was, however, resistance to putting the United Nations in Europe, at least in part because the failed League of Nations had been in Geneva. And by March, the United Nations headquarters committee approved a site in both Westchester County and Fairfield County, Conn. Temporary headquarters were set up in the gymnasium on the Bronx campus of Hunter College, and New York set about welcoming it.
Stanley Meisler, author of "The United Nations: The First Fifty Years" (Atlantic Monthly Press), was then a Bronx high school student and one of many who slept outside Hunter College to be assured of tickets for the Security Council.
Nonetheless, the United Nations got off to a rocky start. Prefiguring the stalemates of the cold war, on March 27, 1946, after a protracted dispute involving the occupation of Iran by Soviet troops, the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, walked out of the Security Council. In the aftermath, citizens in Westchester and in Greenwich, Conn., protested having the United Nations as a neighbor: it moved temporarily to Lake Success, L.I.
Finally, on Dec. 11, 1946, with the United Nations seemingly sure to land elsewhere, the Rockefeller offer saved it for New York, where, half a century later, it remains one of the city's foremost tourist attractions and yet still has not quite worked its way into the hearts of New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: Prom Night for the Airlines

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The United States airline industry is looking a lot like an awkward high-school dance these days.
USAir says it is interested in hooking up with one of the two biggest carriers, United and American. United has said it likes the look of USAir, at least from a distance, while American is acting coy. And the rest of the industry is sizing up potential partners to approach if somebody makes the first move. The Justice Department, meanwhile, is chaperone to this affair, ready to break up anything untoward. 
 While trying to figure out who will link up with whom is now little more than a guessing game, industry analysts say that if two big airlines paired off, they would probably spark the most far-reaching consolidation of the industry since the 1980's wave that wiped away familiar names like National, Piedmont and Republic.
This time, though, the motivation would be different. A decade ago, airlines were driven by the belief that creating bigger route networks would automatically lead to better profits. Instead, it led to overcapacity and years of bruising losses. Now, airlines are determined not to repeat that mistake and are looking for combinations that will both let them grow and keep costs down.
United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, says it will decide whether to proceed with USAir negotiations by the end of the month. But even if it doesn't, and if American, the AMR unit, also pulls back, industry analysts say there will probably be a new round of consolidation over the next several years. They say the strong players in this mature business -- United, American and Delta Air Lines -- may decide that they need to make acquisitions to grow while weaker carriers like T.W.A. and Continental Airlines may need rescuing or go out of business in the next industry downturn.
"Ten years from now, fewer airlines are likely to control an even bigger share of the market than they do today," said Daniel M. Kasper, an industry consultant and a member of a 1993 Presidential commission on airline industry competitiveness.
To be sure, the Justice Department could block any merger that it felt would hinder competition. And airlines themselves might think twice about deals that would increase their debt load or saddle them with the challenge of merging their vast scheduling and computer networks, not to mention seniority lists of union members.
Still, USAir's dalliances with United and American raise two intriguing questions. The first affects the pocketbook of every American traveler: What will happen to fares if the industry does consolidate? And the second is of interest primarily to USAir itself, though the answer could have wide repercussions: As the highest-cost carrier in the country, will it be able to survive on its own?
The answer to the first question, many economists say, is: not much.
Government officials have always worried about the risk of a small number of carriers ruling the industry through tacit collusion. Since the industry's deregulation in 1978, their concerns have been fueled by the disappearance of 5 of the 10 biggest carriers, including Eastern and Pan Am. Airlines have also built near-monopolies at some airports. In Pittsburgh, for example, 9 of every 10 flights is on USAir.
But Clifford Winston, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, says any fears that consolidation will lead to higher fares are overstated. He points out that fares have declined an average 33 percent, adjusted for inflation, since 1976. Even though the largest carriers now hold bigger shares of the market, effective competition has generally increased, he said.
He cited statistics from "The Evolution of the Airline Industry," a new book he has written with Steven A. Morrison, an economics professor at Northeastern University. The data show that the number of similar-sized competitors on routes of less than 500 miles fell only 2 percent between 1978 and 1993, while the number of competitors on routes of more than 2,000 miles surged by 70 percent.
Even if the industry consolidated into four or five carriers, he added, competition would remain strong on busy routes between big cities like New York and Chicago, or New York and Los Angeles. "In most markets, four carriers can lead to significant competition," he said.
Mr. Winston's research suggests that if USAir and United merged, fares in general would rise slightly at first but then drop by about 2 percent, adjusted for inflation, after five years because other carriers would move in.
History suggests that when one carrier disappears, the competitive void does not last long. Three months after Eastern went out of business, fares fell 4.5 percent on its former routes from the previous year, Mr. Winston found.
Even on routes served by only one carrier, he added, the danger of a price explosion is small. That is because other airlines could easily move their aircraft to those markets and undercut high prices, he said.
Indeed, competition throughout the industry has been so fierce that the airlines, collectively, have reported net losses in 9 of the 17 years since deregulation. Their best year in this period was 1988, when the net profit margin was 2.6 percent.
Some industry experts still fear that too much consolidation will lead to some form of collusion that will make the industry more profitable at travelers' expense.
"Many consumers would be disserved if a tightly controlled oligopoly determines the level of pricing," said Paul Stephen Dempsey, director of the transportation law program at the University of Denver. As it is, Mr. Dempsey said there were signs of industry coordination, manifested in the high fares that airlines charge on many routes where there is competition.
The Justice Department is also concerned about the antitrust implications of any corporate merger. While it declined to comment on the potential impact of a linkup involving USAir, a paper written by three of its economists in 1993 concluded that the threat of competition from a third airline would not necessarily prevent two merged airlines from increasing prices sharply, at least in the short run.
Analysts say a merger between USAir and either American or United would be a good fit. Both prospective partners have strong east-west route networks, and both have tried but failed to develop a presence in the densely populated north-south routes along the East Coast, where USAir is strong. The United and American route systems have little overlap with that of USAir, which owns coveted landing slots at National Airport in Washington and La Guardia Airport in New York.
A USAir combined with United or American, with a strengthened frequent-flier program and bigger incentives to dangle before travel agents for swinging market share their way, would be a formidable competitor. Remaining carriers would be expected to pair off quickly in defense.
Analysts see United and USAir as the most likely combination, in part because most of their employees belong to the same unions. If they join forces, the analysts say, British Airways, which holds a 24.6 percent stake in USAir and is a marketing partner, would probably cash out its position. One reason is that British Airways' chairman, Sir Colin Marshall, has said he objects to union leaders serving on corporate boards, as two of them do at UAL.
If British Air cashed out, it might form a marketing alliance with American. Northwest Airlines, Continental, T.W.A. and America West would then in all likelihood be gobbled up, leaving United, American, Delta and probably the small but influential Southwest Airlines as the remaining players, the analysts say.
These would be bold strokes, indeed. But then, airline executives are feeling emboldened these days by their better-than-expected earnings performance for the third quarter. On Wednesday, for example, USAir reported net income of $43.1 million, in contrast to a loss of $180.1 million in the corresponding period a year ago. Like the rest of the industry, USAir is benefiting from tighter capacity, cost-cutting efforts, greater demand and higher fares.
Despite all the speculation about a merger, USAir has a contingency plan to go it alone. But for a company that has lost $3 billion since 1988, that would not be easy.
While USAir is saddled with high-cost wage agreements, a more fundamental problem is that its average passenger journey is 684 miles. United's, by contrast, is about 1,450 miles. That means that other carriers are able to spread the cost of airport fees, ramp workers and gate agents over longer trips.
USAir has received no help from its unions to escape this box. It recently gave up its effort to negotiate wage concessions totaling $500 million a year. And it continues to face incursions into its markets from carriers like Southwest.
Will such competition lead to death by a thousand cuts? USAir says no. It says its long-term strategy, while plodding, will work.
It has, for example, cut $500 million in operating costs, in part through a program to better match plane types and flight schedules to demand. That has helped raise the percentage of seats it regularly fills.
It has also upgraded its computer system for pricing tickets for leisure and business travelers as well as its system for scheduling crews.
The airline is also gradually lengthening its average trip -- to 684 miles today from 505 miles in 1988, an improvement of 35 percent. And it has ordered Boeing 757's intended for long-haul service. It now has a cash cushion of $865 million.
Perhaps most important, its no-layoff agreements with labor start expiring soon. The deal with the pilots -- traditionally the pace setter -- expires in mid-1997. At that point, said Brian Harris, an analyst at S. G. Warburg, management will gain the upper hand in talks.
With all these initiatives, he said, USAir should be competitive over time with the rest of the industry. "There is no reason," he said, "that USAir has to be the laggard."

HEADLINE: THE $1.50 SUBWAY RIDE: THE REACTION;
Bracing for a Heavy Impact As Region Absorbs the Cost

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
A. Leonard Malluck knows his numerals. The number of seconds in a day rolls off his tongue (86,400). He has calculated what it costs to drive a car 20 blocks from his house in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, to the grocery story ($1.50). More important, if a car and a subway train raced from his neighborhood to midtown Manhattan, where he works as a night-shift computer support technician for the city, the car would win by about 10 minutes, until you factor in parking time.
Mr. Malluck's conclusion is that the subway, even with the 20 percent fare increase approved yesterday by the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is to him still one of the best deals around. 
 "The $1.50 will annoy me for a week or two," Mr. Malluck said yesterday morning from the downtown platform of the Cortlandt Street subway stop as he ended his workday. "But I will live with it."
Other number crunchers caution that Mr. Malluck's equations are not as simple as they sound. The fare increase, planners and economists say, will ripple through the New York regional economy in some ways unpredictable and in others just not as simple as a race between a subway and a car. And, they say, it's the less tangible, less direct costs that are probably the scariest.
"The bigger danger is that the system becomes less and less competitive," said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private group that studies local land use issues. His group has calculated that a 25-cent fare increase will reduce ridership by about 24 million rides on the subway over the next year.
Mr. Yaro and other transportation experts said that the first effect of the fare increase would be direct, with hundreds of millions of dollars being siphoned from the local economy and fed into the subway system in 25-cent dribs and drabs. The harshest impact is expected to be felt in the city's poorest neighborhoods, where an extra quarter can pinch.
Several hidden costs may emerge.
To the degree that poorer people will walk or find other ways to commute, the shops clustered around train stations could take their hits in the form of falling revenues.
Commuters will lose time while waiting in their cars in longer traffic jams, because more drivers will be on the roads. They will thus pay for part of the fare increase even if they have never set foot on the subway.
One of the gravest costs, experts say, could be borne by the air itself. If enough transit users drive because they find the system to have outpriced its usefulness, the target air quality standards set by the city under the Federal Clean Air Act could be threatened. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has power to withhold Federal highway money, $2 billion in New York State's case, if the agency concludes that the state has failed to enforce an effective clean air program.
"That's the E.P.A.'s gun under the table," said Jack Dean, a senior planner at the Regional Plan Association.
When the city and state calculated the costs of a $500 million project to rebuild a 3.5-mile elevated portion of the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn, for example, the analysis of environmental effects was based on a $1.25 mass transit fare.
"It's all moot now," said Brian T. Ketcham, an executive vice president at Konheim & Ketcham, a Brooklyn environmental and transportation consulting firm.
Mr. Ketcham estimated that the fare increase would result in 40,000 to 80,000 more vehicles being driven within the five boroughs of New York every 24 hours. The implications of that increase in air pollution and noise pollution, he said, will in turn eventually be felt in higher medical costs.
Some of the variables in measuring the impact of the fare increase will be also be geographic. On the Long Island Rail Road, for example, where fares are to go up by 9 percent, demand is considered inelastic, because riders are more accepting of higher prices. The alternatives on the intensely congested Long Island road system are generally worse no matter how high the ticket prices go.
Similarly, in the poorer areas of upper Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, more transit riders are also expected to pay the higher fares without changing their behavior because many do not own cars and do not have a lot of other options when the fare rises.
New debates on old subjects are also expected to gain significance; for instance, placing tolls on the East River bridges between Manhattan and Brooklyn and Manhattan and Queens. If enough additional people start driving cars over the bridges instead of using mass transit, the traffic implications alone could favor arguments for a toll system, said Jameson W. Doig, a professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University.
Other experts say that in an odd way, the fare increase should make current drivers really want higher tolls on all the city's river crossings, because higher tolls will make the subway and train system more competitive, thus keeping those mass transit riders off the roads.
"People who drive have a huge incentive to support slobs like me who ride the bus," said Jack Dean, a senior planner at the Regional Plan Association.
Several subway riders also said today that much could depend on how well the M.T.A. sold the fare increase to its customers.
"It would be nice to see a breakdown, you know, what the increase is and what it's going to, so we can hold them to that," said Rino Mermini, an investment manager at Chase Manhattan Bank who commutes from Harrison, N.J., to the Chase office in Brooklyn's Metrotech complex, using the PATH system and the New York City subway.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes to Toughen Stance on Illegal Aliens

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The New Jersey State Senate held its first voting session since June today to pass a package of laws that would deal more harshly with youthful offenders, deny worker's compensation payments to illegal aliens and deny state business to any company that employs illegal aliens.
With passage of the laws, which remain to be voted on in the State Assembly, the New Jersey Senate reflects the growing national mood of antagonism toward juvenile crime and illegal immigration. The juvenile justice changes were drawn up by the administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and are all but assured passage in the Assembly. The measures dealing with illegal aliens have been sharply opposed by the Roman Catholic Church and immigrants' rights groups, and face a less certain future. 
 The first of the two measures requires that employers receiving state contracts, tax abatements and the like certify that all of their employees are in the country legally. The second measure makes undocumented workers ineligible for worker's compensation and temporary disability payments for workplace injuries.
Both measures passed with only a few dissenting votes, despite the opposition of the Catholic bishops in the state, who said that the laws could be interpreted to deny illegal aliens such state services as childhood immunization and emergency medical care.
"Because of the potential danger to human life inherent in these two bills, the Catholic bishops are compelled to oppose them," the New Jersey Catholic Conference, an association of bishops, said in a statement.
But State Senator Leonard T. Connors, a Surf City Republican and the bill's chief sponsor, said his legislation was needed to protect taxpayers from the hidden costs of illegal immigration.
"America today is confronted with an invasion of illegal, undocumented aliens," Mr. Connors said. "Illegal, undocumented aliens are driving American workers to the unemployment lines."
Yet the proposal to deny worker's compensation and temporary disability benefits to illegal aliens was opposed by legislators who said that such a law might actually encourage companies to hire aliens in the hope of avoiding having to pay such benefits.
"What we are doing is creating incentives for employers to hire illegal aliens," Senator Edward T. O'Connor, a Jersey City Democrat, declared during the debate. Mr. Connors replied that such illegal hirings would occur regardless.
"Every day," Mr. Connors said, "there are people who jeopardize their freedom by sticking up banks, mugging people and robbing people. So an employer who is unscrupulous about the laws of our country would certainly cheat the laws on worker's compensation or the rules about Social Security, with or without this law."
Governor Whitman has not yet taken a position on the aliens bills, although she has generally opposed denying needy people existing benefits.
The juvenile justice changes would unify all related activities under a new Juvenile Justice Commission; they would also allow the state to compel parents to pay restitution for a wide range of offenses committed by their children, and give juvenile judges greater leeway in sentencing young offenders.
Under the new law, for example, imprisonment would be an option for juveniles considered dangerous.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Strong Growth in Sales Lifts Coca-Cola Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company said today that earnings rose 13.3 percent in the third quarter, lifted by strong growth in the volume of beverage sales in the United States and abroad.
The company, the world's biggest soft-drink maker, said net income increased to $802 million, or 64 cents a share, from $708 million, or 55 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1994. Revenue rose 9.7 percent, to $4.89 billion from $4.46 billion. 
 The latest earnings matched the average estimate of 64 cents a share from 20 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Shares of Coca-Cola gained $1.75, to $73.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sales volume, measured by cases sold of Coke, Sprite and other brands, rose 8 percent in the United States and 7 percent abroad. Coca-Cola, based in Atlanta, sells concentrate to bottlers, which then sell the cases.
Typically, sales growth is faster in international markets than in the United States, where Coke has been sold for 109 years. The company was able to stimulate domestic growth partly because of the success of Coke's contoured bottle, which was reintroduced last year in an effort to lift sales.
"New packaging can be very much a stimulus in the industry," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. "Having a new bottle will help increase sales."
Taking the third-quarter results into account, the company said it expected to meet its goal of achieving annual growth in international volume of 8 to 10 percent.
The company said the gains in domestic sales were driven by its core brands: Coca-Cola classic, Diet Coke and Sprite. Volume at the company's juice unit, however, which makes Hi-C, Minute Maid and Five-Alive brands, declined 1 percent. The company has been shifting its marketing program to support those brands.
International sales growth was led by gains in Brazil, Britain and China. Sluggish economies in Mexico, Japan and Argentina, three of Coca-Cola's largest international markets, acted as a drag on international sales.
Coca-Cola said it repurchased about nine million shares during the third quarter, bringing the total purchased this year to 25 million shares.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Two Bell Companies Report Higher Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Growing demand for second phone lines among residential customers contributed to solid profit increases at the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the BellSouth Corporation in the third quarter before special charges, the companies said yesterday.
BellSouth said its profit rose almost 12 percent in the three months that ended Sept. 30. Bell Atlantic's profit increased 11 percent before extraordinary gains and charges. 
 The performance of both companies met the expectations of Wall Street analysts.
BellSouth's profit of $558.5 million was a record for the Atlanta-based company. It amounted to 56 cents a share, adjusted for a recently announced 2-for-1 stock split.
A year ago, BellSouth earned $499.5 million, or 50 cents a share, in the third quarter.
Revenue was $4.43 billion, up from $4.20 billion a year ago.
BellSouth said the number of access lines it provides was up 4.7 percent from a year earlier, driven in part by strong regional economic conditions. Second lines accounted for 207,000 of the 493,000 in new residential lines for the year that ended Sept. 30. About 70 percent of BellSouth's overall wireline business is residential.
The company also reported its domestic cellular business now had 2.54 million subscribers, up 32 percent from a year ago. Its international cellular operation grew to nearly 550,000 subscribers, up 78 percent.
The company's stock was up 37.5 cents, to $74.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, earned $604.8 million, or $1.38 a share, aided by the sale of overlapping properties when its cellular business merged with that of the Nynex Corporation. The gain amounted to $203 million after taxes but was offset by $40 million in special development expenses.
A year ago, Bell Atlantic lost $1.87 billion, or $4.29 a share, after a charge for changing its accounting practices from a regulated to a competitive business.
Revenue was $3.26 billion compared with $3.46 billion, a decline associated with placing its cellular operations into the Nynex partnership.
Without the extraordinary items, Bell Atlantic would have earned $441.9 million, or $1.01, in the latest quarter and $397.5 million, or 91 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.
The company said the number of access lines it provides was up 3.3 percent compared with the corresponding period a year ago, led by fast growth in customers ordering second lines for their homes.
The company's stock closed up $1.50, to $63.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: 3 Drug Makers Win a Lawsuit To Extend Protection of Patents

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 19

 BODY:
Merck & Company, the Schering-Plough Corporation and Roche Holdings A.G. have won a lawsuit seeking extended protection of patents, against the United States Patent Office and the Food and Drug Administration.
The ruling, reached Monday by the Federal District Court here, is a victory for brand-name drug makers who fought an interpretation of a new Federal law based on the World Trade Organization rules by the F.D.A. and the Patent Office, which limited patent protection. 
 Securities analysts said the ruling could affect sales of billions of dollars of brand-name drugs that would otherwise be open sooner to sharp competition from less expensive generic versions.
Neil B. Sweig, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, said that based on current sales in the United States, the extension could result in $3 billion in sales of Zantac, the ulcer treatment made by the Glaxo Wellcome Company; $1.45 billion in sales of Mevacor, a cholesterol-lowering drug made by Merck, and $280 million in sales of Capoten, a hypertension treatment produced by the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company.
Mr. Sweig added that the court ruling had been anticipated by investors and was already reflected in drug companies' stock prices.
Under a Federal rule that took effect on June 8, drug makers could either have patent protection under the new W.T.O., which allows 20 years of patent protection for new prescription drugs or the previous system.
Under the old system, drug patents were protected in the United States for 17 years after they were granted, plus some of the time drugs were awaiting regulatory review by the F.D.A. In some cases, protection would last longer under the old system.
"The courts ruled that they were wrong, and you can be protected under both systems," said Steve Bercham of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association.
Mr. Bercham said, however, that the court had decided that a patent could never result in exclusive marketing rights for more than 14 years.
As a result of the decision, Merck's patent on its cholesterol-lowering drug Mevacor was extended to June 15, 2001, from Nov. 4, 1999.
Gary Latchow, a Merck spokesman, said the patent for the company's ulcer medication Pepcid had also been extended.

HEADLINE: Investors Push Stock Markets to New Heights

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
On the eighth anniversary of the 1987 stock market crash yesterday, investors were in a buying mood, sending popular averages into record territory once again.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 24.93 points to end at 4,802.45, edging past its record closing of 4,801.80 set on Sept. 14. 
 The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks scored its third consecutive closing high, with a gain of 3.21 points at 590.65, and the Big Board composite index rose 1.10, to 315.39, beating its record close of 314.33 set Sept. 20.
"Thank God the market's nothing like it was in 1987," said Michael Metz, a market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. On Oct. 19, 1987, the Dow Jones index plunged 508 points in the biggest one-day drop in history.
"Interest rates were at 10 percent and headed higher then, and now they're at 6 percent and falling and we have an economy that's slowly perking up," he said.
In the bond market, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose three-hundredths of 1 percent, lowering its yield to 6.30 percent from 6.33 percent on Wednesday.
Mr. Metz said that some stock investors were stepping aside to wait for Friday's expirations of futures and options, a so-called double witching day. Still trading was heavy with volume of 406.6 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Declining issues led advances 1,193 to 1,102 on the Big Board.
But not every index set a record. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 1.60 point, to 1,046.97, which was below its record closing high of 1,067.40 reached on Sept. 13. And the American Stock Exchange's market- value index declined 1.07, to 534.11.
Thom Brown, a managing director at Rutherford Brown & Catherwood, said that corporate earnings were better than Wall Street expected. "Some looked bad, but some are coming in quite strong," he said.
As of Wednesday, 104 of the 191 companies in the Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks that have reported quarterly results had positive surprises, 64 had negative reports and 23 were on target, according to I/B/E/S, a firm that tracks corporate earnings.
Topping the Big Board most-active list was Nokia Oy, the Finnish telecommunications company. Its American depository receipts tumbled 8 3/8, to 60 1/2, after the company posted disappointing profits and said the outlook was uncertain for American sales for its cellular phones.
Motorola, the leading maker of cellular phones, lost 2 1/2 to close at 65 in sympathy with Nokia.
"We've got a lot of nervous holders who run to the hills at the slightest disappointments showing in a technology sector that has high expectations," Mr. Metz said.
Also, in the technology sector, Apple Computer shares declined 2 5/8 to 34 3/4 in Nasdaq trading; the computer maker said late Wednesday that its fiscal fourth-quarter net profit sank 48 percent.
Other technology stocks were firmer, with International Business Machines rising 1 7/8, to 98 1/4, Compaq Computer up 1/8, to $54.25, and the Microsoft Corporation up 1 1/8, to 96 3/4.
General Instruments was the most-active issue, losing 7 to 20, after the company said on Wednesday that it expected its income would be hurt by a slowdown in spending by cable systems.
Computer Associates climbed 3 7/8, to 48 7/8, after it posted stronger-than-expected earnings.
The Cordis Corporation soared 21 5/8 to 107 5/8 on news that Johnson & Johnson was making a surprise $1.6 billion tender offer for it.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Shares a Victory

 BODY:
It sounded very much like another of the upbeat announcements the Giuliani administration often makes when a company agrees to stay in New York in exchange for a break in taxes or rent. There was even more fanfare than usual, in fact, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that his administration had succeeded in keeping Unicef in New York for the next 31 years.
"Our success in keeping this vital agency and its many employees is indicative of our commitment to preserve and support key elements of the U.N. community," the Mayor told a news conference. 
 There was only one problem: the complex deal to keep Unicef was struck two years earlier.
Mayor David N. Dinkins, fearful of losing a prestigious international agency and its 1,500 jobs to Westchester County, had his staff work up a package of financial incentives to get Unicef to stay.
In the succeeding two years, city and agency officials worked out the language of the deal, but the terms remained identical.
Giuliani administration officials maintained that they were not trying to take credit for a deal negotiated by their predecessors. Though John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, dismissed Mr. Dinkins's deal as a press release.
"The difference is that that was an announcement and this is an accomplishment," he said.

HEADLINE: Curb on Trade With Cuba Is Tightened

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Stripped of its most controversial provision, a bill that would moderately tighten the United States embargo against Cuba was approved overwhelmingly today by the Senate. The vote was 74 to 24.
The bill would insure that a country that buys Cuban sugar and molasses does not resell either product to the United States. It also seeks to reduce aid to Russia by $200 million -- the same amount Russia reportedly pays Cuba to rent an electronic intelligence-gathering base. 
 The legislation, sponsored by the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms, also orders the Administration to try to block Cuba from becoming a member of international financial institutions.
In addition, it requires the Administration to seek a worldwide embargo against Cuba at the United Nations. That bid is considered largely symbolic since the General Assembly has repeatedly sided with Cuba when the American embargo has come to a vote. No other country bars trade with Cuba.
President Fidel Castro is expected to raise the issue on Sunday when he speaks before the General Assembly during celebrations of the United Nations' 50th anniversary. The Administration announced on Wednesday that Mr. Castro would be granted a visa to travel to the United States despite Republican objections.
Final passage of the legislation today was anticlimactic. The key vote occurred on Tuesday night when Senator Helms and his allies narrowly lost a procedural vote on a provision to discourage foreign investment in Cuba, which could leave the country's economy prostrate.
Under that proposal, investors would shy away because they would not be assured of legal title to any property they acquired. Senator Helms would have achieved that by allowing American residents whose property was confiscated three decades ago to lay claim to the properties in United States courts.
The House approved a Cuba sanctions bill last month that contains the controversial provision, and Senator Helms said he hopes it survives the process of reconciling the House and Senate bills.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Underground Blues: Straphangers Pay as Suburbs Get Tax Break

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
WHEN New Yorkers look back at October 1995 and try to understand why they were hit with one of the largest transit fare increases in the city's history, they will come to one unavoidable conclusion: that New York's political hierarchy decided to join the rest of America in putting tax-cutting ahead of everything else.
"They shifted the burden," said Richard Ravitch, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. "They made a fundamental decision about how to operate the economy, where the tax burden falls. It ain't necessarily what I would want, but it's part of a process of shrinking public resources. They want the burden of cost of operating the system to go from one group of taxpayers to another." 
 Two basic sources pay the costs of operating New York City's transit system: the fare box and government subsidies. Now 60 percent comes from riders, the rest from government. That split will change to 70 percent from the fare box and only 30 percent from government if the new fare increase -- really just a euphemism for a tax increase -- goes into effect next month as planned.
That does indeed amount to a political decision to shift the cost of operating the system from one group of taxpayers to another. No politician from Albany to City Hall put it that way, of course, but that's what they did, in a decision that involved every powerful leader in the state. It involved Democrats and Republicans, upstaters and downstaters:
*Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who was elected without many New York City votes, withdrew millions of state dollars from the subways.
*Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani complained about bloat and made it easier for the Governor to bleed the system by withdrawing city money, beating the Governor to it. Then he ordered the members he appointed to the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to vote against the fare increase.
*The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, waited until just a few weeks ago before coming up with a plan to save the fare that was destined to fail.
*The M.T.A. chairman, E. Virgil Conway, instead of being New York's most adamant and outspoken subway defender, views his job as being the Governor's loyal servant, and has done his bidding.
Even more significant is something that elected officials do not mention in the same breath with the fare increase: the income tax cut that the Legislature approved last spring at Mr. Pataki's behest. Mr. Silver and his Democratic Assembly approved it along with the Republican Senate. Mr. Giuliani praised it. Few got around to noting that the tax cut came at a cost: an estimated $515 million in the current fiscal year, and an additional $1.8 billion in the next one.
These numbers are significant because $300 million a year would have saved the $1.25 fare; $100 million would have taken a dime off the quarter increase. Put another way, according to the Straphangers Campaign, the advocates for mass transit, the tax cut will save a family that earns $50,000 a year from $7 to $90. The fare increase will cost someone who commutes 50 weeks a year $125.
THAT is shortsighted, to put it mildly, said Robert R. Kiley, a former chairman of the M.T.A. and now president of the New York City Partnership. It was Mr. Kiley and Mr. Ravitch who rebuilt the system after the fiscal crisis of the 1970's robbed it of so much money that it was devastated.
So for the last 15 years, the leaders of New York cooperated, however reluctantly, to make repairs and keep the buses and subways and the rest of the transit system going. They would posture and fuss but ultimately find the money the M.T.A. needed, to prevent another collapse.
"All of this was an implicit deal, explicit, really, that we were all in this together," Mr. Kiley said. "Here in the most turbulent place in the United States, where nobody agreed with anybody on anything, it worked. Everyone made accommodations, and it was all sort of informal, if you will. That turned out to be its fatal flaw."
THE shift of power in Albany last year from a Democratic governor to Mr. Pataki, a Republican from Putnam County who ran on a pledge to cut taxes, undid that informal handshake. This year, all transit systems in the state but the city's got more state aid, and the commuter rail lines got a 9 percent fare increase, compared with 20 percent for the subways and buses.
It is not surprising that Mr. Pataki played to his constituency. But a mayor of New York City, even a Republican one, beating up on the transit system instead of leading the charge to get as much money for it as he could? An Assembly Speaker who, though critical of the fare increase (as is the Mayor), lets months go by before suggesting an alternate strategy that was destined to go nowhere in any case?
This is indeed a curious time for New York. But then again, New York is -- though some like to think otherwise -- just a part of the United States. And the country is changing.
"Everything is changing in our society," Mr. Ravitch said. "It is an inevitable consequence of where our politics are now. Banks are changing. The health care system is changing. And maybe how we pay for our transit system."

HEADLINE: Pataki Aide Criticizes Job Agencies Of Cuomo

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The election for Governor may be nearly a year past, the campaign buttons consigned to the memorabilia pile, but the Pataki and Cuomo people were at it again today, as if the sloganeering had never stopped.
The bickering began when Gov. George E. Pataki's top economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano, summoned reporters for a news conference during which he spent far more time attacking the Cuomo administration than laying out his own plans. Mr. Gargano contended that the Cuomo administration had so mismanaged several state agencies that are supposed to nurture job creation that tens of millions of dollars had been lost. 
 "The taxpayers are saddled with these bills," Mr. Gargano said. "These abuses have hindered real economic growth and made it that much harder for us to turn this state around."
Those charges brought an angry response from Mr. Gargano's predecessor, Vincent Tese, who until today had refrained from commenting on the Pataki administration. Mr. Tese said in a phone interview that Mr. Gargano was being dishonest and was distorting the Cuomo administration's record.
Mr. Tese also happens to be one of the few Cuomo administration officials still working for Mr. Pataki because he serves on the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- with Mr. Gargano. When told of Mr. Gargano's criticism, Mr. Tese said he was seriously considering resigning from the board.
"He sits back and just takes shots," Mr. Tese said of Mr. Gargano. "It's a lack of class, that is what it is."
In going after Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Tese, Mr. Gargano appeared to be setting the stage for a move by the Pataki administration to scuttle some of the agreements made by the agencies, which include the Job Development Authority, the defunct Harlem Urban Development Corporation, the Harlem International Trade Center and the Urban Development Corporation.
Mr. Gargano said that because of its lax procedures in evaluating loans, the Job Development Authority had lost $21 million in 1994 and $22 million in 1995. From 1992 through March 1995, the authority had to write off 83 loans worth more than $34 million, he said. In comparison, from 1966 to 1990, it wrote off only 57 loans.
Mr. Gargano also suggested that the Cuomo administration had used the Urban Development Corporation as a political arm, pointing out that last year, an election year, the corporation handed out nearly $100 million in financial commitments, nearly three times the amount it usually provides annually.
Mr. Gargano declined to say whether he had uncovered anything illegal in the way the agencies were run. He said he had forwarded recommendations to Mr. Pataki about how to handle the agreements made by the Cuomo administration, though he would not give specifics.
He also said that he had instituted new rules to insure that new loans made or guaranteed by the agencies were repaid. "We have put into effect strict criteria in our applicant and review process," he said.
Mr. Tese said that Mr. Gargano was using the Cuomo administration as a scapegoat.
"It's political," Mr. Tese said. "He obviously doesn't want to do some of the loans, so he wants to paint it as being something that is not prudent."
Mr. Tese said it was misleading to blame the Cuomo administration for the rise in ventures by the Urban Development Corporation last year. The vast majority of the agreements, he said, stemmed from what are known as member items -- projects pushed by members of the Legislature, both Democratic and Republican, who were seeking to curry favor with voters.
At least in 1994, Mr. Tese said, the losses at the Job Development Authority were affected by the bankruptcy of one company, Hampshire Instruments in Monroe County. The authority, which had made loan guarantees to the company, had to write off $10 million on that deal, he said. And he explained that there were so many defaults from 1992 to 1995 because of the recession.
Mr. Tese, now a director at Bear Stearns in Manhattan, said he was surprised that Mr. Gargano would criticize the Cuomo administration without acknowledging its successes, like the start of the redevelopment of 42d Street in Manhattan.
"He sat around and took all kinds of credit for 42d Street, and he didn't have one damn thing to do with 42d Street," Mr. Tese said of Mr. Gargano. "Did he ever give credit to a prior administration for 42d Street? The answer is no, so this man is living some kind of charade."

HEADLINE: Hollywood Horrors

 BODY:
Movie flops are like Tolstoy's unhappy families, each different in its own way. But a string of recent box-office calamities suggests a common thread, namely a gathering public revolt against Hollywood's addiction to risk-free formulas and to "bankable" movie stars who are asked to recreate earlier successes without improving on them. The movie industry has been doing that for years and is not the only business to go for time-tested recipes. But economic factors seem to have reinforced Hollywood's self-destructive tendencies.
The news that three hugely expensive movies ("Jade," "Strange Days" and "The Scarlet Letter") opened and flopped in one weekend is only the latest sign that all the marketing genius that money can buy cannot sell counterfeit goods or tired retreads. It is often said in Hollywood that everyone in the United States has two businesses: their own and show business. Nowadays, the motion picture industry has become such an entertaining spectator sport that its ups and downs are more interesting than the movies themselves. 
 Among the forces driving Hollywood toward the safe shore of formulaic and derivative movie-making are the inflated salaries awarded performers whose names are thought to guarantee box-office success. Equally significant, however, is the fact that the multinational corporations that increasingly own the studios almost always look for the sure thing, especially when movie budgets are soaring routinely to $50 million or more.
In that context, breathtaking cynicism rewarded by rejection is reassuring. A national referendum that might terminate the persistent recycling of Sylvester Stallone in ever more mindlessly violent vehicles is welcome indeed. Likewise, empty theaters may force Hollywood to think twice before it tarts up Hester Prynne as Demi Moore, or attempts to merchandise the stripping and lap-dancing in "Showgirls" as art and enlightenment.
Moviegoers do not wish the producers and performers ill. What they do not like is Hollywood's careless assumption that they are easy to manipulate and can be taken for granted. Sam Goldwyn once said, "You gotta take the sour with the bitter." Now the bitter audience is refusing to take it.

HEADLINE: Co-op in Free Fall: A Horror Story

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Lou-Anne Walters and her mother had barely finished arranging furniture and hanging family photos in the apartment they bought in Brooklyn six years ago when their co-op started its free fall.
First the sponsors of the conversion plan went broke, leaving the finances in a mess and renovations of apartments unfinished. Then the bank that took over from the defaulted sponsors went bankrupt two years later. 
 So when the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation stepped in to take over the assets of the bank in 1992, which included many of the apartments, other owners were relieved. Not only would the agency be responsible for the unsold apartments, but it also would hold the individual mortgages of the families who had bought apartments.
"We thought at least there would be some order restored," said Ms. Walters, who lives with her mother in a spacious six-room apartment at 611 Argyle Road in Kensington, a neighborhood consisting mostly of single-family homes near Brooklyn College.
But their comfort was short-lived. Within a year, the banking agency had ended its financial support of the building by stopping the payments for maintenance on the apartments it ended up owning: a majority of the 84 units. Without that support, the individual apartment owners are losing hope that the co-op will be saved. At the same time, they are being pressed by the agency to pay off co-op loans for apartments they will probably never own outright.
In a city with no shortage of horror stories about the co-op market and a reputation as one of the biggest victims of the real estate collapse of the 1980's, the story of 611 Argyle Road stands out. The 18 remaining families who bought apartments are in a mess that includes two mortgages, two banks and a Government agency whose job it is to protect the public.
Initially, 27 apartments were sold, and nine shareholders have defaulted. The rest are occupied by tenants paying stabilized rents of $272 to $675 a month.
The co-op buyers, most of them black or Hispanic, say that when the co-op started to unravel, they were resigned to the loss of equity in their apartments along with their dreams of home ownership. But what they cannot accept is the way they have been treated by the agency.
Ms. Walters, an accountant, said the agency had given her and her fellow shareholders a no-win choice of paying off loans on apartments where they will probably soon be tenants or defaulting on the loans, ruining their credit ratings. She has chosen to take the risk of defaulting.
The F.D.I.C. is only following its legal mandate, said Gary P. Bowen, Northeast regional director of the Disposition Asset Services Division. "This is really a terrible situation," he acknowledged. "But we are supposed to realize the maximum from the sale of these assets. We are not allowed to take money and throw it at a group that happens to be having a bad time."
Ms. Walters and other buyers said they paid $55,000 to $105,000 for their apartments. While some have stopped repaying their co-op loans, all have continued to pay maintenance of $320 to $686 a month.
"These apartments were all that most of us could afford," said Ms. Walters, who with her mother paid $95,000 for the apartment in 1989. "We have suffered for years at the hands of the sponsors of the conversion, various managing agents, the bank and now the F.D.I.C. We are not asking for our money back. But at what point does someone or some entity step up and share the responsibility for this mess, which is not ours alone?"
Shareholders say they were never notified of the F.D.I.C.'s decision to pull out.
"We learned about it when we were served with the notices of the foreclosure," said one of the buyers, Patricia Gore. "The F.D.I.C. didn't even give us any warning."
The building is now in receivership, and it is likely that the bank holding the first mortgage will put it up for auction and that it will be turned back into a rental property.
After four years of being passed from one F.D.I.C. official to another, some co-op owners recently met with agency representatives face to face for the first time. But Mr. Bowen, who did not attend the meeting, held out little hope the residents would be forgiven their loans.
The mess can be traced to the sponsors of the conversion, Aaron Ziegelman and Arthur Cohen. The sponsors, who took out a second mortgage on the building, increasing the cost of maintaining it, defaulted after their costs could no longer be covered by the maintenance payments of shareholders and rents from the tenants who did not buy apartments.
After the sponsors defaulted, the First New York Bank for Business took over the unsold apartments the sponsors owned. It collapsed in 1992. Among the assets inherited by the F.D.I.C. were shares on apartments and co-op loans. The agency determined that the building was a lost cause when it discovered that rents and maintenance payments did not meet the mortgage and the cost of upkeep. The entire building fell into default when Bankers Federal Savings Bank, which held the first mortgage, foreclosed on the F.D.I.C. and the remaining shareholders.
Dozens of co-op and condominium conversion projects ran into trouble in the late 1980's. But many co-ops have been saved through refinancing worked out by banks, shareholders and agencies like the F.D.I.C.
This year, for example, the F.D.I.C. took a loss when it sold a $7.65 million mortgage it held on Celtic Park, a troubled 26-building co-op in Woodside, Queens, to the shareholders for $5.5 million.
But Mr. Bowen sees no such future for the Argyle. "Some projects are more economically viable than others," he said when asked about the distinction between the two properties. "In Queens we held the first mortgage, and the co-op was able to borrow from another lender to pay off the debt."
Ms. Walters said of the agency: "They only see the bottom line. This building did not have to continue to decline. By letting the building go into foreclosure, the F.D.I.C. kept us from helping ourselves."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lou-Anne Walters reading material from her files on the financial problems at the co-op on Argyle Road in the Kensington neighborhood of Brooklyn, during a recent meeting of co-op owners. In the background were two other owners, Jeanette Johnson and Dennis Jackson. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In America;
Losing a March

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I stood at the corner of Third Street and Jefferson Drive on the day after the Half-Million Man March and gazed up at the flag that rippled silently outside the Capitol dome. The dome, wrapped as always in the glory of dreams not yet realized, stood gleaming against a pale blue melancholy sky.
Twenty-four hours earlier an extraordinary number of African-American men and boys had turned up in the nation's capital in search of leadership that would galvanize them, that would show them in a compelling way what they could do to improve the quality of their lives. Even more impressive than the sheer number of the participants was the extraordinary amount of good will they exhibited. 
 It was an opportunity that should have been exploited for maximum benefit. But no one knew how. The throngs were willing, but the leadership was weak.
The atmosphere for most of the day was that of a vast picnic. The warmth of comradeship was everywhere. Smiles and embraces were ubiquitous, and it would be difficult to overestimate the importance of the experience to the young boys who had traveled to Washington for the first time in the arms of, or clutching the hands of, their fathers and uncles and grandfathers.
But something was missing. The men positively thirsted for wise and compelling counsel, the leadership that in these harsh times would draw out the best in themselves.
Where, for example, was the inspirational message about the simple need and the profound value of working ever harder, ever harder, no matter how lousy or unfair it might seem, to achieve personal and collective goals that have proved so elusive for so long?
The men were told repeatedly to reconnect with their families, obviously a positive message, but they weren't given a clue as to how to better support those families. Many of the men I spoke with grew up without fathers themselves. Being responsible family men is new terrain for them.
"I want to do the right thing," said Isaac Taylor, a 24-year-old unemployed laborer from Cincinnati who has two children, a girl, 6, and a boy, 4. The children live with their mother. "I don't really know where things went wrong," Mr. Taylor said. "I could use some guidance."
Where was the serious talk, the blunt talk, about the desperate need to curb the violence that has ruined so many families and spoiled so many neighborhoods? A report released last week by the Carnegie Council on Adolescent Development noted: "The firearm homicide rate for 10-to-14-year-olds more than doubled between 1985 and 1992 (from 0.8 to 1.9 per 100,000). For black males, the rate increased from 3.0 to 8.4 per 100,000 during the same period."
The marchers were open to serious talk. They were more than willing to absorb hard truths. "Stop the violence!" was a point that should have been driven home relentlessly, not sporadically. Those in the enormous crowd who were not violent, the vast majority, should nevertheless have been given the mission to go back home and bring real pressure on their peers to renounce violence.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged the men to take their children to school, another worthy suggestion. But that is not enough (as Mr. Jackson himself has pointed out) when, for example, the New York City Board of Education has to issue updated safety regulations to deal with students who carry guns, knives and box-cutters to school, and who use force, with or without a weapon, "against school personnel, or extreme force against students or others."
I wanted to hear the use of violence denounced repeatedly in the strongest of terms. I didn't.
I wanted to hear about the importance of good study habits, and strategies to counter the taunts of schoolmates who believe that following the rules, studying hard and achieving high grades are ways of "acting white," and therefore should be shunned.
I wanted to hear many things. The fundamentals. In the end, the inspiration came not from the podium but from the crowd itself. Many of the men said they would return home with a renewed sense of purpose. But the leadership is still desperately needed. Without it, the sense of purpose will be lost.
