HEADLINE: G.M. Feels A.O.K. About Vehicle Design Management

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 19

 BODY:
It is autumn in the Motor City, the locust trees are turning gold, and the General Motors Corporation -- with a mix of grandeur, mystery and familiarity -- said today that it was continuing to reorganize its vehicle development process.
In brief, the company named the 13 V.L.E.s who will manage the V.D.P. under N.A.O. That is, it identified the people who will oversee development, knitting together G.M.'s far-flung, diffuse operations. 
 For G.M. watchers -- avid collectors of abbreviations -- the announcement was another opportunity to revel in perhaps the deepest mystery of the business world: how the biggest corporation on earth takes a notion, filters it through thousands of designers, accountants, engineers and manufacturing experts, and turns out a moveable beast of steel, glass and rubber.
Asked today if anyone understood the Vehicle Development Process, Joseph S. Phillippi, a Lehman Brothers analyst who has studied G.M. for a quarter-century, cited a past company president.
"Ed Cole," he said. "Except he's dead."
For many years, the steel, glass and rubber did not seem to fit together very well. Now, executives said today, things are coming together properly. They said G.M.'s cars and trucks will get even better as new product teams under the Vehicle Line Executives exploit changes made over more than a decade of corporate evolution. At least, that's what they seemed to be saying.
"The teams that will initiate new programs over the next couple of years will be able to execute those programs within the capability of the process as it exists at that time," explained Arvin F. Mueller, vice president and group executive for the company's North American Operations Vehicle Development and Technical Operations Group. "The process people are focused intensely on getting the process improved to improve the performance and the output."
For true believers -- the shareholders and customers who are delighted with G.M.'s recent performance -- that assurance is enough. Because of new efficiencies, G.M. made more money in the first nine months of this year than in any full year in its history. And as its vehicles improve, its market share is recovering.
But there are always some who question. "I wanted somebody to sit down and give me a flow chart," Mr. Phillippi groused.
The vehicle development process at G.M. fascinates analysts because it is the key to the company's turnaround. When G.M. dominated the market, the marketing divisions -- ranging from Cadillac to Pontiac -- created their own cars and trucks and competed with each other, because there was plenty of market share to go around.
Now the company has more than enough competitors. So it is centralizing development, having designers and engineers who used to work only for Chevrolet or Buick, say, produce distinct versions of fundamentally similar vehicles for sale through several divisions, which are shells of their former selves.
G.M. wants to exploit its enormous economies of scale while still taking advantage of its dozens of distinct brands, from the Chevrolet Camaro to the Cadillac Fleetwood.
G. Richard Wagoner Jr., president of G.M.'s North American operations (that's N.A.O.), said today that shareholders and owners are rightly indifferent to the whole subject.
"Does the customer care about this?" he asked. "No. Should they care about it? No." The process -- what he called the "plumbing" -- is management's problem.
The bottom line, he said, was that the changes would help G.M. produce cars and trucks in an average of 38 months starting in 1997, 25 percent faster than it does now.
And, because of the changes, G.M. will focus more on what customers want, finely carving the market into groups with names like "the customer-needs segments of the midsize partition." Thus, new vehicles will be better designed to meet customers' desires, G.M. said, and will fetch higher prices, bolstering earnings.
G.M. declined to quantify the savings expected from the changes. But it said the changes were not likely to cost the jobs of any of its 708,000 employees worldwide, since those whose work becomes unnecessary under the new organization can move into new slots. "We'll redeploy those people to the added capacity of the process," Mr. Mueller said. "That's it, pure and simple."
G.M. develops vehicles in what it calls a four-phase process; it actually has five phases. The process begins with a period known as "bubble up," which is Phase 0, the genesis of a new product.
But the process is evolving. "Will we never change this?" asked Mr. Wagoner. "Absolutely not. We'll modify it as necessary for the rest of our lives."

HEADLINE: Starts Fell For Housing Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The rate at which builders broke ground on homes slowed in September for a second month, the Government said today, while new unemployment claims rose last week. The data underlined the economic expansion's slow pace.
The Commerce Department said starts on new homes and apartments fell one-tenth of 1 percent in September, to an annual rate of 1.39 million units. In August, housing starts fell a revised 2.8 percent. They jumped 10.3 percent in July. 
 Despite the decline last month, analysts said builders were starting projects at a healthy pace as the fall building season began.
"That's a pretty good pace, especially for September," said David Lereah, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
During the third quarter, the average number of housing starts stood at an annual rate of 1.4 million units, seasonally adjusted, 9.4 percent higher than the second-quarter rate of 1.28 million starts.
"We're not looking for much further growth in these numbers, but it's encouraging that we seem to be sliding onto a trend of 1.4 million starts a year," said David Seiders, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders.
Lower mortgage rates have helped rejuvenate the nation's housing markets after a weak first half of the year. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today that rates on 30-year fixed mortgages fell to an average of 7.38 percent this week, the lowest level in 20 months and well below the 9 percent rate at the start of the year.
Separately, the Labor Department said today that new claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 361,000 last week, the highest level in a month, from 356,000 a week earlier. But the four-week moving average of new jobless claims, which smooths out weekly fluctuations in the labor market data, fell last week to 348,750 claims from a revised 350,000 claims in the prior four-week average.
Today's reports fit a pattern of moderate economic growth with mild inflation. Analysts said recent economic data have probably convinced members of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee not to cut interest rates when they next meet, on Nov. 15. Applications for building permits rose 1.5 percent in September, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.39 million. They grew 1 percent in August.
Construction starts on single-family homes fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in September after rising 1.8 percent in August. But starts on apartments rose 2.6 percent, identical to the August gain.
Regionally, total starts fell 4.2 percent in the Northeast, 3.8 percent in the Midwest and 2.2 percent in the South. Only the West reported an increase, of 8.7 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Economic Data Spur Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday in response to weaker-than-expected economic reports, particularly for housing.
The market was given a lift in the afternoon by an interview with a Federal Reserve Governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, who told the Market News Service that he felt "inclined" to ease credit further, although not necessarily right away. "As inflation comes down and we get a resolution of fiscal policy, I'm inclined that way," he said. 
 The 30-year bond was up 10/32, to 107 20/32, to yield 6.30 percent, down from 6.33 percent on Wednesday.
Debt futures trended higher in a narrow range in quiet trading as the December bond contract settled at 117 10/32. It reached a high of 11714/32 , just below Wednesday's session high of 117 17/32.
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research and analysis firm, said the three economic reports yesterday -- on housing starts, new jobless claims and business activity -- were essentially consistent with the current climate of moderate growth and slow inflation. He said that September housing starts reported by the Commerce Department were essentially flat at 1.4 million annual units, consistent with solid economic growth.
Mr. McCarthy said that the housing data indicated that economic conditions in the fourth quarter would be consistent with the Fed's desire for a soft landing. "We still look for another 25 basis points later this year to keep the economy growing in 1996," he said, "but unless rates are lowered, the economy will slow in 1996."
The Labor Department unemployment-claims report for the week ended Oct. 14 showed a rise of 6,000, to 361,000; expectations had been for a drop. "But basically, the four-week moving average is at 350,000, which is still consistent with moderate growth," Mr. McCarthy said. "There was nothing new here."
And in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's survey of regional business activity, the index dipped slightly to 25.5 in September. The prices-paid component in the report surged to 30.0 from 13.6, while the new-orders component fell to 22.9 from 29.1. Analysts said that the strength in the overall index combined with the jump in the prices component would be troublesome for the market but that the decrease in new orders would offset it to some extent.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, noted that in the Philadelphia survey fewer respondents saw a decline in business activity.
"On one hand, the market is looking at whether the Fed will ease at the end of the year at this point, and on the other, it is following the budget battle in Washington," Mr. McCarthy said. "While it may appear as a sideshow, it could be an important one. If there is a real deficit reduction, then the market will rally some more."
However, the market to some extent has already priced in a deficit reduction, some traders said, so there is a potential for disappointment if it does not happen.
In when-issued trading, the two-year notes to be auctioned next week were offered at a price to yield 5.65 percent, down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from Wednesday, while the five-year notes that are also being auctioned next week were offered at a price to yield 5.80 percent, also down 2 basis points.
"The market remains bullish, and in the minds of some investors, the soft landing is here," Mr. McCarthy said. "So in this kind of environment, current interest rates could be considered high, leaving room for the Fed to ease by the end of the year." He cautioned, though, that easing would not necessarily come at next month's policy meeting since the budget situation remained uncertain.

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
Birth and Purification via Lotuses and Water

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF 

 BODY:
Water is a major image in "Nine Songs," a work of epic resonance and contemporary relevance that Lin Hwai-min has choreographed for his Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan, a modern-dance troupe that presented very different works in New York in 1979 and 1985.
Even before the curtain rose on the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night, the audience saw an orchestra pit transformed into a linear lotus pond. This liquid-filled trough, on view through the company's final performance tomorrow night at the academy's opera house (30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene) is the magical realization of Ming Cho Lee, the distinguished American stage designer who was born in Shanghai. In Brooklyn, he has not been able to use real lotus flowers as he did in Taiwan. But there is a silky shimmer to his synthetic lily pads and pink lotus blossoms, closed or open, as they float on real water and rise toward the stage above. 
 The lotus is a symbol of rebirth in Asia, and water is a symbol of purification and nature in "Nine Songs," which wends through the river of life on its own theatrically imaginative terms. From these basic images and a 2,000-year-old poem by Qu Yuang, one of China's great poets, Mr. Lin has choreographed a striking pictorial spectacle. The effect is that of a huge Chinese scroll in which movement fills in the unfurling landscape with a series of economical brushstrokes.
The two-hour piece is both poetic in its meditative beauty and occasionally exasperating in its very richness. There are times when Mr. Lin goes on too long, with little hint of the direction in which he is headed. Yet he at least knows his ultimate destination and reaches it with a satisfying sense of resolution.
What seems like an allegory about the seasons and human existence is turned finally into a protest piece. Yet it is not only that; Mr. Lin, who is also a novelist, has taken his cue from Qu Yang. The poet registered a political critique with the authorities who exiled him, by way of a poem cycle that scorned the gods for their ineffectualness. Mr. Lin refers to these gods of shamanistic times with a similar approach, moving from the universal to the specific.
By the end, the masked deities, demonlike or lyrical, who led the dance, are gone. Instead, the stage is filled with scenes referring to historical massacres of the 20th century. When a taped score by the Ju Percussion Group abstracts a machine-gun sound, the stream of images is powerful and clear. The way Taiwanese were executed under Japanese occupation (1895 to World War II) is recalled by figures marching with baskets on their heads. The fall of dancers to the ground and their striking sculptural groupings under Lin Keh-hua's dramatic lighting refers to the little-known execution of Taiwanese on Feb. 28, 1947, by the island's Chinese Nationalist Government.
No one will mistake the allusion to Tiananmen Square in 1989 in Beijing as dancers cross the stage on bicycles, and the bright headlights of an unseen tank take aim at the audience and victims onstage.
It is then that Mr. Lin ties up all the loose ends. Lee Ching-chun, as the female Shaman in red who greeted the gods in the beginning, returns to pour water mercifully on one of the victims. The rest of the 22-member company places votive candles on the floor. Mr. Lee, who has enlarged a lotus painting by the Taiwanese painter Lin Yu-san on a movable backdrop, creates a winding Milky Way of lights, suggesting candles stretching into infinity.
As a choreographer, Mr. Lin once drew mainly from Martha Graham's idiom, and Ms. Lee, as the Shaman, has all the angular percussive shape of a Graham heroine. But elsewhere Mr. Lin borrows from a mix of Asian dance styles (Balinese included), natural movement and acrobatics from Chinese opera and the martial arts.
This eclecticism, reflected in the music (from Taiwanese tribal songs to Tibetan monks' chants and Indian classical music), works better in the second half than in the first, which has overly schematic encounters among the Shaman, the ensemble and deities.
Mr. Lin hits his stride in Part 2 when Wang Chiang-mei, as a River Goddess, dressed in mourning white, curves her lyrical dance within a serene ensemble. There is a spectacular trio of men who are precise in their supporting and balancing act: Wu l-Fang, as the God of Clouds, walks on "air" by standing on one leg on the back or shoulders of either Sung Chao-chiun or Wang Chih-hao. Li Wen-long's animistic solo as the Mountain Spirit was sensitively danced. Huang Hsu-hui, in business suit, was the time traveler who passed through an eye-filling and thought-provoking spectacle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lee Ching-chun, center, in Cloud Gate's "Nine Songs." (Marilyn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RESHAPING MEDICARE: HIGHLIGHTS;
What's in the House's Medicare Bill

BYLINE: By MONICA BORKOWSKI 

 BODY:

Premiums
 
Would increase the monthly premium from $46.10 to $87.60 in 2002. (Under current law premiums would rise to $60.80 in 2002.)
According to the Congressional Budget Office, monthly premiums would be:
 
1996 -- $53.50
1997 -- $56.90
1998 -- $59.40
1999 -- $63.80
2000 -- $72.10
2001 -- $78.90
2002 -- $87.60
 
There would be higher premiums for single people earning $75,000 or more or couples earning $125,000 or more.
 
Savings
 
$270 billion over seven years, or 14 percent of Medicare spending. $147.5 billion would come from limiting payments to providers; $55 billion would come from increases in premiums; $34.6 billion would be saved by moving beneficiaries into alternative insurance plans; $31.8 billion would come from a "fail-safe" mechanism which would automatically cut payments to doctors, hospitals and other providers if Medicare spending overshoots targets set by law; $1.3 billion would come from other provisions including anti-fraud and abuse.
 
 Spending
 
For the first time, the Government would impose annual limits on the growth of Medicare spending. From 1995 to 2002, average spending for each beneficiary would rise 40 percent, to $6,700 from $4,800. (Under current law, it would grow 67 percent, to $8,000 in 2002.)
 
Deductibles
 
Would stay the same, $100 for Medicare Part B, which pays for doctors services.
 
Choices
 
The elderly could choose coverage under the traditional Medicare fee-for-service program, or under a new MedicarePlus program. Under MedicarePlus they could select from a variety of plans. They could enroll in private health plans, including health maintenance organizations, they could enroll in a new type of plan sponsored by groups of doctors or hospitals, or they could choose a plan that combines a high-deductible health insurance policy with a medical savings account. All plans would provide at least the same benefits that are available under Medicare.

 Medical Savings Accounts
 
 Under MedicarePlus, people could combine a high-deductible/low premium health insurance policy with a medical savings account. The Federal Government would contribute a standard per-person Medicare and any excess over the policy premium would be deposited in the individual's medical savings account. The account holder could use the funds in the account to pay for medical expenses. Withdrawals for medical expenses would be non-taxable; withdrawals for personal use would be taxable.

 Malpractice
 
 Limits non-economic damages, like awards for pain and suffering, in medical liability cases to $250,000 per case. Limits punitive damages. intended to punish willfully malicious conduct, to $250,000, or three times the amount of economic damages, whichever is greater. Prohibits the award of punitive damages in a case involving a drug or medical device that was approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

 Antitrust
 
 Relaxes laws to make it easier for doctors and hospitals to form health networks serving Medicare beneficiaries. Doctors who collaborate in such arrangements would, in many cases, be allowed to set their prices in consultation with one another, a practice often prohibited as price-fixing under current law.
 MONICA BORKOWSKI

HEADLINE: Turkey Doesn't Make War on Its Citizens;
Dirty Weapons Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "America Arms Turkey's Repression" (editorial, Oct. 17): 
 The United States Government's foreign military sales activities are more egregious than supporting Turkey's repression of the Kurds. Once, the United States Government supplied arms to Iran. When Iran and Iraq went to war, the United States supplied arms to Iraq. One wonders how many were killed during Desert Storm by Iraqi forces armed with American-supplied arms.
The argument that military exports provide domestic employment is spurious; workers displaced by market changes find jobs elsewhere. If you added up the lost jobs of the past 10 years, the unemployment rate would be at least 20 percent if no new jobs had been created by a dynamic economy.
Equally spurious is the argument that if the United States doesn't supply arms, others will. When taxpayers in other democracies tire of subsidizing their governments' arms sales, poor countries will be compelled to buy only the military equipment they can afford.
It is claimed that exports of military equipment help reduce our balance-of-payments deficit. This is true only to the extent that the United States receives payment for these exports. All Americans must bear the burden when the Government "sells" arms abroad, financed by loans and grants. It's a dirty business, and our Government should get out of it.
 
ALBERT H. HAMILTON
Washington, Oct. 17, 1995

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Gains Against the Franc, Sending the Dollar Down a Bit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most European currencies yesterday as the German mark resumed its ascent against the battered French franc.
"The mark is strong against the franc, and that's pulling the dollar down across the board," said Karl Halligan, currency trader at CIC Bank in New York. 
 The dollar was also hurt after the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, apparently referring to the mark, said that while a strong currency carried disadvantages, "in the end, a country is better off."
In New York late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 100.76 yen from 100.41 yen. But the dollar fell to 1.4232 marks from 1.4147 marks and to 1.1485 Swiss francs from 1.1562 Swiss francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5685 from $1.5731.
Despite the declines against a number of currencies, traders noted that the dollar remained within its recent trading range.
The mark gained yesterday as the French franc continued to be weakened by concerns over the nation's budget deficit and political uncertainty, particularly centering on Prime Minster Alan Juppe. His approval rating among voters has slumped even as the country struggles to cope with a wave of bombings.
France's unemployment rate, at 11.4 percent in August, is among Europe's highest, and its budget deficit is expected to reach 5 percent of gross domestic product this year.
The mark was last quoted at 3.5169 francs, up from 3.5045 francs in New York on Thursday.
Traders also were buying marks for yen, which hurt the dollar against the mark and helped it against the yen. Some mark-yen trading is executed via the dollar, meaning that traders were buying dollars for yen and selling those dollars for marks.
The yen suffers from Japan's anemic economy, which grew only six-tenths of 1 percent in the year ended June 30, and its troubled banking industry, which faces at least $400 billion in bad loans.
"Financial institutions, economic growth -- everything is weighing on the yen," said Olev Trygg, treasurer in charge of currency trading at Swedbank in New York.
The dollar will not be able to sustain significant gains until the United States makes progress in cutting the budget deficit, traders said.
"I will remain bearish on the dollar until we take care of our deficit and debt ceiling," said Ian Spence, currency trader at Rabobank Nederland in New York. 

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1995, Monday

HEADLINE: Congressional Bills Threaten Aid for Immigrant Students

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
A little-noted provision in the Senate welfare bill could deny Federal education aid to tens of thousands of legal immigrants, more than half of whom are college students in New York and California.
The House version, though less strict, could also limit Federal grants and loans to foreign-born college students who live in this country legally. 
 Advocates for higher education said the changes would strip the rungs from a ladder that has allowed generations of immigrants to climb out of poverty.
At the City University of New York, officials say 40,000 legal immigrants, of a total 210,000 students, receive the most commonly used Federal college tuition grants that would be affected by the proposed changes. The officials said that most of the students would become ineligible under the rules being considered in the Senate.
At Rutgers University in New Jersey, nearly 3,000 immigrants could be affected.
"This is just a small provision in a big bill that will have a huge impact," said Terry W. Hartle, vice president of the American Council on Education, which represents 2,000 public and private colleges.
"Legal immigrants are individuals who have played by the rules and who we have decided to let into the country," he added. "The impact of this proposal would be to say to these individuals: 'We'll let you in, but if you want to get ahead, as other Americans do, you are on your own.' "
Though President Clinton has hinted that he could sign awelfare bill that is similar to the Senate's, a senior Administration official said this week that the Administration had deep concerns about the proposed changes to educational aid to immigrants. The bills already include many reductions on Federal assistance to legal immigrants. The President's concern was mentioned in a letter outlining his views on the welfare bills, sent on Wednesday to the leadership of each House and signed by Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Office of Management and Budget.
"Eliminating student aid and loans is really counterproductive for our plan basically to assimilate immigrants into the American economic machine," said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Neither the Senate nor House version would actually issue a blanket prohibition on educational assistance to legal immigrants. Rather, the provision would require that immigrants report the income of their sponsors when applying for Federal assistance programs, including education aid -- even though sponsors are not required by law or practice to provide for the cost of education.
Education officials said that could disqualify many legal immigrants who now receive financial aid, particularly the most common form of Federal assistance -- the Pell grant for needy undergraduates. The reason is rooted in the vague legal responsibility of the sponsor. Most immigrants who cannot demonstrate their financial independence, or who do not have a job that pays adequately when they enter the country, must have a sponsor.
Sponsors are usually family members, though the relation is often distant. The sponsors must prove that they have enough money to prevent an immigrant from becoming a "public charge." That means they may have enough money to prevent an immigrant from receiving Federal aid -- even though in many cases they may not be willing or financially able to spend it on the immigrant's education.
Adele Kurbanali, 21, who immigrated from Trinidad a year ago with her family, said the rules under consideration could hit her hard. A freshman who is studying nutrition at New York University, Ms. Kurbanali qualified for a Pell grant (named for Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who sponsored the legislation) even though both her parents work six days a week. Her father's brother sponsored the family, but "if he knew he had to pay money for my education, he would not have sponsored my family," she said.
"We are just trying to build ourselves up," she continued. "America is built on immigrants. I don't think they should be taking our aid away just because we're immigrants."
Dick Day, the chief counsel to the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, which drafted the Senate provision said the rationale for the provision is based on the idea that education aid and welfare are not fundamentally different. He noted that Congress is also seeking to bolster the legal responsibility of sponsors to immigrants.
"It is like job training or other welfare," he said. "The deal was not to bring people here that are going to have to then be trained at the public expense."
But educators contend there is a crucial distinction: that welfare simply supports a person whereas education aid -- historically open to citizens and immigrants alike -- helps spring a person into prosperity. The effect on immigrants who lost aid, educators say, would be the same as on any other student: taking longer to graduate, transferring to a less expensive school, or simply dropping out.
"There really has been the thought out there that those who can pay more should, and we'll have ways the poor, talented students can go to school," said W. Ann Reynolds, the CUNY chancellor. She has been lobbying Congress hard to scuttle the provision.
"Now we are taking away the support for that poor talented student," she continued. "We are simply knocking that poor, talented, energetic student out of college with this."
In the Senate version, when a legal immigrant applies for financial assistance, the sponsor's income would count for five years from the date the student entered the country. For new immigrants, that income would be counted until they worked and paid taxes for a minimum of 10 years -- even if the immigrant became a naturalized United States citizen in the meantime. Critics said that would create two classes of American citizens.
In the House version, immigrants who are already in the country would not be affected. For new immigrants, sponsors would have to report their income indefinitely -- or until the immigrant they are sponsoring becomes a naturalized citizen.
In either version, Congressional aides said, the income reporting would not apply to immigrants who do not have sponsors. But those people generally have significant jobs or resources of their own. So they might not qualify for Federal assistance in the first place.
A draft report from the General Accounting Office issued this month states that 390,000 legal immigrants nationwide received Pell grants in 1992-1993, representing about 10 percent of all students who received the grants. The maximum grant is $2,400 a year. But the report showed that 82 percent of those immigrants lived in seven states, led by California with 31 percent and New York with 25 percent. The other top states were Florida, Texas, New Jersey, Illinois and Massachusetts.
In New York, there were 96,273 immigrants who received Pell grants, or 26.5 percent of the 363,698 students who received them.
In California, 120,488 legal immigrants received the grants, or 32.6 percent of the 369,078 total students who received the grants, the report said.
At the University of California in Los Angeles, 4,300 immigrants receive Pell grants, and most probably would not qualify under the proposed rules, according to Ronald W. Johnson, the school's director of financial aid.
"It is totally unfair," he said.
In Florida, 30,199 legal immigrants received Pell grants, or nearly 16 percent of the total who receive them. The office of Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat who has been outspokenly against the provisions, said that 8,000 of the 20,000 legal immigrants at Miami Dade Community College stood to lose their Federal financial aid.
"It's so much in the America's national interest to have legal immigrants go to college, to go to vocational school, to be better equipped to contribute," Mr. Graham said in an interview on Thursday. "To cut them off like this is self-defeating."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC HOSPITALS FACING DEEP CUTS IN MEDICARE BILL

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
The sweeping cuts in Medicare making their way through Congress would force major teaching and public hospitals around the nation to retrench drastically or face closure, and to slash doctor-training programs that are the backbone of medical care in many poor neighborhoods, according to health care experts.
The bitter debates over Medicare have focused on its role as the nation's health care system for the elderly. But the $178 billion program is also the largest subsidizer of medical training in the country, and helps hospitals serving poor and uninsured patients. 
 Nowhere would the effects be felt more than in New York City, where 15 percent of the nation's medical students train and where more medical care is provided to the poor than anywhere else.
If the Medicare overhaul becomes law, Bronx-Lebanon Hospital, in the South Bronx, for example, will lose financing for most of the salaries for about 63 percent of its medical residents, who provide the bulk of its patient care. New York City's 11 public hospitals will lose nearly $800 million over seven years if the bill becomes law.
In North Carolina, officials of Duke University, which has one of the nation's premier teaching hospitals, say they would lose 30 percent of the money they depend on for training doctors.
"What people need to understand is that these cuts reach beyond the Medicare population," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade organization. "There is no such thing in a hospital as a Medicare nurse or a Medicaid nurse or a Blue Cross/Blue Shield nurse. Hospitals combine different streams of revenue to pay for everything they do, and so cuts in Medicare payments affect everyone who comes through their doors."
Republicans say the entire Medicare program must sustain cuts to survive. And many experts say there is already less of a need for big hospitals as insurance companies and health maintenance organizations push for shorter hospital stays and more preventive care.
In New York, for instance, city officials contend that there are too many hospitals, many just blocks from each other. The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to close or shrink some of the hospitals in the city's vast public health care system.
Some experts also say that current programs overemphasize specialty training, when primary care is the way of the future.
Though Medicare was created to provide care for the elderly, it also provides hospitals with about $150,000 each year for every new doctor they train. In addition, the program pays premiums to hospitals serving disproportionately large numbers of the poor and uninsured.
Under the House legislation, hospitals would lose $8.6 billion in subsidies for medical education and $7.1 billion for treating the indigent.
Republicans offer several reasons for the proposed changes in Medicare payments for the training of doctors. In a report on the Medicare bill this week, Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee said Medicare was paying more than its share of hospital costs for such training.
House Republicans said it was necessary to cut back payments for foreign medical graduates, which in New York City hospitals make up half of the medical residents, as part of a comprehensive effort to control Medicare costs. Moreover, they said, United States citizens should have priority over foreign medical graduates in the allocation of Medicare money.
Hospitals throughout the country are scrambling to patch the holes these provisions would bore in their budgets. "The margins are vanishing," said Dr. Ralph Snyderman, dean of the medical school at Duke.
If there is less money to hire residents, he said, full-time faculty members will have to spend more time treating patients and less time doing clinical research and training new doctors. The ability of the hospital to provide a wide range of charity care will be jeopardized, he said.
"The real danger is that the infrastructure of the nation's academic health system will fall apart," Dr. Snyderman said. "People have to remember that the cost of medicine has to include the cost of education. These cuts will have a chilling effect on that."
These combined cuts would hit hardest in New York City, a nexus of many of the nation's most prominent teaching hospitals and many of its poorest residents.
With more than two million uninsured people in New York City, the state ranks second in the nation in so-called disproportionate share payments intended to offset the expense of treating large numbers of poor patients. The House bill cuts those payments by 25 percent.
The state also ranks first in Medicare payments for doctor training, which the bill would reduce in three ways.
It would phase in a 27 percent cut in the indirect costs of training doctors, such as extra lab tests and the longer hours needed to make up for the slower pace of teaching.
The bill would eliminate subsidies for doctors training in subspecialties, a major focus of many of the city's most elite and prestigious teaching hospitals. Hospitals now receive half the cost of teaching these subspecialists, among them cardiologists, gastroenterologists and neurosurgeons. In New York City, this would affect about 1,800 of the roughly 13,000 resident slots.
The bill also seeks a vast reduction in payments for the salaries of foreign medical residents who are not United States citizens, refugees or aliens with permanent residence. About 25 percent of New York's medical residents fall into that category. Many hospitals in the city's poorest and most underserved neighborhoods are staffed largely by such doctors, who provide most of the front-line care at cheaper rates.
To compensate for some of these losses, the bill establishes a Graduate Medical Education and Teaching Hospitals Trust Fund. But the proposal does not specify how much money would be placed in the trust, where the money would come from or exactly how the fund would operate.
The plan also contains a so-called look-back provision, which means that if the Government does not meet its projected savings, it could retroactively reduce its reimbursement rates and assess hospitals.
"Personally, I am counting on a Presidential veto," said Stanley Brezenoff, president of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, which faces slashed payments for about half of its 411 residents and interns.
New York City hospitals, like others across the country, are already struggling to keep up with discounts demanded by managed care companies and are staggering from state cuts in their Medicaid reimbursements. Some local politicians and health officials warned that coming on top of those financial threats, the Medicare cuts would cause an economic and health care crisis in the city.
They warned that with more that $12 billion in Medicare and Medicaid cuts to city institutions anticipated under the legislation over the next seven years, more than 100,000 jobs would be lost, hospitals would close in communities where there are no others, and services would be pared to such minimal levels that patient care would be imperiled.
Close to $80 billion is spent on health care in New York State each year. Medicare covers about $13 billion of those costs, with roughly $7.6 billion paid to hospitals for reimbursement and doctor training, $3.8 billion paid to doctors and $900 million paid to nursing homes and home health care programs.
"What will happen is something between meltdown and chaos," said James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, a philanthropic group. "The danger is there comes a point where patients will not be spared the impact. We're at that point."
At Jamaica Hospital Medical Center in Queens, 38 percent of the residents would no longer qualify for full salary payments from Medicare under the House bill because they are aliens, according to the hospital's president, David P. Rosen. Hospital officials say that without that subsidy, they will not be able to employ these doctors.
But their worries about the Medicare changes do not end there. They fear that more prestigious hospitals that have also lost financing for some of their residents would lure away young doctors at Jamaica still subsidized by the Government.
"The most vulnerable safety net hospitals will be even more at risk," Mr. Rosen said.
Health officials said that 20 years of rate regulations that do not exist in many other states have left New York City's hospitals operating on the brink of insolvency.
"We may be forced to make changes without adequately thinking through the impact on communities," said Robert Gumbs, executive director of the Health Systems Agency of New York City, a not-for-profit group that tracks health planning information. "It's disastrous."

HEADLINE: U.S., One of the Founders, Is Now Biggest U.N. Debtor

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The United States, which presided over the creation of the United Nations 50 years ago, is joining the big anniversary celebration next week as its most notorious deadbeat.
The United Nations reported that, as of this month, Washington owed about $1.4 billion for regular expenses and peacekeeping. This week the United States sent the United Nations $151 million, reducing its indebtedness to $1.25 billion. 
 A United States official denied that the payment, the first toward this year's regular budget, was timed to deflect criticism of President Clinton at the celebration, but added, "We're pleased that it comes on the eve of President Clinton's visit."
The United States is not the only delinquent, but it remains by far the worst, at the cost of its credibility in pressing the United Nations to reform.
"We are growing tired of U.N.-bashing," the Canadian Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, said in Toronto last month, "and it is especially irritating when it comes from those who are not paying their bills."
Article 19 of the United Nations Charter states that a member state will forfeit its vote if "its arrears equals or exceeds what it owes in contributions for the preceding two years."
At the present rate, the United States could reach that level of indebtedness in 1997, though United Nations officials admit privately that the penalty would be hard to enforce against the organization's most powerful member.
The failure of the United States to pay its assessed share has exacerbated the dire financial straits in which the United Nations finds itself. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said the regular budget ran out of cash in August, and that $125 million had to be borrowed from peacekeeping operations by deferring payments owed to troop contributors.
"If the United States paid properly 30 days after the assessments were rendered, we would not be in the state we are today," said Joseph E. Connor, the Under Secretary General for Administration and Management.
A United Nations official who has watched irritation mount over the United States's delinquency said, "clearly, the rest of the membership is fed up."
One chief delegate, Robert Fowler of Canada, recently complained, "We cannot accept that member states, some among the richest countries in the world, evade their financial obligations to this institution."
Unlike the United States Government, the United Nations cannot borrow money or finance its deficit by issuing bonds or other promissory notes.
"We have no capital, we have no reserves," Mr. Connor said. "We are totally dependent on the assessment, totally dependent that members will assess themselves properly."
Tardiness by member nations is hardly new. "Most of the countries in this organization do not pay up on time," said a diplomat from one that does, "but most of them do not aspire to a leadership role."
Of the 15 largest contributors, only Ukraine also owes money to this year's regular budget, about $16 million respectively. Russia, whose economy collapsed after the Soviet Union disintegrated, just paid $20 million to settle its regular assessment, and $61 million toward peacekeeping costs.
When the United Nations was created in 1945, the United States assumed nearly 40 percent of the new organization's expenses, based upon an assessment of countries according to their share of world income. As more nations joined, the American share declined to its current 25 percent of the regular budget. Japan and Germany assumed nearly 14 percent and 9 percent respectively as the next largest contributors. By contrast, China pays only .72 percent.
American indebtedness has burgeoned for several reasons. The United Nations fiscal year coincides with the calendar year, with payments from members due by Jan. 31. But the United States, like many other countries, paid its assessment in fairly regular installments, at least until the 1980's.
This changed with the Reagan Administration, which deprived the United Nations of nine months of payments in 1982 by pushing them into Washington's next fiscal year. American funding has since become so erratic that the director of the Financial Management Office at the United Nations, Susan Mills said, "We don't know what, if anything, we're going to get and when we're going to get it."
Disagreement over the amount owed extends to the United States' share of peacekeeping costs, which the United Nations puts at 31.2 percent. This includes a surcharge apportioned among the five permanent members of the Security Council to compensate for breaks given developing countries. The United States calculated that its peacekeeping share should be just under 30.4 percent. Then Congress cut this back to the 25 percent level used for the regular budget, starting this month.
Congress's repudiation of the surcharge caused sparks on Wednesday in the General Assembly's budget committee. During a discussion of peacekeeping costs for Haiti, the United States delegate said his country would pay only 25 percent. This set off "the diplomatic equivalent of a street brawl," as one observer described it, as other irate delegates demanded a legal ruling, which went against the United States.
The Clinton Administration wants to make fuller payment of its debt contingent upon reform of the United Nations bureaucracy. Today, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States representative, told other delegates, "Do not let your understandable frustration over the $1 billion my Government now owes the U.N. cloud your judgment as we pursue our common goal: ensuring that the U.N. delivers programs for people, not jobs for bureaucrats."
Now prospects for even that have been reduced by a Republican-led Congress that regards the United Nations with suspicion. When the Clinton Administration asked for $445 million to pay for peacekeeping, the House and Senate committees appropriated only $425 million and $225 million respectively. The final amount is being thrashed out in conference committee.
Ms. Albright asked other delegations to bear in mind "that even though our payments are often late, we have contributed $1 billion over the last year."
She led the budget committee through the Administration's difficulties in coaxing funds from Congress to pay the United Nations. "And we must do so at a time when public spending for all purposes -- foreign and domestic -- is under extreme pressure," she said.

HEADLINE: Both Sides of the Aisle Sense Capital's Unrest

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Many Democrats in Congress are still seething over President Clinton's statement in Houston on Tuesday night that he had raised taxes "too much" in 1993.
At a private meeting of Democratic senators today to plan for next week, one after another spoke out in anger. Among the most upset were Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Dale Bumpers of Arkansas and Jim Exon of Nebraska, according to a Senator who was there. Finally, the Senator said, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, had to cut off the disparaging talk about the President so the senators could get down to business. 
 One Democratic Senator, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, was so irate when he heard about the President's remarks in Houston that he sat down and scribbled out a scathing speech for delivery on the Senate floor in which he accused Mr. Clinton of running for re-election "on a platform of apology" and declared that the President had no "clear vision of where he believes America could and should be going."
By the time he got to the Senate chamber, Mr. Kerrey had cooled off a bit, he said today, and decided not to make such a harsh speech. But his anger reflected a pervasive view among Democrats in Congress that they are being undercut by the President.
After weeks of agonizing, Senator Kerrey cast the decisive vote in 1993 that led to a tie vote in the Senate on the President's budget, which deferred a promised tax cut in favor of reducing the budget deficit. Vice President Al Gore broke the tie, and the law was enacted.
At a news conference on Thursday, the President went out of his way to backtrack from the comment he had made at a political dinner in Houston about raising taxes too much. Mr. Clinton said that he was extremely tired when he gave the dinner speech and that in fact he was proud of his budget and believed it was responsible for the strength of the country's economy today.
But that was not enough to satisfy many Democrats in Congress who have been complaining for months about how the President seemed to be divorcing himself from them. Many were particularly angry earlier this year when Mr. Clinton proposed his own tax cuts and Medicare savings, stealing from the lawmakers, they felt, the best issues they had on which to counter the Republican offensive.
For them, the Houston speech was the last straw. "You can't imagine how seething our people are," Senator Moynihan said in an interview. "You know, we lost the Senate for good, and we did the right thing, we think. The Democratic Party may go the way of the Whigs because we did the right thing."
A congressman who had dinner this week with Thomas S. Foley, the former Democratic Speaker of the House, said that Mr. Foley was close to tears when he talked about Mr. Clinton's remarks in Houston. Mr. Foley led the battle for the Clinton budget two years ago. He was defeated last year in his Washington state race for re-election, as were many others who voted with the President in 1993. Mr. Foley could not be reached this evening at his law office or his home.
Republicans are making the most of this. The Republican National Committee announced today that the party was distributing a 15-second television commercial showing the President saying in Houston, "You think I raised your taxes too much. It might surprise you to know that I think I raised them too much, too."
Then, an announcer says, "Republicans agree. That's why we intend to keep our word and give middle-class families a real tax cut."
In the speech he never delivered, Senator Kerrey, who ran against Mr. Clinton in the early Democratic primaries in 1992 and is now chairman of the Democrats' Senate campaign committee, wrote:
"The President of the United States is not going to be returned to office on a platform of apology. He is not going to be returned to office on a platform of blame, and he certainly is not going to be returned to office by doing both at the same time. He will be returned to office only by defending proudly where he has taken the country for the past three years and laying out a vision for where he wants to go for the next four.
"What troubles me is that after three years as President, he doesn't appear to know where he wants to lead America. He is developing some interesting theories about where we have been and where we are, but he doesn't talk consistently about where we should be going. He has a handful of programs for which he is prepared to fight, like national service and Head Start, but even they don't seem to be connected to a clear vision of where he believes America could and should be going.
"He is very clear about where he wants to go -- back to the White House for four more years. But as to the country? Well, that is much less clear."
Mr. Kerrey showed the speech to Senator Moynihan, who gave it to The New York Times. A spokesman for Mr. Kerrey said that the Senator had no objection to the publication of an article about his undelivered speech.
This morning, Mr. Kerrey gave a much tamer speech on the Senate floor in which he said he had been "furious" about the President's statement in Houston and remarked that he had written "a very harsh speech" about it. But the Senator added, "I've calmed down since then."
In today's speech he accused Mr. Clinton of a "triangulation strategy," a term politicians are using to refer to the White House's apparent strategy of creating distance between the President and both Republicans and Democrats in Congress.
The tactic, Mr. Kerrey declared, is "strangulating" the relationship between Democratic lawmakers and the President.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Oil Monopoly Pumps Faster These Days

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20

 BODY:
For years, Mexican Governments have seen Petroleos Mexicanos S.A. as a cash cow, taxing the state-owned oil monopoly so onerously, and at times plundering it so voraciously, that little of its revenue was left to drill new oil wells or maintain the old ones.
As a result, production has stagnated for more than a decade. But earlier this year, President Ernesto Zedillo switched course, approving a request by executives of Pemex, as the state monopoly is known, to increase investment in oil exploration and production. 
 Six months later, the increased investment is resulting in the first significant increases in Mexican production of crude oil and natural gas since the early 1980's. Government and company officials estimate that Pemex will produce more crude oil this year than in any year since 1982, and gas production will reach its highest level since Pemex's founding in 1938.
Pemex is prospering, and its prosperity is no small matter to the United States. The Clinton Administration responded to the peso crisis early this year by arranging $20 billion in loans to Mexico that are secured with oil revenue as collateral. As a result, the better Pemex performs, the more securely the American loans are backed.
Pemex's rising petroleum output could allow Mexico to overtake Venezuela as Latin America's leading oil-producing nation, at least for a short time, making Mexico the sixth-largest producer in the world, after Saudi Arabia, the United States, Russia, Iran and China, some oil-industry experts said. Mexico does not belong to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and its growing crude oil output is part of a worldwide pattern of production increases by nonmembers that is dampening OPEC's efforts to increase oil prices.
Mexico's energy minister, Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza, said recently that by increasing production, Mexico hoped to make petroleum, figuratively and literally, the fuel to ignite its stalled economy. But the additional export earnings next year are likely to amount to about $1 billion if price and production trends continue, an amount that would not have a powerful influence on Mexico's $375 billion economy, industry experts said.
The surge in output has been especially strong in natural gas, and industry analysts are viewing it as a sign of a heightened Mexican commitment to the natural gas industry.
"This is a welcome sign because it will lend credibility to encourage foreign investment in Mexico's electric power industry and in natural gas pipelines," said George Baker, a consultant based in Oakland, Calif. who studies Mexico's petroleum industry.
The latest increases are a bit of a surprise, since Pemex's production has varied little for more than a decade.
"Oil production has been quite stable," Jorge E. Navarrete, the deputy energy minister, said in an interview. "This is the first important increase for both crude oil and for natural gas in more than a decade."
After Mexico discovered huge petroleum reserves during the 1970's, crude production rose steadily, peaking in 1982, when Pemex pumped an average of 2.75 million barrels a day. But the Government heavily taxes Pemex's revenue and tightly controls its budget, and after plummeting prices of crude oil devastated Mexico's economy, President Miguel de la Madrid in 1983 raised taxes even further as part of a Government-wide austerity program.
By 1993, taxes amounted to fully 94 percent of Pemex's net income, said William L. Durbin, a director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. The lack of investment has resulted in more than a decade of stagnation in which Pemex's annual average daily production has fluctuated in a range of about 2.4 million to 2.6 million barrels.
Earlier this year, however, the oil monopoly's new director, Adrian Lajous, persuaded President Zedillo to increase the investment budget by more than 20 percent for the crude oil division, Pemex Exploration and Production, officials said. The injection of new funds has allowed engineers to pursue more advanced crude oil-recovery techniques, including horizontal drilling, on rigs in the Gulf of Campeche, said Rafael G. Quijano, a former Pemex executive who is now a director at the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a Washington consulting firm.
The new techniques did not increase production in the first eight months of this year. But in recent weeks, production from two offshore fields in the Gulf of Campeche surged by a total of about 150,000 barrels a day, Mr. Quijano said.
As a result of these and other rises in output elsewhere, Pemex's daily crude oil production will rise to 2.85 million barrels by December, Mr. Navarrete said.
Over the years, Mexico has exported about half its oil, and Mr. Navarrete said that was unlikely to change much.
The jump in crude oil production amounts to 6 percent, measured from December to December. Mr. Navarrete said it was unlikely that production would rise by as much as 6 percent for a year or more.
Natural gas production will, however, continue to rise more rapidly, by 15 percent or more, he said. That is not only because large quantities of gas are captured in the process of pumping crude oil, but also because Pemex has had spectacular surges in output from gas fields in the Burgos basin, along the Texas border in northeastern Mexico, as well as other increases in Tabasco state in the south, officials said.
Pemex is investing heavily in increased gas production because environmental laws will require that the country's electric-power and industrial plants meet significantly tougher air-emission standards. As a result, the state-owned power utility is converting many of its electricity-generating plants to natural gas from fuel oil, which in Mexico is highly sulfurous.
About half of the fuel burned in Mexican factories and generating plants in 1994 was high-sulfur oil, and only 32 percent was natural gas. By 2005, the Government hopes to reduce the fuel-oil proportion to 19 percent and increase the use of natural gas to 32 percent, according to energy ministry documents.

HEADLINE: On the Road, Clinton Hits Driving Pace He Prefers

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Bill Clinton has always been a man in a hurry and, 13 months before the next election, he is once again running as fast as he can.
On Monday night, he went from Dallas to San Antonio by way of Los Angeles. Today, he noodled on the future at a daylong economic conference at Ohio State University. By Saturday, he will have been in 10 cities in 7 days for an almost uninterrupted string of fund-raising events and political appearances. 
 Out on the open road, buoyed by friendly invited crowds and unbowed by lack of sleep, Mr. Clinton's feverish pace is a reminder that as 1996 approaches, this President remains what he was in 1992: a relentless, resourceful campaigner.
Take the first 72 hours of the week: a speech on foreign affairs on Sunday in Connecticut, followed by an address on race relations in Austin, Tex., on Monday morning, a noontime fund raiser in Dallas and a celebrity-studded antidrug concert in Hollywood on Monday night, then a pep rally in San Antonio and another fund raiser in Houston on Tuesday night.
Mr. Clinton's ability to run in overdrive has often proved less effective in the Oval Office than it did on the way there. Back in Washington, the Republicans control Congress, where they are busy passing bills to dismantle 30 years of Democratic policies and blocking many of Mr. Clinton's policy goals.
The President also proved this week -- with his offhand statement at the Houston dinner, quickly retracted, that he raised taxes too much in 1993 -- that as expounder-in-chief, he is capable of stubbing his own toe, especially when he is tired.
But even Republicans concede that Mr. Clinton's persistence has been paying off lately. He has already raised more than $20 million for his 1996 re-election campaign, a record for a sitting President this early in the cycle, and has scared off any sign of a Democratic challenger. The Republican field remains splintered and spluttering, and the candidate many Democrats most feared, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, has dropped out.
Mr. Clinton's sharper stance in Bosnia, adopted after months of hand-wringing in part because he realized that the Balkan war could become an electoral liability, helped produce a cease-fire and the prospect of peace talks. That development so encouraged the President that he has taken to reciting a whole new stump speech on foreign policy, a topic that once seemed to bore or bedevil him.
And he has rediscovered the power of the bully pulpit at home, putting the Republicans on the defensive with his relentless attacks on their plans to cut growth in Medicare and Medicaid spending, vowing new curbs on teen-age smoking and speaking out on sensitive issues like domestic violence and the lingering racism of blacks and whites in the aftermath of the O. J. Simpson verdict and the Million Man March on Monday in Washington. His poll ratings are hovering near 50 percent, about the highest of his presidency.
"There will be problems in this old world as long as people like you and me inhabit the planet because we're not perfect," Mr. Clinton told campaign contributors at the Dallas luncheon on Monday, referring to the nation's problems in language that could equally apply to his own. "But the issue is, are we gaining on it, are we getting closer every day to living by the values we believe in, to lifting up the potential of every person, to giving everybody the chance to be the kind of person that they ought to be?"
Still, the obstacles remain daunting. Whatever Mr. Clinton's approval ratings, his shaky standing in states like Florida or here in the Rust Belt make it extremely difficult for him to piece together an Electoral College majority in a two-way race. While the consensus view is that a third-party candidacy would help the President by splitting the anti-Clinton vote, Gen. Colin L. Powell might have the opposite effect, drawing some blacks and white liberal supporters the President must retain.
On Thursday, the House passed cuts in the growth of Medicare spending despite Mr. Clinton's vociferous objections. And the Republicans could yet prevail on their priorities for cutting the budget, forcing Mr. Clinton to look weak, by compromising on policies he does not support, or ineffective, by allowing Government gridlock to persist even though he took office vowing to end it.
Finally, the sheer pace of travel and late nights that Mr. Clinton loves to keep could lead him into sloppy mistakes and missteps graver than his oratorical flip-flop on taxes.
Aides said the President slept only a bit more than three hours on Sunday night because he was working on his speech on race relations. By Tuesday, deep pouchy blue bags had puffed out under his eyes -- even more than usual. His restoratives of choice are decaffeinated coffee and caffeine-free Diet Coke, but his real fuel is the roar of a crowd.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged the power of such approbation in his appearance on Tuesday at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio. The President had opposed the closing of Kelly, and McClellan Air Force Base in California, this summer, until the chairman of the Federal base-closing commission stipulated that thousands of jobs here could be transferred to the local private sector.
As Mr. Clinton praised the work of Gen. Henry (Butch) Viccellio Jr., the Air Force official overseeing the privatization efforts, some in the crowd of base workers and residents began to applaud.
"Yes, you could clap for him," Mr. Clinton said. And, perhaps thinking of a more famous military man, he went on, "I know generals don't run for office, but they love to hear the applause."
The President's aides, exhausted from trying to keep up with him, continue to marvel at his pace.
"I've never seen anything like it," said his senior adviser, George Stephanopoulos, who is virtually the only top White House aide who traveled constantly with Mr. Clinton in the last campaign. "He'll begin a day, even with very little sleep, and just get more awake. I need three espressos and a good night's rest."
George Bush's top aides unanimously agree that the former President -- flush with popularity from the Persian Gulf war -- made a fatal error in not gearing up his re-election effort more swiftly in the fall of 1991, as concerns about the faltering economy grew and his approval ratings slipped. Mr. Clinton, a devoted student of campaign tactics, has been determined not to repeat that error, just as his 1992 campaign resolved never to let an attack go unrebutted, as Michael S. Dukakis had in 1988.
Since returning from vacation in early September, Mr. Clinton has traveled hard. He stopped in nine cities in four states in one five-day fund-raising swing last month that took him from Pennsylvania to Florida, Colorado and California, the biggest electoral prize of all. He revisited California again on Monday, for the 21st time since taking office.
Tonight, he heads to a Democratic Party fund raiser in Des Moines and the dedication of a museum of Czech and Slovak heritage in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, on Saturday. Other fund-raising events are scheduled for Detroit, New York and Nashville next month to help meet the goal of $30 million by year's end.
As Mr. Clinton returned to Washington from California on his last jaunt, his press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, asked if he intended to keep such a killing pace throughout the coming campaign.
"No," Mr. Clinton said with a smile, nodding his head yes.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Snouts In the Slops

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
From out here in the boondocks, today's Washington seems bizarre. Did you catch the American Medical Association selling Newt Gingrich its vote on Medicare?
The A.M.A. -- that's the doctors' lobby -- came along quietly after Gingrich promised to go easy on cutting Medicare fees for doctors and grant other financial boons. 
 And so what? Nobody familiar with the A.M.A. expects anything of it but an obsession with money for doctors. But lo, behold, and how about that, sawbones fans! -- the A.M.A. is offended by suggestions that Gingrich bought it. The A.M.A., which over the years has paid gazillions to kill every attempt to rehabilitate the country's troubled health- care system -- the A.M.A. resents the suggestion that its honor is forfeit to filthy lucre.
What do lobbyists take us for out here in the sticks?
Gingrich is redistributing the wealth. It is only natural that everybody with a high-powered lobby -- even doctors, noble offspring of Hippocrates though they be -- should fight for a share of the loot.
The spectacle of these huge struggling lobbies summons up memories of "The Last Train From Madrid," of the last helicopter from the embassy roof in Saigon. When the train is leaving the station, when the helicopter is leaving the roof, it is only human for many people to behave swinishly.
Lobbies exist to behave swinishly on behalf of people too delicate to behave swinishly for themselves. Unlike the A.M.A., most lobbies are too worldly to whine when someone notices their snouts in the trough lapping up the slops.
Little news items tucked away far beyond O. J. Simpson and Bosnia tell of lobbies saving their places at the trough despite tales painting Gingrich as the demon hog-starver of Capitol Hill.
The sugar lobby has escaped a cut in its infamous sugar subsidy. The tobacco lobby still prospers even as the Government spends money to control tobacco-related diseases. The entire farm lobby is apparently untouched despite, or maybe because of, the fact that a high percentage of farm subsidies now go to giant agribusiness corporations.
It is unmanly these days to express dismay for the Republican plan to use life's losers to balance the budget, and heaven save us all from indulging in such bleeding-heart sentimentality.
From out in the sticks though, where all we know is what we read in the papers, it seems nutty that Republicans should be so zealous to put the boot into widows and orphans, the halt and the lame as it were, while excusing doctors, Tobacco World and assorted other farm corporations from putting shoulders to the wheel. Isn't this a patriotic endeavor to save the economy?
Gingrich is not the only man here who seems deep in fantasy. How about Mister President? Bill Clinton. He's a Democrat, whatever that means, besides brain-dead.
He is expected to run for re-election and, if the newspapers are right, which they frequently aren't, he may be the only Democrat who will be elected to anything next year.
Newspapers report Democrats leaving the party en masse. "Like rats from a sinking ship" is the cliche. It may be significant that present-day Washington lends itself to animal metaphor: hogs at the trough, rats fleeing the ship. Animals are the stuff of fables, and historians may look back on this age in Washington as a time of fabled absurdity.
Besides those Democrats who are simply refusing to run for re-election, there are Democrats who hate being Democrats but can't bear the thought of going off the Federal payroll. These Democrats come from the old solid Democratic South which has now become the new solid Republican South. Simple wizardry turns them into instant Republicans with safe, dry berths on an unsinking ship.
Speaking of fantasy, how would you like to see President Clinton run against the Democratic Party next year? Congressional Democrats think that's what he had in mind when, talking to a Houston money crowd, he seemed to blame Democrats for high taxes.
With the party melting away from under him, who knows? He might turn Republican himself. He runs better in the polls than any of the Republican candidates. This would clear the way for Colin Powell to run as a Democrat and return the party to life.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Treasury Bond Prices Fall on Dollar's Slide and Greenspan's Remarks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices came under fire from a number of directions yesterday, as the dollar's value slid in world currency markets and investors reacted with concern to a speech on Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Greenspan's comments at the Economic Club of Chicago caused some investors to worry that interest rates would not be cut anytime soon. As a result, some traders sold holdings when trading opened yesterday to lock in recent gains. 
 The 30-year Treasury bond fell 24/32 , to 10628/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, reached 6.36 percent, up from 6.30 percent on Thursday. The yield was also up 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, for the week.
With little economic news to clear up the policy debate, comments from Fed officials have taken on greater importance, traders say.
On Thursday, a Fed governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, told Market News Service that he felt inclined to ease credit further, and the market promptly rallied. But it reversed direction yesterday, after weighing Mr. Greespan's remarks.
Foreign-exchange weakness and the budget battle in Washington added to concern.
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management, a Washington firm that manages $6 billion in bonds, said the market was driven by two factors this week -- "its response to economic data and in the background its response to the international and domestic political economy."
He said recently released statistics suggested economic strengthening, giving the market a clue as to what it might expect next Friday when third-quarter gross domestic product is first estimated.
The economic figures this week included an unexpectedly large jump of four-tenths of 1 percent in business inventories for August, reported on Monday; analysts were expecting one-tenth of a percent. On Wednesday, the Government said the trade deficit for August shrank more than expected, to $8.8 billion, because of strong export growth. On Thursday, a survey of regional business activity by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve showed little change in October from a fairly strong level a month earlier.
Mr. Carpenter said the yield on the 30-year bond did not fall any lower than the 6.28 percent reached on Tuesday "because money market economists and bond managers saw little chance that the central bank would lower the Federal funds rate" at next month's policy meeting, "especially if that meeting occurred on the heels of what is likely to be a 2.75 percent reported growth rate for the third quarter."
Issues in the domestic and international political economy have also created background turmoil for the market.
Mr. Carpenter said the debate between the Clinton Administration and the Republican-controlled Congress on debt-ceiling legislation "is an obvious source of uncertainty."
"In the international arena," he said, "the indication that the Fed had for some time been engaged in strategizing and fashioning what may eventually amount to a bailout of the Japanese banking system has caused a lot of concern among bond holders." He said these investors "theorize that the bond market would be swamped with additional U.S. Treasury bond supplies released by Japanese banks in exchange for U.S. dollar liquidity provided by the Fed."
Next week, the market focus will be on Friday's figures on real gross domestic product and their implications for monetary policy, Mr. Carpenter said. Traders will also consider two other economic reports. On Wednesday, statistics on existing-home sales are expected to show a decline of 1.5 percent to 2.5 percent for September, Mr. Carpenter said. On Thursday, the report on orders for durable goods is expected to show a drop of 1 percent to 1.5 percent, he added.
Weekly unemployment insurance claims are expected to stay in a range of 355,000 to 360,000, a level "which equates to economic malaise," Mr. Carpenter said.
In when-issued trading, the new two-year note to be auctioned on Tuesday was being offered at a price to yield 5.72 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.87 percent.

HEADLINE: A Noncandidate, Bradley Plans an Issue-Oriented Trip

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Senator Bill Bradley announced today that he planned to travel to California next week to listen to people "and try to figure out if some of my ideas about where people are, are correct."
When the New Jersey Democrat announced in August that he would not run for a fourth term in the Senate, he said he was considering an independent Presidential candidacy. Asked today if his travels were preliminary to a run for the White House, he said, "This is not about a candidacy -- at this time." He continued, "But it is about trying to reconnect the political process to people's lives." 
 Mr. Bradley, interviewed in his office here, said he had three main ideas he wanted to discuss in more than a dozen stops on Monday and Tuesday. He said he wanted a serious dialogue "that gets to the deeper level of the racial issue."
He said, "Unless we can find a way to deal with this issue, we will not be able to move the country forward."
He said Americans had to face "rising economic insecurity that makes any attempt by a politician to reach them suspect." He called corporate America "ruthless," "insensitive" and "short-sighted" as "economic forces take over and disrupt our lives."
But, he said, "these things are not going to be dealt with until we have fundamental campaign reform." He said his approach, which many scoffed at, would require a Constitutional amendment to overcome a Supreme Court decision that allowed candidates to spend as much as they want.
Mr. Bradley proposed allowing individuals to make campaign contributions of about $500 but requiring the donations to be distributed equally among all candidates, regardless of the donor's party, and "that's all the money" that could be spent. That would mean much less money would be available, he said, but if candidates could not buy "30-second spots to attack their opponent's character," the public would not lose anything important. He said candidates would find other ways to make themselves known.
He said only in-state contributions should be allowed in Senate races, and was not sure whether House contributions should be restricted to the specific Congressional district or the state.
He said the main thing wrong with the financing of the Presidential campaign was that it gave short shrift to independents.
The money mess, he said, is not a problem especially "as a corrupting element, although there is some, but it's a distracting force that people are forced to consider" and an enormous drag on politicians' time just to raise it.
Lesser solutions, like tighter controls on existing sources of money, would not work, he said, because "money in politics is like gnats in your kitchen."
"They are either all out or they will find their way in."
He acknowledged that he did not have the same sort of specific proposals to deal with the racial and economic problems he wanted to see on the table for discussion.
But he said that in the context of the O.J. Simpson's acquittal on murder charges and the Million Man March in Washington, thinking about race relations was too heavily focused on immediate issues, not on "how you create a spiritually transformed community in which reconciliation is possible."
Most politicians avoid serious discussions of race, Mr. Bradley contended, for fear of "saying the wrong thing."
As to economic problems, he said there was a serious question whether the latest technological revolution, like previous ones, would end up producing more jobs. He said there were 90 million repetitive jobs in the nation that were at risk, and millions of people "clawing to stay middle class."
A focus on these concerns, he said, was essential "to recommit the political process to people's lives." And before that could happen, he said, people had to discard the Republican idea that "government is the problem."
Only Government, he said, "can balance private power," and insure such essential reforms as making pensions truly portable from one job to another, or requiring employers to maintain health insurance for a year or two on workers they dismiss.
Asked if he might launch a Presidential campaign as a way to get greater attention for his ideas, he demurred. "I think you run for President to win," he said, "not to popularize an idea."
The point of this trip, he said, is "to go out and talk to people and see what's on their minds."
Next week's trip to San Francisco, Los Angeles and the Silicon Valley area near San Jose will include stops at churches, schools, homes and civic organizations. He said his future travel plans extended beyond California but, "they don't include Iowa or New Hampshire," the sites of the first caucus and first Presidential primary.
