HEADLINE: Rich or Poor, More Russian Mothers Go It Alone

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The collapse of the Soviet state has changed everything in Russia -- except the relationship between the sexes. Expectations are low, but divorce rates remain high and the numbers of single mothers, either divorced or never married, keep growing.
Yelena Polyakovskaya, 32, has two small children, by two fathers, and never really expected either man to stay or help her financially. 
 "People tell me I'm so strong, such a heroine," she said of her struggle to hold down a demanding job as a television reporter while raising children.
"I'm not strong. It's our men who are weak. They seem to have no sense of responsibility at all."
In a trend that is as unmistakable to sociologists and social workers as it is distressing, millions of maids, factory workers and university professors alike have grown inured to raising their families without men. Instead they have come to rely on mothers, sisters and aunts in the kind of matriarchal society -- and downward spiral of poverty and limited horizons -- that in the United States has become a hallmark of the poorest urban areas.
Here, however, paternal absence and neglect is a reality shared widely by Russian women, regardless of background, aspirations or income.
"As I understand it, in the United States, single mothers are mostly teen-agers with very low education," said Marina Kiyenya, 35, a professor of Spanish who started a support group here five years ago for single mothers like herself. "Most of our single mothers have a university degree, some are very active in their professions."
She, too, detects something deeply wrong with the way men and women relate in her country. "Seventy years of Soviet rule taught men to be selfish and passive," she said. "The biggest problem I see is the total lack of responsibility of our men."
Even in Communist days, the unhappiness of Russian families was hard to hide. The divorce rate in the 1970's was 46 percent (now it is 51 percent) and alcoholism, though never officially quantified, was blamed.
Communism gave women the right, and necessity, to work as equals, but a notion of male superiority clung despite 70 years of official propaganda.
Women worked at their jobs, then did nearly all the housework and child-raising. Men did not help, and were not expected to help. They were expected to drink, and they did.
Sociologists blamed Soviet life, its regimentation, oppression and lack of individual freedom, for men's alcoholism and apathy to work and family.
Nowadays, many people blame democracy, or rather, the economic free fall many Russians find themselves in, for those same things.
"There is so much economic uncertainty and real fear," Ms. Kiyenya said. "Men feel humiliated that they cannot provide for their families, and they just walk away."
With a bitter laugh, she said her own story was typical. "When I got pregnant," she explained "my boyfriend promised to marry me, then he changed his plans and disappeared."
He lives in Moscow but never sees their 10-year-old daughter and provides no support, she added.
One thorn of Russian society is that while single mothers complain of isolation and social disapproval, men who abandon their families -- or even several families -- do not appear subject to much censure.
"Its a strange thing, but fathers who don't pay child support are not ill favored by public opinion," said Aleksandr Sinelnikov, a researcher at the State Institute of the Family.
"His friends say that it is her own fault for throwing him out. And if a mother goes to the police to try and force him to pay up, well, police officers are men, and they tend to side with the father."
Ms. Polyakovskaya lives with her 6-month-old baby, relying on friends and baby sitters to watch Aleksandr when she is at work.
The father, an unmarried journalist, has never seen his child. Her 6-year-old son, Simeon, is being raised by his grandmother and great-grandmother in Kiev. Ms. Poliakovskaya says she hopes to bring him to Moscow, but cannot even afford train fare to visit him.
She loves her job covering music and ballet, but it is ill paid. In her bare one-room apartment, she sleeps on a tiny, fold-out couch next to the baby's crib. An ironing board serves as a desk. But like many women raising children alone, she said she does not want to marry again.
"My life is difficult," she said, "but God, if I had to come home from work and clean, cook and iron for a husband who keeps telling me I am doing it wrong, it would be even worse."
Russians can be wildly romantic, but few seem to harbor much sentimentality about marriage.
Nina Vasiliyeva, 40, a single mother who is twice divorced, runs a matrimonial agency for Russian women seeking American husbands. Called Russian Romance, the agency matches American men who seek traditional wives with Russian women who want a dependable husband.
There are dozens of such agencies in Russia today, many of which use high-tech tools of the mating game, like computer match-ups, electronic mail, and videocasettes.
"American men are more polite, they don't drink as much, and they accept responsibility for their families," Ms. Vasiliyeva said of her American clients' reputation among her Russian clients, many of whom are single mothers who despair of finding a reliable husband here.
So does Ms. Vasiliyeva. She left her first husband after he became the leader of his local Communist Party organization and he began acting like a tyrant at home. She divorced the father of her son, an unemployed alcoholic, after he went to jail for drug dealing.
In addition to her matrimonial agency, which she runs out of her apartment, she works as an office manager in a French photo agency, and makes $1,300 a month, enough to raise her 5-year-old son and pay her husband's $250 monthly rent -- the price she pays to keep him at bay.
A teacher turned business executive, Ms. Vasiliyeva said says women are adapting better to Russia's new market economy than most men.
"In Soviet times, our men had it easy," she explained. "They went to work, but they didn't have to work hard, they put in two hours and spent the day smoking, drinking and playing chess, then came home and lay on the sofa. Women did everything else. We were already used to working hard. Men are having problems because nobody wants to pay you for doing nothing anymore."
Demographers at the State Institute of the Family who have studied a 1994 microcensus, estimate that 15 to 20 percent of all Russian families are run by a single parent, and that 94 percent of those parents are women, either widowed, divorced or never married.
The numbers of single mothers are not significantly higher than those in Western and Eastern Europe and are far lower than in the United States, where sociologists estimate that 27 percent of mothers are single.
What distinguishes single mothers in Russia is that they come in all ages and evenly span the social spectrum.
Some sociologists, like Mr. Sinelnikov, say single mothers are not much worse off than married ones because so many single mothers (31 percent) live with their mothers or relatives and rely on them for assistance.
At the Center for Gender Studies in Moscow, Olga Zdravomyslova dryly disagreed. "The women we surveyed don't want to live with their mothers -- its just that they have no choice," she said.
Ms. Zdravomyslova worked on a study begun in 1991 comparing single mothers in Russia to those in Eastern and Western Europe, and found that the plight of Russian women was different.
Half the single mothers in countries like Switzerland were living with boyfriends. Only 5 percent in Russia had found a new partner.
"They are not just legally single -- they are absolutely alone," she said.
The study also found that Russian fathers had far less contact with their children than those in any other country. "We found there was almost no relationship at all," she said.
Russian divorce law does not allow for joint custody. Child support payments, while required by law, are difficult to collect, and increasingly, given the nature of Russia's free-market economy, men can better hide their real income from tax collectors and ex-wives.
Ms. Kiyenya, the professor, said it was better to be a single mother than a divorcee.
"I still get a Government stipend, even though it is only $12 a month," she said. "I could never drag that out of an ex-husband."
But many single mothers in Moscow, including Ms. Polyakovskaya, the television reporter, do not have residency permits and cannot apply for welfare. Parliament is drafting a new law aimed at providing deadbeat fathers with more flexible child support payments. But few expect the Government to make a dent in so deeply rooted a social problem.
"We must help ourselves, " Ms. Kiyenya said firmly.
"If our children's fathers don't want to help us, why would the state want to do it?"

HEADLINE: Facing Charges, NATO Head Steps Down

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The NATO Secretary General, Willy Claes, resigned bitterly today, a day after his former Belgian parliamentary colleagues voted to let prosecutors charge him in a bribery scandal over defense contracts signed when he was a Belgian Cabinet minister in the late 1980's.
Angrily insisting that he was "totally innocent," Mr. Claes said in Brussels this afternoon that he was resigning for the good of the 16-nation alliance after eight months of trying to do a difficult job and defend himself at the same time. "Nobody can deny that I no longer have enough credibility to insure the leadership of the alliance," he said. "Is there another word than 'political murder?' " 
 On both sides of the Atlantic, governments agreed that Mr. Claes (pronounced klahss) had done the right thing by leaving. And they began looking for a successor to help guide the alliance through the complexities of taking on a huge peacekeeping mission in Bosnia and taking in new members from Central Europe without reviving the divisions of the cold war.
"On paper, the NATO Secretary General has no real power except to conduct meetings," one diplomat said, "but the reality is that he plays a key part in the decision making and, if he is good, he can influence things enormously."
Francois Heisbourg, a former director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said the Secretary General could "suggest compromises, float ideas, and influence the debate and direction of the alliance."
"This is very important today, because NATO still doesn't have a clue about its reason for being in the wake of the cold war," Mr. Heisbourg said.
Mr. Claes's predecessor was Manfred Worner of Germany, who died of cancer in August 1994.
Mr. Worner pushed for NATO to use air power to bolster United Nations peacekeeping forces in Bosnia. Mr. Claes, with strong support and encouragement from the United States, shepherded the alliance into crucial decisions to lay out a blueprint for future expansion into Eastern Europe and to plan a 50,000-member peacekeeping force in Bosnia to replace the United Nations after a peace settlement is achieved.
His successor, diplomats say, will have the crucial task of helping to define a new security role for the alliance, and by implication for the United States, in what could be a highly unstable 21st-century Europe.
Most of the NATO leaders will be in New York City this weekend for ceremonies marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, but they are not expected to decide on a successor that soon.
No American has held the job since the alliance was formed in 1949, since American generals and admirals have always held its top military posts. Candidates from France and Spain, which are not full members of NATO's military structure, are also unlikely to be considered.
Diplomats say that former Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain could have the job in a minute, but he said today that he was not interested. "It may need some days to make sure they've got the best man or the best woman to do it," said Mr. Hurd, who only recently took a job with National Westminster Bank in London. His successor in the Foreign Office, Malcolm Rifkind, has also been mentioned as a possibility.
Defense Minister Volker Ruhe of Germany ruled himself out, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today, "No German candidate is available."
Former Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers of the Netherlands is in the running, but Mr. Kohl vetoed him last year as head of the European Union's executive Commission because of his less-than-enthusiastic attitude toward German unification, and NATO picks its civilian leaders by consensus.
Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway has been mentioned, but Norway does not belong either to the European Union or to its military arm, the Western European Union, and diplomats from other member countries say that probably rules her out.
Former Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen of Denmark, on the other hand, makes no bones about wanting the job. "The post as Secretary General is so important that I could not say no if there was a chance that I could get it," Mr. Ellemann-Jensen said in a statement.
Unlike members of Denmark's present Government, Mr. Ellemann-Jensen has not been vocally critical of France's resumption of underground nuclear testing in the Pacific, which could make him a compromise candidate acceptable to the French.
Mr. Claes was Belgium's Economic Affairs Minister in 1988 when his Dutch-speaking Socialist Party was accused of taking $1.72 million in kickbacks from the Italian aircraft manufacturer Agusta S.p.A. in exchange for agreeing to a $267-million contract to build 48 helicopters for the Belgian Army. Investigating magistrates from the Belgian High Court are also investigating charges that the French defense company Dassault paid a $2 million bribe to the party for a contract to modernize F-16 and Mirage jet fighters in 1989.
Prosecutors have indicated that they will charge Mr. Claes with corruption, fraud and forgery, because they say, he knew about the bribes but testified that he did not.
The investigations started after a former leader of the French-speaking branch of the Socialist Party was found slain in Liege in 1991. Three ministers from that party have since resigned as the scandal burgeoned, and a former chief of the air force committed suicide last March.
Mr. Claes appeared before the full Belgian Parliament on Thursday to defend himself, but members voted 97 to 52 to lift his parliamentary immunity from prosecution.
Secretary of Defense William J. Perry said today, "I believe that NATO will probably move very quickly and very effectively to restore new leadership." The post will be filled in the interim by Mr. Claes's Italian deputy, Sergio Balanzino.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Willy Claes appeared at a news conference at NATO headquarters in Brussels yesterday where he resigned as Secretary General. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Farewell to a Mill That Shaped the Modern City

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 18

 BODY:
The George Washington Bridge came from here. So did the basic structure of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the Chase Manhattan Building, Madison Square Garden, the Metropolitan Opera House and the Time & Life Building.
All were built from steel made and shaped at the Bethlehem Steel Company's mill here on the banks of the Lehigh River. In fact, the single-piece H-shaped girder -- the building block of skyscrapers -- was first produced here in an early 20th-century financial gamble for technology that was as daring for its time as the latest silicon chip plants are today. 
 "If we go bust, we'll go bust big," Charles M. Schwab, the president of Bethlehem, remarked a few years after the turn of the century as he was raising millions of dollars for the experimental plant.
[On Friday, the last red-hot heavy-duty beam was pounded and rolled into shape. The old heavy-duty beam mill then fell silent.]
In a few weeks, the last blast furnace and related equipment will be shut down and basic steelmaking will cease in this valley for the first time since 1873.
When it does, a way of life that has long been in decline will come to an end. "My father and grandfather worked here," said Mike Martin, a supervisor at the mill. "This place has a history and a soul that the new mills do not."
It is the kind of place where a man with two levers controls a 20,000-horsepower steam engine that drives the steel through rolls weighing six to seven tons to squeeze it into shape. For all the force involved, it is a surprisingly delicate job.
"If he waits until the bar is fed in to start the rolls, he's likely to stall the engine," said Bill Wilde, the senior supervising engineer for the mill and a second-generation steelmaker. "But if he starts it too soon, its likely to be moving too fast and may break the bar."
There will be no more bars. Mr. Wilde will be moving on to a small finishing-steel operation, which will remain to shape smaller beams from steel imported from Steelton, Pa. But for most of the 1,800 workers facing shutdown, their time with Bethlehem is over.
Company officials described the closings -- which were announced nearly a year ago -- as a rational adjustment to an economy that is not building many of the tall office buildings that require the jumbo beams. "Companies today are decentralizing," said Timothy Lewis, the manager of Bethlehem's structural operations. "You don't need Sears Towers anymore."
Prodded, they will concede that the rise of efficient mini-mills, like those operated by the Nucor Corporation and the Chaparral Steel Company, has made it difficult for older companies to compete in a market where price is paramount.
The new mills rely on many fewer workers and a simpler production process than the old companies. They also do not carry the heavy health care and pension expenses that traditional steelmakers do.
"There are many companies capable of supplying this product," Curtis H. Barnette, Bethlehem's chairman, said. "We have to make our investments wisely and we decided to put our investment dollars elsewhere." He said the structural division had been unprofitable.
Until Mr. Schwab came along to take a chance on the turn-of-the-century technology with his investment dollars, H-shaped steel beams were riveted together from plates and angles, limiting their strength and the height of the buildings that could be built.
Henry Grey was an English-born inventor who developed a process for rolling wide-flange beams of uniform thickness in the late 1890's. But he was at first unable to persuade any American steel companies to adopt his technology directly.
After a mill was built in Germany and the products from it became successful, Mr. Schwab decided to get into the business. In 1907, he began building the mill. The first beam was rolled in 1908 and a new generation of skyscrapers was designed by engineers and architects who could simply specify the size of the girders they needed. They were called Bethlehem sections.
Steel companies do not rush to replace equipment that can be repaired and Mr. Grey must have been a good engineer; some of the equipment installed in the mill in 1907 was still operating this week.
The single-piece H-beams -- bigger and broader than the better known I-beam -- were a huge economic success and helped build Bethlehem into the nation's second- largest steel company, after United States Steel. Indeed, the company's symbol includes a representation of a wide-flanged beam.
The irony is not lost on the workers. "This mill built Bethlehem Steel," said Radwan Jarrouj, who prefers to be called Ed. "A lot of us are feeling betrayed as a community."
Unhappy feelings aside, the workers were producing steel flat out in the days before the closing. Word that the mill would be shutting down had produced a last-minute flurry of orders.
"They say there are no orders for big beams, but that's all we have been rolling," said Tim Betz, who operated a huge motorized saw that cut the beams to lengths specified by customers. "And we are going to produce the best products we can up until the last minute."

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
What the Poor Deserve

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL

 BODY:
THE STARK WORD FROM WASHINGTON IS that America's War on Poverty has been totally transformed. It is now a War on the Poor.
If you prefer your news in images, picture a slashed and tattered Safety Net. That was the guarantee of minimal security for the fallen that Ronald Reagan proclaimed forever secure back when he began his assault on the New Deal. 
 Who's to blame? Republican wreckers? Disarmed Democrats? A pandering President? The rich who want to be richer? A callous middle class? The poor themselves? In the view of Prof. Herbert J. Gans, a Columbia sociologist and perceptive critic of American life, almost all the nonpoor must share the blame. Despite the New Deal and what he calls the Great Society's "Skirmish on Poverty," Americans have for much of their history demonized the poor as undeserving shirkers and cheats. And after poring over the literature, journalism and scholarship about poverty, he is especially critical of wordsmiths and image makers for spreading stereotypes that stigmatize the poor and question their morality and values.
Gans deserves notice. Besides being historically informed, he is downright prescient. Little did he know when he sent his new book, "The War Against the Poor," to the printer early this year, that by the time it was published there would be in motion in Congress: 1) a major reduction in Federal appropriations for Medicaid, the medical insurance program for the poor; 2) not only a reduction in Federal assistance to poor families with dependent children but rescission of the welfare program's 60-year-old guarantee that when all else fails, their Government would be there with a modest subsistence payment, and 3) most startling of all, a significant contraction of the earned-income tax credit, a 20-year-old program of modest tax rebates to the working poor, which President Reagan called "the best antipoverty, the best profamily, the best job-creation measure to come out of Congress."
Gans demonstrates that a part of the war against the poor is always a "war of words -- or of pejorative labels -- that stereotype, stigmatize and harass the poor" as undeserving. His most recent example: "the underclass."
The term was adapted 30 years ago from the Swedish underklass and hyphenated to "under-class" by Gunnar Myrdal, Gans reports -- but only to describe an economic grouping, the underprivileged. As the hyphen was lost, he shows, the term acquired a behavioral connotation and was applied to all kinds of people: street criminals, addicts, hustlers, alcoholics, drifters, the homeless, the mentally ill, welfare recipients, school dropouts, delinquents, residents of "the projects," illegal immigrants, teen-age gang members.
Most deplorably, Gans observes, the underclass (with its hint of an underworld) is presumed to have rejected commonly accepted values. Its men are assumed to be lazy or unable to learn the importance of work; if they wanted to work, jobs would exist for them. Its women are imagined to have an unhealthy and immoral taste for early sex and for having babies as adolescents. All are presumed in need of discipline to cure their "dependence" on welfare or their antisocial activity.
"I argue instead," Gans writes, "that the causes of these behaviors, when they do occur, are in fact usually poverty-related effects; that sometimes poor people are driven by the effects of poverty to actions that violate their own morals and values . . . because poor people lack the funds, the economic security and sometimes the social supports and emotional strength to behave in mainstream ways."
Why do Americans scapegoat the poor and treat them more harshly than most advanced societies do? Here Gans can only speculate. Perhaps it helps Americans to postpone politically difficult and costly measures to enlarge the economy and create more work. The millions of jobless poor people now outnumber job vacancies by at least 6 to 1, he notes, and the "downsizing" of staffs and "outplacing" of work continues. And, he wonders: Does the scapegoating actually assist society by keeping people out of the work force?
Gans pleads with scholars to shift their research from mere analysis of the poor to the unseen social forces that "decide" that a part of the population will end up poor -- the economy's preference in workers, the behavior and biases of employers, the conditions that create and maintain inequalities.
He also implores the media to debunk the stereotypes in news and entertainment. He asks that we distinguish between harmful and merely divergent conduct. He asks that we demonstrate how much our poor forebears, too, were stereotyped. He asks that we show "why poor people cannot always act like better-off people and how much their life consists of coping with frequent crises and trying to obtain the security" that mainstream conduct requires.
IS AMERICA'S DISCOURSE REALLY SO distorted, so cruel? I have encountered poignant inquiries into the lives of the poor, though mostly on public television, in The Times and a few other major papers, but hardly enough to counteract the flood of stigmatizing street crime in films and on television. Only rarely do American artists and journalists probe the deeper questions that Gans raises: Is morality really an attribute of class? Are poor muggers less deserving than the manufacturers of defective products who buy their way out of trouble? And if a poor mother who spends her days watching television instead of taking care of her child is undeserving, isn't that equally true of the affluent one who shops all day and drags her child along? Does our economic stability require that some fraction of the population be kept in poverty?
Gans concludes his dense treatise with a program of sorts that he thinks would relieve poverty in America. He would do everything possible to increase consumer demand to create jobs and labor shortages, to encourage labor-intensive industries, public works, community development. And he would increase welfare payments and tax credits that put money into the hands of the poor, until they can qualify for the housing and other subsidies routinely available to better-off Americans.
Would these proposals sound so radical if the poor were considered deserving -- not just of subsistence but of a decent standard of life? If Gans were wrong about our war and our propaganda against the poor, would it be so shocking to come upon this explosive thought from him: "Education is still held out as the best escape route from poverty, but only if the class structure is not reproduced, so that poor children get the best schools, teachers and equivalents for the preschool preparation more affluent parents can give their children."
The best for the poor? Sounds almost un-American.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The Other Brill Building;
Empire State Building's Unnoticed Teeny Cousin

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE Brill Building at 49th Street and Broadway was renowned for several decades as the hub of the popular-music business. But there is another Brill building, one that no one seems to notice.
The three-story building rests on an L-shaped site that wraps around the northwest corner of 41st Street and Madison Avenue, and it was probably just luck that it survived the wave of development of the 1980's. 
 The upper floors have been empty for about 10 years, but now a new tenant is moving in, providing some measure of stability for this teeny cousin to the Empire State Building.
Samuel, Max and Maurice Brill entered the clothing business in the 1880's on Cortlandt Street, and became known for evening clothes and livery for butlers and chauffeurs. In 1935 the firm expanded to a three-story building facing 41st Street and jutting out at midblock between the tall office structures at 300 and 310 Madison, at the corners of 41st and 42d Streets.
The blockfront was owned by the Carbide and Carbon Company, which had its headquarters at 310 Madison Avenue and in about 1929 had wanted to build a new skyscraper on the block, to replace 300 Madison Avenue and also the site that in 1935 became the Brill store.
They chose as architects Shreve, Lamb & Harmon, designers of the Empire State Building. In the 1920's Richmond Shreve and William Lamb had transformed the old Beaux Arts firm of Carrere & Hastings into a completely modern practice, emphasizing machine work and careful planning of the building operations. For their Empire State Building, their new partnership of Shreve, Lamb & Harmon precisely coordinated steel deliveries, construction trades and other elements to build with near-scientific precision.
This emphasis on economics endeared the architects to big business, and they gained as clients the biggest American corporations. On the Carbide and Carbon project, Shreve, Lamb & Harmon proposed a slender skyscraper, rendered with dramatic shadows and lighting, a project that never went ahead. It would have looked similar to their office building at 500 Fifth Avenue, at the northwest corner of 42d Street.
The Depression changed the outlook for new construction and in 1931 Carbide and Carbon put up the three-story structure, which the Brill brothers occupied in 1935. In it, Shreve, Lamb & Harmon reworked several elements from their Empire State design.
THE soaring, vertical stainless steel strips of the Empire State Building were laid over much larger horizontal panels. As with their earlier building, the architects gave the Brill interior lush trimmings of black onyx and chromium.
Instead of the limestone of the principal walls of the Empire State Building -- which was meant to melt softly away into the sky -- Shreve, Lamb & Harmon used black brick on the Brill building, which serves much the same purpose, letting the edges fade away into the great shadows of its neighbors, even as the stainless steel facade seems to float off of its black background.
The critic Lewis Mumford liked it, but it was otherwise ignored until the 1970's when the architects Francoise Bollack and Thomas Killian featured it in a lecture series on "everyday masterpieces."
The Brill store went out of business in the 1940's, but it was Samuel Brill who in 1931 built the office structure at the northwest corner of 49th and Broadway that would become synonymous with the music business.
IN the 1960's and 1970's an office supply store, Goldsmith Brothers, was the ground-floor tenant on Madison Avenue.
It appears that in the early 1980's a company headed by Edward A. Strasser bought the Brill building and the surrounding assemblage, paying about $15 million. (Mr. Strasser says there is litigation on the property and declines to comment.)
By that time the plot had grown to 39,300 square feet, including the Brill building, 300 Madison Avenue, 310 Madison Avenue, and 15 and 19 East 41st Street, a potential site for redevelopment, even with two tall buildings to demolish.
Richard McNealus, an architect familiar with the buildings, said he recalled a giant perspective sketch for a futuristic design for the site but no project ever went ahead.
Perhaps because they are possible candidates for demolition, none of the buildings on the site have received the makeover that many midtown buildings got in the 1980's. They generally look tired.
But even soiled the Brill building still looks fresh and crisp -- if you ignore the huge Duane Reade drugstore that has massacred the ground floor architecturally. Above, the stainless steel has only a few dents, and the black brick looks as if it might be 10 years old rather than 60.
Except for those on the second floor of the 41st Street wing, all the windows have been replaced with modern, metal ones, even simpler than the original casements. In some ways that is an improvement; if anything, the original casement windows were the most backward-looking element of the structure.
The architects Tuller McNealus are now refitting the second and third floors of the store for a photographic office. They are not changing any part of the facade, and, at least for the near term, the Brill building will remain to be either enjoyed or ignored.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Brill building at 41st Street and Madison Avenue in 1935, left, and the facade today. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times); The architects, Shreve, Lamb & Harmon, reworked several elements from their design for the Empire State Building, including giving the interior lush trimmings of black onyx and chromium. (F. S. Lincoln/Historical Collections and Labor Archive, Pennsylvania State University)

HEADLINE: The View From: New London;
Where Students Learn to Succeed

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
MICHAEL AITKEN has accomplished what he thought was impossible. The 20-year-old Middlefield resident is preparing to graduate in the spring from Mitchell College, a two-year institution in New London, and plans to continue his studies toward a four-year degree. He is the only one of eight children in his family to attend college.
"I didn't think college was possible for me," said Mr. Aitken, who has dyslexia, a learning disability that makes reading difficult, and who missed five years of public school while his parents attempted to teach him at home. 
 At Mitchell, Mr. Aitken has found help with his reading problem and teachers willing to show him how to study, organize his notebooks and prepare for classes, he said.
"I learned that it isn't as hard as it looks," Mr. Aitken said. "I have more confidence than I had before."
Many students who enroll at Mitchell, a private college, have little self-esteem and are unaccustomed to success. Some, with academic records that are average or below, were overlooked by high school guidance counselors. Others failed at four-year colleges and are getting a second chance.
Classes are small, 15 to 25 students, and after two years of concentrating on their abilities and learning to be more adept at coping with life's problems, 90 percent of Mitchell's graduates go on to four-year colleges.
Mary Ellen Jukoski, who was appointed Mitchell's president last March, summed up her message to students who fear that they may not be bright enough to handle college: "Your past is your past. Forget the baggage you bring with you. You have special talents and gifts. We'll help you discover what your strengths are and how to use them."
Mitchell is emerging from several difficult years of decreasing enrollment, financial troubles and labor conflict. Ms. Jukoski assumed leadership of the college when enrollment was at its lowest level in 18 years. The number of students had dropped to 392 in September 1994, from a peak of 772 in 1967-68.
Mitchell competes for students with nearby institutions like Three Rivers Community Technical College in Norwich and the Avery Point Campus of the University of Connecticut in Groton. As the number of high school graduates has dropped, that competition has gotten tougher. The recent economic recession also threatened Mitchell's future.
Its fortunes seem to have reversed, however, with the recent announcement that total full-time enrollment this year reached 503, a 28 percent increase over last year. The current freshman class is the largest since 1989. The recovery occurred because Mitchell sent out a clearer message about its mission, said Joseph Silvestri, spokesman for the college. Mitchell began last year recruiting students from a larger geographical area, keeping closer contact with prospective students and making a greater effort to invite them to the campus.
Mitchell faces further competition from four-year schools that are accepting students they might not have admitted in the past, said Mr. Silvestri. Seventy-three percent of the 223 colleges and universities in New England had vacancies last May, said Wendy Lindsay, assistant director of regional services for the New England Board of Higher Education.
Mr. Silvestri said: "Ten or 15 years ago, students came here because they couldn't go to a four-year college. Now, Mitchell and the four-year schools are competing for the same students."
But young people who have not yet experienced achievement are Mitchell's priority. The Center for Student Academic Success, opened last January, assigns four people to each student: a resident director, who lives in the dormitory; a career adviser; an academic counselor, and a staff member who tries to make sure that students head off any problems that may cause them to quit school.
Greg Markovich, assistant to Ms. Jukoski and one of the founders of the center, said he remembered what it was like to take the long route to maturity. During his high school years, Mr. Markovich said, he was a poor student. He ran away from an unhappy home several times to live with friends. Although it was years before he graduated from college, the words of his high school coach and his Army sergeant sustained him.
"My coach was after me all the time, telling me I could do it and pushing me to study, because I couldn't play unless I studied," he said. "My Army sergeant had a lot of faith and confidence in me. He told me: 'You have good test scores. Why don't you start focusing?'
"What we are trying to do at Mitchell is create an environment of challenge and support. That's what we're about, taking students and showing them they have the ability to do it."
Mr. Markovich said his goal was to be able to know in three minutes the status of any 20 students, including their studies, career plans and personal growth. He started the Discovery Program this year, described in a newsletter to parents as a program that "works as an insurance policy for your tuition dollars." Discovery assists students who need extra support in choosing an academic major, planning a career, identifying their skills and making important decisions.
"This program will make sure nobody falls through the cracks," Mr. Markovich said.
Amy Dansicker, a freshman from Baltimore, said she was taking advantage of the the one-on-one tutoring available in all academic areas. "In high school, the teachers didn't give their time to help you," she said. "Here, they're willing to give you their time to make you successful."
Her tutor one recent afternoon was Ted Frostad, who teaches mathematics, physics and computer science. A resident of North Stonington, Mr. Frostad retired from the Navy two years ago.
"A common thread I've found among the students is a lack of fundamentals, the building blocks for the skills a college normally tries to hone," he said. "We go back and rebuild that foundation."
Success is a word Mr. Markovich uses repeatedly when describing Mitchell's approach. "Students today have problems far greater than they did in the 60's," he said. "At that time, they had a passionate desire to know they could make a difference and change society. In the 90's, they feel desperation, and their attitude is fatalistic. They need a positive attitude."
Freshmen who failed to win scholarships in high school are eligible for competitive merit scholarships based not on past performance but on the future. Awards of $1,000 to $2,000 are given to freshmen who demonstrate potential in leadership, community service, academics or who have a special talent.
"Sometimes it's the only award they've ever received," Mr. Markovich said.
Small but significant events on campus are celebrated. On Moving Up Day, which takes place on Parents' Weekend, freshmen are honored for having gone through the rituals that signify the beginning of college. They survived the first weeks of living away from home and are part of a college community. They have taken a college quiz. They have roommates.
Aaron Wilson of Stamford, in his second year at Mitchell, said he found it better to start off slowly and work his way up to a four-year school. Mr. Wilson, who has a learning disability, is studying computer science and plans to be a programmer or systems analyst.
His caution has apparently paid off. Along with the friends he has made, Mr. Wilson is proudest of the fact that he overcame his fear of speaking out and asking for help. "Just because you have a learning disability doesn't mean you're any slower or any better than anyone else," he said.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
23 Towns, and 1,000 Workers, Brace for a World Without Jamesway

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: ROXBURY

 BODY:
It was a week of seemingly endless bad news for the loyal customers and employees of the Jamesway store in the Ledgewood Mall here.
On Monday, the store said it would no longer accept personal checks, American Express charges, refunds, exchanges, layaways, or competitive markdowns. On Tuesday, the store announced that the weekly bingo game for the elderly would be discontinued. And on Wednesday, the parent company filed for bankruptcy for the second time in two years because of weak sales, operating losses and tight credit. 
 Now, the Jamesway Corporation, based in Secaucus, is expected to hold "going out of business" sales and decide soon whether to close its 90 stores, 23 of them in the state -- a move that would put more than 1,000 New Jerseyans out of work, including the 70 employees here.
Many employees and customers are bracing for the worst.
"Yes, I've heard about their problems," said Bridget Brennan, a Hopatcong resident who was buying a Jurassic Park Halloween outfit on Wednesday with her young son, James. "I would definitely miss it if it closed because it's very convenient and they have good brands, quality merchandise, and good prices."
Jamesway, which has been here for 17 years, is not the only discount department store around. But it is an important one in this and many other communities as a one-stop-shopping destination, a point of reference, a known quantity.
"Jamesway was a small regional discount department store, well-run, well-liked, that served its community well and had a good image," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, a forecasting firm in Scotch Plains. "But the company failed to keep up with the competition, failed to keep up with the changes in consumer taste, and the unfortunate end, I think, is at hand. It's sad."
Jamesway's troubles are nothing new. Other regional discount stores have struggled in face of cutthroat price competition from other retailers, particularly bulk-sale giants like Costco and ever-expanding national chains like Wal-Mart and Target. Jamesway is the third East Coast retailer to seek bankruptcy protection in the just last few months; the Caldor Corporation filed in September, and Bradlees Inc. did it in June.
Jamesway was founded in 1960 by Herbert Fisher in Jamestown, N.Y. and at one point had 122 stores in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Virginia, West Virginia, and Maryland. The Roxbury store has been around since 1978, a staple of the local economy and an anchor for dozens of stores that have come and gone in a mall that has had its hard times. It is common around here to speak of the Ledgewood Mall as "the one with the Jamesway," to distinguish it from the Roxbury Mall down the street.
"It's like a family, especially with the customers you see all the time," said an employee who has been with the store since 1978. "Sometimes they give you gifts at Christmas because you've helped them out. Even when I shop in other places, they'll stop me and say hello."
But as Mr. Fisher fell into declining health, so did the company. In July 1993, three months after he died, the company filed for bankruptcy. It closed several stores when it emerged from bankruptcy in December 1994 with a $115 million line of credit. Then, on Oct. 12, Jamesway dismissed 200 employees, including several top executives, from its Secaucus headquarters. The next day, the New York Stock Exchange suspended trading in Jamesway stock; it was trading at 56 1/4 cents a share, down from a 52-week-high of $4.25.
At the Roxbury store last week, none of those numbers filtered through; the only things that mattered were the "All Sales Final" signs and the determined faces of the employees, dressed in their red top and khaki or black bottom uniforms.
Customers and neighbors reflected on what Jamesway meant to them. They recalled the weekly bingo games on Tuesdays, which would be held on the jewelry counter and draw up to 75 elderly people who receive free coffee and doughnuts (and a chance at a $5 gift certificate). But Tuesday was the last bingo game, and the last time elderly customers could receive a 10 percent discount.
They talked about the big sales and weekly circulars. But they noticed the bold-face signs declaring the store's new policy, effective Oct. 16: no rain checks, no store credits.
"Oh God, no," said Denise Bulka of Allamuchy, a regular here for eight years. "I hope they don't close. I have to come here every week -- I get my laundry detergent, my black nail polish, my stockings."
And Linda Eble, a Stanhope resident who arrived with her two children just before the store opened at 9 A.M., said:
"It's automatic: you know what you're going to get. If this store closed, it's not like it would be this or nothing else, but I would be sad."
There are other shopping options in this exurban area of Morris County, including the Caldor's down the street and the Ames store in Flanders. But with several stores already vacant in the Ledgewood Mall, Jamesway's departure would add pressure on the existing anchors, Stern's and Marshall's, to pick up the slack.
"Jamesway brought a lot of traffic into the mall, and the community must have liked them from what I understand," said David Dondona, manager of W. Kodak Jewelers, just a few shops down in the mall. "Any store that leaves the mall, that hurts."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
A Long Way From Leningrad

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
WHEN Alla Rosenfeld immigrated to the United States from Leningrad seven years ago, her friends in what was then the Soviet Union freely tossed her advice: Forget about drawing. Forget about teaching art history. In America, art history doesn't exist. Be practical. Learn bookkeeping.
"No," Ms. Rosenfeld would insist. "I will give lectures on Russian art history." 
 Among the possessions she packed, in the few suitcases she was allowed to take with her, were 200 slides of Russian art and icons she had used in at Soviet academy classes. "The customs people were laughing," she said, recalling her departure.
Since her arrival, she has not had to wait on tables or bother with double-entry ledgers. As she promised herself, she has earned her living teaching art history. And three years ago, she collided with a job so right that had it been love, it would have been the making of a Rodgers and Hammerstein song: she became the curator for Russian and Soviet art at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University.
Her hiring was one serendipity among many in the ferreting out and buying, the transporting and the displaying of the Norton and Nancy Dodge Collection of Nonconformist Art From the Soviet Union, which opens to the public today. On view is a sampling of about 300 artworks from a total of 12,000 in the Dodge Collection, all of which will be permanently housed and exhibited at the Zimmerli.
The story behind the acquisition of these renegade artworks, created from 1956 to 1986, when glasnost and perestroika meant that artists could once again paint what they wanted, is as unlikely as a James Bond movie plot. It involved the passion of Mr. Dodge, a walrus-mustached professor of economics from Maryland described by friends as resembling an unmade bed, according to John McPhee, who chronicled his story in his recent book "The Ransom of Russian Art." The art Mr. Dodge discovered in a series of trips to the Soviet Union over 30 years represents the secret work of a generation of artists all over the country.
He found it in cramped, pipe-lined attics and smuggled it out, sometimes rolled in carpets, a vast array of art of various styles and topics created in secrecy and seen, if at all, only by friends. The art was so illegal that the artists could be, and sometimes were, imprisoned for making it.
Ms. Rosenfeld and Jeffrey Wechsler, a Brooklyn native and Rutgers graduate who has worked at the Zimmerli for 20 years and is now its assistant director for curatorial affairs, organized the show. It took about two years to select and organize the huge assortment of paintings, sculptures and video art. The curators divided the forbidden art into categories: religious, abstract, hyperrealism (including paintings accurately depicting gloomy scenes), performance-art photos and Sots art, which parodies the only official art of the Soviet era, Socialist Realism, with its depictions of happy workers, war victories and noble politicians.
Ms. Rosenfeld, 35, was too young in the 1960's to know about the boiling but lidded art scene in Leningrad, since renamed St. Petersburg, then as now the most cultured and Westernized of Russian cities. Her talent was recognized early. She began taking art classes in fifth grade and went on to study graphic design at the Leningrad academy of fine arts.
At 18, she met her future husband, Alexander, a dissident engineer who was Jewish. Ms. Rosenfeld, who knew almost nothing of her own Jewish heritage, said she had experienced some nasty anti-Semitic remarks at school and on the street, although this never held her back professionally. Through her husband, she met Jews and others unhappy with Soviet life. "I read books prohibited, at night, when no one would see you," she said. "I went to a seder. No one I knew had heard of seders. It was clandestine activity. Exciting, yes. I was young."
She also saw nonconformist art. By the mid-1970's, it could be shown in rented spaces, even though it was still illegal and unthinkable to display it in an official museum or gallery. "You could freely see; you wouldn't go to prison," she said. She had her first look at Surrealism and abstract art. She came away confused, sometimes shocked: "I didn't know what they were doing."
In the Soviet Union she learned something of her country's nonconformist art, but in America, she said, she has learned far more. "My taste changed in seven years," she said. "Conceptual, video art, performance art -- all I started to appreciate here, not in Russia."
Ms. Rosenfeld said she was happy enough in Leningrad and had no thoughts of leaving. She liked teaching painting, drawing and art history in a cultured, charming Baroque city, close to her family. Her father was a writer, her brother a flutist, her mother a lawyer. Like them, she was successful in public and critical of the system in private.
"I had to lead a double life," she said. "I was interested in questions related to Judaism. But it was dangerous to go to synagogue if you were starting in a good school. Ideology was everywhere."
Her husband was having a bad time. He had applied to emigrate years earlier and was refused; as a refusenik, he had trouble finding work and was the cause of demotions for his parents, both architects. "They were almost crying," Ms. Rosenfeld said.
Finally, after perestroika, Ms. Rosenfeld and her husband were allowed to come to the United States. They settled with their son, Benjamin, now 9, in Stamford, Conn. Ms. Rosenfeld began her successful hunt for jobs in graphic design and lecturing on art history.
"I walked into a gallery, the I.B.M., interviewed, presented myself," she said, referring to the former I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art in midtown Manhattan. "Maybe I was interesting and exotic." She was hired to lecture on French Impressionism and Tibetan sacred art at the gallery.
She boned up on Impressionism and learned, literally from scratch, the esthetics and history of Tibetan art. She could read and understand spoken English fluently but could not speak well. "I didn't realize how difficult, to give a lecture in a foreign language on something I don't know," she said. She would write her lectures, have American friends read them into tape recorders and memorize the proper pronunciation of words. She worked, as well, in other galleries, in New York City and Greenwich, Conn.
So successful was she that in 1993, riding the train to interview for a job at the Zimmerli, she wasn't sure she wanted it. "I thought, not so prestigious," she said. The opening was for a curator for another Zimmerli collection of Russian art, donated some years before by George Riabov, a Russian-American Rutgers alumnus. It consists of more than 1,000 works of Russian art from the 18th to the early 20th century.
The proximity of that collection was one reason Mr. Dodge, who was storing the thousands of paintings in some of the 40 buildings in his 960-acre Maryland farm, chose to give them to the Zimmerli. He had had them there for years, and since some were starting to deteriorate, it was crucial to move them to a proper, protected, temperature-controlled space.
Ms. Rosenfeld and Mr. Wechsler have spent most of the last two years readying the nonconformist collection. Together, they selected from the voluminous pile of art, compiled the categories, had walls built to hang pieces, wrote explanatory placards. "A Russian education is strict, truly academic," Mr. Wechsler said. "You do not question the professor. You learn specific things, facts. It's not like an American education, where they teach you how to think. Alla maintained the absolute importance of the factual biographies of artists -- where they studied and so forth. I'd be the one to say, 'You have talk about the paintings.' "
Ms. Rosenfeld "has a better knowledge of American and British literature than most American college students," he added. "I'd have to tell her, 'Americans won't know this person or book or fact.' "
Ms. Rosenfeld is now living in the Chelsea section of Manhattan with her son; she and her husband have divorced. She loves the culture and bustle of Manhattan. There, she has met many more Russian artists than she did in the Soviet Union. Some are thriving, succussfully making and selling art. Others are not.
"Now they are competitive," she said. At parties, Russian artists "talk about the period of the 1960's with great nostalgia," she went on, and added: "It was a spiritual time. At gatherings, people would talk of philosophy and art and drink vodka into the night. There was nothing to compete for. Now there is jealousy, envy. Artists that were friends in the 60's are now enemies."

Alla Rosenfeld at the Zimmerli Art Musem, where the Norton and Nancy Dodge Collection of Nonconformist Art opens today. (Photographs by Julio A. Ibarra Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Back on Track

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
THE NEXT time you find yourself parked at a railroad crossing, waiting for eight million pounds or so of freight containers to roll by, you could count them.
You could curse them. 
 Or, like Wayne Eastman, you might simply marvel.
Last Friday Mr. Eastman, the district superintendent at the Conrail Oak Island switching yard in Newark, stood on a bridge over Newark Bay and watched a 142-car train laden with axles for the G.M. plant in Linden, wheat flour for Nabisco's Fair Lawn bakery, a tankerful of isobutane for a Mobil refinery in Paulsboro pull into the yard.
"There it goes," he said. "A microcosm of the New Jersey economy."
The once-crippled rail freight industry is booming now, and nowhere more than in New Jersey. The triumph of intermodal shipping, in which the same container can be moved from ship to train to truck, has combined with glitches in the region's transportation system itself to make the state a rail freight capital. These days, chances are that your morning glass of orange juice, your television set, the newsprint on which these words are printed, even the car in which you sit at the rail crossing all entered the state on a pair of tracks.
When it comes to shipping freight, trucks are still king: they carried 158 million tons in and out of New Jersey in 1994. But consider these recent developments:
* From 1982 to 1994, freight shipments to and from New Jersey by rail grew more than five times as fast as shipments by truck, and totaled more than 28 million tons last year.
* At Port Elizabeth, which combined with Port Newark is the second busiest port in the country, the number of containers transferred directly between ships and trains has increased by 465 percent since 1988. In December, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plans to open a new rail terminal at Port Elizabeth that is twice the size of the existing one.
* In May, Toys "R" Us opened a new 885,000-square-foot distribution center along the Morristown and Erie tracks in Flanders, one of the biggest rail-driven economic development projects in the state since before the interstate highway system was built in the 1950's.
* Within the last three years, many of the nation's biggest trucking companies, including J. B. Hunt, Roadway and Consolidated Freightways, have started using trains for the longest legs of their cross-country hauls, boosting business at the half-dozen intermodal rail terminals in New Jersey.
To understand the rail resurgence, it is helpful to view the world from the inside of a shipping container. Imagine that you are a pair of sneakers, fresh from the factory in Korea and bound for the feet of a little boy in Paramus.
You and several thousand mates are packed into a container like those carried on the backs of tractor-trailers, and placed on a steamship headed for Los Angeles or Oakland. On arrival, your container is set down on train wheels, and you are zipped across the country to an intermodal terminal like Conrail's Croxton Yard in Jersey City. There a truck picks up your container and drives you to a warehouse, where you are sorted for the final truck ride to the Garden State Plaza.
This is intermodal transportation, which now accounts for about three-quarters of rail shipments into and out of the state. (And it can beeven more complicated than that. A container rarely rides the same train all the way across the country, and breaking a train apart at a switching yard, sorting the cars and assembling a new train takes much more time than hoisting a container from one train to another.)
A decade or two ago, when the rail freight standard was the boxcar, transferring goods from a shipping container to a boxcar and then back to a container for truck distribution was so costly and time-consuming that ships from Asia sailed through the Panama Canal to truck terminals at Port Newark. But today, in most cases, the "land bridge" moves merchandise across the country several days faster than a ship can.
Say you are a California avocado. Only a few years ago, you would have made the cross-country journey by truck. But railroad operators have increased hundreds of clearances in tunnels and under bridges, and now shippers can double-stack containers on low-riding bucket-shaped platforms. This, combined with a chronic shortage of truck drivers, has made it more economical for trucking companies to haul by train. For example, a terminal operator in North Bergen says it costs $500 to $600 to ship a 45,000-pound container from Chicago to North Jersey by train, compared to $750 to $800 by truck.
A fully loaded container train can now take the place of 200 tractor-trailers.According to the Association of American Railroads, trains are three times more fuel efficient than trucks and emit one-tenth the hydrocarbons.
Add this to the mule work that trains have always done better than trucks -- the movement of heavy loads, like sand from the mines of Cumberland County or coal to P.S.E.&G. plants in Atlantic County, and dangerous ones, like the explosive and corrosive compounds used by the refineries along the state's "chemical coast" -- and the growth of rail freight seems almost inevitable.
"It's like this," Mr. Eastman said. "We bring in Tropicana orange juice from Bradenton, Florida, on 65-car unit trains two to three times a week. They unload it and distribute it all over the Northeast. You buy it, you drink it, you digest it, it goes to the sewage treatment plant, they put the sludge on rail cars and we take it down to Texas. We do it all. The whole food chain."
 
End of the Line
There are 1,332 miles of track used for hauling freight across New Jersey. The Consolidated Rail Corporation, as Conrail is officially known, owns or uses 949 of them. The rest of the tracks belong to 10 independent short-line railroads that connect to Conrail's lines.
The largest freight carrier east of the Mississippi and north of the Ohio River, Conrail was created by the Federal Government in 1976 to restore and operate 12,000 miles of track abandoned by six railroads that had gone out of business because of competition from trucks and onerous regulation. The Government sold its share of Conrail in 1987, and the Philadelphia-based company is now publicly held, with revenues of $3.7 billion in 1994.
Conrail's operations in the northern part of this state are enormous. They include intermodal terminals in Jersey City, Kearny, North Bergen, and Ports Newark and Elizabeth that have already handled more than 350,000 containers this year; five auto-loading terminals both for cars made in New Jersey and for cars shipped here for sale; two bulk-transfer terminals where, say, a candy maker can send a truck to suck corn syrup out of a tanker car; and the 30-track switching yard at Oak Island in Newark.
Several local transportation problems make North Jersey an even better place to put a rail freight terminal than it would otherwise be. One is the highway congestion on Routes 1 and 9 near the ports, which is so bad that many shippers try to use trucks as little as possible. Another is the fact that for eastbound freight headed into New York City or Long Island, the nearest place a train can cross the Hudson is in Albany. That makes New Jersey the logical end of the line for a cross-country rail shipment.
Conrail's business in North Jersey is so good, in fact, that it's becoming a problem. Truck congestion at the South Kearny Intermodal Terminal forced Conrail to open a new terminal at Port Elizabeth in September, and train traffic jams on the single-track Hudson River line and other stretches sometimes delay deliveries.
Ted Matthews, manager of ports, terminals and freight for the state Department of Transportation, notes that in some ways, Conrail is finding itself a victim of its own recovery strategy.
"Conrail has been downsizing its system over the years in response to loss in traffic," he said, "and now that people are moving back to the railroad, Conrail is finding that the slimming down they did to make themselves able to compete is now working against them."
Solving the track congestion problem is not going to be easy. Mr. Matthews said that the state's plans to lay more track in North Jersey are currently on hold. Even so, Mr. Matthews and other transportation officials and planners, citing the strides in efficiency railroads have made in the last decade, predict that the demand for freight rail service will keep growing. Mr. Matthews said he has been fielding an increasing number of calls from industries considering a move to New Jersey who "absolutely require" rail access.
And Don Lotz, the Port Authority's intermodal manager and the man overseeing the new intermodal terminal at Port Elizabeth, said that improving rail connections was essential to the port's ability to compete against others on the Eastern Seaboard.
"A Chicago importer bringing in Heineken beer has a choice," Mr. Lotz said. "If our port can't build the best mousetrap, he's going to go to Halifax or Philadelphia."
 
The View From the Cab
As seen from a freight train -- even a state-of-the-art, double-stacked container train -- the world is an old-fashioned, slightly squalid but largely charming place comprising backyards, aging factories and scrubby greenery of the sort that flourishes in gravel.
Mostly, this is because there is no rail equivalent of the interstate highway system, which allows drivers to bypass towns and cities. Trains run where they've always run, past the civilization that sprang up alongside them.
In New Jersey, the freight train passes through dozens of tiny towns whose boom times, such as they were, are long gone -- a string of settlements along the vanished Morris Canal in Warren County called Rockport, Port Colden and Port Murray; places in South Jersey called Norma and Newfield.
In bigger towns, the train typically runs along a street called Railroad Avenue, at least half of whose real estate is on the wrong side of the tracks. Last Sunday, on a run from the Oak Island yard up past the New York border at Suffern, Brian Reilly admired the view.
"You go places no one ever really sees," said Mr. Reilly, the conductor of a 44-car train hauling mostly paper, plywood and plastic. "You see the industry, the backbone."
Mr. Reilly, 26, is a second-generation railroader. His family is from Scranton, Pa., a city built on the railroad, but though he still lives there, Mr. Reilly, like his two brothers, finds that much of his work is in New Jersey. He has been on the railroad for a year.
As the train chugged through Jersey City, Mr. Reilly scanned the tracks for signs of trouble. The stretches where the train passes the public housing projects in Jersey City and Hoboken, Conrail officials say, have the highest looting rate in the whole Conrail system. Despite the presence of Conrail police officers, bands of brigands sometimes force a train to an emergency stop by disconnecting the air-brake lines, then break into the cars and throw off television sets, cases of beer, anything of value. Sometimes they don't even wait for the train to stop.
"They can unload a juice train while it's moving," Mike DiGuglielmo, a yardmaster at Oak Island, had said. "They break through a sealed door and take off half a car of juice faster than Tropicana can unload it when it's stopped in the yard."
On this day, however, there appeared to be only the usual trespassers -- an old man walking a basset hound, a guy passed out inside a car, little kids looking for mischief.
At Saddle Brook, engineer Michael Walkerwicz stopped the two-engine train to drop off nine cars of paper at the New York Susquehanna and Western yard. Mr. Reilly hopped off to light flares at an unsignaled intersection while the train backed into the siding, then went to the back to disconnect the cars.
Farther up, Mr. Reilly waved at a man and his son walking along the road by the tracks. "In Scranton, when I tell people I'm on the railroad they seem skeptical because it really did die out over there," he said. "They don't know how big it is out here."
 
 
 
Short Lines Fill In The Gaps
IF Conrail is the giant, the Microsoft of rail freight, then the short lines are the Lotuses and Wordperfects and Novells. The nine independently owned railroads, ranging in length from 2 miles to 79, operate spurs off Conrail's main tracks to serve local customers. Another railroad, the New York Susquehanna and Western, is more of a regional line, linking North Jersey to several long-haul freight lines in Buffalo and Binghamton.
Some of the short lines have been around for decades, but many of them run on some of the 429 miles of track that Conrail has abandoned over the years because it could not operate them at a profit. Conrail inherited more than 1,500 miles of track when it was formed in 1976, but found that many of its spur lines had too few customers or were too dilapidated to be worth keeping.
The smaller railroads, because they have lower overhead, do not pay union wages and can offer more personalized service, have often been able to succeed where Conrail couldn't. By and large, the arrangement suits both parties just fine.
"We're very good at moving long volumes long or short distances, but we don't do as well moving light volumes over shorter distances," said a Conrail spokesman, Robert Libkind. "We can work with a short line which has different economic structure, and because the short line gathers business, they in turn become our customer."
And gather business they do. In May, Toys "R" Us opened a huge warehouse in Flanders eight miles along the Morristown and Erie line from the Conrail connection in Roxbury Township.
"When we met with them, they told us that rail service was vital to all their distribution centers, and that they wouldn't even consider a site without rail access." said Frank Reilly, the Morris County Transportation Director, who helped bring Toys "R" Us to Flanders.
Successes like the Morristown and Erie's are being repeated all over the state. The Southern Railroad of New Jersey will soon begin hauling loads of fish from a new processing plant being built in Woodbine, Cape May County.
"One of the reasons they located there was that there was outbound rail service," said Tom Collard, the vice president. The Southern Railroad, formed three years ago, has seen its business grow from 545 cars hauled in the first nine months of 1994 to more than 1,500 this year.
Sometimes, to get a short line back in working order, local government will step in to buy or fix up the track. At Mr. Reilly's suggestion, Morris County has bought 15 miles of track, holding onto several manufacturers who would have left if they had lost their rail connection, and attracting others. "I think what a lot of people don't realize is that you don't need to have a 300-mile long railroad to improve your local economy," he said.
Because the short lines are dependent on Conrail for connections to the outside world and sometimes for equipment, the arrangement is not always a comfortable one. Several short-line executives used the word "captive" to describe their situation, and Jack Dean, a planner for the non-profit Regional Plan Association in New York, said that Conrail has been less accommodating to the short lines of late.
"Conrail is tightening up its service relationship with short lines," he said. "They're being more strict on price policies, how they can use cars."
On the other hand, the New York Susquehanna and Western has been able to thrive in head-to-head competition with the giant. N.Y.S.W., which offers westbound connections to the Norfolk Southern and other major lines in New York State, specializes in double-stacked containers and has intermodal terminals in Jersey City, North Bergen, Ridgefield and Saddle Brook.
"If a customer needs a car in the middle of the day," said the company's vice president, Robert Kurdock, "we're small and flexible enough that we can adjust our plans almost instantly."
Sometimes, however, N.Y.S.W. and Conrail team up to compete against trucking firms. "We have a unique relationship with Conrail," Mr. Kurdock said. "It takes a bit of diplomacy."
