SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2085 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Building a Better 401(k)

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
A TRILLION dollars. Now there's a figure that commands some respect. That's the amount that those retirement plans with the yawner name -- 401(k) -- will likely claim as their own in just three or four years. Nearly 18.5 million American workers have these tax-advantaged accounts, and many millions more will doubtless soon join them. For the 401(k) has been heralded by economists, politicians and investment advisers alike as a key to a comfortable retirement in the post-pension world.
But the 401(k) idea has a flaw. No, not just the frequent lament that many eligible workers do not join the plans, or do not invest enough in them, or do not allocate their assets appropriately. This other problem centers not on the worker at all but on the company, not on an ill-informed investor but on a malformed plan.
This is a story about how some workers who were enrolled in such unsatisfactory plans -- two San Francisco architects, a newspaper editor in Philadelphia, the treasurer of a parking-lot company and a whole set of workers at a food company in upstate New York -- voiced their concerns and persuaded their companies to make the necessary changes.
Unfortunately, such reformers are rare, even if the defects that roused them are not. While companies generally follow Labor Department guidelines on the basic features of a good 401(k) plan, those minimums leave plenty of room for discretion. And, for a host of reasons, the executives who choose 401(k) plans for their companies are simply not the unerring judges that workers may assume.
For many executives, the 401(k) question often yields to more pressing issues -- like meeting the competition. And even if the 401(k) gets their attention, it may be for naught. "In many cases," said Daniel P. Wiener, publisher of the newsletter Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, the executive who does the choosing "doesn't have a clue about investing."
Even the pricing of such plans is not clear-cut. "Many companies, and even benefits consultants, feel confused on pricing because it's all over the map," said Tom Johnson, vice president for marketing for Fed Services in Pittsburgh, which manages $80 billion in 401(k) money.
And where knowledge is sketchy and prices fuzzy, social connections often become decisive. The choice of a corporate 401(k) plan, Mr. Wiener said, often hinges less on its merits than on "the relationship between the person at the company who makes the decisions and a sales agent for a mutual fund company." Selecting a plan after a round of golf hosted by such agents, he said, "is no way to design a plan."
The results, the experts say, are plans with too few choices, arbitrarily set contribution limits, hidden fees, and other traits that can at best dampen the great promise of 401(k) plans and, at worst, seriously hobble workers' efforts to prepare for retirement.
Here are the tales of those workers who have become Norma Rae's of the 401(k). They describe what weak spots they found, how they discovered the problems and what reform strategies they used -- from pushing for less costly changes on the theory the company is more receptive to them, to exploiting the investment savvy of in-house financial officers in mapping a new plan.
For the rest of the 18.5 million 401(k) investors, the lesson these workers teach is that while your 401(k) may be far from perfect, it may also be far from written in stone. Now may be a particularly good time to explore both those questions, with plan vendors engaged in a fierce competition that means dirt-cheap prices for buyers. Indeed, delay may be dangerous. The tax breaks that make the plans so attractive to workers are also attracting the attention of Congressional budget-balancers.
Yet assessing one's 401(k) plan is a long-term exercise, too. Just as today's workers must take charge of their own retirement investments, they also must scrutinize the contours of the plans. The stories below teach us to ask the critical, overarching questions: How good is my 401(k)? Are there hidden fees or costly features that serve little purpose? Do its mutual funds perform well, and are there enough of them? Asking these questions -- and pushing for change if the answers are unsatisfactory -- are critical chores for the workers who will be the pioneer retirees of the 21st century.
 
Two Puzzled Architects
 In 1993, two young architects in San Francisco, Kevin Kennedy and Steve Jackson, noticed something odd about their 401(k) investments. The plan's no-load mutual funds reported returns in the newspaper that were much better than the returns they reported to the plan.
Confused and worried, the men approached the owners of their firm, Gordon H. Chong & Associates. The owners agreed to a 401(k) review, with the firm's 50 architects electing a four-member committee to perform it.
The committee, which included Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Jackson, was soon poring over the plan documents and unraveling the complexities of the 401(k). But it didn't take long for them to discover why their existing mutual fund options did so much better in the newspaper than on their plan's papers: buried in the pricing of their 401(k) documents was a 5 percent commission on purchases of these "no load" mutual funds.
Naturally, the committee began to look elsewhere. Mr. Jackson, for example, used his personal computer to conduct a detailed performance analysis of various mutual funds over intervals ranging from three years to one month.
The committee also interviewed mutual fund companies and other vendors of 401(k) plans, and became pretty smart shoppers. "The really big guys in mutual funds offered very good service -- but you had to buy only their funds and that put us off a little bit," Mr. Kennedy said.
Given their past experience, they were acutely attuned to hard-to-detect fees. "We also felt that they had some loads, some costs, that you don't necessarily see upfront," he said about some vendors. "That made us a little leery because there were plenty of pure no-load funds out there."
The committee worked for more than a year, eventually prompting the firm's owners to retain Schwab One, which allows workers to pick from six investment options offered by several different mutual funds and other money managers. And the new plan reduced, from one year to several months, the waiting period before new employees could enroll.
 
A Borrower and a Lender Be
 Jonathan Neumann, enterprise editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer, mentioned to one of his superiors in 1994 that he was planning to borrow some money. She suggested he take out a loan against his 401(k) savings. To Mr. Neumann, who had put away the maximum allowed since the plan began in 1989, the idea made great sense. He needn't worry about applying for a loan, and instead of paying interest to a bank he would be paying it to himself.
But when Mr. Neumann asked for loan forms he got a shock.
"Much to my surprise," he said, "I learned that the union employees were not allowed to borrow, but people in management could."
Mr. Neumann went right to the top, asking both the paper's publisher and the president of his union, Local 10 of the Newspaper Guild, the whys and wherefores of the rule. "Neither had any answers," he said.
So Mr. Neumann and a colleague called R. Theodore Benna, a benefits consultant in Langhorne, Pa., who is widely credited with popularizing 401(k) plans. Mr. Benna said there was no legal reason such loans could not be made to union employees, that the paperwork involved would cost less than $1,000 and that all other loan costs could be charged to borrowers.
"We went back to the publisher and the union president and they said, 'That's all it takes?' and in about two months it was done and I got my loan," Mr. Neumann said.
Such "self-lending" is a big attraction of the 401(k) and its nonprofit cousin, the 403(b). About $17 billion of these assets have been borrowed, with an average loan balance of $6,200, according to Access Research, a market research firm in Windsor, Conn. Under Federal law these loans are limited to half of account balances, up to $50,000.
 
Good Stuff Real Cheap
 Doug Bowlus was not too pleased with the performance of the money manager for his 401(k) plan at ABM Industries, a San Francisco company that runs parking lots and janitorial services across the country.
"Nobody was particularly happy with our investment manager," Mr. Bowlus, ABM's treasurer, said. "I tracked their performance and came to the conclusion that we could do better."
But Mr. Bowlus knew that he faced some constraints. "We are not a high-margin company," he said, "and so cost control and avoidance is a serious issue."
So, with some colleagues, Mr. Bowlus focused on cheap ways to make ABM's 401(k) plan better. And he succeeded, ultimately persuading his superiors to switch investment managers, to change administrators to improve 401(k) record-keeping, and to provide additional features, such as two more investment options.
"We got all of these improvements," said Mr. Bowlus, "for virtually no additional cost to the company." In fact, he said, the switch to a new administrator should lower administrative costs.
Equally important are the new plan's improvements in 401(k) communication and education. Employees can now get daily valuations from an 800 number, for instance, and each quarter they also receive reports on how each fund option did compared to all similar funds.
"We are also getting much more, and much more professional, educational materials," Mr. Bowlus said. "It will help our employees understand the difference between savings and investment and what different options can mean to their retirement income, and to better understand that investment is a long-term process and not 'What did you do for me this quarter?' "
And in securing the new plan, Mr. Bowlus used a strategy that may prove useful to others. As ABM's treasurer, he is financially knowledgeable, and he relied as well on other ABM finance specialists in his efforts.
Such specialists add needed investment acumen for 401(k) design, said Thomas Schlossberg, president of Diversified Investment Advisors. While there has recently been a big shift of 401(k) responsibility to financial executives, "About 60 percent of the time the benefits or human resources people, especially at smaller companies, decide on the 401(k) plan," he said. "Better to get the chief financial officer's people involved, too."
 
Everybody Into the Act
 At Curtice-Burns Foods in Rochester, N.Y., a battle over corporate ownership last fall had left many employees fretful about their future. To allay concerns and show its benevolence, the company decided to greatly improve the retirement plans of its 1,200 salaried workers.
But first the company, which makes Comstock pie fillings and Nalley's chips, surveyed its workers to find out their sentiments. What it learned was a surprise -- and led the company to change direction.
"We knew we needed to do something in the area of retirement," said Lois Warlick-Jarvie, vice president for human resources. "We were looking at improving the defined benefit plan, but based on what we heard from our employees we decided to work on the defined contribution plan." In other words, while the company was readying a plan to augment its pension, workers were pointing to their 401(k)'s instead.
And improve them, it did. The company increased the plan's investment options from two to four and, while there was no company match before, Curtice-Burns offered a 50 percent match, up to 3 percent of pay.
The lesson for workers is twofold: Speak up about changes you desire because your company may have no clue about your preferences. And when you do speak up, your company may well say yes.
Congress first authorized the 401(k) plan in 1980. By the year 2000 -- a mere 20 years later -- the predictions are that 25 million American workers at 350,000 companies will have invested $1.175 trillion in such plans.
That growth makes it critical for workers to realize that, in the world of the 401(k), intelligent investing means more than just mastering and following the rules of asset allocation, diversification and the like. It also means stepping back, scrutinizing the overall plan as vigorously as they scrutinize investments, and pushing for change if change is needed. For weak plans can make strong portfolios -- and a secure retirement -- impossible to achieve.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2902 words

HEADLINE: At Justice, The Taming of A Whirlwind

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was the early heady days of her tenure as the Clinton Administration's top antitrust enforcer, and Anne K. Bingaman was not about to compromise.
She was facing skeptical questioning from her boss, Associate Attorney General Webster L. Hubbell, about her sprawling investigation into charges that the General Electric Company was rigging the prices of industrial diamonds around the world. Mr. Hubbell had received calls from Ben W. Heineman Jr., G.E.'s general counsel and a close friend to many powerful Democrats, pleading that the case be dropped, particularly since the company had persuaded the Government's leading witness, an executive-turned-informant, to sign an affidavit saying he had "no personal knowledge" of price-fixing. 
 Refusing to yield, Mrs. Bingaman announced the company's indictment with considerable fanfare. But just weeks after the case went to trial last October, Federal prosecutors were thrown out of court because their evidence was so weak.
Now, a year later, Mrs. Bingaman, a 52-year-old former law professor and antitrust litigator, said she has no regrets. "It was a tough case and sometimes you lose tough cases," she said in a recent interview in her office in the Justice Department. "I don't see it as a setback."
But many outsiders do, calling it a stinging defeat that serves as the demarcation line between Mrs. Bingaman's activist, whirlwind start as head of the department's antitrust division and a harsher new reality that has left her unbowed but increasingly on the defensive.
Before the G.E. case was thrown out, Mrs. Bingaman was on a roll, quickly reviving the division from the torpor of the Reagan and Bush years. Her lawyers were winning cases in the courts and striking agreements in a number of mergers that in earlier days would have gone unchallenged. She moved legislation briskly through Congress. And she managed to exploit the divisions within a weaker rival agency, the Federal Trade Commission, grabbing away high-profile investigations like the antimonopoly case against the giant Microsoft Corporation.
Since the G.E. case, however, the antitrust division has faced a wide range of challenges -- ideological, political and bureaucratic -- that together are starting to rein in Mrs. Bingaman and her agenda, outsiders said.
"From early on, she tried to be quite aggressive, but she has run up against the reality that there are strong limits to what she can really do," said Robert W. Crandall, a senior fellow of economic studies at the Brookings Institution.
For openers, Mrs. Bingaman is facing tough opposition on Capitol Hill from a new Republican majority that is eager to drastically cut back the division's regulatory role in telecommunications and health care. And off the Hill, she is facing a renewed rivalry from a rejuvenated F.T.C.
Meanwhile, though her division continues to have a strong enforcement record, one of its highest-profile cases -- a price-fixing investigation of agribusiness giant Archer-Daniels-Midland -- has quickly turned problematic because of recent disclosures about another executive-turned-informant who is a key Government witness. The executive, Mark E. Whitacre, has been accused by Archer-Daniels of embezzling millions of dollars. Mr. Whitacre, who attempted suicide two months ago, has offered to plead guilty to two felony counts, and according to one Government official, is "quickly being seen as the antitrust division's Mark Fuhrman."
And then there are the hard lessons of the G.E. case itself. One out of four pending grand jury investigations supervised by the division involves the conduct of American and foreign companies abroad -- and the number of such cases appears to be growing. The defeat in the G.E. case, Mrs. Bingaman said, shows how difficult it is to win when Federal prosecutors and courts cannot get their hands on critical witnesses and documents that are abroad.
But there is another lesson, detractors say. To them, the defeat demonstrates that in her zeal to elevate the profile of the antitrust division, Mrs. Bingaman occasionally overreaches.
And for that reason, they say, the case raises basic questions about just how long the division's reach should be.
If American companies have to operate in a world economy that is largely a free-for-all, do too many antitrust rules at home hamper their ability to compete? How can American regulators control the behavior of foreign companies that are shipping more and more goods to the United States? And if the mood of the country favors less government and fewer regulations -- and the trend among many industries is to consolidate -- where does that leave a regulatory agency whose traditional role has been to attack big companies as the enemy of free competition?
UNDOUBTEDLY the division is different than when Mrs. Bingaman arrived 26 months ago. For decades until Ronald Reagan became President, it played a vital role in the economy, deciding the fate of corporate mergers and acquisitions, breaking up companies it thought were too dominant and handling a wide array of bid-rigging and price-fixing cases of enormous consequence to the marketplace.
But that all began to change with the Reagan Administration's commitment to reducing the role of government in Corporate America.
The division was further threatened by changing domestic and global economic forces.
The tumultuous reconfigurations of four bulwark American industries -- health care, defense, telecommunications and computers -- left legal scholars and economists questioning the relevance of vigorous antitrust law as a pillar of open and competitive markets. Although the antitrust division scored a coup in the early 80's, forcing AT&T to break up and starting a new wave of competition in the telephone industry, its failure to accomplish anything similar with the International Business Machines Corporation was an indication of the difficulties it would soon have trying to regulate rapidly changing technology markets.
And new economic realities emerged abroad that threatened to transform the antitrust division into a vestigial organ of the legal system. The proliferation of imports of everything from automobiles to videotape machines meant that American antitrust prosecutors would no longer be able to protect domestic markets merely by policing American companies. But with few methods for getting at incriminating documents and corporate informants abroad, antitrust enforcement in the American marketplace began to sound a hollow ring.
Meanwhile, the job that Mr. Reagan began -- cutting out wide swaths of enforcement -- was continued after he left office by many of the Federal judges he had appointed. Through the last decade, the courts have issued a string of opinions sharply curtailing the ability of companies and consumers to bring their own cases to enforce antitrust laws.
AWARE of these legal and economic obstacles, Mrs. Bingaman vowed to turn on the lights when she arrived on the darkened antitrust scene. A litigator whose hero is Adlai Stevenson, she had little in the way of a public track record, and the perception that she was a plaintiff's antitrust lawyer with populist ideas gave encouragement to some consumer groups while causing some executives to worry that she would revive the enforcement zeal of the 1960's.
Those worries were justified, said William F. Baxter, the intellectual father of the Reagan Administration's antitrust policy and head of the antitrust division for three years.
As it happens, Mrs. Bingaman studied antitrust law with Mr. Baxter while she and her future husband, Jeff, now a Democratic Senator from New Mexico, were students at Stanford University's law school. Though Mr. Baxter said he remains Mrs. Bingaman's friend and speaks with her regularly, he readily criticizes his former pupil and her division.
"They started off with unrealistic ambitions and expectations and they've had a number of failures," he said in a telephone interview last week. "They set off with this crusading notion that there's lots and lots of violations and they would try to do whatever they could to throw out the rascals, and they have now found out it is not so easy to do that. The larger companies are well-counseled and don't get into the kind of trouble that the antitrust division is looking for. So, instead, they go after the little companies, hoping to score some kind of political advantage."
For her part, Mrs. Bingaman said she has tried to walk a fine line, ratcheting up the division's aggressiveness without going over the top.
"You get respect for antitrust by doing things -- but not doing stupid things," she said. "Antitrust was trashed in the mid-1980's. It has been built back, beginning with my immediate predecessor, Jim Rill. There was talk when I first got here about how I was going to return to the 60's and 70's and do all the crazy things that were done then. But my basic goal has been to build respect for the law."
Mrs. Bingaman and her troops have largely been meeting that goal, a number of antitrust scholars said.
"They have shown populist leanings tempered by a lot of good common sense," said George L. Priest, who teaches antitrust law at Yale University. "They haven't fought bigness just for the sake of bigness. They've done it for other reasons, or they've recognized that bigness is not necessarily anti-competitive."
Indeed, the biggest proposed merger now on the division's plate, the $19 billion takeover of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. by the Walt Disney Company, is widely expected to be approved.
And putting the General Electric case aside, the division has managed to avoid getting bogged down in big antitrust cases, as other administrations have, scholars agree.
"This Justice Department has been tough but pragmatic," said Steven C. Salop, an economist who teaches at the Georgetown University Law Center. "They're not on an escapade to restructure the economy. They are making fixes to encourage competition, while at the same time permitting benefits from the kinds of efficiencies that come with mergers."
Typical of such an approach was the consent decree the division wrote in AT&T's $12.6 billion acquisition of McCaw Cellular Communications last year. Mrs. Bingaman gave AT&T most of what it wanted, but also took steps to preserve competition even as the communications industry consolidates. The consent decree requires AT&T to keep its cellular-telephone operations separate from its long-distance and equipment manufacturing businesses. In addition, McCaw customers were permitted to select any long-distance carrier for cellular service.
Still, Mrs. Bingaman has moved aggressively. During her first two years, the division doubled the number of cases in which it challenged, restructured or blocked proposed mergers. It brought the first case to block a vertical merger -- the acquisition of the Liberty Media Corporation by Tele-Communications Inc. -- in 11 years. That case ended in a consent decree under which Tele-Communications, the largest owner of cable television distribution systems in the nation, is prohibited from discriminating against competing programmers.
The division has also used American antitrust law to open foreign markets that had been closed to United States companies. Its biggest victory came last year against Pilkington P.L.C., the British glass maker, in a case that Justice Department officials estimate could add as much as $1.25 billion to American export sales of glass products over the next six years.
ALL of which leaves Mrs. Bingaman bristling when presented with the view of some economists that antitrust enforcement is no longer relevant in industrial policy. "That's ridiculous," she said. "If you talk to the merger and acquisitions bar, I think they will tell you a lot of deals don't get done because they don't pass antitrust muster. I would just dispute the idea that we're not relevant.
"The law has been narrowed in some areas," she concedes, acknowledging the decline of private suits by companies against competitors. "But we still have the tools to do what we need to."
The question now is whether that will be the case for much longer.
In the current debate over Medicare legislation, some senior lawmakers in the House have moved to provide new antitrust exemptions to doctors and other health care providers. And separate bills have already passed both the House and Senate that would substantially reduce the antitrust division's authority over the telephone industry, removing Mrs. Bingaman from making important decisions about how the Baby Bells can be involved in the lucrative long-distance market.
"This is an industry that is already highly regulated, by the Federal Communications Commission and the states," said Thomas J. Tauke, executive vice president for governmental affairs at the Nynex Corporation, the Baby Bell based in New York. "It doesn't need a third regulator."
The telecommunications legislation, which the White House has threatened to veto, is awaiting action by a conference committee to iron out differences.
Mrs. Bingaman is also facing a new rival in Robert Pitofsky, the aggressive new chairman of the F.T.C. Mrs. Bingaman said she and Mr. Pitofsky are longtime friends and that she supported his nomination. Still, it is now difficult to imagine Mrs. Bingaman reaching in and grabbing control of enforcement investigations like the one against Microsoft. If anything, it is Mr. Pitofsky who appears to have gained the upper hand, at least in some cases.
Earlier this month, he won a turf tussle with Mrs. Bingaman over which agency would review the proposed $7.5 billion merger between Time Warner Inc. and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. Mr. Pitofsky is also preparing a series of hearings about virtually every aspect of antitrust law, to consider what changes ought to be made.
BUT if her division is on the defensive, Mrs. Bingaman hardly sounds like someone on the run.
She declined to comment about Archer-Daniels, but she said she would bring the G.E. case again tomorrow even if she knew it would end the same way.
Far from discouraging the division, she said, the case has sent out a positive message. The number of complaints from companies about antitrust abuses is up significantly, she said, because of the perception of a reinvigorated prosecutor's shop, as well as a new leniency policy she implemented. It permits a company to avoid criminal prosecution for illegal conduct, under most circumstances, by coming in and confessing to its role.
That kind of feisty attitude was also apparent in the division's most closely watched enforcement actions, involving Microsoft. Competitors of the company have said that Mrs. Bingaman was too lenient on Microsoft when the Justice Department settled a complaint accusing it of violating provisions of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
Mrs. Bingaman had sold the agreement as a tough one that would limit the company's dominance of the software industry, a view that was scorned by others.
"She created great expectations by taking the case from the F.T.C. and beating her breast about it, but then ended up landing a minnow," said the head of the antitrust practice at a leading law firm that was not involved in the case.
Yet when Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin refused to approve the agreement and suggested that Microsoft be investigated for other possible antitrust violations, Mrs. Bingaman wagged her finger and lectured him in court, saying he was no longer a top enforcement lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission and thus it was improper for him to play the part of prosecutor.
"For antitrust lawyers, it was more exciting than most days of the O. J. Simpson trial," said one top aide. Other lawyers said that although Mrs. Bingaman was exonerated when the United States Court of Appeals here reversed Judge Sporkin's ruling, her brazen challenge to the judge was hardly appropriate.
Mrs. Bingaman offered no apologies on that front, either, insisting that criticism of the division for being too lenient had nothing to do with its later decision to commence a second investigation of Microsoft. That review led the company to drop its proposed $1.5 billion acquisition of Intuit Inc., the maker of Quicken, the personal-finance software.
Still unclear is what the division is going to do, if anything, about Microsoft's plan to include software for its new on-line service in all new personal computers that carry its Windows operating system. On-line competitors said that kind of marketing blitz amounts to an unfair advantage.
ON the run or not, Mrs. Bingaman sooner or later will be leaving the division, of course.
About her future after the Justice Department, Mrs. Bingaman said "you couldn't pay enough" for her to try the cloistered life of a Federal judge. Instead, she said she is intrigued about the possibility of becoming an executive at a company, "even though I have no qualifications to be hired by business."
But many in the antitrust bar are in no rush to see her leave.
"Most antitrust lawyers in Washington are very happy with Anne," said Robert E. Litan, a former deputy in the antitrust division who left earlier this year to take a senior position at the White House budget office. "Even though they have to litigate against her, she is making them quite rich."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 34; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: What Makes Trump Tick?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There's nothing wrong with a little healthy ego or selfishness ("What My Ego Wants, My Ego Gets," From the Desk Of, Sept. 17), but Donald J. Trump's ego is not healthy; the term egomaniac might more aptly apply. 
 I happen to live in the neighborhood of Manhattan where Mr. Trump wishes to satisfy his ego to the tune of 15 40-story towers, caring nothing for what effect this monster project will have on this overcrowded area's environment -- the air quality, the inadequate subway service, the traffic jams and an already overtaxed sewage system.
As for his ability to obtain backing for these developments, how has he been able to obtain zoning changes against the will of a large segment of the community where the Riverside South Project is being developed.
What is even more galling is that this project has a loan guaranteed by the Housing and Urban Development Department. These loans are supposed to be for urban renewal; the Upper West Side of Manhattan is hardly in need of renewal. Granted his loan will be from a private lender, but in case of default, HUD (ie. the taxpayers) will foot the bill.
Wouldn't it be wonderful if Mr. Trump would dedicate his overactive ego to the building of low-income housing, which is so desperately needed.
 
FAITH STEINBERG
Manhattan, Sept. 18

HEADLINE: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;
A Different Kind of Paper Chase

BYLINE: By JOSEPH GEMIGNANI; Joseph Gemignani is an editor for the Money and Business section.

 BODY:
AFTER an extended period of forced cooperation and communication, my high-school-senior son and I were feeling pretty good about his college search this time a year ago. After all, we'd figured out the difference between Cornell College (in Iowa) and Cornell University (above Cayuga's waters in upstate New York). And we'd become sophisticated enough to know that California University was a lot closer to Pittsburgh than to the Pacific Ocean.
Having digested all such information, my son was starting to make realistic choices. Admissions essays were being written, references lined up and transcripts arranged. 
 But wait! While Phase 1 of the application process was winding down, we were about to enter Phase 2: the financial aid labyrinth.
Chances are that if you're a mortgage slave like me, you're not so well off that you can afford to pay college bills out of pocket and still maintain some sense of personal solvency (a crude "means test" for the lowly middle class these days). Chances are also that while you might have managed to put away a bit of college money, other things -- like, say, replacing your furnace -- kept stopping you from putting away as much as you had wanted. In my case, even if I had listened to E. F. Hutton 10 years ago and managed to salt away $2,000 a year, I'd still be coming up real short. After applying to six colleges, my son picked a state university with a respected journalism program -- but out of state -- where tuition, room, board and other expenses will total $15,500 the first year.
In late November, armed with calculators and a fistful of lethally sharp No. 2 soft pencils with perfect erasers, we confronted the second wave of applications -- to help us manage that amount.
The United States Education Department serves up a big chunk of the nation's financial aid pie (unless the Republicans in Congress get too carried away). This year's portion is $32.5 billion, and it comes in the form of need-based grants, loans and work-study programs. Grants don't have to be repaid, although any amount used for room and board will have to be reported to the I.R.S. and will wind up increasing your adjusted gross income. Loans are available for students and parents, and must be repaid starting six months after graduation at interest rates of 8.25 to 8.98 percent or with no interest. In a work-study plan, jobs are provided through the school and the student is paid directly, or the earnings are deducted from the student's bill. (In both cases the pay is heavily subsidized by the Government.)
The key to just about all aid is a document called Fafsa (eduspeak for Free Application for Federal Student Aid), which is intended to assess how much a student and his parents can afford to pay for his education. It comes in a comic-book-size packet (the only thing comic about it) and is not available on your local guidance counselor's shelves until mid-December. The Government won't accept Fafsa if it is mailed in before Jan. 1; most schools then want the assessments, which are actually done by a Government-designated clearinghouse, in their hands by March 1. A little deadline pressure always enhances quality, I say.
The form we filled out, which the colleges use to divvy up financial aid awards, covered 16 pages, with 12 for instructions. The first time we sat down with our Fafsa, my son and I answered detailed questions for both student and parents on marital status, parental status, military status, resident alien status, education and the like. It was tough, but by this time we thought we were, too.
Then came Section F, with a barrage of inquiries about our earnings, solvency and assets. We scrambled to gather the W-2's, 1099's, tax bills and bank statements we'd need; documents that, for the most part, hadn't even been delivered by our weary mailman. After a couple of hours, we retreated. Fafsa would have to wait until I had completed our 1994 income tax returns.
So would FAF, Fafsa's cousin in the private sector. One of my son's six schools wanted this form, a product of the College Board that, unlike the free Fafsa, cost $15.50 if reported to one school and $10.50 for each additional report.
But even with Fafsa and FAF out of the way, we weren't finished. Each of those six colleges also wanted an even more detailed in-house financial aid application. Essentially, these forms are tools for parceling out the schools' own grants.
Applicants this year, however, will have something different to look forward to. The College Board is replacing FAF with a new form -- the CSF/Financial Aid Profile -- that aims to cover the same territory as FAF as well as eliminate the need for the in-house forms.
But this came too late to ease our frustration. So, feeling that anything was worth a try, we sharpened more pencils and tackled the in-house forms, too.
In the same spirit of desperation, I remember asking a financial aid officer at Southern Methodist University in Dallas whether my son might qualify for one of the school's diversity scholarships, whose aims included insuring "ethnic and cultural variety" as well as "geographic distribution." The financial aid adviser politely pointed out that while it was true that my son didn't exactly fit the profile of the traditional S.M.U. student, New Jerseyans weren't among the groups historically "targeted" for diversity grants.
BUT we did hope to gain points at Purdue University with our response to this question on its aid form: Did my son have a grandfather or great-grandfather who served in the military in World War I? Yes, we answered honestly. After all, it didn't ask in which army, or even on which side.
In the end, the Federal Government offered to lend my son about $2,500 a year with interest and to lend me and my wife the rest, also with interest. He accepted his loan, but we turned down the other. It's probably a good idea for him to have some financial stake in his education, but my wife and I didn't see ourselves still paying for his education for years after his graduation and while we were supposed to be planning retirement.
If we didn't get a sweeter deal from the Government or the colleges, it was probably because we didn't deserve one. So I should stop whining and start figuring how I'm going to finance the next seven years. After all, there's a 15-year-old in my house who'll start college the same year her brother is scheduled to graduate.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FOREST HILLS;
Cuomo Says Lessons Learned On Housing Have Been Ignored

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
For Mario M. Cuomo, mediating the housing project controversy in Forest Hills in the 1970's was a first feature performance on the public stage that he would later dominate over three terms as Governor of New York.
In an interview, Mr. Cuomo said that issues raised more than 20 years ago in Forest Hills have particular resonance now and offer a window into the nation's failure to deal with problems of race and poverty. 
 "Forest Hills describes a situation in Queens that in many ways was a metaphor for the larger situation with race," he said. "Color was the most important thing, and it shouldn't have been. Economic class should have been the most important thing."
Mr. Cuomo, who chronicled his work as a mediator in a book, "Forest Hills Diary" (Random House, 1974), said that New York City found answers in Forest Hills that have been ignored since.
"The idea of a small dose of integration that could be absorbed by the larger community had intelligence," he said. "It's just that they never did it again, anywhere else."
The problem, Mr. Cuomo said, was that most communities were highly resistant to having a mix of economic classes. To illustrate his point, he offered another Queens example.
"At the same time Forest Hills was happening, Baisley Park was happening," he said. "Baisley Park was in South Jamaica, and involved the plan for a low-income housing project in an established stable middle-class community, except that Baisley Park was all black, it was black middle class. And the Baisley Park reaction was at least as furious as the Forest Hills reaction. The point I drew from that is that there is something beyond color here, it's economic class and distinction."
Much of the contention at the Forest Hills Cooperative today involves the question of shareholder rights, with tenants wanting more control over who moves in. Mr. Cuomo predicted the danger of calling a public housing project a cooperative in his book 23 years ago. (The idea was promoted by Borough President Donald Manes to assuage opponents.)
Mr. Cuomo wrote: "One of the aspects of the cooperative that is most appealing to the community is the fact that it provides for a board of directors. . . . It is apparently being commonly assumed that such a board of directors would have the right to make the ultimate tenant selection. . . . I am convinced this is not so and could not be so legally. There is a great danger in not making this clear. . . . I've tried to, but the little publicity given my remarks has been lost."
In the interview, Mr. Cuomo focused on how the book ties into the current problems in housing policy and race relations.
"The most obvious lesson about housing, which everyone refuses to address, is that we made a colossal blunder in insisting that the poor people be stacked one on top of the other in small confined areas," he said. "You have to do everything you can to involve as many people as you can in the circle of opportunity. You can't just keep them out there and live your comfortable existence, wherever it is." D.M.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SHEEPSHEAD BAY;
New Language, and a New Life, for Avenue U

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
When the Rev. Paul Tseng moved the Brooklyn Chinese Christian Church from Flatbush into an old American Legion hall in Sheepshead Bay seven years ago, about 30 worshipers went to his weekly Baptist services. These days more than 200 attend.
"The community changed," Mr. Tseng said last week in his church, on East 15th Street and Gravesend Neck Road. "More Chinese came to buy houses and settle. We have the D and Q train here, which goes to Chinatown. We have stores and restaurants on Avenue U. And we have the church." 
 A growing Chinese population is slowly transforming Sheepshead Bay. Markets selling star fruits, bok choy, won ton skins and fresh fish are cropping up around Avenue U's old Italian salumerias and bagel stores. Video stores rent the latest Hong Kong thrillers. And the Ocean Palace Pavilion -- a marble-fronted, two-story, 300-seat restaurant serving seafood and Hong Kong cuisine -- opened in July to become one of the avenue's largest restaurants.
The area's Chinese population has grown from 2,706 in 1980 to about 10,000 now, according to census figures. And Frank Vardy, a senior demographer with the City Planning Department, said the actual number could be significantly higher. He said many Chinese families are moving to Sheepshead Bay from Chinatown, mirroring the migration of Italians and Jews who moved there from the Lower East Side half a century ago. "It's a pattern," he said.
Many were attracted to Sheepshead Bay by its abundance of one- and two-family houses and its proximity to Chinatown via the D train. Once the first waves came,more followed to join the growing community.
Many of the new Chinese businesses -- along with a growing number of Russian stores -- are being credited with revitalizing the commercial stretch along Avenue U, which suffered economically after the Kings Plaza Mall began drawing shoppers away.
"It's the mom-and-pop types of things that you cannot get at the mall," said John Nikas, the chairman of Community Board 15. "Now you've got specialty shops selling foods and clothes that the mall cannot match."
Brenda Tong, a real estate broker at Century 21, said the influx has helped keep the housing market steady while other neighborhoods have declined. Like many other businesses in Sheepshead Bay, Century 21 has Cyrillic, Chinese and Latin lettering on its awning.
Ms. Tong, who has lived in the area for 24 years, was pleased when stores like the V & H Supermarket opened on Avenue U and East 13th Street to sell everything from snails, live crabs, snow pea tips and oyster sauce to green tea, woks and rice cookers.
"I used to go to Chinatown once a week to go shopping," she said. "Now I go here. They have everything."
There have been tensions. In the late 1980's, a series of racist fliers charged that the Chinese were "smiling at us behind our backs and planning to take over the whole neighborhood." And there have been problems with the gangs that prey on Chinese people all over the city: two years ago the police rescued nine hostages from a Bedford Avenue house after they had been kidnapped by members of the Fuk Ching gang.
But Mr. Tseng, of the church, said that relations have improved and that officers from the 61st Precinct have been helpful. Now Mr. Tseng -- whose church comprises two buildings and a basketball court marked by a sign proclaiming "Jesus Is Lord" in English and Chinese -- is thinking about expanding. His summer day camp has grown so large that he now rents space from Public School 254, on East 18th Street.
 MICHAEL COOPER

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Imagine the Internet As Electronic Casino

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
THOSE searching for insights into what will be driving the post-cold war economy may have got an important, if unexpected clue last week: the Alliance Gaming Corporation announced that it was acquiring Bally Gaming International Inc. for $215 million.
Now some might regard the combination of two Las Vegas companies that essentially manufacture souped-up slot machines as something less than an economic milestone. But Craig I. Fields, a man who knows a few things about the cold war, thinks otherwise, and this merger may prove him right by making high-stakes gambling as easy as flipping on your PC -- despite a raft of policy and regulatory hurdles. 
 Mr. Fields is the vice chairman of Alliance Gaming, but he is better known as the former director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, which financed cutting-edge technologies for the Pentagon. Among the known projects Darpa helped shape was the system now called the Internet.
And that is precisely why last week's acquisition was potentially important: Mr. Fields said Alliance Gaming now hopes to transform a computer network developed to defeat the evil empire into a powerful medium for indulging America's growing weakness for wagering.
"I'm frustrated that I haven't been able to move ahead before this," Mr. Fields said. "I think this is going to be received as an entirely new form of entertainment. The prospects are not modest."
After years of fiddling with electronics as merely a way of enhancing the experience of those who visited casinos, the gambling industry has discovered both people like Mr. Fields and the way to bring casinos to the people -- and into the center of American life, the home.
 
Moral Barriers
 Perhaps equally important, it will also transform those devices into voracious collectors of information about what turns each individual gambler on, how they play, what they play and when they play. These are data that will be used to keep people coming back.
That has been a dream of a variety of visionaries and hucksters, but now some major players may make it a reality. Sega, the high-tech video game company, is entering the gambling business with sophisticated new devices, and other slot-machine companies are transforming their machines and putting them on-line. But only very recently has gambling -- once isolated by government in places like this unlikely oasis of neon and temptation -- been able to enter the mainstream through a slow but dramatic lowering of the country's moral barriers and a steady advance of technology.
"When I was looking around for what I would do next I decided to do something in the entertainment and gaming industries because they're now the greatest users of advanced technologies," Mr. Fields said. "It used to be the defense industry."
If that seems jarring, consider how gambling has grown since the fall of the Berlin Wall. The whole gambling economy, including everything from wagering on blackjack and horse racing to the money casinos spend on alcohol, slot machines and staff, is now estimated at $482 billion a year. The take in casinos alone, about $18 billion last year, is more than the amount consumers spent on movie tickets, theater and music concerts combined. Every state except Hawaii and Utah permit some form of gambling now.
And the industry is organizing as never before both to fend off assaults from the Christian right and to lay groundwork for expansion. This summer it organized its first unified trade group, the American Gaming Association, and chose as its head Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., former chairman of the Republican Party.
"When you build gaming facilities, you're not putting up a factory that's spewing out smoke," said Mr. Fahrenkopf of how the industry is pitching its economic role as clean and family-oriented. "But I'm not an advocate for the industry. My job is to make sure that whoever makes decisions at the state level has the correct facts."
How those facts are presented will be crucial as the gambling interests approach the legal hurdles to playing poker on the Internet, such as barriers against certain kinds of gaming across state lines. In addition, there is not yet a secure means of moving money on-line and, without regulation, gamblers will have to worry whether the electronic casinos are fair in their payouts.
 
Ambiaence Counts
 And there is the not unimportant question of whether gambling in your basement office will be as fun-filled as playing in a garishly lit hall, where the air is filled with smoke and the constant ding of bells, where you can catch a Paul Anka show if you like.
"I believe we have the answer to all those questions," promised Mr. Fields. "I can't talk about the details yet. But I think you'll see some real innovation."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The New Latin Scandals Challenge Democracies

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
FOR the third time in less than four years, Latin America has been riveted by the spectacle of a sitting president being subjected to a Watergate-style investigation that could lead to his impeachment. This time the spotlight is on Ernesto Samper Pizano, President of Colombia, implicated by tape recordings and the testimony of former aides as the knowing beneficiary of $6 million in campaign donations from the Cali cocaine cartel.
It is still much too early to tell whether Mr. Samper can survive the scandal, or whether, like Fernando Collor de Melo of Brazil and Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, he will eventually have to resign. But in any case, as the Brazilian magazine Veja put it, "a strange epidemic seems to be devastating the presidential palaces of Latin America" lately: Ecuador's Vice President resigned and fled the country this month because of a corruption investigation; Peru and Guatemala are seeking the extradition of former presidents to face criminal charges, and former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico has had to take refuge in the United States amid inquiries into his tenure. 
 In the past, violence or political instability have usually accompanied such crises. But there are several remarkable and encouraging things about this new outbreak. In each case thus far, the military, having been weakened by its own recent inept rule and budget constraints, has avoided the traditional response of throwing out the civilians and taking charge itself in the name of restoring order and probity. Even more striking, the disgraced civilian leaders have not tried to suspend their constitutions or legislatures and proclaim themselves dictators. They have simply stepped down.
"This turbulence is actually welcome and should be regarded as a sign that democratic institutions across the continent are maturing," argues Candido Mendes, a Brazilian political scientist. "What we are seeing is absolute obedience to the rule of law and constitutional procedure, and civil society clearly emerges strengthened and revitalized when that happens."
 
I Rule, Therefore I Rob
 In fact, ordinary citizens, disgusted though they may be with their elected officials, have resisted the time-honored tradition of entrusting the national salvation to a caudillo, the kind of autocratic strongman exemplified by Juan Peron of Argentina. Instead, they are demanding that democratic institutions be given an opportunity to function and that their rulers be held accountable for acts of malfeasance and corruption.
That has not always been the case. Back in the 1950's the powerful governor of Sao Paulo state in Brazil, Ademar de Barros, actually campaigned under the slogan "rouba mas faz," which translates as "he steals, but he gets things done." They may not always have liked it, but Latin Americans were accustomed to slipping a small bribe to a government clerk to get some bureaucratic procedure moving, and expected elected officials to routinely skim 10 percent or so off the top of government contracts.
But the colossal amounts of money that have been injected into the region's once-closed economies over the last 15 years, both from drug trafficking and increased foreign investment, have changed the rules of the game. The stakes are much higher, putting the cost of graft out of reach of the average person -- and enabling the small elite responsible for this inflation of corruption to buy whatever it wants.
"Now if you want something done -- say you need to bribe some official to get your papers taken care of -- it can cost you $50,000," said Eduardo Gamarra, a Bolivian who is the director of the Latin America-Caribbean Center at Florida International University in Miami. "This has distorted every parameter of corruption we knew before, and people are outraged by it."
Prompted by growing popular discontent, the 30 heads of state who attended the Summit of the Americas in Miami last December promised to take tangible steps to combat the continental scourge of corruption. A follow-up meeting is scheduled next month in Uruguay, and there are many signs that a vigilant public does not intend to let this opportunity degenerate into just another empty pledge.
Around the region, for instance, investigative journalism is on the rise and chapters of Transparency International, a citizens' corruption-fighting organization, have been springing up. Several countries, including Costa Rica, Colombia and Bolivia, have also established ombudsmen or independent, nonpartisan constitutional tribunals to assume some of the duties that had been performed by Supreme Courts, which are widely seen as politicized, inefficient and crooked.
No single word either in Spanish or Portuguese corresponds exactly to the English-language notion of "accountability," so many of those involved in the movement have simply adopted the English term. In much the same fashion, tens of thousands of Brazilians marched peacefully in the streets in 1992 with banners imprinted with the English word "impeachment." More recently, middle-class Mexicans have banded together in a nonpartisan grassroots movement called "El Barzon" -- named for the leather strap that tied plows to oxen -- to protest economic policies that they say have beggared their nation while enriching a few corrupt leaders.
 
Impunity Dies Hard
 The deep yearning for honest government also helps explain the transformation of an ordinary civil servant like Alfonso Valdivieso Sarmiento, Colombia's chief prosecutor, into a national hero. Mr. Valdivieso, whose cousin, Luis Carlos Galan, was assassinated by the Medellin drug cartel when Mr. Galan ran for president in 1990, is the one mainly responsible for summoning Mr. Samper to testify about possible illegal acts, and for imprisoning other powerful officials, including Defense Minister Fernando Botero Zea.
"Society works out different options of its own and finds its own leaders," explained Maria Jimena Duzan, a columnist for the Bogota newspaper El Espectador and author of "Death Beat," a book about the drug cartels and their penetration of Colombian society. "That's a great change for us, to see big, important politicians in jail. For the first time, we are realizing that impunity is not the only reality we can have here."
There are, of course, still many influential pockets of resistance, as well as frequent indications Latin America's tradition of impunity is not going to die easily. In Chile, for example, Gen. Manuel Contreras, the chief of state security during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, spent years defying the court that sentenced him to prison for masterminding the 1976 murder in Washington of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier. He was finally jailed Saturday.
In societies in which the powerful have always been exempt from the law, simply obtaining an unfavorable verdict against a general or a president -- let alone jailing one -- is a major achievement that engenders optimism. "We are witnessing a qualitative change," Dr. Mendes said. "Now that there is a political consciousness to build on, we must continue and deepen our efforts, and I think we are capable of that."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Presidents together: from left, Armando Calderon Sol of El Salvador, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada of Bolivia, Carlos Menem of Argentina, Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil and Eduardo Frei of Chile. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Service With Some Bile

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
IT may be hard for many Americans to imagine under what circumstances a salesclerk might actually say to a customer, "Stop shouting, can't you see I'm eating?" But in China, it is common for clerks to abandon their post without notice, and to ignore -- or even insult -- customers who happen to come along.
One of the legacies of Communist rule has been atrocious service. For years such workers could justify their laziness by decrying attentive service as bourgeois. They could rest assured they would not be fired for performing badly. Managers, too, had few incentives to motivate their staff to do better. 
 Now market economics are taking over, and with competition emerging, things are changing, even service. But improving service one step up from bad still leaves the customer with pretty bad.
 
How Bad Is It?
 There is a surplus of pretty bad service in any number of Chinese stores, airports and hotels. But a year ago, as part of a nationwide politeness campaign, the Chinese Government began enforcing a strict policy aimed at reigning in the hostility common at the counter. Just a few months ago, it published a list of 50 phrases that are banned from use at any service counter.
"Didn't you hear me, what do have ears for?" is one such forbidden phrase. "Are you finished talking?" is another. Both hint at the animosity that often erupts at the counter.
If one measure of China's progress toward a functioning economy is a program in which store managers actually demand that their staff be courteous, another is how hard it is to change an old system when the authorities rely mostly on a campaign in newspapers.
Still, the publication of a list of 50 officially banned phrases offers a clue to understanding how bad service is, rather than a reflection of any genuine effort to improve it.
"Buy it if you can afford it, otherwise get out of here," speaks to the impatience that salesclerks are loathe to hide. "What can I do? I didn't break it," echoes the reluctance to take responsibility for a store's faulty products.
Wang Dao, deputy office director at Shanghai's Number One Department Store, one of the stores chosen to lead the campaign, said: "These phrases were chosen because they are so common. Otherwise why would we pick them?"
A ban on such phrases is unlikely to work in any comprehensive way, since the authorities who are so good at policing dissidents are not yet as strict in the service industry. The Chinese have become inured to political campaigns, too, knowing they must heed them in the short term but that enthusiasm will wane after a while.
So for now, many salesclerks are at least pretending to treat the politeness campaign earnestly.
"It's very serious," said Lin Gan, a 45-year-old salesclerk at the electronics counter in the Number One Department Store. "We're not allowed to stand around in groups of more than two. We're not allowed to fold our arms. And, of course, we have to watch what we say."
 
A Half-Hearted Effort
 One floor down, however, in the men's garment section, six salesclerks were huddled, all arms folded, chatting away while two customers tried to get help.
"Okay, okay, what do you want?" one salesclerk, Ye Ping, said finally, skating close to one of the banned phrases.
"I've been in this store 38 years," said Ms. Ye after the customer left without buying anything. Queried about her attitude, she replied, "I've worked hard all these years. I don't see why we are always asked to do better."
Mr. Wang said his store was serious about the campaign and enforcing it with fines and dismissals.
How many of his 2,000 clerks have been fired since the store began its strict policy a year ago?
"No one yet," Mr. Wang said.
How many have been fined?
"It's hard to give an exact number," he said,
Mr. Wang added hopefully: "Change is not going to come overnight. It's going to take some time."

HEADLINE: NO DEAL;
50 Years of Droning for Diplomacy

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
IN the annals of the United Nations, this week may be remembered as the one when they installed a traffic light. Not for vehicles or even pedestrians, but for words. At the lectern where a three-day marathon of speeches by more than 140 heads of state and government begins today to mark the United Nations' 50th birthday, there are now green, yellow and red lights to signal speakers to start, slow down and stop after five minutes.
The remarkable gab-a-thon in the General Assembly will highlight the foremost accomplishment of United Nations, though it is one that many of its critics will surely scoff at. That is talk, and lots of it. For half a century, diplomats here like to think, world-class chin music has helped deter global war. 
 In that time, United Nations speechifying has evolved into a genre all its own, marked by exquisite courtesies, lavish praise, grandstanding to televised audiences back home and coded language that conceals all manner of evil intent, and often withholds a fair amount of candor in the interests of a civility not always present in the earliest debates. Speechmaking here today is like those related arts of tedious circumlocution, legalese and bureaucratese, in that often the primary aim is hardly to be concise, frank or provocative at all. And here the stakes are arguably much higher than in the courtroom or office.
 
Greater Numbers
 Inserting a stopwatch and a five-minute rule into this process today (when Presidents Clinton, Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Fidel Castro of Cuba are scheduled to speak) will be an interesting experiment. This is the chamber where for half a century the powerful have indulged themselves for hours on the sounds of their own voices and where an African diplomat, Abdul Salim Salim of Tanzania, once danced on the desktops to celebrate an American humiliation over the expulsion of Taiwan. But theatrical or just long-winded, debate has rarely produced a historic breakthrough.
The need to put the brakes on speeches arises not because they are getting longer or more outrageous -- in fact they have shrunk substantially and been tamed since the United Nations' early years. Numbers are the cause of today's crisis. In 1945, there were 51 members nations; now there are 185. All their leaders or stand-ins, plus a score of other world figures, are on the speakers' roster over the next three days.
To Betty Teslenko, the five-minute limit may be something of a blessing. Ms. Teslenko, now 73, has been taking dictation in the Assembly since 1945, and she thinks the quality has dropped precipitously in the age of television and speechwriters.
"In the early days, the debates were really very wonderful," she said. "There was less text and more extemporaneous debate. There were real orators here."
"Abba Eban was one of the really great ones," she said of the Israeli statesman. "He and Mohammed Fawzi Bey of Egypt had some wonderful debates and witty exchanges." She also recalls the verbal dexterity of Adlai E. Stevenson, who served under President John F. Kennedy, and the acerbic Krishna Menon of Egypt, who once actually collapsed during a Security Council speech but revived himself and carried on.
Armed with her steno pad, Ms. Teslenko not only wrote down what all these people said, but also sometimes smoothed over the words to save someone embarrassment.
"We're called verbatim reporters, but that's a bit of a misnomer," she said, recalling a speaker dwelling on South Africa under apartheid. "He said that guerrillas 'go out and expose themselves in the bush every day.' That's not what he meant." When the text came out, she had neatly rendered the troublesome phrase "exposing themselves to danger."
 
The Tumult of '60
 The General Assembly's most memorable session was indisputably 1960, when a new world was being born of decolonization and revolution and emotions ran high.
"It was an extraordinary time," said William J. vanden Heuvel, then an aspiring New York politician who would later become the United States permanent representative at the United Nations. He was one of the only two envoys ever to be physically assaulted on the job here, when Trotskyites from California burst into the Security Council chamber and covered him and his Soviet counterpart, Oleg Troyanovsky, with red paint. As Mr. vanden Heuvel tells the story, Mr. Troyanovsky's reaction was, "Better red than dead."
The 1960 Assembly session is best remembered for Mr. Castro's four-hour speech and for Nikita S. Khrushchev's explosion after a Filipino delegate, Lorenzo Sumulong, suggested that a Soviet resolution on decolonization should also cover the peoples of Eastern Europe. Mr. Khrushchev turned on Mr. Sumulong, calling him "this toady of American imperialism."
The Soviet leader marched angrily up to the podium, then back to his seat, took off his shoe, waved it around his head and slapped it on the desk in front of him. In the tumult that followed, the Assembly President, Frederick Boland of Ireland, broke his gavel trying to restore order.
Today, speeches always begin with kudos to the chair: "Mr. President, I am confident that your high competence and profound experience will contribute effectively to the success of the work of the present historic session," the Foreign Minister of Iraq, Mohammed Saeed Al-Sahaf, said to Diogo Freitas do Amaral of Portugal when debate began in September. Ditto almost every other Foreign Minister to take the stand.
Then the thanks to last year's presiding officer: "To your distinguished predecessor, His Excellency Mr. Amara Essy of Cote d'Ivoire, I should like to convey our deep appreciation," began Ali Alatas, Foreign Minister of Indonesia.
Relevant generalities follow: "A 50th anniversary is a climacteric, usually joyous but not necessarily so," said Pranab Mukerjee, India's Foreign Minister. "In ancient India this is around the time in a man's life that he would be expected to withdraw into a forest."
A few pages into the speech, the meat arrives. It might be a defense of a country's policies, a don't-touch-us warning, a plan for righting the world's economic or social wrongs or a broad commitment to noble causes.
At the end, let phrases ring: "History moves on," Qian Qichen of China said. "Mankind is progressing."
Colin Keating, New Zealand's representative here, said the greatest tragedy that has befallen the General Assembly in half a century is that its once-electric, off-the-cuff give and take has been replaced by made-for-television performances. On many days, the Assembly hall is all but empty as speaker after speaker drones on to the cameras. The business of the Assembly has shifted to committees and working groups.
"Delegates don't do much listening to what anyone else says," he said. "They charge in and give a speech and then charge out again. To a large extent now, the speeches are for a domestic audience."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
When Spies Look Out For the Almighty Buck

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IMAGINE you are in the White House, drawing up a list of hot spots abroad where the nation's intelligence agencies should be nosing around. A few things to watch are obvious: Serbian troop movements, the Iraqi and North Korean nuclear programs, and China's military maneuvers off Taiwan's coast.
But does it make sense for the Central Intelligence Agency to leap on the rumors -- which flew through Wall Street and Washington last week -- that a major Japanese bank might be about to go under? If it happened, such a collapse could set off a cash crisis that could circle the globe in minutes, requiring the Federal Reserve to pump billions of dollars into the system to prevent what the Treasury Department delicately calls "a contagion effect." 
 With the Japanese Government unlikely to volunteer much information, learning the truth could require waging a surveillance campaign against Japan -- America's most important political friend in the Pacific -- with the same ferocity as is customary against a military opponent. It is a mystery whether the United States might be turning its elaborate spying equipment, some of it in Japan, on conversations between Japanese bankers and the Ministry of Finance. But many Japanese officials now believe it is likely.
And that raises a question few in the Clinton Administration or the intelligence community are willing to discuss openly: Is the economic advantage gained by such surveillance worth risking America's already rocky relationship with Japan?
Or with so many in Washington officials repeating the mantra that economic security and national security are now synonymous, is such spying to be expected?
The question of how far to go to secure American economic interests is especially sensitive in Washington these days, after revelations that the C.I.A. listened in on the conversations of Japanese negotiators during heated automobile talks last spring -- one example of what has quietly become routine practice. Japanese officials (who are among the world's premier practitioners of economic espionage) feigned shock and demanded explanations. The Administration, preparing for President Clinton's visit to Japan next month, responded that it wanted to think about its response.
There is nothing new about spying on allies: Just ask the Israelis. Nor is assessing the economies of friends and enemies a new C.I.A. task: Its analysts spent four decades tracking the Soviet Union's industrial capability and the better part of last year peeling back the layers of Mexico's financial balancing acts.
Still, the elevation of commercial interests to what Secretary of State Warren Christopher calls "the very top of our foreign policy agenda" has deepened the agency's clandestine economic intelligence-gathering.
"The question is the tradeoff," said Philip Zelikow, a former career diplomat now at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard who is completing a study of the changed world of economic intelligence. "You have to ask whether this stuff is worth the candle, or could you get to the same conclusions by massaging public and 'gray area' information. And then you have to balance it against other political interests."
Mr. Zelikow and many members of the Clinton Administration say that the balancing is ad hoc at best, and usually does not happen at all. During the car talks the C.I.A. was on autopilot: It was assumed that the Japanese, in the absence of eavesdropping satellites of their own, were using every other means to scope out the American position (including taking American journalists out to endless lunches), and that the United States should use every means at its disposal to do the same. Nor was there much discussion about the merits of spying against France on the GATT talks. There should have been; when the C.I.A. blundered, France asked the station chief and his underlings to leave, and intelligence liaison was suspended.
Despite such incidents, so far nobody has worked out a system for insuring that there will be debate on the merits of an economic spying mission aimed at an ally. "We're quickly learning," one senior Administration official said this week, "that we have to think through what is appropriate and what is not."
 
An Intelligence Flood
 The issue has crept up on the Administration because in just a few years, what had been a trickle of economic intelligence about Japan, Germany, France, Britain and others has turned into a torrent. Every day the Treasury, the United States Trade Representative's Office and the Commerce Department receive raw and digested intelligence on everything from France's position on letting more Hollywood movies into the European Union to the blandishments that foreign governments offer Indonesia's ministers for a slice of its boom in power generation.
The intelligence agencies, eager to prove that their $28 billion budget is as vital to American security as it was in the days of counting Soviet missiles, are more than happy to oblige. Their problem is "adding value;" in many cases, including the Japanese banking crisis, a wealth of data is already publicly available. Now, almost by default, the agency has become the integrator of the public and the secret.
"The fact of the matter is that the intelligence agencies are the center where all this is put together -- the economic, the political and the security concerns," said Robert B. Zoellick, a former top State Department official who handled much of the economic portfolio in the Bush Administration. "And perhaps that makes sense, because they should have more detachment than the individual economic agencies would."
Some, including traditionalists in the agency, say this is no way for a superpower to spend its intelligence resources. Winning a contract in China, they argue, will never be as central to national security as keeping Pakistan and India from a nuclear war.
But more and more, policy makers are echoing the view of Jeffrey E. Garten, who just left his job as Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade to become dean of Yale's school of management. He made the case that economic interests are still subordinated to political concerns too often -- even in this White House -- out of a fear that the United States not be seen to be using its muscle for "crass mercantilism, unworthy of a great power and especially a lone superpower."
"That's the wrong way to look at it," he concluded. "If America can exercise effective commercial diplomacy, its authority and leverage will be much more substantial, not just in the economic realm, but across the board."
Such logic would lead to the conclusion that if the economic stakes are high enough, it may make perfect sense to turn the nation's satellites on Japanese bankers. The problem is how to explain it to the Japanese when it all becomes embarrassingly public, as this sort of thing inevitably does. The State Department is still working on that one, and no one expects it to have a convincing answer any time soon.
