HEADLINE: Adviser Who Has President's Ear Thrived as Anti-Clinton Strategist

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
If Republicans are looking for a guide to explain how to defeat President Clinton next year, they need look no further than the President's chief political strategist, Dick Morris.
Republican politicians and campaign strategists who have worked closely with Mr. Morris in campaigns around the country recounted in interviews that only months before he emerged as a prominent player in the White House, he openly and forcefully ridiculed Mr. Clinton's personal conduct and policy stands -- and advised his clients about how to seize on the President's vulnerabilities for their own campaigns. 
 It is widely known that Mr. Morris has had a long and sometimes tense relationship with Mr. Clinton, beginning with his first campaign for governor of Arkansas in 1978, and that Mr. Morris has since divided his loyalties between Democrats and Republicans. But the extent of Mr. Morris's criticism of Mr. Clinton has never before been documented.
In a speech he proposed for a Republican candidate running last year, for example, Mr. Morris wrote that Mr. Clinton's military budget cuts "make our military a joke," that his economic stimulus package "funds Alpine slides in Puerto Rico and warming huts for swimming pools in Connecticut" and that Americans "don't want gays in the military."
Asked if the White House was troubled by Mr. Morris's past comments about Mr. Clinton, his press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said: "I can't honestly say whether that will be of concern to the President. The President prefers an environment where there is a free give-and-take, but he prefers that that occur privately."
The proposed speech was written by Mr. Morris for Jim Smith, who was Secretary of State in Florida when he ran in the Republican primary for Governor in 1994. Mr. Smith's campaign manager, Brian Ballard, said Mr. Morris had urged him to contrast his candidate's experience as a prosecutor with the ethics controversies swirling around Mr. Clinton.
"He said, 'Let's use the Bill Clinton analogy,' " recalled Mr. Ballard, a chief of staff to former Gov. Bob Martinez. "He really thought Whitewater was going to be an issue that sucked the President up. He said all the happenings of the Rose Law Firm were going to destroy Bill Clinton's Presidency. He said he knew some things going on that weren't out yet. When I heard he was working for Bill Clinton, I was shocked."
The thrust of Mr. Ballard's recollections was corroborated by 10 other people, most of whom spoke on the condition that they not be identified. They also described conversations with Mr. Morris in which he criticized Mr. Clinton, often for his personal conduct.
Mr. Morris may even have had a favorite candidate for President in 1996 -- and it was not Mr. Clinton. Several close advisers of Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts said Mr. Morris, while working on the Governor's re-election campaign in 1994, had frequently encouraged the idea that Governor Weld, a centrist Republican, run for President in 1996, stressing his background as a Federal prosecutor and contrasting it with Mr. Clinton's ethical troubles.
"Dick always felt strongly that the Governor had great Presidential potential," said Ronald Kaufman, a White House political director in the Bush Administration who is close to Mr. Weld. "In a very analytical way, he would talk about the race and the perceived problems the incumbent has based on his performance and some of the perceived problems that arose out of Whitewater." But Mr. Kaufman disputed others who said Mr. Morris had been out to do in Mr. Clinton, saying, "I would classify it as analytical versus critical."
Whatever the motive, Mr. Morris's advice to these candidates raises questions about the allegiance of the man whom Mr. Clinton has turned to for advice on how to respond to the Republicans in Congress and how to plan his re-election.
In an interview on Friday, Mr. Morris insisted that he had never traded on inside information about the Clintons or made disparaging comments about their ethical behavior. And he disputed the accounts from people close to Mr. Weld that he had counseled the Governor to run for President.
"I never questioned President Clinton's ethics and never urged anyone to run against him in any election," Mr. Morris said. "On the contrary, I have specifically refused on several occasions to become involved in campaigns against Clinton because of my loyalty and respect for him."
He added, "These allegations are a collection of hearsay gossip -- largely from Republican political operatives who are trying to hurt President Clinton."
Mr. McCurry said today that Mr. Morris was a valuable adviser to the President. "The up and down relationship of Bill Clinton and Dick Morris has been well chronicled," he said. "But there is no question that Mr. Morris helps the President advance the argument the President is making to the country about his policies."
Governor Weld brushed aside suggestions that Mr. Morris had urged him to run. "I've always felt that Dick Morris was a brilliant strategist and a pro," he said, "and nothing has caused me to see fit to change my opinion."
Many current and former associates of Mr. Morris, who is 47, agreed that he was a sharp political strategist who has helped the President in recent months by pulling him toward the right on many issues. But they also said his performance had been erratic, and several asserted that he had worked for so many candidates of such different ideologies that they could not trust him. Some said they had been put off by the way Mr. Morris would talk about Mr. Clinton.
Brose McVey, who was campaign manager for the re-election drive of Senator Daniel R. Coats, Republican of Indiana, in 1992, said that he had dismissed Mr. Morris before the end of the campaign. He said Mr. Morris had often spoken disparagingly of Mr. Clinton and suggested that Mr. Morris had been trying to demonstrate that he was loyal only to Republicans.
"There seemed to be this fascination with Clinton that followed Dick wherever he want," Mr. McVey said. "There was an effort for Dick to beat up on Clinton in order to validate his conversion. He was motivated to treat Clinton like the Antichrist." He added, "Most of the chats about Clinton went to issues of his personal life."
One example of Mr. Morris's anti-Clinton counsel comes from the speech he drafted for Mr. Smith, who lost in the Republican primary for Governor of Florida last year. Mr. Morris was never formally hired by the campaign, but he proposed the speech as a sample of his strategy should he come on board.
The speech indicted the central themes of the first half of the Clinton Administration, with Mr. Morris building the oratory around the notion that neither Mr. Clinton nor Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, would be re-elected. The tone of the speech is the opposite of the praise Mr. Morris showered on Mr. Clinton on Thursday night at the McManus Midtown Democratic Association in Manhattan, when he called the President a "genius" and said that "meeting with him is the most daunting experience you can have."
In the sample speech, Mr. Morris wrote: "These stellar forces which are helping our Republican Party grow and strengthen are, of course, President Bill Clinton and Governor Lawton Chiles. Bill, Lawton, we couldn't have done it without you!"
Continuing the Clinton-Chiles theme, Mr. Morris wrote that they would "discover that America and Florida knows that higher taxes don't close deficits, they cause them."
"They are going to discover that America and Florida knows that we shouldn't stop providing good health care just to provide universal health care," the speech continued.
"They'll learn that we don't want gays in the military," it said. "They'll learn that we don't want a state that spends a third of its education dollars outside the classroom or a nation that funds Alpine slides in Puerto Rico and warming huts for swimming pools in Connecticut and calls it a stimulus program. They'll learn that we won't accept defense cuts that make our military a joke. They'll learn American values and common sense."
He went on: "The only difference is the date of their graduation. Bill Clinton will complete his course of study when he is defeated in 1996. But Lawton Chiles is on an accelerated course. He's going to learn his lesson in November 1994!"
Asked about his proposed speech, Mr. Morris said: "When I work for a client, they tell me what they want to say and I say it for them. They're not my opinions; they're the client's opinions. That was reflective of Jim Smith's opinions, not mine. I'm not running for Governor -- he was."
But Mr. Ballard, Mr. Smith's campaign manager, said that he had rejected the speech outright because he had wanted to focus on themes relating to the rival Republicans, not to the President. "That was an unsolicited speech," Mr. Ballard said. "He wrote it on his own. Not only was it not Jim Smith's style or Jim Smith's thoughts, it was never delivered by Jim Smith."
While Mr. Morris has maintained an on-again, off-again relationship with the Clintons for years, it is unclear how much he saw or spoke with the President when he was advising Republican campaigns in 1992 and 1994. But Champ Terney, a Republican lawyer in Jackson, Miss., who is close to Mr. Morris, said that he was one of the few people who knew that Mr. Morris was advising the Clintons during the turbulent Democratic primaries in 1992 -- at the same time he was working for the 1994 re-election campaign of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi and other Republicans.
Mr. Terney said that Hillary Rodham Clinton had made the initial overture but that Mr. Morris had kept it quiet out of fear of angering his Republican clients.
"He called me one day four years ago and said, 'Champ, Hillary Clinton called me to come to Little Rock,' " Mr. Terney said, speaking of Mr. Morris. "He said, 'I've talked to Trent, and he said it's O.K. I'm going to be involved behind the scenes.' "
Mr. Terney, the son-in-law of the late Senator James O. Eastland, a Mississippi Democrat, said that at the time, Mr. Clinton had been confronted by allegations that he was a womanizer and that he had dodged the draft. "They were involved in a hot political campaign," Mr. Terney said. "They realized they had problems. And they feel secure with Dick and his political judgment."
Some Republicans say they will never forgive Mr. Morris for telling them he had forsaken Mr. Clinton and the Democrats, only to become the President's leading political adviser.
"My biggest beef is that he told us a baldfaced lie," said Allan B. Hubbard Jr., who was deputy chief of staff to Vice President Dan Quayle and worked with Mr. Morris in Senator Coats's campaign. "When he came to work for Coats, we had a candid conversation. He said, 'Look, I've gone both ways. I realize now that was a mistake. I will never, never work for a Democrat again.' He repeated it as forcefully as he possibly could."

HEADLINE: Shannon Hoon, the Lead Singer Of Blind Melon, Is Dead at 28

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Shannon Hoon, a singer and songwriter whose band, Blind Melon, shot to the top of the charts in 1993 with their eclectic single "No Rain," died today. He was 28.
Mr. Hoon died on his tour bus, said Sgt. Marlon DeFillo of the New Orleans police. His band members apparently could not wake him and called the authorities. 
 Sergeant DeFillo said Mr. Hoon, a native of Lafayette, Ind., died about 1:30 P.M. The bus was parked in a parking lot at the time. The sergeant said that there was no sign of trauma, and that the cause of death remained unclassified pending an autopsy.
The band, based in Los Angeles, was in New Orleans to play at Tipitina's, a music club. In Los Angeles, a security guard at Capitol Records, the band's record company, said that no one was available to comment.
After mixed reviews of the band's appearance at Woodstock '94, the group had been beset by personal problems. Mr. Hoon had been arrested for drunken and disorderly conduct in New Orleans during the recording of the band's second album, "Soup."
On stage, Mr. Hoon was wildly emotional, spinning around his microphone stand in bare feet and sometimes shedding his clothes. His high-pitched voice was described by a critic for The New York Times as "a vintage whine" that sounded like "Neil Young after a coughing fit," as he sang with desperation of the uncertainties of youth and the fears of entering adulthood.
The band, which mixed trappings of 1960's psychedelia with rural rhythms, got its name from neighbors of the group's bassist, Brad Smith. They were unemployed hippies in Mississippi who called each other "blind melons."

HEADLINE: One Campaign Over, Another to Begin?

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 20

 BODY:
With two appearances in this Navy town today, Gen. Colin L. Powell completed the last lap of his book-signing tour -- 29 events in 23 locales in 20 days -- without getting writer's cramp, losing his voice or dropping any easy clues about two questions on the minds of his admirers and putative Presidential rivals: Will he run for President in 1996? And if he does, what's his raison d'etre for wanting to move into the Oval Office in 1997?
For the umpteenth time since his book tour began, General Powell said today that he intended to spend the coming weeks deciding whether to run for the Presidency or to opt for some other form of service to the nation. The General's mulling-things-over posture, however, has not deterred campaign professionals from acting as though it is a fait accompli that he will run. Some professionals have reached out to General Powell's friends and advisers, including Ken Duberstein, a White House chief of staff for Ronald Reagan, for advice on joining a Powell campaign. 
 During the weeks General Powell crisscrossed the country, interest in him and his Presidential ambitions never flagged. All of his final stops -- Atlanta on Thursday and Norfolk today -- drew long lines of book buyers. If anything, some of the major news events of recent weeks -- O. J. Simpson's acquittal on double-murder charges and the Million Man March -- have only heightened interest in the retired general's grasp of domestic issues and have led local television news reporters to ask constantly for his analysis of the nation's racial problems.
Generally throughout the book tour, General Powell espoused centrist ideas that seemed to resonate with moderate Democrats, moderate Republicans, independents and some G.O.P. conservatives.
The retired general's admirers, of course, and those shopping around for an alternative to the current cast of candidates were more than willing to explain why they felt he might be Presidential timber. The Powell loyalists and the Powell browsers who lined up early this morning at the Norfolk Navy Base's main retail exchange and later this afternoon at Prince Books and Coffee House were pleased to have the retired four-star general sign their copies of his book, "My American Journey."
"Colin Powell is a very good man," said Janice Van Houweling, an employee of the base exchange who gained a spot among the first 20 in line by camping out at 4 A.M. "I'd like to see him run for President. He has the same beliefs I do on abortion, gun control and crime." Her issues checklist does not mean that she is a classic liberal. She said she was a registered Republican -- "an open-minded" one -- who voted twice for Ronald Reagan and for George Bush in 1992.
As upbeat as one might expect Powell supporters to be, some were concerned about the impact of recent events on his potential candidacy.
"I have a little bit of a problem with the O. J. business," said Dan Westbrook of Jasper, Ga. "I wonder if that's going to take some steam" out of his political future. Mr. Westbrook's friend in line at a book signing, Dick Roy, said that because of the Simpson trial and the march, General Powell will now be "seen as a black man." If there is any negative effect on General Powell's viability as a candidate, Mr. Westbrook said he hoped that it would "blow over."
In interviews in a Detroit suburb, around Atlanta and here, this self-selected but racially and economically diverse slice of American book buyers and voters articulated similar reasons for wanting General Powell to run. His centrist views on most issues, according to these people, could make him the great moderate hope in Republican primaries -- a man who could galvanize party moderates and woo a significant slice of Republican conservatives like the Rev. Tim Mowry of Traverse City, Mich., and Mr. Westbrook.
A Vietnam veteran and the owner of a small chemical company, Mr. Westbrook said he wanted General Powell to run as a Republican. "I hope he does," he said as he stood near the front of the book-signing line inside the cavernous Sam's Club in Duluth, Ga., on Thursday morning. "Politically, I'm a pretty staunch Republican, a very hard-shell Republican." He said General Powell's moderate views did not scare him off. "He's a little more moderate on certain things," he said. "I think he's a fine outstanding man. It's hard to put into words what he exemplifies."
General Powell's performance during the Persian Gulf War, Mr. Westbrook said, restored his pride in military service. "A lot of people are trying to be everything to everybody," he said. "And Bill Clinton represents the fact that that's hard to do. Maybe there is room for a middle-of-the-road Republican."
Mr. Mowry, a conservative Lutheran minister who said he had attended every Republican Presidential inauguration since 1969, organized his day Wednesday so that he and his wife and two children would be near the head of the line at the Barnes & Noble in West Bloomfield, an affluent suburb outside Detroit.
"Colin Powell is not as conservative as I am," Mr. Mowry said. "But the fact that he is an ethical man and a moral man goes a long way with me." Mr. Mowry said he did not know whether General Powell would be trounced in Republican primaries dominated by conservative voters. "He doesn't have to come across as being extremely conservative," said Mr. Mowry. "If he runs an inclusive campaign, he'll do well. He'd be a shoe-in for vice president on anybody's ticket."
Even those who are squarely in General Powell's corner wonder about a moderate's chances of prevailing in Republican primaries. "I would prefer it if he would run as a Republican," said Roy McGinn, a Navy electronic technician stationed in Norfolk. "But I'm worried that because of some of his stands he won't win. There are too many conservative Republicans who might try to squelch him."
Staunch is not exactly the word Paula Leach would use to describe her brand of Republicanism. In recent Presidential elections, Mrs. Leach voted for Ronald Reagan twice and George Bush twice but calls herself an independent Republican, and she said she was eager to see General Powell run. "He's a very independent thinker and no one is going to push him into something he doesn't want to do," said Mrs. Leach, of Rochester Hills, Mich., who has a son in the Army. "I have more respect for Colin Powell than for other political figures."
During stops in the Midwest and the South this week, General Powell's remarks in brief "press availabilities" suggested that he had not become intoxicated by all the attention that he and his book have received. In West Bloomfield, he said that he would never confuse the popularity he enjoyed with the political ratings citizens give elected officials. And he has reminded the press at almost each stop that running for President is not his only option.
Whether it is winning the hearts and minds of a thoughtful conservative like Mr. Westbrook or attracting the attention of a disgruntled Democrat, General Powell must now figure out whether his appeal among some voters as the uncandidate can be easily converted into political support, financial contributions and votes for a declared candidate. In essence, whether he is a feel-good flash-in-the-pan celebrity with a hot book or the real thing many Americans say they want, a leader of unassailable character and judgment?
What his admirers often see first is a quintessential role model. "I think he's rational," said Kathleen Davidson, a Smyrna, Ga., resident who was first in line at the Oxford bookstore in a posh section of Atlanta on Thursday. "He embodies the American work ethic." Mrs. Davidson said she admired his life style and family as well. "He appears to be a family man," she said. "I'd prefer it if more of our politicians live it and not just preach it."
In the closing days of his book tour, General Powell has offered no public answer to the other big questions: Where would he take the nation? What's his vision? Since he is the uncandidate, his observations remain broad and sweeping. As close as he comes is the response he offered when asked whether conservatives in the Republican Party viewed him as a liberal for his pro-choice stance and his qualified support for affirmative action. "I'm really not trying to craft a message," he said during a brief news conference in West Bloomfield. "I'm trying to tell people what I feel, what I believe about the issues."
Occasionally, though, General Powell's remarks inch dangerously close to those that would be made by a man on the cusp of entering the Presidential race. Here in Norfolk today, when he was asked if a Robert Novak column about him had stung this week, he opened his response with a classic Powell sound bite and closed his answer with thoughts and phrasing that could foreshadow a run for the White House.
"I haven't gone ga-ga or run into a bunker and hidden," he said. "It's not the first time in my life people have criticized me. I understand that the political world will be one of constant pouring over everything I say, everything I do. And I will have political opponents who will attack me regularly and try to persuade people to follow their ideas. This is part of the great American dialogue; it's called democracy. I fully understand it, and I fully know what I'll be getting into if I join the political debate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gen. Colin Powell was greeted by supporters on Friday in Norfolk, Va., where he wound up his book tour. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: THE DIPLOMATS;
For Many Who Serve, No Room for Pomp

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
The diplomat's typical day begins in an apartment in Rego Park, Queens. Tesfa Seyoum, charge d'affaires for the African nation of Eritrea, then boards the G train to his modest midtown office, where his duties are multiple: debating disarmament or human rights as one of his country's representatives at the United Nations; or typing, filing and answering the phone.
"That's the routine," said Mr. Seyoum. "I am diplomat, administrator, and secretary to myself." 
 Mr. Seyoum is not paid a salary, but a "subsistence allotment" of $800 a month (Eritrea's formal representative to the United Nations, who doubles as his country's Ambassador to Washington, receives $1,200 a month). Mr. Seyoum's wife babysits for extra income; his children attend public school. And his sense of economy is such that his business cards, printed with a misspelling of his name, have all been self-corrected in pen.
The Eritrean diplomat's spartan, constrained life is far from the exception among the men and women assigned to the United Nations from around the world. Of the 185 nations with representatives at the U.N., nearly two-thirds are categorized as economically underdeveloped. For most of those nations, there are no limousines, no elaborate fetes, no casual arrogance about unpaid bills or parking regulations. They don't make for easy stereotypes.
And so in the pomp and security attending the arrival of world leaders for the United Nations' 50th anniversary, it may go largely unnoticed that many of the diplomats for the poorer countries live in Queens or Staten Island, occupying a circumscribed world of long hours, shared fax machines and monthly dramas about whether the money from back home will arrive. Their spouses usually work; their health insurance coverage, State Department officials say, is typically nonexistent. The unpretentious ordinariness of the lives of these diplomats -- offset slightly by tax breaks and a certain immunity from bill collectors -- can be measured in myriad ways.
A diplomat from Laos, unable to support his family here or pay for airfare, hasn't seen his relatives in three years. While eager to say she is living out a dream, Consuela Maria Maas, first secretary at the Honduran mission, lacks health insurance and is so busy that she's lucky to make it home to Astoria one night a week to cook a meal. The ambassador from the Republic of Georgia, short of hard currency from his beleaguered Government, said he once had to personally borrow money from a friend to pay his staff. Dornella Seth, a diplomat from Antigua who lives in Co-op City in the Bronx, said her country had staged but one reception in the last six years.
Zaire, unable to withstand the monthly financial hemorrhage caused by Manhattan office rents, decided to combine its official mission with its U.N. diplomat's residence in North Caldwell, N.J. Diplomats from the Maldives, who live doubled-up in an East Side apartment, have not moved their official car from the United Nations garage since July. The delegate from Rwanda arrived at his country's official residence in Bronxville last year only to discover that his predecessor had left and taken the bed, television and refrigerator with him.
All of this, of course, is set in contrast to, say, the French Mission. France has more than a dozen diplomats and another three dozen support workers assigned to its mission at One Dag Hammarskjold Plaza. Its United Nations representative occupies a Park Avenue duplex, and many of the lesser officials live in apartments across the city that the country owns.
Robert Moller, a counselor to the United States Mission to the United Nations, said certain financially struggling missions use a rotating cast of office workers, paying them low wages, but assuring the low-level foreign diplomats of continued legal status. And he said the problem regarding health insurance had grown so great that talks were being held with Beth Israel Medical Center about establishing what he called "a diplomatic H.M.O." The Georgian mission to the United Nations is housed in a small office on the ninth floor of the old Soviet Union compound on 67th Street. The Russians allow them to stay for free; there is one copying machine; U.N. memoranda are stacked on the floor. Most of the staff of five live in the Bronx.
"We are a poor country," said Peter Chkheidze, the Georgian Ambassador. "Most of my calls to other diplomats begin like this: help us, please."
Domingos Ferreira, head of the United Nations mission for Sao Tome e Principe, off Africa's western coast, knows how capriciously the diplomatic life here can turn. When the cocoa export business went bust, his country sent home his fellow diplomats, and he sent his wife and children back as well. Things got so bad that he moved from Hackensack, N.J., to Roosevelt Island in Manhattan, to avoid the cost of daily bridge tolls.
"I feel embarrassed sometimes -- before my landlords, before the U.S. Government," said Mr. Ferreira. "I have enough salary to survive. Rich is out of the question."
Like Mr. Ferreira, the Eritrean, Mr. Seyoum refuses to complain about his less than sumptuous diplomatic life. Eritrea endured 30 years of war before becoming an independent country in 1993. The average life expectancy in the northeast African nation is 46 years -- Mr. Seyoum will turn 47 soon -- and the average annual per capita income is $115.
"My life here requires a certain amount of commitment," said Mr. Seyoum, who noted proudly that Eritrea makes its annual payments to the United Nations in full and on time. "But I do not crave luxury."
Daily life at Rwanda's mission to the U.N. is one that combines determination and heartbreak, embarrassment but great pride, too. Manzi Bakuramutsa, the delegate, says people, assuming the worst because of his country's state of bloodshed and deprivation, ask him how he manages. He tells them his driver doubles as clerk, that he sometimes sleeps in his office, that he negotiates hard with the utility companies, and that he has taken loans from other countries.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tesfa Seyoum, charge d'affaires for the Eritrean mission to the United Nations and among the diplomats from poorer countries who lead a modest life in New York, commutes to work from Queens by subway. (William Lopez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Delegates of Labor Gather, Battered but Now Buoyant

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
The nation's labor unions, for years mired on the margins of industry and politics and lately rent by discord, are massing in New York City this week to try to renew themselves.
Four months after an insurgency chased Lane Kirkland from the presidency of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, the federation's national convention will choose as his successor either his longtime deputy, Thomas R. Donahue, or a leader of the coup, John J. Sweeney, in the first contested presidential election in the organization's 40-year history. 
 But far more than the selection of a new face to lead them was on the minds of the delegates as they began gathering this weekend for sessions that do not officially begin until tomorrow. While troubles remain, labor these days is becoming infused with a sense of renaissance, buoyed by union mergers that promise renewed strength; by a new emphasis on organizing unskilled, low-wage workers, a development reminiscent of the earliest days of the American labor movement; by plans to mount aggressive campaigns against Congressional Republicans at the polls next year, and by a movement to open the federation's top ranks to long-excluded women and minorities.
To a large extent, changes like these were probably inevitable if big labor was to survive as a force in the American economy. Even now, its officials worry of its consigning itself to "irrelevance," a term that Mr. Sweeney was the first federation leader to invoke openly.
"That's what this convention is about," he said in an interview. "Our numbers continue to decline. Our political effectiveness continues to decline."
The weeklong national convention is the first for the federation since the Republican sweep last November reduced union partisans in Congress to a small minority. Largely as a result of that sweep, the federation now sees itself as the only remaining sizable institution in a position to speak for American workers and thwart what it calls a relentless political assault on their wages, benefits and longstanding rights, including the freedom to strike or organize without fear of being discharged.
Both candidates for the presidency are Irish-American New Yorkers, groomed in the same service workers' local in the city, but they bring very different credentials to the election, scheduled for Wednesday.
Mr. Sweeney, 61, is head of a union that, during a decade of shrinking membership among unions generally, has doubled in size, to one million, by attracting the low-wage workers that many other unions have ignored. He arrives at the convention, held every two years, claiming the support of unions that account for 55 percent of the votes.
Mr. Donahue, 67, who has been president of the federation since Mr. Kirkland was sent into forced retirement this summer, is the candidate of most small unions and professes support for the entire Kirkland record, which critics say was largely characterized by sluggishness in organizing. Mr. Donahue acknowledges that he is behind in the race but says he hopes to lure more votes his way, and his supporters are looking for fights over rules to let some unions, whose delegates normally vote as unanimous blocks, split their votes.
The sense that the labor movement, which today represents only 15.5 percent of all workers, stands at the dawn of a renaissance has particularly swept many of the bigger and richer unions and is making the convention, at the New York Sheraton, the largest in the federation's history. More than 1,000 voting delegates, most of them representatives of the federation's 78 unions and their 13 million members, will not only elect the new leader but also adopt scores of goal-setting resolutions.
"Whatever the outcome," said Peter DiCicco, a top federation official, "it means change for the better. It puts us on a new track. That's what we're all encouraged by."
Kate Bronfenbrenner, director of labor education research at Cornell University, said: "This is an extremely important moment, not just for the labor movement but for the country. This could be a point of regeneration, depending on whether they're able to live up to their goals and platforms."
Daniel J. B. Mitchell, a labor economist at the University of California at Los Angeles, said that given the 20-year erosion of blue-collar wages and benefits, along with layoffs and the proliferation of temporary and part-time jobs, "there's a ferment out there for somebody to capture."
"Unions," he said, "have to find a way of seizing that issue."
Mr. Sweeney's Service Employees International Union is one that already has, Professor Mitchell said. "They organized 8,000 janitors around Los Angeles," he said. "You just don't see gains like that these days."
Such experts say the very contesting of the presidential election is a sign that the house of labor enters this convention on the threshold of real change after the 16-year tenure of Mr. Kirkland, whose ouster arose from a sentiment within many unions that he could not relate to the rank and file and that he gave little more than lip service to aggressive organizing. His secretary-treasurer, Mr. Donahue, may defend Mr. Kirkland's record, but is nonetheless keeping abreast of Mr. Sweeney in promising change.
Much of the change is already well under way. As in industry, a wave of mergers has swept a union movement eager to consolidate its resources, the better to take on the giant employers that labor accuses of chipping away at the middle-class standard of living the unions won long ago.
The United Steelworkers have just taken over the strike-impoverished United Rubber Workers, and the steelworkers, the United Automobile Workers and the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers have announced that they will form a two-million-member colossus by the year 2000. Two old New York unions, the International Ladies' Garment Workers and the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers, combined this year.
Whatever their differences, Mr. Donahue and Mr. Sweeney are also both committed to a shift in the federation's priorities. That shift entails less emphasis on saving veteran workers' jobs in shrinking industries, instead authorizing increases of as much as tenfold in spending to recruit the millions of low-wage workers in service industries whom most unions have neglected.
Both candidates also promise big increases in spending, staff and training to topple Republican incumbents in Congress in the elections next year. Mr. Donahue says he would throw 500 specially trained workers into 50 Congressional districts starting three months before the elections. In the last elections, he said, only 240 workers joined the campaign, and did so only the month before.
"We're at the point in America where the average worker has to take into consideration what these people in Congress are doing to their jobs," said Gerald W. McEntee, president of the 1.2-million-member American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. "Overtime, pay, health care and workplace safety -- they're all on the table to be taken away from them."
Changes appear imminent in the look of the federation's hierarchy as well. Union ranks today are one-third female and one-fifth black, but nearly all unions -- and the federation itself -- are still led by white men who have spent years in the labor bureaucracy. Once elected president, most cling to office without challenge long past the age when most people retire, fostering an image of themselves as self-satisfied dinosaurs.
But in a resolution to be presented to this convention, Mr. Sweeney is proposing that anyone past 70 be ineligible to run for the presidency that Mr. Kirkland, now 73, had hoped to hold at least until turning 75 and that his mentor and predecessor, George Meany, held to the age of 85. The provision would limit Mr. Donahue, at 67, to two terms of two years each.
Both presidential candidates are also making room for women at the top. Mr. Donahue's running mate for secretary-treasurer, the federation's No. 2 post, is Barbara Easterling, 62, who rose from telephone operator to secretary-treasurer of the 478,000-member Communications Workers of America.
Mr. Sweeney's candidate for secretary-treasurer is a man, Richard L. Trumka, 45, president of the United Mine Workers, lawyer, former miner, passionate orator and the most obvious successor to either Mr. Donahue or Mr. Sweeney.
But running with Mr. Sweeney and Mr. Trumka, for what will become the new post of executive vice president if the convention gives its approval, is Linda Chavez-Thompson, 50, a former illegal immigrant who became vice president of the State, County and Municipal Employees.
Both presidential candidates are also promising to break open the federation's clubby, 35-member executive council, composed mostly of union presidents, to make room for more women and members of minorities and respond to resentment among smaller unions that have been without a voice on it. Mr. Donahue would admit the presidents of all the federation's 78 member unions, while Mr. Sweeney has suggested adding 8 or 10.
Along with these changes, a prominent symbol of union indulgence and target of rank-and-file ridicule will also soon perish: the weeklong retreat in which the executive council and hundreds of staff members have for years partaken each February in Bal Harbour, Fla. The executive council will still gather -- indeed, will do so more frequently -- but plans are for the meetings to be held in cities around the country, not at resorts.
The Kirkland regime had already booked a hotel in Bal Harbour for this winter's meeting. But Mr. Donahue said, "That next meeting will be the last."

HEADLINE: Some Question Match of Gingrich's Words With Actions

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Ever since Newt Gingrich ascended to power in January, he has presented a perplexing profile on the subject of race. He is the white leader of a conservative revolution whose aim is to shrink the Government's role in social welfare and return power to the states, yet he also calls for compassion and preaches the moral imperative of lifting the underclass up from poverty.
Across his 10 months as Speaker, his words have been consistent. When Mr. Gingrich, a fiercely partisan Georgia Republican, was sworn in in January, he credited the "liberal wing of the Democratic Party" for ending segregation. He went on to use that momentous occasion to remind his new flock of "the moral urgency of coming to grips with what's happening to the poorest Americans." 
 And on Monday night, after the Million Man March, he made an impassioned speech to a group of white conservatives: "I don't think any white conservative anywhere in America ought to look at Louis Farrakhan and just condemn him without asking yourself: 'Where were you when the children died? Where were you when the schools failed? Where were you when they had no hope?' "
Mr. Gingrich has stood as a protector of the destitute District of Columbia, and although he opposes quotas, he has not called for an end to affirmative action. Two portraits hang in his office in the Capitol, those of George Washington and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Yet, Mr. Gingrich's critics see an unbridgeable gulf between his talk and his actions. Under Mr. Gingrich's leadership, the House has set about overhauling the nation's landmark social welfare programs -- Medicare, Medicaid, welfare, the earned income tax credit, to name a few -- that critics say will surely increase the hardships of those trying to escape poverty.
"There's a massive contradiction," said Ronald Walters, chairman of the political science department at Howard University. "He set a theme of racial reconciliation and harmony, and yet when you look at his support for the new crime bill and welfare reform and the devolution of power to the local level and the building of prisons, with no emphasis on rehabilitation, and the destruction of HUD and the withdrawal of resources, these are all deleterious to the life of inner-city residents."
One of the starkest displays of the gap between his words and his actions is evident in the case of the District of Columbia. Unlike President Clinton, who made a brief foray into a black neighborhood when he first moved to Washington and made no further public overtures, Mr. Gingrich appeared far more committed. Saying he wanted to make Washington an "urban jewel," the Speaker formed an unusual alliance with Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., a Democrat, and intervened when a House subcommittee proposed to curtail the district's right to self-government.
But last week Mr. Gingrich supported severe budget cuts that city officials did not expect. Mr. Barry, who was not warned or consulted, said that Mr. Gingrich had betrayed their bond of trust and that the cuts would wreak havoc on the city.
At the Million Man March, instead of being praised as the "transformational figure" he likes to present himself as, Mr. Gingrich was harshly repudiated as a force of destruction. The Rev. Jesse Jackson compared him to Bull Connor, the racist Alabama police chief, saying Mr. Gingrich's policies inspired hundreds of thousands of black men to march on Washington last week just as Mr. Connor inspired the legendary march for civil rights in 1963.
Current Republican orthodoxy is perceived as so anti-black that after O. J. Simpson was found not guilty, some pundits predicted that whites angry at the verdict would react by voting Republican and expecting drastic cuts in the social welfare programs.
Mr. Gingrich acknowledged in an interview that he had been unable to convince many blacks that his efforts were sincere. He said they had misperceptions of him, for which he blamed the elite media, white liberals with an investment in the status quo, and "irrelevant" black leaders, including Mr. Jackson and Representative John Lewis, the Georgia Democrat and civil rights warrior, who, he said, were trapped in the "anachronistic" view that Government should transfer wealth from those who create it to those who do not have it.
He said the social programs that his critics wanted to save -- from Head Start and the earned income tax credit to welfare -- had become disasters, but then he suggested that his proposed changes were not all that drastic. It seemed a puzzling comment from a self-described revolutionary whose philosophy is built on transforming what he calls the destructive welfare state into an "opportunity society."
"We are around the edges trimming and manicuring and trying to rethink and modernize these programs, but there is not a single one of the big programs we're touching in a profound way," he said in the interview, which took place on Thursday morning before the House's vote to restructure Medicare, an undertaking that he has previously described as the keystone to the Republicans' plan to balance the budget and hence the centerpiece of the party's credibility.
"This is a long, long way from some kind of Goldwaterite libertarianism that says, 'Let's eliminate all these and let them fend for themselves,' " he said.
He also said that he had ideas about what to do -- re-establish the work ethic, have blacks and whites join in common goals -- but that he did not know how to communicate them.
"There are a lot of things wrong with our message," he said. "There are a lot of things wrong with the way we approach them as a party. If 400,000 people show up because they're dissatisfied with the current system, and we're the replacement for the current system -- had we been the party we should be, we would have found a way to have welcomed the marchers, encouraged the marchers and signed them all up. We'd have said, 'We agree with you; let's change everything.' But we literally don't think like that."
This was the closest he came in a half-hour to suggesting that his approach was part of the problem; mainly, he said his ideas were part of the solution. His basic precept: blacks have to learn to create wealth, not expect it to be transferred passively to them, and to create wealth they have to learn self-discipline.
Roger Wilkins, a long-time civil rights advocate and now a professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., said Mr. Gingrich was both blaming blacks and underestimating them by suggesting that they did not have a work ethic or good values. He also said Mr. Gingrich was ignoring how racism impeded black progress.
"I gave total credence to his words," Mr. Wilkins said. "But as my Grandma used to say, 'Actions speak louder than words.' The Medicare bill will cut the resources severely of the big public hospitals where most of the black poor get their medical treatment. He can praise the end of segregation all he wants, but if he uses his power to cut these public hospitals and make black people sicker, and to cut Head Start and make black and brown and poor white kids less able to compete, I would say those conciliatory words are absolute nonsense." Mr. Wilkins said Mr. Gingrich had no intention of putting on his agenda one of the most crucial issues: jobs for black men.
Mr. Gringrich said one reason blacks had the wrong idea of him was the news media, which he said was engaged in "a continuing, unending disinformation campaign" against him. He said his remark that some children might be better off in orphanages after all else fails was "deliberately, grotesquely distorted into a cheap way to defame me and redefine me."
The second problem, he said, which posed a much bigger challenge for him, is "the old anachronistic black leadership approach," which he described as, "You owe us; we've had a bad history; send the money."
"That is absolutely hopeless," he said. "First of all, nobody will send the money. Second, even if they did, it would just fail because you would not have created the personal discipline and personal responsibility to use the money as an investment."
Mr. Gingrich saw evidence for his solution in the World Series. Black players for one team will not cheer black players on the opposite team, he said, but whites and blacks on the same team will cheer each other.
He said that if blacks and whites can engage in common goals -- improving their schools, ridding their neighborhoods of drugs -- they can help eliminate racism.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2359 words

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: THE CHALLENGES;
The U.N. at 50: Facing the Task of Reinventing Itself

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Imagine an international corporation with 53,589 employees, a New York headquarters, half a dozen regional branches and scores of field offices around the world. Then add a 185-member board of directors, most of whom think the best jobs should go to candidates from their hometowns. Consider that all of this is presided over by a chief executive who is neither elected nor chosen through open competition, recruitment or even in an interview process.
This is the United Nations. 
 On Oct. 24, 1945, within months of the end of World War II, the United Nations formally came into being when its Charter took effect. There were 51 members -- pledged to create a better world, free of "the scourge of war" -- and enough optimism to go around.
This weekend, the largest gathering of world leaders in history -- more than 140 heads of state or government, at last count -- will come together here for a three-day celebration of the 50th anniversary. If the founders believed that they had put catastrophe behind them, the inheritors of their legacy are more likely to fear disaster ahead.
In three days of speeches, each address optimistically limited to five minutes, they are likely to talk about pulling the organization back from the brink of bankruptcy and reinventing it to make it a credible force in the next century.
In no corner of the world except perhaps in the United States is there a lobby for dismantling or significantly weakening the United Nations. For half a century it has served as a manager of disputes and a useful site for the venting and checkmating of East-West hostilities that might have otherwise exploded. Its far-flung empire of agencies and associations became part of daily life worldwide, battling the spread of weapons, disease and unfair labor practices, among other issues.
But there is an almost universal sense that the United Nations is overstretched and still in search of missions and without clear priorities in the post-cold-war world.
When it comes to restructuring, some countries, led by the United States, would like to see the United Nations shrink, while many poorer nations want it to grow, to open more offices, to create more jobs, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said in a recent interview. The developing nations are in a majority.
"The third world is for proliferation, all because of the possibilities of jobs or for prestige," he said. "Poor countries want five offices, not one, because all the nieces and daughters of the President work as secretaries."
In this anniversary year, there is no shortage of reform proposals. In at least half a dozen books and countless seminars, experts and dabblers alike have been writing and talking extensively about how to invigorate, and then pay for, a new-look United Nations.
Among the reforms most often mentioned are enlarging the Security Council, streamlining the General Assembly and its web of committees, consolidating overlapping work by specialized agencies, rethinking the moribund Economic and Social Council (which was intended to deal with human development with the same weight the Security Council dealt with strategic concerns), greater participation by nongovernmental organizations and a more efficient, less political system for selecting a Secretary General.
Undermining the work of the United Nations, moreover, is the absence of modern management practices, said Karl Theodor Paschke, a former head of the German Foreign Ministry who was brought in a year ago as an inspector general. In this environment, former diplomats or other untrained administrators are often put in charge of fractious, multicultural departments that they cannot manage.
In studies over the last year, Mr. Paschke has found that waste, inefficiency and corruption are often the symptoms, not the causes, of malaise in the organization.
There have been no career development programs and few honest employee assessments here, said John L. Washburn, a former American diplomat and an adviser in the Secretary General's office from 1988 until last year.
The key to reform is "personnel, personnel, personnel," he said. Only recently have staff assessments begun to have meaning -- and the shock has led to predictable resistance.
The rapid globalizing of economies and the perception that the world's most threatening problems no longer have national or bureaucratic boundaries should create the right atmosphere for real change in the international system. But when the speeches end, the trouble begins.
With no outside oversight -- apart from that exercised by member nations, which are almost never in unanimity -- no check-and-balance system or grass-roots voters to contend with, the United Nations organization is mostly left to its own devices in bringing about change.
The 185 member nations can hasten or slow the job as national interests dictate. Governments have their own priorities; a clutch of them can stall action endlessly.
It took weeks of negotiations this fall, for instance, to arrive at a ceremonial declaration of commitment to the United Nations' next 50 years.
Battle lines formed over issues like how to define "sustainable" development, which poor countries sometimes interpret as richer ones' telling them how to use their resources, and how far to go in embracing "self-determination," which some nations see as license for rebellion by separatists.
 
Secretary General
Trying to Improve An 'Impossible' Job
 Sir Brian Urquhart, who has spent a lifetime studying the United Nations from inside and out, has described the Secretary General's role as "the world's No. 1 fig leaf and scapegoat," an official easy to fault because his job is all but unworkable.
"If you look at all the things he -- or, we hope, she -- is supposed to do on paper, the job does look impossible," said Sir Brian, a former Under Secretary General and now Ford Foundation scholar in residence. "Just the political side is taking 24 hours a day now."
He and Erskine Childers, a writer on international policy, recommended in a recent study that four deputy secretaries general be created to share the load. The idea caught on briefly, then vanished from the agenda.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali, a scholar of international law and former Egyptian Government minister, became the sixth Secretary General at the beginning of 1992, after the cold war had ended and the future of the United Nations seemed especially bright.
Because his term expires at the end of next year, his future and that of the secretary generalship have been thrown into the wider debate about reform.
But no Security Council member has pressed for debate on the issue. Setting up a selection process formally outside the Council could weaken the Council's political power over the selection -- and over the winner.
Though there is wide agreement that the organization needs a strong leader to make its case and give its bureaucracy a human face, a powerful Secretary General would not be welcome in Washington or other influential capitals.
"There is a serious question whether the main governments want an absolutely perfect Secretary General," said Sir Brian, who is British. But there is no doubt in his mind that the selection process is a "joke."
"Harvard spent 18 months on the search for a president," he said. "For a job like the Secretary General's, which is potentially so important, the world should be the recruiting ground."
 
Security Council
Restructuring Needed but Elusive
 Nothing is talked about more -- or is less likely to happen soon -- than a restructuring of the Security Council, the strategic center of the United Nations, where decisions about peacekeeping, sanctions and other issues of international security are made.
There is agreement on what is wrong: 50 years after its creation, the Council does not reflect the world's diversity, and its five permanent members, with the exception of the United States, are no longer the dominant powers they were in 1945.
Britain and France have lost their empires and have become part of the European Union; Russia, which inherited the seat of the Soviet superpower, is less than it was only a decade ago. And China, holding the seat created originally for the anti-Communist Nationalists, now in Taiwan, uses it defensively, playing little role in international policy-making.
Other nations have become economically or militarily more important, among them the two major defeated nations of World War II, Germany and Japan.
And Italy's United Nations representative, Francesco Paolo Fulci, says, only partly in jest, that if these two "defeated nations" are given Council seats, why not Italy? The Italians have proposed other ways to reform the Council that would not add to the five permanent members.
Larger developing nations -- Brazil, India, Indonesia, Mexico and now South Africa -- are demanding to be heard, as are smaller countries that contribute to the United Nations' work.
The Security Council has 15 seats, with the 10 nonpermanent ones rotated among 180 countries grouped in regional networks. Smaller countries rarely get a chance; larger nations say an occasional appearance on the Council is not enough. A country like Israel, which belongs to no regional caucus, never gets an opportunity to vie for a seat.
What has stalled efforts to make the Council more reflective of a changed world is disagreement over which nations should become permanent members and how large the body should become to make more seats available to the rest.
There are also debates over whether a third category of membership should be created for larger developing nations or regional powers that would enable them to hold seats more often or to become a new kind of permanent member without a veto.
The Clinton Administration was an early supporter of permanent membership for Germany and Japan, and would consider adding a few seats to the nonpermanent ranks.
But in a letter written in August to governments around the world outlining the American position, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate, said a limit of 20 members was "vital to maintain Council effectiveness."
Other nations have argued for 25 or more seats and want the permanent membership to be less dominated by the industrial powers, particularly the Europeans.
A committee appointed last year by the General Assembly was unable to report any conclusions in September and has now been given another year to try to find a consensus.
 
General Assembly
Spidery Network Of Vested Interests
 Mr. Boutros-Ghali was venting his frustration over the subject of United Nations reform in an interview recently. Forget the Security Council, he said; "the real change must come in the General Assembly."
The Assembly, to which all member nations belong and in which other groups like the Holy See or the Palestine Liberation Organization have observer status, was created not only as the center for international debate but also as the organ that can by majority vote amend the United Nations Charter, establish new commissions or departments and close atrophied branches.
The Assembly's committees are nests of political posturing and intrigue as they work on delicate issues from human rights to nuclear disarmament. Nongovernmental organizations focus their lobbying efforts here.
The Secretary General said that since taking office almost four years ago, he had abolished nearly a third of the higher-ranking civil service positions.
But he said member nations of the General Assembly had then created several new departments -- an Under Secretary for Humanitarian Affairs, a High Commissioner for Human Rights and an Inspector General -- that added more jobs.
"I wrote twice to the Assembly asking them to abolish the Trusteeship Council, and still it has not been abolished," he said, referring to the body that oversaw the transition of many former colonies to independent nations. Palau, which became an independent member of the United Nations last year, was its last client.
Diogo Freitas do Amaral, a law professor and former political leader from Portugal who is this year's General Assembly president, says he will try again to close down or transform the Trusteeship Council. He also wants to eliminate some committees and working groups.
"On some issues, we have sometimes five or six or seven subcommittees or groups dealing with exactly the same subjects," he said.
James Gustave Speth, administrator of the United Nations Development Program and the highest-ranking American in the system, says streamlining can be done -- though any change in the "business as usual" atmosphere, where countries can shoehorn their citizens into jobs they cannot perform, is bound to create a backlash.
In two years, Mr. Speth, the former president of the independent World Resources Institute in Washington, has introduced a 30 percent staff cut in his agency to take place over six years, plus new procedures for openness in hiring and promotion.
He has also made staff members personally accountable for losses to the agency. Auditors are working their way through his field offices.
Sir Brian, the former Under Secretary General, said numbers were not the primary problem. He said the portrayal of the United Nations as an overgrown bureaucracy is "grossly overdone."
"I don't think the organization is so much bloated," he said. "It's that you get whole areas of the Secretariat designed for one moment in history that go on into another, and it's very hard to move people out. In fact, parts of the Secretariat are grossly understaffed by national standards."
"The trouble in changing the U.N. is that there is a constituency for almost every document and every part of the Secretariat," Sir Brian said. "Reform plans have always been nibbled to death by diplomatic log-rolling and compromise."
 
 
The U.N. at 50: An On-line History
Articles and photos from The New York Times on the birth of the United Nations in 1945 are available on @times, the Times service on America Online. Software and information: (800) 548-5201.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United Nations doesn't normally fly its members' flags in bad weather, but with world leaders coming to town they were flying high yesterday. (Suzanne Dechillo/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "HISTORY: The First 50 Years"
 As the United Nations has grown from 51 countries in 1945 to 185 today, its mission, its budget and criticism of the way it operates have mushroomed, too. This week, during ceremonies in New York for the organization's 50th anniversary, world leaders are expected to offer prescriptions for molding the United Nations into a more effective force in the post-cold-war era.
 
JUNE 1945: U.N. Charter signed in San Francisco.
 
OCTOBER 1945: U.N. is created as Charter comes into force.
 
NOVEMBER 1947: General Assembly votes to end British mandate in Palestine and, against Arab wishes, partition region between Jews and Arabs.
 
JANUARY 1949: U.N. envoy Ralph Bunche secures cease-fire between new state of Israel and Arab neighbors.
 
MAY 1949: Israel admitted to U.N.
 
JUNE 1950: Security Council calls for force under U.S. command to repel North Korean invasion of South Korea.
 
OCTOBER 1960: During General Assembly debate, Nikita S. Khrushchev pounds shoe on table when a delegate refers to Soviet-controlled Eastern Europe.
 
SEPTEMBER 1961: Dag Hammarskjold dies in air crash on mission to the Congo.
 
OCTOBER 1962: Adlai Stevenson shows photographic evidence of Russian missiles inCuba.
 
DECEMBER 1966: Mandatory sanctions imposed against Rhodesia.
 
NOVEMBER 1967: After six-day war, Security Council adopts resolution 242, laying bases for future negotiations on Israeli-Arab conflict.
 
JUNE 1968: General Assembly approves Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.
 
OCTOBER 1971: General Assembly expels Taiwan and seats China.
 
NOVEMBER 1974: General Assembly bars South Africa.
 
NOVEMBER 1974: Yasir Arafat speaks to General Assembly wearing a pistol.
 
NOVEMBER 1975: General Assembly equates Zionism with racism.
 
MAY 1980: World Health Organization declares eradication of smallpox.
 
SEPTEMBER 1987: Treaty is adopted in Montreal to protect ozone layer.
 
NOVEMBER 1990: Security Council authorized force to repel Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
 
DECEMBER 1991: General Assembly repeals 1975 resolution calling Zionism racism.
 
MARCH 1992: UN peacekeeping forces sent to the former Yugoslavia.
 
MARCH 1995: U.N. withdrawqs from Somalia after fighting famine but failing to impose political order.

HEADLINE: San Francisco Donnybrook Bores Voters

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
With less than three weeks until Election Day, the race for Mayor in San Francisco has turned into a close, tense, verbal dogfight whose snarling, biting personal exchanges belie the city's reputation for laid-back liberalism.
But despite the sharp verbiage, the issues continue to be muddled, and polltakers report that 1 in 4 voters remains undecided -- either confused or turned off. 
 Among the seven candidates on the Nov. 7 ballot are the incumbent, Frank Jordan, a dour, no-nonsense former police chief; Willie L. Brown Jr., the glib, wily, sometimes outrageous former leader of the California State Assembly, and Roberta Achtenberg, a former Federal urban affairs official and a leader in San Francisco's large and politically powerful gay community.
When Mr. Brown jumped into the race after term limits ended his tenure in the Assembly at three decades, it was expected he would run away with the contest, given his standing as one of the nation's leading black political figures, his envious mastery of campaign techniques and fund raising and San Francisco's traditional ready acceptance of outspoken mavericks.
But that has not yet happened. Rather, the race is a dead heat between Mr. Brown and Mr. Jordan, with a second-round runoff likely because Ms. Achtenberg, who formerly served on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, seems to have enough support to prevent either man from winning a majority in the first round.
"You'd think that this would be a great contest because of the city's many economic and social problems and the various backgrounds of the candidates," said Scott Shafer, a San Francisco political consultant who is not allied with any contestant this time around.
"Yet voters are just yawning at the generalities and nasty digs being handed out," he continued. "There's a lot of hot talk from the candidates but not much in the way of hot ideas or hot vision. It's a disappointment and a turnoff."
How do the candidates see it?
"It's a grind like I've never experienced," Mr. Brown said as he wearily left one late-evening community meeting and headed for another, just steps behind Mr. Jordan and Ms. Achtenberg.
"I must have been to 750 functions like this," he added. "But that's what you do in San Francisco if you're going to win. That's what people expect -- face to face."
For all its beauty, charm and laissez-faire approach to life, ethnicity and doing one's own thing, San Francisco has most of the usual problems that beset other major American cities -- red ink, red tape, crime, unemployment, potholes and struggling schools. But the candidates who would clean up all of this tend to spend more time talking about one another's personal shortcomings than about solutions.
Mr. Brown charges that Mr. Jordan is "nice, but completely incapable, a phony."
"This used to be a magical city but in recent years the magic has disappeared," he said during the community meeting, high up in the Twin Peaks section, near the city's southern edge.
Mr. Jordan calls Mr. Brown "Slick Willie" and "a political hustler" and questions whether he would take an interest in governing San Francisco or use the mayoral job as a step to something higher up the political ladder.
"I want to make the tough decisions for San Francisco and I won't worry about stepping stones to some future location," Mr. Jordan told the community gathering.
Ms. Achtenberg, a bit less acerbic, calls Mr. Brown a "failed" legislator and Mr. Jordan a "failed" Mayor.
"Everywhere I go, people want to know if we can ever make our government work, if somebody out there has the ability" she said during the community meeting. "I believe I can. Talk the truth."
The best bet seems to be that, in the end, as originally anticipated, the mayoral contest will be won by Mr. Brown, a former shoeshine boy who escaped the poverty and racial discrimination of his native Texas, became a California lawyer, Assemblyman and then, as Assembly Speaker, perhaps the most influential black state legislator in the country.
Yet because of the large undecided vote it is too early to write off the two other major contenders.
"No candidate has really caught on," said David Binder, an independent San Francisco poll taker. "There's a lot of personal attacking now but not much else, and time is running out."
Since early summer, polls have shown Mr. Brown and Mr. Jordan tied with about 25 percent of the vote each, with Ms. Achtenberg trailing at 15 percent. Another 25 percent is undecided and the obscure rest of the field shares the remaining sliver of the electorate.
If no candidate wins a majority on Nov. 7, a runoff between the top two vote getters will be held a month later.
Political experts say that if the runoff is between Mr. Brown and Mr. Jordan, Mr. Brown would be more likely to gain the Achtenberg voters and win the election.
San Francisco is one of the last great strongholds of liberalism in the country, so all of the candidates are Democrats, save one badly lagging Republican. But though the city is passionately ideological, the Mayor's race is nevertheless technically nonpartisan.
The polls indicate that while Mr. Brown shares some of the hardest core liberal vote with Ms. Achtenberg, Mr. Jordan claims most of the city's moderate voters, along with most of the tiny handful of Republicans. Much of the undecided vote is in the large and increasingly powerful Asian community.
"At this point, Achtenberg is the candidate who is most under the gun," Mr. Binder said. "Even though she has big support in the city's huge gay community, she doesn't seem to have enough overall support to make the runoff. And time is running out.
"For Jordan, the challenge is to make Brown run a poor second the first time around and hope that will provide the momentum to carry a runoff. And that's by no means out of the question since the Jordan supporters are the older, middle-class kind of voters who tend always to turn out, whereas many Brown supporters tend to be younger, poorer and less driven and motivated to vote."
Will Mr. Brown be hurt by the race factor?
"You never really know," said Mr. Shafer, the consultant. "Don't be surprised if the city goes against the bad racial winds now blowing in this country and once again goes its own contrarian way."

HEADLINE: New York Again the Most Unionized State

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
New York has reclaimed its position as the most heavily unionized state, surpassing Hawaii, with a union membership that is nearly double the level nationwide, recent census data show.
Thanks mainly to strong growth among unions for government workers, New York remains one of the few bright spots for a labor movement that has seen membership slide for two decades. 
 Union members made up 28.9 percent of the state's work force in 1994, up from 27.9 percent in 1989, giving New York the lead it last held during the 1970's and early 1980's, according to a study by two economics professors at Florida State University, Barry T. Hirsch and David A. Macpherson. During that same period, union membership nationwide dropped a full percentage point, to 15.5 percent, half what it was in the 1960's. California leads New York in sheer numbers of union members, with 2.19 million compared with New York's 2.05 million. But as a percentage of the total work force, the California figure is just 17.9 percent.
While the New York numbers are welcome news for the A.F.L.-C.I.O, which is holding its annual convention in Manhattan this week, New York's unions have not been immune to the battering that labor has taken nationwide in recent decades. With the loss of manufacturing jobs, management's greater resistance to unions and the explosion of jobs in the hard-to-organize service sector, the percentage of New York workers belonging to unions is down from 32 percent a decade ago.
One way of looking at New York's relatively strong performance is that unionism in the state has declined less than in the rest of the nation. Unionization remains strong not just in government jobs, but also in construction, retail, hospitals and manufacturing.
Labor's dynamism is showing many faces throughout the state. The Buffalo Bills cheerleaders have signed up with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. The Office and Professional Employees Union has applications from close to 1,000 fashion models who want to join a union. That union is also seeking to organize 650 Blue Cross workers in Middletown, N.Y. Deputy sheriffs around the state have recently joined a union, as have more than 3,000 graduate school assistants at the State University of New York.
Labor is also far stronger in New Jersey and Connecticut than in the nation as a whole. In New Jersey, 24.9 percent of the workers were unionized in 1994, including 62 percent of government workers, while in Connecticut, 20.3 percent were unionized, including 65 percent of government workers.
In sharp contrast to the situation in New York, just 3.8 percent of workers in South Carolina belong to unions, giving the state by far the lowest rate in the nation. Other states in which union membership is below 8 percent include Arizona, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Texas and Virginia.
Richard Hurd, a professor of labor studies at the Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations, explained the resilience of New York's labor movement this way: "If unions are relatively extensive in a state, as is the case in New York, they tend to have bargaining power, and that creates a better image in terms of appealing to workers. If unions are strong in a state, workers want them."
The central reason that New York's union membership is so high, labor leaders and scholars say, is that the percentage of government employees in New York who are unionized -- 72.9 percent -- is easily the highest in the nation. That compares with 38.7 percent nationwide. In New York, unlike many other states, virtually all teachers and nonmanagerial municipal workers are unionized.
There are several reasons why New York's government unions, which account for just over half the state's 2 million unionized workers, have outpaced the rest of the nation. They had a head start compared with other states because in the 1960's, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller made New York the first state to pass legislation that fostered collective bargaining in government jobs. The state's government unions have built powerful war chests to organize workers. And the two major political parties -- especially the Democrats -- have long curried favor with unions, providing them with fertile ground for organizing.
Leo Troy, a Rutgers University economics professor who specializes in labor matters, said it was not surprising that New York unions enjoyed a resurgence when Mario M. Cuomo was Governor and David N. Dinkins was Mayor.
"During 12 years of Democratic rule in New York, the Democratic Party and the public sector union movement were almost indistinguishable," he said. "Democrats like Mario Cuomo encouraged the unionization of public sector employees. Not only do they not fight it, but they welcome it."
Some labor leaders fear that government-job unionism may have crested, because of the election of Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who are committed to shrinking government in fiscal hard times, and have been in the forefront of efforts to turn public services over to private companies.
"Given the cutbacks in city services and the city work force and given the cutbacks in the state, it might be hard to see public sector increases in the future," said Victor Gotbaum, the former head of New York City's main municipal employees union and now a senior researcher at City University of New York.
And even as New York's government unions have grown in the last decade, the percentage of nongovernment New York workers belonging to unions has steadily declined. In 1994, 18 percent of New York's nongovernment workers were in unions, down from 24 percent a decade earlier.
"We've lost in the private sector only because many industrial plants have closed down," said Edward Cleary, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Unlike some other states, we have not seen any mass desertion from unions because of dissatisfaction."
