HEADLINE: In Frenetic First Week, Crew Charms and Cajoles

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
If there was a moment last week that captured the difference between New York City's new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, and his predecessor, Ramon C. Cortines, it was at 5:10 P.M. on Friday at City Hall.
At that point, Dr. Crew and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani emerged from a 50-minute meeting, arm in arm and smiling. And memories of Mr. Cortines, who stepped down this month after nearly two years of criticism from the Mayor, seemed distant. 
 For Dr. Crew, 45, it was the capstone of a frenetic first week in which he began to sketch an outline of how he will lead the nation's largest school district.
He immediately served notice that he intended to stretch the powers of his office to the limit, seizing control of more than a dozen failing schools. He rechristened his office's bully pulpit, visiting schools to urge students to raise their expectations and then stooping to embrace them.
And he pledged to rid the Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn of the "bloat" long derided by the Mayor, saying he would return employees with teaching licenses to the classroom and find new jobs for others.
Along the way, he crisscrossed the city to ask for support at, among other places, an intermediate school on the mend in the South Bronx, a dinner with business executives on the Upper East Side, a huddle with black political leaders in Harlem and appointments with at least two borough presidents. He also took his first ginger steps onto the political tightrope that upended his predecessor, met separately with the board and the Mayor -- and, remarkably, left with both singing his praises, at least for now.
"He's off to a great start," said First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers.
At many stops, Dr. Crew made it clear that he would hold out his own story -- that of a black child raised in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., by a widowed security guard who insisted that his son extract greatness from himself -- as an inspiration to a system populated by numerous poor children not unlike himself.
"I'm here," he said in a lunchtime interview on Tuesday with reporters and editors at The New York Times, "because a lot of people made it possible for me to walk in the front door of a school, learn algebra, learn Spanish, take the courses I needed to go to Babson College, come out with a degree in economics and have the presence of mind to know how to navigate my way through the rest of graduate school and into your dining room here."
Having resigned as Superintendent of Schools in Tacoma, Wash., only two weeks ago, Dr. Crew said that people seeking the details of his agenda would have to wait. But in his travels around the city, he won early endorsements, not the least for his energy and self-assurance.
"He is quite sure of himself," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the former chairman of the city's Municipal Assistance Corporation, who joined several other business leaders at a three-hour dinner with Dr. Crew on Wednesday night. "He is very sophisticated. He has a clear understanding of the minefields and traps of the job he has taken on. And he has no illusions about it."
"This," Mr. Rohatyn added, "is no small-town guy."
But soon, a stump speech will not be enough, and Dr. Crew -- who led the 141st largest school district in the nation (Tacoma) and the 68th largest (Sacramento, Calif.) -- will be expected to deliver results in the largest of all.
"He seems to have done well with the Mayor," said Frank Macchiarola, the dean of Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School, who served as Chancellor from 1978 to 1983. "The board is in love with him. And the various constituencies seem to be receptive. But the more profound questions remain to be answered: how well-equipped is he to lead the system, and will the system in fact be led?"
From his first moment on the job last Monday, at 6:54 A.M., Dr. Crew set about trying to prove he could answer those questions. In a signal that he will be a vigilant caretaker of his own image, his press office had invited reporters and photographers to greet him. He did not leave the back seat of his blue Ford Crown Victoria until he was assured that all the television cameras were ready.
Twenty minutes later, in a stage-managed moment more evocative of a United States President than a schools chancellor, the same press corps was ushered into his office to observe -- without asking questions -- 60 seconds of his first meeting with the director of his transition office and two aides he had inherited from Mr. Cortines.
The subject was one to which Dr. Crew would return throughout his first week: the threat by the state, issued over last weekend, to shut down 17 failing city schools, where a vast majority of students can neither read nor write at their grade level.
Dr. Crew immediately set out to take over the schools himself, a strategy that his two predecessors, Mr. Cortines and Joseph A. Fernandez, had used in several isolated cases, but not without legal challenges from the local school districts they superseded.
Dr. Crew discussed his plans by telephone on Monday with Richard P. Mills, the State Commissioner of Education, and again on Tuesday, in a meeting with Mr. Mills and Carol A. Gresser, the board president. Both were receptive. On Wednesday, the board met in executive session and informally endorsed his strategy.
And on Thursday, after Dr. Crew held a news conference at which only student journalists were permitted to ask questions, the spokesman for his transition team, David Begel, announced that the Chancellor was assuming direct control of 16 of those schools.
What comes next, of course, is the hard part, as Dr. Crew tries to fashion plans to rehabilitate each school -- working with existing principals in some cases, removing them in others -- all under the watchful eye of Mr. Mills, who has threatened to close any school that does not show improvement by June.
After their conversation on Monday, Mr. Mills said, "I have confidence in Dr. Crew."
So, apparently, does virtually everyone Dr. Crew reached out to during his honeymoon week.
On Tuesday, he met with Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island to discuss, in Mr. Molinari's words, why his borough "seems to be doing better with less money than the other districts." Mr. Molinari pronounced himself impressed with the Chancellor's interest. "He was the type of person that, in a short meeting such as we had, left me with the impression that he would be in total control," he said.
On Wednesday afternoon, he met with Mr. Molinari's counterpart in the Bronx, Fernando Ferrer, who came away, he said, with a commitment from Dr. Crew to somehow restore junior varsity sports -- the victim of a recent round of budget-cutting -- to every high school in the city, perhaps using private donations. "To say he was dazzling was probably an understatement," Mr. Ferrer said.
And that night, he engaged a group of business leaders gathered at the East Side home of Robert Kiley, former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, in a discussion of the bedrock idea of his chancellorship: that every child is capable of learning. "Everyone liked him," Mr. Kiley said.
Perhaps Dr. Crew's trickiest task, however, will be satisfying the two often-squabbling masters he effectively serves: the seven-member board and the Mayor, who has expressed a willingness to make Dr. Crew his education commissioner if the State Legislature acts on his proposal to abolish the board and transfer its powers to City Hall.
On the issue of school security, for example, Dr. Crew disagrees with a precondition Mr. Giuliani had set during the chancellor search -- that the next chancellor cede control over school safety to the police. Instead, Dr. Crew agrees with his board, which advocates a greater role for the police in training and recruiting school safety officers, but wants the ultimate responsibility for security to rest with the schools themselves.
But unlike Mr. Cortines, Dr. Crew said he expected to provide the Mayor with occasional briefings on his plans. Although it was unclear who called whom, the first of those briefings occurred on Friday, with Dr. Crew and Mr. Giuliani sitting down to discuss special education, the $8 billion schools budget and the ongoing negotiations with the teachers' union, whose contract expired last Sunday.
"There are a whole host of things," Dr. Crew said afterward, "that we've obviously got as high priorities for working together over the course of the year."
Another priority for Dr. Crew in New York was visiting his 23-year-old son, also named Rudy, a production assistant for the television program "Yo! MTV Raps," who was able to spend a moment with his father on Tuesday night.
Famished and drained from a long day that had left him little time to eat, Dr. Crew arrived on his son's doorstep on 108th Street at 10 P.M. and made a beeline for the refrigerator. To his dismay, he found only a jar of mustard.
And so they spent the next half-hour laughing and catching up, with the new Schools Chancellor politely rebuffing his son's repeated attempts to get him to listen to the new album by the rap performer AZ.
"Once this whole mess dies down and people get used to him being around," the younger Mr. Crew said, "we're going to be able to hang out on weekends."

HEADLINE: China Faulted by New Trade Group

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: HARROGATE, England. Oct. 21

 BODY:
The world's four major trading powers are united in agreement that China still falls far short of meeting criteria for joining the new World Trade Organization, the United States said today.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said members of the Quadrilateral bloc grouping -- the United States, Japan, the European Union and Canada -- all shared his view that China needed to make much more effort before becoming a member of the trade organization. 
 The apparent setback to China's hopes comes at an awkward time, with a meeting Tuesday in New York between President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China.
Beijing failed to secure membership in the trade body at its founding in January, after completion of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks. The United States has blocked its efforts to enter as a developing economy, making it eligible on less stringent terms.
"I don't know of any major trading nation which has been impressed by China's offer so far," Mr. Kantor told reporters.

HEADLINE: NYC;
5 Best Reasons To Allow U.N. To Park Here

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
YEARS ago, at another time when its public image needed Simonizing, the United Nations ran television commercials that ended with this sobering message: Maybe it's not the United Nations that is preventing World War III. But who would want to find out?
Here we are in 1995 with the know-nothings again riding high in Washington, urging that the United States tell the foreigners off and go it alone, as though there are many Americans left who can even get dressed without putting on a shirt that was stitched somewhere like Sri Lanka. 
 New York is not that anti-foreigner. But it is hardly free of provincialism, which has taken a familiar form as the United Nations throws itself a 50th birthday party. It is a word-association game. Say "United Nations" or "diplomats" and what comes to mind? For many New Yorkers, the answer is easy: unpaid parking tickets.
A PREVAILING view is that citizens of the five boroughs have exclusive rights to any violation of parking rules in their territory. New Yorkers who put up with all manner of indignities can grow apopletic at the thought of ambassadors' not paying their parking tickets, a common assumption being that a diplomat is a fellow in an Armani suit who spends his day looking for a fire hydrant to block before heading off to Lutece for a discussion of European Union veal-import quotas.
Indeed, some foreign envoys are insufferable, condescending toward both the city and its regulations. But the stereotype is often wildly exaggerated, and it has been somewhat exploited in the runup to the United Nations anniversary, an occasion for some to drag out that old New York tabloid chestnut: diplomats as deadbeats, skipping out on good-hearted merchants by invoking immunity.
The collective local debt of these foreigners is in fact high, estimated as much as $8.5 million. For some reason, it is growing rapidly. But a closer look shows that most of the money is owed by five countries -- Uganda, Somalia, Congo, Sierra Leone and Liberia. Uganda alone accounts for at least half the total. And while no one should shrug off debts, it bears noting that all those countries can be described diplomatically as political or economic basket cases.
If you really want the biggest deadbeat in town, go to the corner of First Avenue and East 45th Street. There, you will find the United States Mission to the United Nations, representing a country that owes the world organization $1.3 billion.
Still, the United Nations has a public-relations burden, aloof and irrelevant as it seems to many New Yorkers. Recognizing the problem, city officials are accentuating the positive, cranking out figures showing that the huge diplomatic corps generates nearly 31,000 jobs and $3.3 billion in economic development.
ALL that is fine. But there are other advantages to having the United Nations around that the press releases ignore. Here are a few, unsolicited:
(1) Since the headquarters in Turtle Bay is considered international territory, a visit provides a low-cost foreign vacation.
(2) You can feel better about life's petty problems by wandering over there. You think you've got troubles? How about the freedom-yearning Tibetans on a hunger strike across from the Secretariat building? And unlike many protesters in New York, the Tibetans are nice.
(3) Thanks to the United Nations, people in Long Island City, Queens, have a more pleasant view across the East River than a sight of the slaughterhouses and slums that made up Turtle Bay 50 years ago.
(4) The United Nations gives First Avenue the most interesting lampposts in town. One is crowded with signs announcing Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, Shcharansky Freedom Walk, United Nations Plaza and Raoul Wallenberg Walk. Some people know it better as East 47th Street, and there is a sign for that, too.
(5) Some good movies have benefited from the United Nations' presence in New York, an example being Hitchcock's "North by Northwest," which includes an important murder scene at the headquarters.
One can add that unpaid tickets may be considered a small price for having an organization that reinforces this city's claim to being capital of the planet. But that would probably draw an argument from some.
Maybe they're right. Maybe it's not the United Nations that keeps New York a great city.
But who would want to find out?

HEADLINE: Economic Espionage

 BODY:
As the Central Intelligence Agency shops around for new business, it has discovered the attractions of economic intelligence. Encouraged by President Clinton, the agency is turning its spying machinery on targets like the Japanese trade ministry and the French Prime Minister's staff, looking for information that might give American trade negotiators an advantage.
With the cold war over, there is little question that economic and financial developments can threaten American interests as quickly as foreign armies. The Mexican peso crisis earlier this year was an example. But it is a good deal less clear that the C.I.A. is the right place to turn for help. 
 The C.I.A. considered the Soviet Union an economic power when it was actually an economic wreck, and there is little evidence that the agency's expertise on financial issues has improved since the cold war ended. David Sanger and Tim Weiner recently reported in The Times that Clinton Administration consumers of C.I.A. economic intelligence find much of the material unsophisticated and of limited use.
Banks, brokerage houses and other financial institutions have far more experience and expertise in tracking bond markets, currency fluctuations, inflation rates and budget deficits. The C.I.A. has not made a convincing case why it should start from almost no base to build a center for economic intelligence and analysis when the Government can hire outside experts or look to agencies like the Treasury Department that already have more knowledgeable staffs.
Clandestine efforts to gather financial secrets, especially from American allies, seem even more dubious. Friendly governments are not above spying on each other, but whatever the C.I.A. learned about Japan's bargaining strategy in trade talks on automobile issues probably was not worth the embarrassment to both Washington and Tokyo when the spying was disclosed. Over the long run, American access to Japanese markets is not likely to be improved by spying on the Japanese trade ministry.
The mismatch between cold-war-style espionage and economic matters was evident in the C.I.A.'s clumsy effort to lure an aide to the French Prime Minister into parting with secrets about his Government's position on trade talks. The gambit backfired when French intelligence officials detected the maneuver and tipped off the aide. It is not easy to see what the C.I.A. thought it could learn about French bargaining positions that were openly declared and widely publicized at the time.
The one area where traditional spycraft might prove useful is warning when foreign countries or companies are using bribery or other illegal means to obtain business contracts. The C.I.A., using intercepts of telephone and other communications, has notified the State Department when it learned of these practices. That, in turn, has given Washington a chance to protest. In at least one case, the business ended up going to an American company.
The C.I.A. itself is not the best judge of what new missions it should pursue. The desire to protect a large budget and staff has a way of distorting decisions about new ventures, particularly in an organization that devoted better than two-thirds of its work to monitoring and studying a country, the Soviet Union, that no longer exists.
William Casey had many faults as Director of Central Intelligence in the Reagan Administration. But he did know a thing or two about economics. Whenever he wanted economic intelligence, Mr. Casey often said, he would ask a businessman, not an intelligence analyst.

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES '95: NOTEBOOK;
Anderson Isn't Waiting by the Phone

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
The telephone rings often at the Anderson home in Thousand Oaks, Calif., but the calls are from friends wanting to talk and organizations seeking an after-dinner speaker, not from prospective employers looking to fill a particular position.
"I have not talked to one single person," Sparky Anderson said, interrupting his breakfast roll and coffee. "I don't think anybody will call. I knew that when I stepped down. I never thought there would be any. I never thought I'd get a call from anyone." 
 Anderson is three weeks removed from the day he ended his 17-year tenure as manager of the Detroit Tigers. He may be three weeks removed from the day he ended his whole career as a manager.
The Baltimore Orioles, about to hire Davey Johnson as their new manager, have not called. Oakland, which could lose Tony La Russa, has not called. St. Louis, which has made La Russa an offer, has not called. Cincinnati, whose owner earlier this year said something about having him come back, has not called.
The Mets, Los Angeles, San Diego, Pittsburgh and the Chicago White Sox all rehired their managers without calling. George Steinbrenner, who has spent the past two days meeting with Buck Showalter, has not dialed the number with the 805 area code.
"I never thought there would be any unrest in New York," Anderson said, speaking of Showalter's status. "Everybody talks, but I know George. He'll sit back and watch other people. Then he usually is very generous with people. That's the way I looked at it from the start. I think this guy has done an outstanding job. If you don't get rewarded when you do outstanding jobs, what happens when you do a mediocre job? I never gave that a doubt. I told my wife that guy will be all right."
When earlier this month it appeared that Steinbrenner might jettison Showalter and end the longest uninterrupted term any manager has had in his 23-yeas ownership, there was the fleeting thought that he might be tempted to pursue Anderson, who could attract fans.
But if Steinbrenner even gave the idea a moment's thought, he hasn't thought out loud enough for it to reach newsprint. At the same time, Anderson would not campaign for anyone's job, certainly not Showalter's because, as he said, "I really like the guy."
Perhaps privately Anderson is hurt that no one has called, but he said he doesn't feel insulted. Nor, he said, does he feel the game will suffer in his absence, if he remains absent.
"Our game never suffers from the loss of anyone," he said. "As soon as guys understand that and can face that fact, that when they're gone this game will continue, we'll be in better shape. I think we have this thing among all sports people that when they leave, it don't go on. It will go on, believe me. I've always been able to keep that thing in control.
"I always knew that I was not the game, that I wasn't bigger than the game. I always knew the game was giving to me; I wasn't giving to the game. If I've done anything at all, at least I've showed some people the game can benefit from your help, but the game doesn't owe you anything; you owe it all to the game."
Just in case anyone is thinking of asking Anderson if he would be interested in a front-office job, he should save his time. "I'll never be in a front office," Anderson said.
But there is a role he could play, he added, a role played by many former players, managers and coaches.
"I would enjoy sitting in a ball park judging players," he said. "In Los Angeles, in Anaheim. Calling and saying if you want to go for him, do it. I would never sit in an office. I have to be outside. I can't be locked in. But I would love to watch games. I could watch players. I would enjoy that. I'm there to help anybody who would like me to help."
 
Fundamentals, Fundamentals
 A league championship series isn't exactly the place for teaching young players the proper way to execute plays, but Lou Piniella, the Seattle manager, found an at-bat by Dan Wilson, his catcher, to be instructive.
Wilson, who later in the same game would commit a series-clinching two-run passed ball, batted after Luis Sojo led off the third inning of a scoreless sixth game with a double. Piniella could have had Wilson sacrifice Sojo to third, but he was reluctant to give up the out and figured Wilson at least could hit a grounder to the right side that would accomplish the same goal.
But Wilson swung at the first pitch from Dennis Martinez and hit a grounder to the left side, to shortstop Omar Vizquel, forcing Sojo to remain at second.
"He was trying to go the other way," Piniella said, "but Martinez gave him a little offspeed pitch down and in, and that's the only place you can hit that pitch. You got a 40-year-old guy pitching against a 25-year-old kid. It's a huge experience difference. How do you learn? You learn from experience. You take that pitch, you just take it, and wait for something out over the plate. Or if he's going to keep giving you that pitch, you back completely off the plate, back off another half a foot or so. It's like we had a left-handed pitcher on the mound and the guy is trying to go the other way with the ball. It's hard to go the other way with a slow curveball. So you just take it and wait for something else."
 
Irony of the Astros?
 Drayton McLane Jr., owner of the Houston Astros, and William Collins, a Washington businessman, have initiated talks about the possible sale of the Astros. Collins and his partners have been like economic vultures, waiting to pounce on any troubled team that looks ripe for purchase -- the Pirates, the Mariners, the Astros.
Of course, Collins's aim in buying a team is to move it to northern Virginia, a step that other owners may not necessarily approve. If, however, Collins were to buy the Astros and gain permission to move them, it would be ironic for the city of Houston.
McLane's predecessor, John McMullen, was vilified in Houston for the way he operated the Astros. It didn't matter to his critics that when McMullen bought the team in 1979, he saved it for the city. They just wanted him out, saying that if he sold it, they would come.
But the fans haven't, and now the city faces the Astros' possible departure 16 years after McMullen came to their rescue.
 
Plugging the Holes
 While George Steinbrenner continues to talk with Buck Showalter about his status as manager and the Yankees search for someone who will take a general manager's position devoid of authority and the normal general manager's duties, other clubs are filling their vacancies.
The Detroit Tigers have settled on Randy Smith as their general manager, replacing Joe Klein; the Baltimore Orioles are zeroing in on Davey Johnson as their manager, replacing Phil Regan, and the St. Louis Cardinals are trying to lure Tony La Russa into their managerial uniform that was last worn by Mike Jorgensen.
The Orioles still have to decide on a general manager, which they are expected to do by the end of the week. The Montreal Expos, President Claude Brochu said, are taking their time finding a general manager "who fits." The San Diego Padres are interviewing candidates for their general manager vacancy. The Tigers need a manager but won't do anything until after they officially name Smith. Oakland continues to consider alternatives to La Russa should he decide to accept the Cardinals' offer.

Wednesday

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

PROFITS
 
The Black Ink Flows Freely
A tide of rising earnings washed over the markets but did not quite lift all boats. Allaying Wall Street's biggest fear, Microsoft reported that Windows 95 was selling very well indeed and that its earnings were up 58 percent. Intel, Sun Microsystem, Silicon Graphics and I.B.M. were also strong performers; Apple Computer was the major disappointment, down 47.6 percent. Pharmaceutical companies and brokerage houses also had strong quarters, and General Motors beat expectations. But Ford Motor took a stiff loss, its profits down 68 percent as costs rose and overseas sales slipped. The Dow, the S. & P. 500 and the Big Board composite rode the news to record highs.
 
ALARM BELLS
 
So Much for Oversight
The Federal Reserve and Daiwa Bank's management won no applause for their review of trading problems at the bank's New York branch. A former Fed official disclosed that nearly two years before Daiwa disclosed its $1.1 billion loss from unauthorized trading, the president of the New York Fed had met with Daiwa to discuss the employee, Toshihide Iguchi, and his trading practices. Clearly the followup left a lot to be desired. As Mr. Noguchi pleaded guilty in Federal court to a variety of charges, both he and prosecutors said two senior executives at Daiwa conspired to conceal the loss. Daiwa said only that it was continuing its own investigation.
 
SAFETY NET
 
Dialing for Dollars
Concerns about Japanese banking go far beyond Daiwa. The Federal Reserve put in place a system to provide Japanese financial authorities with billions of dollars in cash, almost instantly, in exchange for U.S. Treasury bonds and bills held by the Japanese. The goal is to avert a catastrophic bank collapse that would ripple around the globe. And because the Treasury would receive its own issues in exchange for the cash, the safety net appears to be risk free.
 
TAXES
 
Stumbling on the High Wire
First President Clinton told a group of business executives that he had raised taxes "too much" in his first budget, providing comfort to Republican critics and infuriating Democrats who had stood by him at the time. A day later, he backtracked and said he was "very, very proud of what I did."

TRADE
 
Progress, Setbacks
The good news about trade? The U.S. trade deficit fell sharply to $8.8 billion in August, helped by a surge in exports, especially to Western Europe. The bad news? The U.S. trade deficit with China grew 18 percent to $3.9 billion for the month -- more than three-quarters the size of the much-publicized deficit with Japan, which was essentially unchanged, at $5.1 billion.
 
BANKING
 
Deal of the Week
Hostile takeovers are rare in the world of banking, in part because of the regulatory approvals needed, but Wells Fargo plunged in with a whopping $10 billion bid for First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, a company it has long coveted. First Interstate, which holds a strong position in 14 Western states, said it was "deeply disappointed with this uninvited action," but Wall Street and investors, who bid up Wells Fargo stock, reacted with enthusiasm.
 
DISSONANCE
 
A Nod to Shareholders
Some large institutional shareholders of Archer-Daniels-Midland have been sharply critical of how cozy the company's directors are with management, all the more so after it was learned the Government was investigating the giant food processing company for possible price-fixing. At the annual shareholders meeting, the crusty chief executive, Dwayne O. Andreas, the chief executive, cut off his critics, but the board did agree to appoint a committee to recommend changes.
 
SEATS
 
Big Board, Big Seat
A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold for $1 million -- the first time in seven digits since just before the 1987 crash and up $50,000 from the last sale in September. The price is four times the recent low, in 1990. By contrast, the Dow Jones industrial average is less than three times its post-crash low. The current price remains below the record high of $1.15 million, a month before the 1987 crash. And what does the buyer get for $1 million? One of 1,366 seats that confer the right to trade stocks on the floor of the Big Board, an activity that involves a lot of running around. Buying a seat does not provide a place to sit.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Diary column of the Money and Business section on Sunday about the $1.1 billion trading loss at the New York office of Daiwa Bank referred incompletely to accounts of discussions two years ago between the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, William J. McDonough, and a top Daiwa executive. Although a former senior official of the Federal Reserve said the name of the trader responsible for the loss came up at a meeting on Oct. 4, 1993 -- with Mr. McDonough and Takeshi Ohta, then the vice chairman of Daiwa Bank Ltd. -- Mr. McDonough denied that account late last week.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ADVERTISING -- Down Time for Best-Known Billboard -- The Goodyear blimp Stars and Stripes, shrouded in fog at Lunken Airport, Cincinnati, en route to Atlanta, where the World Series opened last night. Goodyear's blimps, in service since 1925, are a fixture at sports championship, swapping aerial views of the field for promotional shots of the airship on screen. During the American League championship games in Seattle, viewers had to settle for a blimp's-eye view of the roof of the Kingdome. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FOREST HILLS;
Cuomo Says Lessons Learned On Housing Have Been Ignored

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

 BODY:
For Mario M. Cuomo, mediating the housing project controversy in Forest Hills in the 1970's was a first feature performance on the public stage that he would later dominate over three terms as Governor of New York.
In an interview, Mr. Cuomo said that issues raised more than 20 years ago in Forest Hills have particular resonance now and offer a window into the nation's failure to deal with problems of race and poverty. 
 "Forest Hills describes a situation in Queens that in many ways was a metaphor for the larger situation with race," he said. "Color was the most important thing, and it shouldn't have been. Economic class should have been the most important thing."
Mr. Cuomo, who chronicled his work as a mediator in a book, "Forest Hills Diary" (Random House, 1974), said that New York City found answers in Forest Hills that have been ignored since.
"The idea of a small dose of integration that could be absorbed by the larger community had intelligence," he said. "It's just that they never did it again, anywhere else."
The problem, Mr. Cuomo said, was that most communities were highly resistant to having a mix of economic classes. To illustrate his point, he offered another Queens example.
"At the same time Forest Hills was happening, Baisley Park was happening," he said. "Baisley Park was in South Jamaica, and involved the plan for a low-income housing project in an established stable middle-class community, except that Baisley Park was all black, it was black middle class. And the Baisley Park reaction was at least as furious as the Forest Hills reaction. The point I drew from that is that there is something beyond color here, it's economic class and distinction."
Much of the contention at the Forest Hills Cooperative today involves the question of shareholder rights, with tenants wanting more control over who moves in. Mr. Cuomo predicted the danger of calling a public housing project a cooperative in his book 23 years ago. (The idea was promoted by Borough President Donald Manes to assuage opponents.)
Mr. Cuomo wrote: "One of the aspects of the cooperative that is most appealing to the community is the fact that it provides for a board of directors. . . . It is apparently being commonly assumed that such a board of directors would have the right to make the ultimate tenant selection. . . . I am convinced this is not so and could not be so legally. There is a great danger in not making this clear. . . . I've tried to, but the little publicity given my remarks has been lost."
In the interview, Mr. Cuomo focused on how the book ties into the current problems in housing policy and race relations.
"The most obvious lesson about housing, which everyone refuses to address, is that we made a colossal blunder in insisting that the poor people be stacked one on top of the other in small confined areas," he said. "You have to do everything you can to involve as many people as you can in the circle of opportunity. You can't just keep them out there and live your comfortable existence, wherever it is." D.M.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;
13 Charged in Decade-Old Car-Theft Ring

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
When Ira Mandel wrecked his gray Mercedes-Benz in an accident on Long Island over Labor Day weekend two years ago, he knew just whom to call. He phoned David Prevete, a known purveyor of gleaming stolen automobiles and parts, said the Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown.
Mr. Prevete had an identical car stolen and fitted with the vehicle identification number from the wrecked car, allowing Mr. Mandel to drive an undamaged Mercedes 300 SE worth $53,700 and collect insurance money, officials said. 
 Investigators brought an end to Mr. Prevete's multimillion-dollar theft ring last week when they arrested him, Mr. Mandel and 11 other men, said Mr. Brown, who announced a 103-count indictment.
The ring had operated for more than a decade in Queens, Brooklyn and Nassau County, sometimes raking in $1 million a day, investigators said. The men were arrested at their homes after a 22-month inquiry.
"This indictment exposes a network of thieves, cutters, chop-shop operators and stolen-parts distributors that has plagued legitimate car owners," Mr. Brown said. "It also goes to the heart of a lucrative black market run by organized crime."
The indictment charges that Mr. Prevete, 33, of Valley Stream, L.I., and Nicholas Scalfani, 32, of Howard Beach ran the daily operation of the Prevete Brothers Company, a licensed automobile wrecking business on Roosevelt Avenue in Flushing.
The men owned and operated the Prevete-Scalfani Organization, which was at the same address and was the central headquarters and distribution center for the resale of stolen cars and parts, law enforcement officials said.
They were teamed up with Ciro Tucci, 27, of Brooklyn, investigators said. The investigators said that Mr. Tucci ran a chop shop at 303 Elton Street in Brooklyn and that he would steal cars as ordered by Mr. Prevete and Mr. Scalfani, dismantle them and deliver the parts to the Prevete Brothers. Mr. Tucci was charged under the state's Organized Crime Control Act with engaging in a corrupt enterprise.
Mr. Prevete was also charged with engaging in a corrupt enterprise and faces up to 25 years in prison. Mr. Mandel was charged with grand larceny and faces up to 15 years in prison.
Also charged were Kevin Sardo, George Omeste and Paul Famano, who the officials said were employed by Mr. Tucci to steal the cars, dismantle them and deliver the parts. They also reportedly dismantled cars that had been falsely reported as stolen to insurance companies , the officials said. They were each charged with engaging in a corrupt enterprise.
James Cadicamo of Howard Beach and Andrew Iglio of New Hyde Park, L.I., were indicted for their roles at what officials said was a chop shop on Douglass Street in Brooklyn. The men were accused of receiving orders for car thefts from Mr. Prevete and Mr. Scalfani. Both men were charged with grand larceny.
The authorities said the ring was the second largest auto theft and chop shop operation to be dismantled this year in Queens, which has the city's highest car theft rate.
In February, a man identified by the authorities as a captain in the Bonnano crime family and 12 other people were charged with running a criminal enterprise that included car thieves, dismantlers, receivers and illegal parts dealers. LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SHEEPSHEAD BAY;
New Language, and a New Life, for Avenue U

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
When the Rev. Paul Tseng moved the Brooklyn Chinese Christian Church from Flatbush into an old American Legion hall in Sheepshead Bay seven years ago, about 30 worshipers went to his weekly Baptist services. These days more than 200 attend.
"The community changed," Mr. Tseng said last week in his church, on East 15th Street and Gravesend Neck Road. "More Chinese came to buy houses and settle. We have the D and Q train here, which goes to Chinatown. We have stores and restaurants on Avenue U. And we have the church." 
 A growing Chinese population is slowly transforming Sheepshead Bay. Markets selling star fruits, bok choy, won ton skins and fresh fish are cropping up around Avenue U's old Italian salumerias and bagel stores. Video stores rent the latest Hong Kong thrillers. And the Ocean Palace Pavilion -- a marble-fronted, two-story, 300-seat restaurant serving seafood and Hong Kong cuisine -- opened in July to become one of the avenue's largest restaurants.
The area's Chinese population has grown from 2,706 in 1980 to about 10,000 now, according to census figures. And Frank Vardy, a senior demographer with the City Planning Department, said the actual number could be significantly higher. He said many Chinese families are moving to Sheepshead Bay from Chinatown, mirroring the migration of Italians and Jews who moved there from the Lower East Side half a century ago. "It's a pattern," he said.
Many were attracted to Sheepshead Bay by its abundance of one- and two-family houses and its proximity to Chinatown via the D train. Once the first waves came, more followed to join the growing community.
Many of the new Chinese businesses -- along with a growing number of Russian stores -- are being credited with revitalizing the commercial stretch along Avenue U, which suffered economically after the Kings Plaza Mall began drawing shoppers away.
"It's the mom-and-pop types of things that you cannot get at the mall," said John Nikas, the chairman of Community Board 15. "Now you've got specialty shops selling foods and clothes that the mall cannot match."
Brenda Tong, a real estate broker at Century 21, said the influx has helped keep the housing market steady while other neighborhoods have declined. Like many other businesses in Sheepshead Bay, Century 21 has Cyrillic, Chinese and Latin lettering on its awning.
Ms. Tong, who has lived in the area for 24 years, was pleased when stores like the V & H Supermarket opened on Avenue U and East 13th Street to sell everything from snails, live crabs, snow pea tips and oyster sauce to green tea, woks and rice cookers.
"I used to go to Chinatown once a week to go shopping," she said. "Now I go here. They have everything."
There have been tensions. In the late 1980's, a series of racist fliers charged that the Chinese were "smiling at us behind our backs and planning to take over the whole neighborhood." And there have been problems with the gangs that prey on Chinese people all over the city: two years ago the police rescued nine hostages from a Bedford Avenue house after they had been kidnapped by members of the Fuk Ching gang.
But Mr. Tseng, of the church, said that relations have improved and that officers from the 61st Precinct have been helpful. Now Mr. Tseng -- whose church comprises two buildings and a basketball court marked by a sign proclaiming "Jesus Is Lord" in English and Chinese -- is thinking about expanding. His summer day camp has grown so large that he now rents space from Public School 254, on East 18th Street.
 MICHAEL COOPER

HEADLINE: The Zone

BYLINE: By Daniel Johnson; Daniel Johnson, the literary editor of The Times of London, was the Bonn bureau chief of The Daily Telegraph from 1987 to 1989.

 BODY:

THE RUSSIANS IN GERMANY
A History of the Soviet
Zone of Occupation, 1945-1949.
By Norman M. Naimark.
Illustrated. 586 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/
Harvard University Press. $35. 
 IF ever a nation deserved to be occupied by a vindictive foe, it was Germany in 1945. Yet it is impossible to read Norman M. Naimark's masterly analysis of the Soviet occupation between the end of the war and the emergence of two German states in 1949 without feeling some sympathy for the East Germans. For them the hour of defeat was only the beginning of an ordeal that lasted more than a generation. When the German Democratic Republic disintegrated in 1989 and 1990, the roots of discontent could be traced back to those four years of Russian military rule. The very fact that East Germany did collapse so easily, despite the best efforts of the Bonn Government to sustain it over the previous decade, is inexplicable unless one takes into account the grisly circumstances of its birth.
Even now, the legacy of Stalinization haunts these lands between the Elbe and the Oder: a disparate amalgam of provinces then united only in misfortune, and hence identified by the inhabitants just as "the zone." Having labored long in the archives -- German, Russian and American -- Mr. Naimark, who teaches at Stanford and is a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution in California, writes densely. But the richness of his documentation is one of the strengths of his book, and one forgives him his occasional repetitions.
At the level of high politics, his story is one of mutual disillusionment: the Russians' exasperation with the Germans, who obstinately refused to show their gratitude at the ballot box, to work overtime to pay reparations, or to admire Soviet culture; and the German Communists' frustration with their masters in Moscow, who could not see that their cause was undermined by the occupiers' arbitrary violence, their evisceration of the economy and their high-handed manner. A handful of personalities emerge: the great Marshal Georgi Zhukov, the conqueror who was not above furnishing his Moscow apartments with German plunder; the formidable Col. Sergei Tiulpanov, the balding Russian propaganda chief who shocked visiting American officers by walking arm in arm with Germans; the obedient Walter Ulbricht, the future dictator of East Germany, whose unpopularity was outweighed for the Russians by his loyalty; the ruthless Erich Mielke, mastermind of the secret police, who had orders "to know everything and to report everything worth knowing"; the pliable Otto Grotewohl, who led the Social Democrats into a shotgun wedding with the Communists (as the Socialist Unity Party, or S.E.D.) and who returned from Moscow proclaiming, "Comrade Stalin is the father of the world."
While he brilliantly untangles the politics of the S.E.D. and the Soviet administration, Mr. Naimark also tells us what was happening to the population. Up to two million German women were raped in the Soviet zone or while being expelled from the eastern provinces; these rapes, often accompanied by murder, continued long after hostilities ended. Thousands of Junkers and other landowners who had survived the Soviet invasion and the seizure of their estates were rounded up and forced to live on the freezing Baltic island of Rugen, where an unknown number died. One-third of the surviving industrial plant in the zone was dismantled and taken to the Soviet Union (very little was ever reassembled), while 60 percent of the remaining production was confiscated as reparations. In October 1946, thousands of German scientists and technicians were rounded up at night and deported with their families and possessions to the Soviet Union, where they remained for at least three years.
Most chilling of all is the account of the zone's unofficial gulag, which lasted until 1950. There were 11 "special camps," and since the discovery of mass graves in 1992, their full horror has become plain: Mr. Naimark accepts a figure of 95,000 deaths out of 240,000 prisoners, mainly dissidents and "class enemies" rather than Nazi war criminals. Others disappeared into the Soviet gulag. Scarcely less grim were the East German uranium mines, to which tens of thousands of workers (including thousands of women) were conscripted every year to work in nightmarish conditions, knee-deep in radioactive slime. There are no figures for deaths, but in three months in 1948 there were 574 accidents; an average of 10 workers died in each.
There are some touching moments in this chronicle of inhumanity. When Ulbricht tried to persuade a group of farmers to expropriate the local landowner, they replied, "But we have no law for this." Ulbricht's response was characteristic: "All right, fine, if you want a law, we will make a law so that you can carry it out in a completely orderly fashion." This very German obsession with law and order, which the impatient Russians saw as mere temporizing, is a recurrent theme.
 THE most original chapter in this startlingly original book shows how the rapes committed by Soviet troops undermined the basis of the East German Government long before it existed. The ritualized humiliation of German womanhood was the retribution for Hitler's racial war of extermination. But for German women, who were not allowed to air their suffering and fear in public, it meant a lasting trauma -- divorce, illegitimacy and abortion rates all shot up, accompanied by an epidemic of venereal disease -- and alienation from the Soviet Union and East Germany. Women seem to have voted for the S.E.D. in markedly lower numbers, and it is easy to see why: Mr. Naimark recounts in detail public meetings at which women's anxieties were dismissed and the word "rape" was never mentioned; Nazi bandits in Soviet uniforms were blamed for all such attacks.
One issue Mr. Naimark raises but does not analyze in depth is the role of anti-Semitism on both sides. The ferocity of the Russian occupiers is partly explained by the fact that they had been led to believe that most victims of the Nazi death camps were Russian prisoners; the Final Solution was played down by Stalin. The ablest members of Tiulpanov's staff were Germanophone Russian Jews, but they were sent back to the Soviet Union once Stalin's "anticosmopolitanism" witch hunt began. Whether German anti-Semitism exacerbated tensions with these Russian Jews is not explored here, but S.E.D. leaders generally kept German Jews out of sight. Survivors of the Nazi camps were seen as less reliable than Soviet-trained exiles.
When East Germany fell, its opponents included many women, as well as the spiritual (and often actual) descendants of groups on the left who, 40 years before, had refused to join the S.E.D. and were sent to penal colonies. It was appropriate that a Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, precipitated the collapse; for it was one of his forerunners, Stalin, who by his brutal policies in the late 1940's helped insure that the "first socialist state on German soil" did not outlive its founding fathers.

LENGTH: 1310 words

HEADLINE: Victorians and Their Discontents

BYLINE: By Frank Kermode; Frank Kermode's memoir, "Not Entitled," will be published next month.

 BODY:

THE NAKED HEART
The Bourgeois Experience:
Victoria to Freud. Volume 4.
By Peter Gay.
Illustrated. 463 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95. 
 PETER GAY is the author of many books, but his multi volume work "The Bourgeois Experience: Victoria to Freud" is clearly meant to be his masterpiece. "The Naked Heart" is the fourth volume of the series, and it seems there is at least one more to come. The first, "Education of the Senses" (1984), was intended to revise conventional notions of the place of sex in 19th-century bourgeois culture. It was followed two years later by "The Tender Passion," which moved the inquiry from sex to love. In 1993 there followed "The Cultivation of Hatred." These are all very long books, discursive in method but carefully annotated, supplemented by huge bibliographical essays and animated by the same Freudian interest in the discontents induced by the conflict between what human beings desire and what their civilization permits.
Freud is not only Mr. Gay's terminus but his mentor; his presence is decisive without being obtrusive, a sort of ground bass to the evidence, which is drawn from a thousand sources, American, English, French and German. These books testify to an astonishing assiduity in research. Mr. Gay, the Sterling Professor of History emeritus at Yale University, likes to approach his grand theme anecdotally, and the multitude of case histories he offers constitutes much of the pleasure of reading his work -- though one may occasionally feel that his passion for storytelling is such that the flood of illustrations swamps the basic argument.
His first volume opened (after a valuable "general introduction") with the tale of Mabel Loomis Todd, "that reputable, socially ambitious wife and mother" who became the mistress of Austin Dickinson, the treasurer of Amherst College and brother of the poet Emily. Mabel Todd kept a sexually informative journal, preserved, along with many letters, in several boxes. Mr. Gay saw no reason to be economical in his account of this treasure, and, although he has rarely treated other individuals in quite such detail, he showed in his pages on Mabel Todd how he meant to continue.
In the earlier volumes Mr. Gay also discussed in his lively, thorough way such matters as Victorian sex manuals and courtship customs, but in the third he turned away from the study of love to the study of hatred, sometimes the antithesis, sometimes merely the obverse, of love. Explaining how this bourgeois society dealt with innate human aggression called for disquisitions on the dueling customs of German students, the cult of manliness, the oppression of women, the appetite for corporal and capital punishment, and much else, above all nationalism and war -- in short, all the seemingly uncontrollable aggressive forces that the bourgeois conscience had to try to contain.
Mr. Gay has always emphasized the surviving influence of Enlightenment thinking on the 19th-century bourgeoisie -- neglect of this influence he takes to be one of the reasons that the conventional representations of that class have been inadequate. In "The Naked Heart" he takes up the question of its Romantic inheritance, most visible in its changing conceptions of selfhood. This is not a new topic, but Mr. Gay treats it in his own way. He seeks and finds in abundance evidence that the bourgeoisie sought in the 19th century as never before to lay bare their hearts. And the efforts of the period to understand individual as well as general human motivation culminate, of course, in Freud.
The new starting point is, rather unexpectedly, music, which Mr. Gay regards as an important indication of a new taste for "inwardness." That the bourgeoisie inherited from the late 18th century a taste for music, and owned pianos (which became an index of class), is certainly true. It is also true that music came to be listened to with reverence and deep emotion; Mr. Gay aptly quotes Stendhal's remarks that music can provide "a deeply regressive communion with one's past." Wagner and Schumann set everybody an example by combining inspiration with craftsmanship, Mr. Gay writes, a coalition of genius and prudence held to be typical of the general cultivation of a controlled "inwardness." He does mention the phenomenon of Bayreuth hysteria, which surely entailed some loss of selfhood, but perhaps you could succumb to the ecstasies of the second act of "Tristan und Isolde" without quite forgetting yourself. I'm reminded of the French Symbolist who urged all poets to proceed to Bayreuth on their knees, but reminded them that there was an excellent train service.
 THE book really gets going when Mr. Gay begins to talk about Romantic literature and its legacy -- a new sense of selfhood -- to the Victorian bourgeoisie. Now "the Romantic egotistical sublime broadened out into a bourgeois egotistical sublime," and one consequence was a profusion of autobiographies, written "in Rousseau's shadow" but constrained by both the fear of saying too little and the fear of saying too much.
This section obviously and irresistibly invites more biographical narrative, and there follow many pages on Goethe, John Stuart Mill, Cardinal Newman and others. Edmund Gosse's "Father and Son" is an example of the sort of minor work that here gets deserved attention, and Mr. Gay offers some wise remarks on the theory and practice of autobiography. Inevitably there was also a new cult of biography, which grew increasingly candid; the change of tone is neatly illustrated by Mr. Gay's comment on three lives of Horatio Nelson, in which Lady Hamilton's part in the story is progressively revealed. The desire to tell all began to prevail over bourgeois reticence.
Tainted by fashion, history -- to the annoyance of some professional historians (critical and colorless, as Lord Acton said they should be) -- grew more biographical, more inward; and fiction, also taking part in this quest for inwardness, grew more arcane, thereby dividing the audience for fiction into connoisseurs who could understand Henry James and the mass of readers who didn't even try.
Such is Mr. Gay's breadth of learning that at times it seems impossible to believe that a single person could know so much and in such detail. He has such relish for writing that he will tell you the plot of "David Copperfield," even though he has reason to believe you already know it, and you get used to his saying things like this: "Its history is well known but deserves retelling" -- a remark that introduces an informative disquisition on the history of the British post office. However, he is right to assume that none of his readers can possibly know a tenth of what he does; he covers so much ground that this book could serve as an example, but also a warning, to aspiring cultural historians.
That they must spend much time in dusty archives Mr. Gay demonstrates by his use of unpublished personal letters and journals. They can be touching as well as appropriate to his theme. A dying 19-year-old woman of precocious learning says of her journal: "I have poured out my feelings. . . . I have written much that I would show only to a very few, and much that I would on no account submit to any human eye." "Her innermost self was nobody's business but her own," Mr. Gay comments. Except ours, of course, as we study the progress of the bourgeoisie toward inwardness. If they weren't quite bold enough to expose the naked heart, we, no longer troubled by reticence, will do it for them.
With the aid of Freud, the 19th-century conflicts between instinct and civilization are here as fully examined as anybody could wish. And we are left with the possibly erroneous conviction that whatever our own problems, they aren't such that they can prevent us from understanding those of the Victorians.

HEADLINE: ART;
Not One Drop Of British Reserve

BYLINE: By CAROL KINO; Carol Kino has written about art for The Atlantic Monthly, Artnews and the British magazine Modern Painters.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
DAMIEN HIRST PUTS CUT-UP COWS in formaldehyde. Rachel Whiteread makes inside-out casts of furniture and rooms. Marc Quinn is best known for a self-portrait bust, cast in his own blood. Mona Hatoum has led viewers through her own intestines aided by an endoscopic camera.
The media these artists use include painting, sculpture, assemblage, photography, collage, installation, video and a few that haven't yet been named. Some of these works take the artist's own life for inspiration; others are propelled by a fashionably streetwise esthetic. In still others, lyricism or history are driving forces. And throughout there is a none-too-subtle undercurrent of anomie and sex. 
 These artists are young, mostly under 35, and live and work in London. Left to their own devices in a climate of deep recession and intense social change, they've created a scene that is putting London back on the map as an iconoclastic international art center. And starting today, work by 22 of them can be seen in " 'Brilliant!' New Art From London," at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.
Some of the pieces have appeared in shows before: Sarah Lucas's 1993 "Concrete Boots," a Doc Martens look-alike, and Sam Taylor-Wood's 1994 photograph "Slut," a self-portrait showing her neck covered with love bites. Others are fresh from the studio, like Jake and Dinos Chapman's fiberglass sculpture "Ubermensch," which perches Stephen Hawking, the wheelchair-bound physicist, on top of a rocky crag.
At first glance, the London art scene appears to be a kind of social club of artists who studied together, many at one or another of the city's 10 art schools, and who still often share studios and socialize at the same boozy, smoky openings. They operate spaces to show one another's work, appear together in group shows and sometimes work together on projects. "They have this kind of rivalry and camaraderie at the same time," said Victoria Miro, a London dealer who has four artists in "Brilliant!"
Another dealer has a somewhat different view. "This is a group of artists who have emerged in the post-Thatcher era, with a mentality of 'You can get what you want if you club together,' " said Jay Jopling, the 31-year-old London dealer whose tiny commercial gallery, White Cube, in Piccadilly, is viewed by many as the club's salon.
At second glance, the milieu is also one of savvy marketing and individual chutzpah. Mr. Hirst, Mr. Jopling's most celebrated artist, has alienated many art followers by using what some regard as a particularly trendy brand of nihilism to turn himself into an art star. Five years ago, Mr. Hirst created an unsettling life cycle in a glass box: a rotting cow's head, a pile of maggots and a bug zapper to kill the flies that hatched. For his "Natural History" series he filled more glass boxes with formaldehyde and added such things as a shark, a bisected cow and a fluffy white lamb. Though Mr. Hirst makes other sorts of assemblages, as well as paintings, his continued use of dead animals has made him a favorite of the tabloid press.
Mr. Jopling defends such tactics. "I don't call it shock value," he said. "For years, arts editors of national newspapers have lambasted contemporary art in this country. Artists have had to fight that much harder to have any attention paid to their work."
Besides, he pointed out, people tend to forget that Mr. Hirst is a team player. He first came to public notice when, as an art student in 1988, he helped curate "Freeze," a polished and successful group show held in a warehouse. And while he has gone on to a vigorous solo career, Mr. Hirst still insists on showing as part of a group, sometimes alongside freshly minted art school graduates.
Mr. Jopling, for his part, has risen to prominence as a sort of freelance ringmaster, helping artists put together temporary, often site-specific shows in the floating gallery scene that began to flourish in London during the late 1980's. The collapse of the art market in the early 1990's, which practically decimated the city's tiny gallery world, conveniently coincided with a depressed real-estate market that left plenty of atmospheric warehouses, slaughterhouses and office buildings empty.
Floating galleries took off on roughly the same schedule as acid house parties and raves, and, like them, depend as much on the experience of being there as on the actual work presented. For many, the job of extracting marketable artifacts from this scene sometimes became a work of art in itself. Two years ago, Tracey Emin, a 32-year-old Londoner, sought investors in her "creative potential," offering four letters a year as collateral.
Mr. Jopling gave Ms. Emin a show at White Cube and has been marketing her life-as-work pieces ever since. At a recent art fair, he installed her in a bed, covered by a quilt -- which promptly sold -- that Ms. Emin had made from old clothes and other mementos. In "Brilliant!" she will exhibit a tent appliqued with the names of all those with whom she has ever shared a bed.
Are these artists and dealers cynically exploiting a gullible public for their own gain? Or do they display an admirable seat-of-the-pants creativity of the sort that is desperately needed to recharge a depressed climate? In Britain, which remains comparatively socialist, that is the kind of major moral quandary provoked by Thatcher-style entrepreneurism.
If many of the marketing tactics seem to be born of Thatcherism, what appears to bind the work together thematically is a reaction against it. When British Pop Art boomed more than 30 years ago, its artists (like Richard Hamilton and David Hockney) were the product of a more cohesive society, a spirit of playful cross-class experimentation and a fascination with consumerism.
 THE CURRENT SCENE finds inspiration in the dour notion that British civilization has reached the end of its road. A lively obsession with mortality and decay can be seen across the board, starting with that famously rotting cow's head and even echoing through an older generation perhaps best illustrated by Lucian Freud's mordant and fleshly nudes.
For a recent gallery opening, Anya Gallaccio festooned the walls with Pop Art-like daisy chains and left them to decompose, a project she is repeating at the Walker. Work like Mr. Hirst's and Ms. Gallaccio's is often said to refer back to the "memento mori" tradition, bespeaking an unblinking, fundamentally healthy acceptance of death. But blink another way, and it looks like a political response to consumerism, which tends to promote itself by promising everlasting youth.
Many young artists in Britain are similarly fixated on domestic life, community and civic planning, all totems of the partly dismantled welfare state. Two years ago, in an installation called "I Love You," Rachel Evans stenciled a lace curtain on a gallery window in Vaseline and filled the air with the scent of Vicks. Abigail Lane, whose work appears at the Walker, constructs art from media like ink pads and stamps and crime photographs, the evidence of an increasingly intimidating police force.
Ms. Whiteread, probably the best known of the "Brilliant!" 22, is celebrated for her simple, elegiac casts of domestic objects like sinks, cabinets and mattresses. In 1993, she won the Turner Prize, Britain's major contemporary art award. The same year she also made a monument using as her mold the interior of an entire Victorian row house.
Yet politics, for the young British artist, offers endless ironies. While Ms. Whiteread's inside-out "House" was praised as a paean to vanishing notions of community and public housing, it reportedly sat less well with the working-class people who had to live alongside it.
Ms. Whiteread, like many of her colleagues, received a major career boost when she was discovered by Charles Saatchi. Mr. Saatchi, a founding partner of Saatchi & Saatchi, the giant advertising company that helped lever Mrs. Thatcher's Tory Party to power, has long been a major collector of contemporary British art, some of which he presents to the public in a privately run gallery.
But perhaps the most curious contradiction of all is that the British press and the public, both of which have long been renowned for their dislike of contemporary art, have recently begun to embrace it. Last month alone, three art events attracted large crowds and mostly enthusiastic reviews.
In an installation by Cornelia Parker in Hyde Park, Tilda Swinton, the star of the 1993 film "Orlando," reclined in a glass vitrine alongside other vitrines holding objects like one of Queen Victoria's stockings and the pillows from Sigmund Freud's couch.
With the support of Artangel, a charity that organizes several site-specific events a year, the director Robert Wilson mounted a work called "HG," a rabbit warren of mysterious, stunningly theatrical installations in some medieval dungeons beneath London Bridge.
And those old provocateurs, the always well-dressed performance artists Gilbert and George, displayed brightly colored photomontages depicting their naked selves and their own bodily waste. Though this show, installed in a Government-financed gallery, could have been expected to raise hackles, two weeks into its run only two written complaints had been received.
Today, with the opening of its first major museum show, an art movement apparently born of social dissent seems to be verging on public acceptance. Maybe in the end, it will turn out to cohere not around transient change but around deeply rooted tastes: the national passion for theater, the appreciation of style for style's sake and a longstanding love of nose thumbing. Or perhaps what binds it together is the simple fact that, as Gilbert told a visitor recently: "There's a kind of anarchic atmosphere underneath, in London. And that's where art is."

HEADLINE: MEDIA: PRESS;
The Miami Herald's ninefold path to reader enlightenment raises some journalists' eyebrows.

BYLINE: By William Glaberson 

 BODY:
YOU used to sit down with your morning newspaper and say, "Let's see what's happening in the world."
But in Miami, that is being updated: Get your morning coffee, settle back with The Miami Herald and read all about what is happening in nine subject areas. 
 Nine? In a recent memorandum to the paper's staff that has drawn bemusement in newsrooms across the country -- and has perplexed some journalists at The Herald -- the newspaper's publisher said the paper was now going to "focus its newsroom resources on nine subject areas that readers have told us are especially important and useful."
Here, then, is what might be called The Miami Herald's Top Nine list: local government, education, sports, environment, consumer news, Florida news, health and medicine, Latin America and crime.
Sorry, Mr. Perot: The Presidential race didn't make the cut. "I think the net effect of this is a lot of head scratching in the newsroom," said Tom Fiedler, The Herald's chief political writer.
The Oct. 11 memorandum, signed by the paper's publisher, David Lawrence Jr., and its president, Joe Natoli, also happened to mention that the paper, which has been cutting its staff and closing bureaus for some time, is in store for more newsroom slimming. The Herald, owned by Knight-Ridder Inc., will soon have still fewer journalists as it keeps squeezing costs.
Mr. Lawrence asserted there was no relationship between the new "focusing" and the new cutbacks. He said the paper conducted "the best newspaper research project we have seen anywhere."
The research included studies by consultants of reader preferences. The decision to focus on some of those preferences, Mr. Lawrence said, was simply a response to a problem affecting many newspapers: sinking circulation.
Mr. Lawrence and the paper's executive editor, Doug Clifton, sounded offended in separate telephone conversations when asked whether the decision to focus on nine subjects might mean readers would get a less expansive view of current events. Both pointed out that the paper would still cover things that weren't listed.
Mr. Clifton acknowledged, however, that if gardening, for example, weren't on the list of nine subjects, "I guess you could say gardening would be somewhat diminished; there would be those kinds of trade-offs."
Gardening isn't on the list. But, as several journalists at The Herald noted with a touch of anxiety, in addition to national politics, other areas that didn't make the list include religion, economics, investigative reporting and, for that matter, world affairs.
Mr. Clifton said all newspapers make decisions about what to cover. He said a recent 18-month strategic planning process that included hundreds of Herald journalists had come up with coverage priorities that were similar to those identified by readers in the research.
Mr. Clifton added that the list of nine subjects would simply give editors a road map to help them make daily decisions. As an example, he said the paper would probably beef up consumer coverage and make sure such features as product-recall information could be easily found by readers.
But what if something other than a product recall happened in London, Tokyo, Denver or, say, Bosnia?
Readers of Miami's alternative newspaper, New Times, may have been given a hint of what is in store at The Herald in an article dealing with The Herald's coverage of the Bosnian war this summer. New Times published a memorandum written by Mr. Clifton to his staff in July on The Herald's computer system.
The memo, whose contents were confirmed by staff members, indicated he was not convinced that readers considered the paper's war coverage to be important and useful. By then, it is now possible to speculate, Mr. Clifton might have already been given an early tip that Bosnia had not made the Top Nine list.
"If anyone has an idea on what to do with the Bosnia story, I welcome it," Mr. Clifton wrote. "I'm embarrassed to say I long ago stopped reading this story of enormous human tragedy and significant global consequence."
Mr. Clifton argued that the fault belonged partly to journalists who had failed to answer what he said was the main question of readers: "What does this mean to ME?"
"If we can't make that clear in type and visuals," he added, "the story becomes one of faraway strangers killing other strangers in cities with unpronounceable names."
There were a few on the staff who took the reference to "visuals" as a sign that the wind was not blowing toward more in-depth journalism at The Herald.
Juan Tamayo, then the foreign editor, answered Mr. Clifton electronically. Mr. Tamayo attacked what he seemed to see as Mr. Clifton's destructive message.
Mr. Tamayo's sarcastic memo was also printed in New Times. "We want punch, pizazz," Mr. Tamayo steamed in his E-mail response. "We want that graphic that explains it all in three easy steps, that one zinger story that catches up those of us who have NOT BEEN READING some of the truly great stories we have carried over the past two years."
Outside the paper, some Herald watchers also do not like what they have seen lately. Joseph A. Angotti, a former senior vice president of news at NBC who now teaches communication at the University of Miami, said such moves as the issuing of the Herald list seemed to be driven by focus groups and reader research. He said he worried that newspaper editors were abdicating their job of deciding what was worth covering.
Reader research, Mr. Angotti said, probably would not have provoked coverage of the civil rights movement, for example. "I think one of the problems with The Herald -- and with a lot of newspapers -- is they pay too much attention to focus groups," he said.
