HEADLINE: In Mississippi, Will Poor Grow Poorer With State Welfare Plan?

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 17

 BODY:
Nine hundred miles away in the nation's capital, liberals are warning that the Republican plan to eliminate the Federal entitlement to welfare will encourage states to "race to the bottom."
Mississippi is already there. 
 It is a state where one of every three children lives in poverty, where the percentage of households without telephones or complete plumbing is twice the national average and where 22 percent of babies delivered last year were born to teen-age mothers. It is also the state with the lowest cash benefits for welfare recipients -- $120 a month for a mother with two children, less than a third of the national median. And unlike 31 states, Mississippi has no welfare program for single men and childless couples.
Now, as members of a House and Senate conference committee prepare to negotiate a final welfare bill, the question in states like Mississippi is whether newly granted autonomy will tempt them to discard their tattered safety nets altogether. Or will the states, unfettered by Federal requirements, respond by devising creative anti-poverty programs that may move recipients into the work force and out of dependency once and for all.
Those on the left argue that block grants, the lump sum social services payments to states that would replace direct Federal payments to welfare recipients, would be a dangerous tool in the hands of men like Gov. Kirk Fordice, a conservative Republican. "Fordice's position is that the only job training that welfare recipients need is a good alarm clock," said Rims Barber, executive director of the Mississippi Human Services Agenda, an advocacy group based in Jackson.
But Mr. Fordice, who faces re-election next month, responds that the notion that he cannot be trusted to care for the poor of his state is "a disgusting, elitist argument."
"I'm the Governor of a sovereign state that has the people of Mississippi a whole lot more at heart than any soul up there in the Congress of the United States," Mr. Fordice said in an interview.
And yet, Mr. Fordice also manages to confirm many of the worst fears of his opponents.
He said he would gladly accept less money from the Federal Government for social services under the block grant system so long as he is freed of Federal regulations on how to spend it. Both the House welfare bill, which was passed in March, and the Senate bill, which was passed in August, essentially would freeze Federal spending on Aid to Families with Dependent Children for the next five years.
Under the House bill, for instance, Mississippi would receive a slight increase in A.F.D.C. money for the next fiscal year, from $76 million to $79 million, according to estimates by the Department of Health and Human Services. Over the next five years, the state would receive $47 million less than it would if the current welfare system was maintained, according to Health and Human Services estimates.
Social services advocates worry that Mississippi, with the second lowest median income in the country, would have limited capacity to compensate for a loss of that kind if a recession causes the welfare rolls to balloon. And even if the state did have the capacity, they say, it might not have the inclination given that Mississippi's political leadership is largely conservative and white, while 82 percent of its welfare recipients are black.
In general, Mr. Fordice and the leaders of his Department of Human Services believe strongly that the government should use punitive measures to change the behavior of welfare recipients.
Mr. Fordice already has secured a waiver from the Clinton Administration that will go into effect on Nov. 1 to allow Mississippi to prohibit extra benefits for mothers on welfare who have additional children.
The Governor said he was convinced that mothers on welfare became pregnant precisely so that they could collect the $24 a month in extra benefits currently offered by the state. "Anybody who thinks they don't don't know what they're talking about," he said. "We can't keep subsidizing the production of additional illegitimate children."
Mr. Fordice also said he was interested in placing a time limit on the payment of welfare benefits, with two years being "the absolute outside limit."
To eliminate what some call the financial incentives that encourage some recipients to remain on welfare, Mississippi is pinning great hopes on an experimental program known as Work First. The program enables Mississippi to seize welfare and food stamp benefits from recipients and offer them as subsidies to employers who hire the recipients.
"Work First requires people to work for their benefits in a real job, not a hokey program picking up garbage along the highways," said Larry Temple, deputy administrator of the Department of Human Services.
The Work First program began in six of the state's 82 counties earlier this month under special permission from the Clinton Administration. Mr. Fordice said that a block grant system would allow him to expand the program statewide.
In a six-month training period, the state gives companies the equivalent of $3.25 an hour to employ welfare recipients, leaving the employer to contribute at least $1 an hour to bring the worker's pay up to minimum wage. Mothers with children over 3 years of age are required to participate, and the state provides vouchers for child care and transportation to and from work.
The state serves as a clearinghouse to match welfare recipients with jobs, and the recipients are required to accept any position they are offered. If they refuse to participate, they and their children are removed from the welfare rolls. After six months, the state's subsidy ends and employers are expected to hire the welfare recipients permanently. If they do not, the state seeks another job for the recipient.
"I can't blame someone who thoroughly understands the Federal system, as many welfare recipients do, and has calculated that they're much better off laying on the couch and watching TV all day than they are going out and taking a job," Mr. Fordice said. "What we're about here is making it more profitable to take the job."
Mr. Fordice seems to have women like Stella R. Thomas in mind.
The daughter of a woman who spent 21 years on welfare, Ms. Thomas is a 24-year-old single mother of three children who already has a seven-year dependency of her own. She has worked from time to time but has always had to quit because of problems finding child care.
Now she stays home in her Spartan apartment in Jackson's Christian Brotherhood housing project, watching cable television and trying to keep her children away from drug dealers and drive-by shooters.
Ms. Thomas acknowledges that some mothers on welfare would rather collect a government check than work, but said that she was not one of them. She is eager for her youngest child to turn 3 in December, she said, so she can qualify for Work First and its state-provided child care.
"My mom was on welfare so I guess I didn't know any other way and I just followed behind her," Ms. Thomas said. "But that $144 a month and $397 in stamps isn't enough when you have three kids and you cook every day. I don't want to do it all of my life."
With the Work First program just weeks old, state officials expect it to cost money in the short term but to generate significant savings as welfare recipients join the work force.
Because Mississippi's economy is relatively healthy, with unemployment hovering at about 6 percent this year, state officials are optimistic that they can find jobs for all eligible mothers. Employers like Carrie M. Shelton, who hired two Work First participants for her daycare center in Jackson earlier this month, said she had difficulty finding good workers and considered the state subsidy "a blessing."
But the task may get difficult in the poorest parts of the state, like the catfish-and-cotton country of the Mississippi Delta, where unemployment in several counties soars above 15 percent. Although the state's A.F.D.C. caseload has dropped by almost 11 percent to 50,000 families during the last two years, many Delta counties still have more than 10 percent of their population on welfare. And in those same counties, literacy rates and education levels can be remarkably low for welfare recipients, making it difficult to match many with even the most menial jobs.
Warren Yoder, the director of Operation Shoestring, a social services agency in Jackson, worries that without a federally guaranteed income for the poor, states like Mississippi will leave their most destitute citizens with little support, just as they did when emptying psychiatric institutions.
"I think we're shambling our way toward another disaster like that," he said, "but of much greater proportions."
Next: How Michigan puts welfare recipients to work.

HEADLINE: Louisiana Governor's Race Will Be a Study in Contrasts

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 22

 BODY:
In a clear reflection of the course of Southern politics, Louisiana voters on Saturday placed a conservative white Republican and a liberal black Democrat in a runoff to become the state's next governor.
Pollsters and political analysts predicted today that the racial and ideological makeup of the state should give State Senator Mike Foster, a 65-year-old Republican from the bayou town of Franklin, an easy path to victory over United States Representative Cleo Fields, a 32-year-old Democrat from Baton Rouge. If Mr. Foster wins in the Nov. 18 runoff, he would become only the second Republican governor elected in the state since Reconstruction. 
 As the South has become increasingly Republican in recent years, Louisiana has been a relative holdout. Its Governor and both United States Senators are Democrats, and its Congressional delegation became majority Republican only this year when Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin switched parties.
"We're a little behind the curve," Edward F. Renwick, director of the Institute of Politics at Loyola University in New Orleans, said today. "It's happening here as one of the last places because Louisiana has always been one of the most populist Democratic states. But it happened last night."
Bernie R. Pinsonat, a Baton Rouge pollster, said: "Louisiana is going to become like the rest of the South -- a lot of white Republicans. And the blacks will become the dominant force in the Democratic Party."
In campaigns elsewhere around the South this fall, Democrats have been taking pains to sound like Republicans.
In Mississippi, for instance, Ronnie Musgrove, the Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor, is airing television commercials that describe him as "a common-sense conservative" who supports prayer in the schools, opposes gun control and favors "making able-bodied people on welfare work."
Similarly, in Kentucky, Paul Patton, the Democratic candidate for governor, is running as "a different kind of Democrat" who supports smaller government and boot camps for repeat juvenile offenders.
In Saturday's nonpartisan primary in Louisiana, voters essentially picked the two candidates at the ideological extremes of a 16-person field.
Mr. Foster, who switched from Democrat to Republican in early September, finished with 26 percent of the vote, including 34 percent of the white vote and 5 percent of the black vote, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls conducted by The Times-Picayune and WDSU-TV. Mr. Fields received 19 percent, including 60 percent of the black vote and 2 percent of the white vote. About 28 percent of Louisiana's 2.26 million registered voters are black.
Less than 10,000 votes separated Mr. Fields from State Treasurer Mary L. Landrieu, a Democrat and the daughter of Moon Landrieu, the former New Orleans Mayor; she finished with 18 percent. Rounding out the field were former Gov. Buddy Roemer, a Republican, also with 18 percent; Phil Preis, a Democrat and a Baton Rouge lawyer, with 9 percent, and Lieut. Gov. Melinda Schwegmann, a Democrat, with 5 percent.
Mr. Roemer, another former Democrat, had been the front-runner through most of the campaign, but Mr. Foster gained momentum about a month ago as conservative voters began to perceive him as a legitimate alternative. As primary day approached, Mr. Roemer came under heavy assault in advertisements that reminded Louisianians of the failures of his tenure as Governor and his willingness to reposition himself on any number of issues.
Mr. Foster, the grandson of a former Governor, is a millionaire businessman with interests in land, sugar and oil. He also owns a plantation, Oaklawn, where tourists pay a $6 admission. About 80 percent of the $2.2 million Mr. Foster spent in the primary campaign came out of his own pocket.
And yet Mr. Foster succeeded during the primary campaign by casting himself as the right-wing Everyman of Louisiana politics. He made an asset out of his expansive bald head and corpulent physique, declaring in television advertisements that he was "not just another pretty face." Throughout the campaign, he quipped that he just wanted to get the election behind him in time for duck hunting season.
"Somehow I was able to attract people because I somewhat do what they do, look like a lot of them and think like a lot of them," Mr. Foster said in an interview today.
Mr. Foster also touted legislation he sponsored to make it easier for Louisianians to carry concealed weapons and gladly accepted the support of conservative Christian groups and David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who nearly won the 1991 gubernatorial race.
"Why get mad at a guy who says you're the true conservative in the race?" Mr. Foster asked today. "That doesn't make any sense."
Mr. Fields, a protege of Jesse Jackson, is a slightly built, soft-spoken and earnest young leader who has moved through a remarkable succession of political victories at an early age. The 7th of 10 children, he became a State Senator at 24, the youngest legislator in state history, and a Congressman at 30.
Unlike Mr. Foster, Mr. Fields supports abortion rights and affirmative action and has called for more state spending on education and better job training programs for welfare recipients. He said at a news conference here today that he believed those positions would appeal to voters of all races.
"A man walking down the street at 5 o'clock at night with a pink slip in his hand is not black or white," he said. "That man is unemployed and needs a job. Kids who are in classrooms and don't have proper school supplies, they're not black or white kids. They're kids who need help."
Saturday's primary came at a time of deep dissatisfaction in Louisiana with the state's corruption-plagued politics. Using wiretaps, Federal investigators have turned up evidence that a number of state legislators may have taken bribes to protect the state's nascent gambling industry. The state's oft-investigated Governor, Edwin W. Edwards, who has dominated state politics for 25 years but chose not to run for re-election, is so unpopular that Mr. Foster came under heavy suspicion last week simply for meeting with a group of Edwards allies.
Voters reacted to the scandals by defeating several prominent legislators in the primaries on Saturday and forcing several others -- including Sammy Nunez, the Senate president, and B. B. (Sixty) Rayburn, a 46-year veteran of the Legislature -- into runoffs for the first time in decades. A referendum to limit state lawmakers to three four-year terms passed with 76 percent of the vote.
Several political analysts said that the state's newfound intolerance for corruption also allowed Mr. Foster to transform his personal wealth into a political asset.
"We've seen so much cronyism, stealing and corruption," Mr. Pinsonat said, "that there's a feeling that if a person like him has money, what will he need to steal for?"

HEADLINE: Parties Shift Budget Debate to How Proposals Affect Children

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
After weeks of attacking the Republican budget in the name of the elderly, the Democrats are shifting tactics and arguing that the country's children will suffer unduly if all the spending cuts become law. Not to be outdone, the Republicans are countering that their programs would benefit the young in the long run.
But in this argument, many economists side with the Democrats. 
 Speaker Newt Gingrich gave a preview of the Republican position in a speech on Thursday night, saying a vote to curb Medicare spending would halt the rise in the national debt, saving today's children from paying unbearable taxes in the future.
But legislating for posterity by reducing the deficit and thereby reducing future taxes mostly helps children who grow up to become jobholders and taxpayers.
Many economists do say that reducing the deficit now could lead to faster economic growth and, eventually, more jobs and a higher overall standard of living for today's children. But most of these economists also say the specific spending cuts in the Republican plans would fall very heavily on poor and lower-middle-class children today, leaving them less able to hold jobs in the years ahead. These poor and lower-middle-class children are the net losers even when the effects of higher long-term growth and more jobs are included.
The Democrats will promote their children-first arguments in a campaign that is to begin with a visit by Hillary Rodham Clinton to a children's hospital in New York on Monday morning. That same day the White House will release an economic analysis of the effect of the Republican budget proposals on children. Throughout the week Cabinet officials will fan out across the country giving speeches portraying Republicans as politicians willing to steal children's school lunches and ignore their medical needs.
One Administration official said the theme will be, "You can balance the budget for children without balancing the budget on the backs of the children."
Republicans are not waiting for the Democratic assault. Mr. Gingrich has scheduled a visit on Monday to the Boys Town orphanage in Nebraska, which he praised last year as a model of private charity replacing Government in caring for the poor.
The Republicans' planned cuts affecting low-income families with children would be substantial. At a time when a quarter of the nation's children live in poverty, the Republicans propose to cut projected spending on welfare, including the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program, turning that program into block grants to state governments. House Republicans are also calling for spending freezes or cuts for programs that maintain minimum health and nutrition standards for children and provide preschool education for young children in poor families.
The White House recently calculated that the poorest fifth of American families with children would lose an average of $1,521 a year in income and $1,662 a year in health benefits under Republican plans. These are families with an average annual income of $13,325.
To present themselves as defenders of children, Republicans have emphasized their $500-a-child tax credit. "It is real," said Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska. "It will help families with children and be very, very meaningful."
But the tax credit would do little to help children in low-income households. Families that have no Federal income tax liability after other exemptions and deductions would not be eligible for refunds.
For example, a family of four with both parents working and both children in child care programs would not qualify for the credit if it earned less than $24,000 in 1996. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal Washington research group with a reputation for accurate statistics, has calculated that 23.7 million children, or 34 percent of the nation's children, live in families too poor to qualify for the credit. Another 7.1 million children, or 10 percent, would qualify only for a partial credit.
The real winners from the Republican tax and budget plans are likely to be affluent children, who receive relatively little direct Federal spending but will have to pay much of the taxes for the national debt that today's adults leave behind. According to Congressional Budget Office figures, Federal budget deficits would total $1.35 trillion more over the next decade under President Clinton's plan to balance the budget in 10 years than they would under the Republican plan to balance it over 7 years.
Braking growth in the debt will hold down net interest payments on the debt, which have already risen to 15.3 percent of the Federal budget from 8.9 percent in 1980.
"It does seem pretty clear that those who will gain over the longer term will be those who would be paying the taxes," said Alan J. Auerbach, a professor of economics and law at the University of California at Berkeley.
Economists differ sharply about whether the proposed spending cuts would foster or impede economic growth by the time today's children are adults. Clinton Administration officials make the case that the Republicans are eliminating so many educational and training programs that they will hurt future growth, and the Administration plans to distribute a list of academic articles on Monday supporting that position.
"Those programs have a very high rate of return to the society and therefore are justified against other forms of investment," said Martin N. Baily, a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.
But most economists take the view that cutting the budget deficit will in general help future economic growth and children, by leaving money to be invested productively in the private sector instead of collecting it as taxes. "There would be a net benefit over the lifetime of young people, but not necessarily to everybody," said Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office. "What you're looking at is a situation in which, disproportionately, children in low-income homes would be contributing to the deficit reduction effort."
While paying few of the costs of deficit reduction, affluent children would benefit at least as much as poor children from a bigger economy. To the extent that poor children are less educated or even less nourished during their formative years, they will prove less able to compete for good jobs with the children of affluent families.
Advocates for children condemn that possibility as unacceptable, and some question the view of budget experts that the economy will grow more with the Republican budget plans. "It's very anti-family, anti-young family," said James D. Weill, the general counsel of the Children's Defense Fund, a liberal group in Washington. "If you cut the deficit by trashing the programs that you need to have children that are healthy and well nourished, the offsetting effects on the economy will hurt growth and in the long run hurt efforts to control Government spending and deficits."

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50;
And Now for the Next 50 Years: New Promises, Familiar Demands
Following are excerpts from remarks by heads of state and other leaders at a special session of the General Assembly yesterday marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations as compiled by the Federal Document Clearing House:

A Pledge of Support By the White House
Bill Clinton: President of the United States

 BODY:
 This week, the United Nations is 50 years old. The dreams of its founders have not been fully realized, but its promise endures.
The value of the United Nations can be seen the world over in the nourished bodies of once-starving children, in the full lives of those immunized against disease, in the eyes of students eager to learn, in the environments sustained, the refugees saved, the peace kept, and most recently, in standing up for the human rights and human possibilities of women and their children at the Beijing Conference.
The United Nations is the product of faith and knowledge -- faith that different peoples can work together for tolerance, decency, and peace. Knowledge that this faith will be forever tested by the forces of intolerance, depravity, and aggression.
Now we must summon that faith and act on that knowledge to meet the challenges of a new era. In the United States, some people ask, "Why should we bother with the U.N.? America is strong. We can go it alone."
Well, we will act if we have to alone, but my fellow Americans should not forget that our values and our interests are also served by working with the U.N.
The U.N. helps the peacemakers, the care providers, the defenders of freedom and human rights, the architects of economic prosperity, and the protectors of our planet to spread the risk, share the burden, and increase the impact of our common efforts.
Last year, I pledged that the United States would continue to contribute substantially to the U.N.'s finances. Historically, the United States has been, and today it remains, the largest contributor to the United Nations.
But I am determined that we must fully meet our obligations, and I am working with our Congress on a plan to do so. All who contribute to the U.N.'s work and care about its future must also be committed to reform, to ending bureaucratic inefficiencies and outdated priorities.
The U.N. must be able to show that the money it receives supports saving and enriching people's lives, not unneeded overhead. Reform requires breaking up bureaucratic fiefdom, eliminating obsolete agencies, and doing more with less.
The U.N. must reform to remain relevant and to play a still stronger role in the march of freedom, peace, and prosperity.
We see it around the world in the Middle East and Northern Ireland, people turning from a violent past to a future of peace. In South Africa and Haiti, long nights of fears have given way to new days of freedom.
Throughout this hemisphere, every nation except one has chosen democracy, and the goal of an integrated peaceful and democratic Europe is now within our reach for the first time. In the Balkans, the international community's determination and NATO's resolve have made prospects for peace brighter than they have been for four long years.
 
Russian Leader Is Wary Of Regional Groups
Boris N. Yeltsin: President of the Russian Federation
There is a dangerous tendency to play down the role of the United Nations, to circumvent its charter and the collective will of the Security Council.
Today the world, more than ever before, needs not only equality and tolerance, but respect for the identity of each state and an understanding of the peculiar features of its history. Each of them can and is willing to make its contribution to the development of a world community, and to find a worthy place therein. We should not allow the revival of the atmosphere of animosity and prejudice against countries and peoples.
Does the United Nations have the ability to achieve these goals?
In the opinion of Russia, it does. The United Nations can and should become the main instrument for building new international relations. It has all the necessary powers to do so. To carry out this mission, it should be provided with appropriate means, including financial resources. Russia meets and will continue to meet its obligations to the United Nations.
Certainly, the United Nations has not been able to achieve success in all areas, but the roots of its failure first and foremost lie in ourselves and the behavior of states and organizations. Russia is concerned at the situation whereby, as has recently been the case in Bosnia, the Security Council was relegated to the sidelines of events. It represents an obvious and clear-cut violation of the foundations of the world organization laid down by its founders.
It is inadmissible for a regional organization to take decisions on the mass use of force bypassing the Security Council. Russia has worked hard to bring closer peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. We are ready to support the operation on the implementation of a peace agreement with the participation of multi-national forces including Russian forces, but only under a clear-cut mandate of the United Nations Security Council.
Military force should never be used in those cases where diplomacy has proved unable to succeed. The effects of that would be tragic...
The main concern of Russia is to achieve stability in Europe and Asia. We are in favor of establishing a security system based on compromises rather than pressure. European security is indivisible. There is no alternative to that.
This is precisely the reason why Russia supports the idea of the earliest establishment of a new system of all European security where all European states would be represented. And this is precisely the reason why we are against NATO's eastward expansion. It will put a barrier on the way to establishing a unified Europe.
The question is an extremely acute one.Either such a system would be established for all Europe or as in the past, only for a select few. The strengthening of one bloc today means new confrontation beginning tomorrow.
 
Cuban Leader Attacks 'New Colonialism'
Fidel Castro: President of Cuba
Half a century ago the United Nations organization was born after the continuation of a monstrous war, where an average of 10,000,000 lives were lost at its peak moments. At present, 20 million men, women, and children are dying every year of hunger and incurable diseases.
Some wealthy nations have a life expectancy of up to 80 years, while others have hardly 40. So there are billions whose lives are cut off. How long shall we wait for this carnage to end?
The Cold War is over. But the arms race goes on. And nuclear and military hegemonism perpetuate themselves. How long shall we wait for the total removal of all weapons of mass extermination, for universal disarmament, and for the elimination of the use of force, arrogance, and pressure in international relations?
The obsolete veto privilege and the ill use of the Security Council by the powerful are exalting a new colonialism within the very United Nations. Latin America and Africa do not have one single permanent member on the Security Council. In Asia, India has a population of almost one billion, but it does not enjoy that responsibility.
... We lay claim to a world without hegemonism, without nuclear weapons, without interventionism, without racism, without national or religious hatred, without outrageous acts against the sovereignty of any country -- a world of respect for the independence and self- determination of peoples -- a world without universal models that totally disregard the traditions and culture of all the components of mankind.
We lay claim to a world without ruthless blockades that cause the death of men, women, and children, youths and elders, like noiseless atom bombs. We lay claim to a world of peace, justice, and dignity where everyone without exception has the right to well-being and to life.
 
South Korea Is Called A U.N. Success Story
Kim Young Sam: President, the Republic of Korea
The Republic of Korea was established in accordance with a U.N. resolution in 1948. At that time, it was one of the poorest countries in the world. Today, it is the 11th largest economy in the world and a truly democratic nation.
Our success has been a great manifestation of the ideals of the United Nations.
We are now one of the most active member nations in U.N. activities around the globe. We are already participating in the U.N. peacekeeping operations in the Western Sahara, Republic of Georgia, and Angola, and elsewhere. The Republic of Korea will also actively take part in various U.N. development and environmental projects and increase its monetary contributions...
I am convinced that the Korean peninsula will surely be unified in a democratic way in a not too distant future. I humbly and sincerely ask you all to become solid supporters for the peaceful unification of Korea.
 
Peacekeeping Is Seen Hurting Development
Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga: President of Sri Lanka
The new agenda of the United Nations with its heavy emphasis on peacekeeping operations has affected adversely on the development process. As a developing country, Sri Lanka attaches great importance to the role which the United Nations can and must perform in advancing the development process.
Unless the principles of the Declaration on the Right to Development, adopted in 1986 are applied positively with the full commitment of the developed and developing countries, the development process will not be sufficiently advised. We believe that the effective strengthening of the United Nations system is an essential requisite for advancing its goals. The organization has, regrettably, sometimes come to be seen by the more bilateral states as primarily serving the interests of the more powerful states. We welcome the timely initiative of the President of last year's General Assembly to strengthen and empower the United Nations system.
Such an effective empowerment requires, in our view, that, firstly, development priorities should not be sacrificed in the pursuit of political, military operations which must be set at realistic, even modest levels.
Secondly, decision-making by the United Nations in all areas must be based on full engagement of all members. The Security Council, in particular, must become more representative and more responsive to the general membership of the United Nations.
Thirdly, commitments made for multilateral action in all fields must be honored and diligently pursued. In short, the revitalizing forces must enhance the capacity of the United Nations rather than merely effect economies and scale down its scope.
 
Leader of Croatia Defends Nation's Destiny
Franjo Tudjman: President, Republic of Croatia
Destiny has allotted to small nations the role of promoters of great ideas. They are the leaders of positive changes in the evolution of humankind that turn the force of a struggle for national survival into a creative vision of tomorrow's world -- no longer a world of the large and small, the powerful and weak.
But only a world of equal nations and states committed to coexistence.
The boundaries of our freedoms are set by set by boundaries of the freedom of others. The affirmation of human dignity and the universal rights of the individual upheld by the charter of the United Nations can be achieved only through the respect for different ethnic, cultural and political identities through an efficient system of collective security and through respect for a law governed state and international law.
We have to turn negative energy into positive momentum. Reform of global relations and mechanisms must provide for greater respect for civilization's differences, for creative blending and dialogue on an equal footing.
 
Zambia Repeats Call For Broader Council
Frederick J.T. Chiluba: President of the Republic of Zambia
In a world of growing tensions and challenges the United Nations has performed well since its inception in 1945, and deserves a word of appreciation and thanks.
Some of its officers and personnel have made supreme sacrifices in the execution of their selfless tasks. Among them was the second Secretary General of the U.N., Excellency Dag Hammarskjold, who died in a plane crash on 17 September 1961 on Zambia's soil.
We must always remember all of them for their valor. Zambia is fully convinced, Mr. President, that the U.N. can do and must do even better. It's efficiency must be augmented and fortified.
Zambia, therefore, joins those countries which have called for restructuring of the U.N. to enable it to cope with increased demands and challenges. The U.N. today faces a crisis of confidence and expectations. The structures of 1945, designed and made to serve almost homogenous membership of 50 countries, which has since increased almost four fold are no longer capable to serve and service the bigger and wider globe.
Membership has increased in numbers, as well, as in regional diversity which calls for equitable, broader representation...
The Security Council, we believe can no longer be maintained like the sanctuary of the Holy of Holies with only the original members acting as high priests, deciding on issues for the rest of the world who can not be admitted.
Broader and geographical representation is the answer.
 
Norway's Leader Offers Plans for Reform
Gro Harlem Brundtland: Prime Minister of Norway
Though the U.N. today faces great difficulties, we the member states are responsible. The plowshare that worked for five decades is worn. Let us forge anew.
Today I will address five pressing issues. First, finance. Some dozen Parliaments hold this organization hostage by withholding their membership fees. How unworthy. We must all pay our fees in full and on time. We require some countries to pay more than their fair share. Other countries voluntarily pay more than their fair share. Many countries pay too little or hardly anything at all.
Second, we must reform. Change and renewal is a must for every effective organization. Reform of the Security Council is needed, where the issue of a reasonably balanced enlargement now must be addressed. The most obvious candidates being, of course, Japan and Germany, while the council's decision-making efficiency must be retained and its implementing ability greatly enhanced.
Responsibility for sustainable development for poverty, population, education, the environment is spread out. Mandates overlap. Let us draw up a schedule for implementing what we have decided in Rio, Cairo, Copenhagen and Beijing.
Third, we must coordinate our humanitarian assistance activities better allowing us to react more quickly and more effectively. Funds, people and resources often prove to be available only when human suffering has aggravated enough to dominate the evening news while other tragedies of famine, environmental degradation and underdevelopment remain unnoticed.
Fourth, we must improve our peacekeeping and conflict prevention capacity to save more lives and to save expenses...
Five, we must build the civilized world on law and contracts.
 
Japan Presses Its Call To End Nuclear Arms
Tomiichi Murayama: Prime Minister of Japan
The 50th anniversary of the United Nations is also the 50th year since the tragedies of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. It is time that we accelerate our efforts towards the ultimate elimination of nuclear weapons. I thus find it all the more deplorable that nuclear testing continues at this juncture. I strongly call for the immediate cessation to nuclear testing.
Toward this end, it is extremely important that a resolution calling for the cessation of nuclear testing be adopted and during this session of the General Assembly with the support of as many members states as possible. As a major step towards nuclear disarmament, I also believe that it is a most urgent task to complete the negotiations on a comprehensive Test Ban Treaty by next spring and to sign it by next autumn.
Mr. President, in our previous statement at the general debate, we outlined Japan's position on the reforms that are necessary if the United Nations is to be able to fulfill its mission.
Firstly, Japan having been playing a major role as the second largest contributor, earnestly calls upon all member states to face up to the financial crisis of the United Nations to honor their financial obligations and to urgently and seriously address the question of U.N. financial reform.
Secondly, it is increasingly necessary to reform the United Nations system in the economic and social fields. In proving the efficiency and reviewing the mandates of the economic and social council, and other related organs are pressing tasks. From this perspective, Japan will continue to actively participate in the discussions on an agenda for development so that it can make its distinct contribution.
Thirdly, with regard to reform of the Security Council, it is required that its functions be strengthened by enhancing it's effectiveness and it's legitimacy. This will necessitate an expansion of the Council that includes an increase in it's permanent membership and improvement in it's working methods, for example, through enhanced transparency.
 
Arafat Returns to U.N. Praising Forces of Peace
Yasir Arafat: Chairman of the P.L.O.
Mr. President, the history of the United Nations is intertwined with that of the question of Palestine. It was the United Nations which adopted the resolution on the partition of Palestine into two states, one Jewish and one Arab. Since then, the United Nations has not ceased to deal with the question of Palestine in all its ramifications and developments.
The history of the United Nations and its resolutions constitute an expression of its permanent legal, political and moral responsibility. They make the United Nations a witness to the immense suffering of our people and their sacrifices, their displacement and scattering in all parts of the world, as well as to the wars and massacres which have been inflicted upon them. ...
...Mr. President, the winds of change are blowing in our world. A new world order is emerging. It is our responsibility in the United Nations and in the international community to make it a good order for the stability, security and peace of the world with the wider participation of the states and peoples of the world.
We, therefore, support the trend towards the enlargement of the membership of the Security Council which will give it new vigor and will ensure justice and equality among all.
Mr. President, I came to you 21 years ago as a fighter for freedom, liberation and independence carrying with me the torments of my struggling people. Today, I come to you with a heart filled with love and peace now that the olive branch has adorned the peace of the brave, has adorned the peace of the brave.
 
Iranian Foreign Minister Attacks the U.S.
Ali Akbar Velayatin: Foreign Minister of Iran
Much of the ills of the international community stem from diversion of precious resources from development to arms race. Adding to an already complex problem are unilateral, economic measures ranging from protections policies and various forms of conditionalities to outright, coercive, economic measures and the United States policy of economic terrorism against independent states as well as to attempts to push aside the development agenda of the United Nations.
The efforts of the United Nations system in the area of cooperation for development, particularly those carried out by specialized agencies and programs have had the primary contribution in introducing ordinary people in the remotest parts of the world to the name, if not the ideals, of the United Nations.
The development agenda of the United Nations should not be overshadowed by other, more glamorous subjects, or undermined in the course of reform.
Indeed, the needs and aspirations of these very same people who constitute the majority of humanity must be the focus and foundation of any effort to revitalize, restructure and reform the organization whose conceptual objectives should be to render the United Nations decision making process transparent, democratic, rule-based and inclusive.
This is in total contrast with the self arrogated position of leadership of the United States which insists on misusing its position within the organization, and even at the 50th anniversary of the organization reserves for itself resort to unilateral measures against the will of the United Nations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United Nations General Assembly began its 50th anniversary celebration yesterday with the first of three days of speeches. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Better Wage Becomes a Luxury;
New Omni Hotel Employees Pursue the American Dream

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
To guests who begin checking into the newly refurbished Omni Berkshire Place in Manhattan this week, the white marble floors and recessed lighting will probably seem like the stock trappings of a luxury hotel.
To Rommel Vassell, however, they mean much more: the first gleaming rungs on the ladder of upward mobility in America. 
 "This is heaven-sent," Ms. Vassell, 36, said last week between training sessions at the hotel, on East 52d Street near Madison Avenue.
For most of the decade since she emigrated from Jamaica, Ms. Vassell has worked as a home health care attendant, making as little as $5 or $6 an hour with minimal benefits. As a housekeeper at the Omni, she makes more than $10 an hour with full medical coverage and a pension.
She is indeed among a lucky lot. Omni officials said they had about 320 job openings at the hotel, which is reopening after a year of renovations. They said they expected to receive about 5,000 inquiries and were stunned to field calls and take applications from more than 17,000 people.
That number speaks volumes about the hunger in New York City for full-time jobs with full benefits, a humane working environment, reasonable hours and a living wage. It also suggests the increasing extent to which relatively unskilled workers here and elsewhere in the country are turning to the service industry in general, and to corporate hotel chains in particular.
"The city, the state, the country have lost many, many, many manufacturing jobs, and the service industry is picking up the slack," said John Turchiano, a spokesman for the New York City Hotel Trades Council, a group of unions that represent hotel workers in various trades.
For example, in 1975, manufacturing provided about 16 percent of all jobs in New York City, while service positions represented about 23 percent, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Today, by contrast, manufacturing jobs represent less than 9 percent of all those in the city, while service jobs represent about 35 percent.
During the same period, the number of jobs in hotels and other places of lodging in the city grew to about 33,000 from about 25,000, according to the bureau. Nationally, the rise was even sharper, to nearly 1.7 million from about 898,000. One reason is an increase in foreign tourism in the United States, encouraged by a decline in the value of the dollar and by more aggressive marketing of American tourism.
What the statistics cannot capture is how coveted the best of these jobs are, how much they mean to people who desperately want better salaries and career growth in an economy that often thwarts those ambitions.
Most people who applied for jobs at the Omni, which has 396 rooms that cost about $250 a night, were not unemployed, said Chuck Wing, the hotel's director of human resources. Rather, they were stuck in jobs without benefits or much potential for raises, Mr. Wing said. What they felt they could get with the Omni Corporation, which operates 40 hotels in the United States, was possibility, security, hope.
During the two weeks in late July and early August when Omni advertised that applicants could stop by the hotel for interviews, the line of hopeful people stretched at times along Madison Avenue from 52d to 54th Street, then along 54th Street from Madison Avenue to Fifth.
Omni officials moved up the beginning of interviews from 10 A.M. to 7 A.M. Some applicants arrived as early as 4:30 A.M. to beat both the heat and the crowd.
One was Nancy Evangelista, 32, a single mother rearing three children in a five-room apartment in the Norwood section of the Bronx, and paying $900 a month in rent.
Although Ms. Evangelista has worked, variously, as a secretary, waitress, house cleaner and home health attendant, she has seldom made more than $8 an hour and never had full benefits.
At the Omni, as a front desk telephone operator, she has benefits and a wage of $10.60 an hour. If she picks up some overtime and continues to clean a few homes, she said, she may be able to inch her income toward $30,000 and save for her children's college educations.
She is working toward a sociology degree at Lehman College and would like to advance into the Omni's human resources department. "I'm going to try to go as far as I can," Ms. Evangelista said. "You know when a rose begins to open? That's how I feel."
Lawal Ahmed's new job as a bellman at the Omni, which he said may end up paying him as much as $30,000 a year in wages and tips, is not his most lucrative job. After emigrating from Ghana in 1987 at age 22, he ascended through the ranks in restaurants from dishwasher to manager, eventually making about $40,000 a year.
But he was putting in about 80 hours a week, which left him no time for his wife, his two children or his plans to get a college degree. At the Omni, he will work from 7 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., then head to classes at Bronx Community College, near his home in the Mosholu section. Maybe a college degree will pave the way toward better positions at the Omni, he said.
Ms. Vassell, Ms. Evangelista, Mr. Ahmed and other new employees at the Omni said that without a college degree or technical skills, it can be brutally difficult to find a decent job.
Their positions at the Omni, like those at many hotels in the city, are union jobs, which they said was one selling point. In any case, Ms. Vassell said, she now understands why her friends talk about jobs with hotel chains with envy and longing. The Omni allows her paid sick days and even a paid day off for her birthday -- little perks exotic to her. "I feel feel like I've made a big turn in my life, a whole 90-degree angle," she said.
Ms. Vassell, a single mother with a grown son living at home and a daughter at Florida International University, said she could envision the day she can afford the $845 a month rent for her apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn, without leasing a room to a boarder.
She just increased the allowance she sends her daughter, who is attending school on financial aid, from $80 a month to $150 every two weeks. She has an extra gift in store. One of her new benefits is a free three-day stay at an Omni hotel. There is one in Miami, near the Florida International campus, and Ms. Vassell looks forward to treating her daughter to a very special weekend.

HEADLINE: Damascus Journal;
Let Loose on the Streets, 10,000 Mice Rout Buses

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 21

 BODY:
In a city where little else moves quickly, there is a reason the 10,000 minibuses that seem to run wild on the streets have come to be known affectionately as mice.
Only four years ago people in the Syrian capital had little choice but to rely on creaking green Government buses to carry them, even though service and management were so poor that residents spoke of a transportation crisis. 
 Now that has changed. In the most visible consequence of Syria's new enthusiasm for private investment, swift Japanese minibuses have come to dominate the city's thoroughfares, and they have spread so rapidly that they have virtually driven their state-run rivals from the streets.
To be sure, the old buses live on, but mostly to shuttle Government workers from ministry to ministry. In a way unimaginable in London, Paris or New York, public transportation within this ancient capital is now entirely private.
For centuries, Syria has been a country of farmers, merchants and traders; some estimates say that as much as 60 percent of the economy is in private hands. But in a country more recently steeped in state socialism, no one here is ready to talk about full-scale privatization.
Still, if Syrians are not yet ready to entrust the country's state enterprises to the free market, what has happened on the streets of the capital has brought a surprising twist in an experiment the Government calls "parallel private development."
"The private sector just wiped the public sector out," declared Bourhan Odeh, a businessman who was among those who seized on the 1991 opening in Syrian law that set off the transformation. Until that law passed, anyone tempted to compete against the Government transportation system had to contend with the 200 percent duty that Syria imposed on imports of most vehicles, one of the barriers that have made this country's economy isolated even by the standards of the region.
The new measure, adopted after the Soviet Union's collapse, was an important shift. Among the inducements that Syria offered to private investors were a five-year tax holiday and, most significantly, a waiver on customs fees. It did not take long before the streets of this city of three million began to reflect the long-shunned world in which a $15,000 Mazda minivan could be had without paying three times that price.
Instead of waiting half an hour for a bus, people found that a minibus passed by every few minutes. At about 10 cents, the standard fare is about what a bus used to be, and riders could count on a seat.
Among those who remember the 1980's, when taxis were scarce and a shortage of foreign currency meant that buses sometimes ran short of spare parts, the change has marked the beginning of an era.
"The micros solved a huge crisis," said Fadi Murdem, 35, who sold his share in a sweets shop to buy a minibus. "Now you just pay three or four pounds and you get what you want in a hurry."
In a long-isolated city where only in the last two years have people been able to buy Western cigarettes and bananas on the open market, it is the revolution in transportation, even more than the arrival of Adidas and Benetton shops on downtown streets, that is most often described as a metaphor for welcome new ways.
"On the bus, you get hassled," said Rola Badoun, an 18-year-old student. "People push you and I hear silly phrases from men, like 'Oh, what a beauty,' and, 'Such beautiful eyes,' which does not make me comfortable. On the micro, there is no hassle at all."
So many Syrians jumped at the chance to join the cavalcade that the Government has cut off the flow of duty-free vehicles, but even that has not halted the rush to a private business, which some find lucrative enough to enter without the inducement. Minibuses now venture regularly onto the narrow streets of the city's old souk, raising talk that they may one day cause problems of traffic and air pollution as large as the one they solved.
But few Damascenes bother to defend the despised old buses, whose drivers have begun to see the light. After four years behind the wheel of a Government bus, Khdir Mahmoud, 32, tripled his monthly salary to about $250 when he decided to quit his job last year and drive a minibus.
In other parts of the Syrian economy, change is less apparent. But Mohammed Surakbi, director of the Government's investment office, says the campaign to attract private investment has brought to Syria new ventures worth as much as $7 billion that will compete against Government enterprises as part of the "parallel development."
But while the country is plainly eager for more foreign currency, diplomats and Syrian officials say that the country intends to maintain strict limits on just how far the private sector can go.
For what it calls strategic reasons, the Government still retains control over commodities like oil, cotton, wheat and barley. And when it comes to sharing the spotlight, officials close to the Government point to the sidelined buses in the capital as evidence that big Government businesses still have a long life.
"The official attitude is that if the public company is a failure, then why burden the private sector with it?" said Dr. Rateb Shallah, president of the Damascus Chamber of Commerce. "And if the company is successful, why privatize?"

HEADLINE: Today, Shoppers on Internet Get Access to Electronic Cash

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
A prominent project to create electronic cash that can be zapped over the Internet to buy goods and information is scheduled to start issuing its first real money today.
Digicash, an Amsterdam concern run by the noted cryptography expert David Chaum, said Mark Twain Bankshares of St. Louis would be the first bank to offer customers Digicash's E-Cash. 
 Amid all the hoopla about the potential for offering goods and information over the Internet, one big stumbling block has been the development of a secure and reliable system to pay for these products.
Mr. Chaum, a former University of California professor, holds some key patents on coding techniques used to make electronic money, and his software has been made available without charge over the Internet for most of the year, with 60,000 people testing it with play money.
Mark Twain, which hopes to attract customers for E-cash from around the world, was chosen as the first to offer an actual account because it is one of the few banks that accepts small deposits in the United States in a wide range of foreign currencies.
At first, only a handful of companies will accept the E-Cash, including Maryland Public Television and Pentagon CD's and Tapes, an on-line music store.
To use the system, a customer establishes an account with Mark Twain and sends an initial deposit, say $200. Then using software provided by Digicash, some of that money is electronically transferred over the Internet to the customer's computer. The current balance is displayed in a small window on the screen.
While surfing the net the customer comes across something to buy -- say the 1996 stock picks of Louis Rukeyser, which Maryland Public television intends to sell for about $3 using E-Cash. Then the customer simply pushes a button on the E-Cash software to transfer the money again over the Internet to the television network, which deposits the funds in its own bank. The customer can then read or download the stock picks.
The small amount of Internet commerce that has been done so far uses credit cards, which have the advantage of already being in the wallets of most Internet users. But credit cards have a number of disadvantages for certain types of electronic transactions. Because they offer itemized billing, for example, credit cards are too expensive for very small purchases, like news articles that might cost 10 cents each. And banks only allow established merchants with a credit record to accept credit cards.
E-Cash is intended to get around these problems. Payment is immediate, with no billing statement, so very small payments are economical. Moreover, anyone with an E-Cash account can both send and receive funds electronically, allowing virtually everyone to set up shop on the Internet.
With E-Cash, the banks do not know where the customers spend their money. Nor do the merchants know the identity of their customers, unless the customers voluntarily identify themselves.
Using a complex coding mechanism, all this information is stored in the electronic messages that represent the payments, but it can be unlocked with keys that only the customer keeps.
Using those keys, consumers can obtain from their bank the electronic equivalent of a canceled check to prove a payment was made to a particular merchant in case of a dispute. And they can get a refund for electronic money lost if say, their computer's disk drive fails.
Digicash's system has one major disadvantage compared with credit card plans: Initially, at least, it is more expensive.
As of Friday, the final fees had not been set, but it was expected to cost about $10 to establish an account and an additional $2 to $5 a month to maintain it. Those who deposit or withdraw more than a set amount -- about $100 -- will pay a 2 to 4 percent fee. Merchants expecting higher volumes will be able to set up accounts with bigger fees and lower percentages.
Other banks say they are interested but cautious.
"The market for small payments on the Internet will grow very slowly, so it hasn't been our highest priority," said Martha C. Campbell, a senior vice president of the Bank of America, who nonetheless complimented the product's design.

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Only Bills and Notes

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bills and notes markets, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. Tomorrow the Government will auction a two-year note, followed by Wednesday's auction of a five-year note.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.25 percent, traders said, while the six-month bill was at 5.32 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a rate to yield 5.72 percent and the five-year note at a rate to yield 5.87 percent.

HEADLINE: Most Go on Line at Home, Study Finds

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
A new survey conducted at one of the Internet's most popular hangouts suggests that most people are tapping into the World Wide Web and commercial on-line services from home, not from the office or at school.
The survey of Internet users, conducted by Yahoo Inc. and Jupiter Communications Inc. for release today, concludes that computer networks are become a mass market medium much faster than many people expected. 
 Separately, a continuing survey of consumer on-line services found that Americans are still signing up for computer networks at a rapid pace, with nearly 14,000 new commercial on-line service accounts being opened each day.
According to the Information and Interactive Services Report, 9.9 million Americans subscribed to consumer on-line services as of Sept. 30, an increase of 78 percent from a year earlier. America Online, with 3.8 million subscribers, was both the largest and the fastest-growing service, according to this study.
And Silicon Valley executives were briefed last week on the preliminary findings of yet another major survey of the Internet and the World Wide Web. The release of the Commercenet/Nielsen study, believed to be the most comprehensive attempt yet to count the number of Internet users and define their habits, is expected early next week.
Unlike the other studies, the Yahoo/Jupiter study is unusual because it was conducted entirely on line, with the goal of determining the habits of visitors to Yahoo's World Wide Web directory.
Yahoo asserts that some 300,000 people visit its Web site (http:// www.yahoo.com) each day, as a first step to finding other sources of information on the Internet.
All visitors at the Yahoo site were given the opportunity to participate in the survey, conducted in August and September. According to Yahoo and Jupiter, more than 60,000 computer users answered a questionnaire in the first phase of the study, and 10,000 of those answered a more detailed second survey.
The Yahoo/Jupiter survey found that participants in the study spent an average of 20 hours a week on line. More than half of the respondents said they had cut back on the amount of time they watched television to spend more time on the Internet.
A majority of respondents said they had been on the Web less than a year, and spent at least one hour on line in their most recent session. Most said they visited the Web or other on-line services more than once a day.
While 55 percent said their primary access to the Web was at home, many of those who said their primary access was at work or school also had secondary access from the home. All together, 85 percent of the Yahoo users who answered the survey said they were able to tap into the Internet from home.
"It's a sign we're heading in the direction of critical mass for consumer marketing on the Internet," said Gene DeRose, Jupiter's president.
Only 8 percent of the respondents in the Yahoo/Jupiter survey said they gained primary access to the Web through one of the commercial on-line services, like America Online or Compuserve. Half of the respondents said they reached the Web via an Internet service provider. Forty percent said their primary Web access was at work or school.

HEADLINE: A Strategy for Lower Manhattan

 BODY:
Once the unassailable financial capital of the world, New York City finds itself in endless negotiations these days to dissuade this or that company from leaving town. A package of nearly $100 million in state and city subsidies has now been ponied up to persuade the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange not to move to Jersey City. The danger here is that more and more companies will demand special treatment. A broader, less piecemeal approach is needed to secure the city's economic future.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has rightly emphasized steps to lower the cost of doing business in the city. Lower Manhattan poses a particular problem because many financial institutions are located in antiquated buildings that require major investments to bring in the new technology needed for today's globally competitive environment. 
 To its credit, the city has begun to change zoning regulations so that new office buildings can span some of the old, narrow streets in the area. The administration is also studying creation of a special district in lower Manhattan so that it would be easier to build apartment complexes, stores and recreation areas, helping to transform an area that is traditionally dead after working hours into a place where people go or even live all hours of the day. The State Legislature recently approved a package of tax abatements designed to encourage developers to convert old buildings and put up new ones for residential and commercial use.
In the last decade, scores of individual deals with companies have been struck to keep them in the city, with hundreds of millions of dollars spent in subsidies. Some of those deals proved disappointing when companies that received benefits turned around and reduced their staffs or moved parts of their operations out of the city anyway. The Giuliani administration has improved on the process by obtaining commitments from each company to retain a fixed number of jobs or forfeit part of the subsidy. But all the deals should be scrutinized by the City Council or others to determine if they meet the strictest cost-benefit standards.
It may well be impossible to restore lower Manhattan to its former glory. Its property values are declining faster than the general rate in Manhattan, and its office vacancy rate is approaching 25 percent, a postwar high. Many buildings are half-empty. If lower Manhattan fails as a financial powerhouse, the entire region will suffer.
Instead of competing with New Jersey, Connecticut and other parts of New York State for jobs, the Mayor needs to enlist them in developing improved commuter rail access to lower Manhattan, including steps to bring the Long Island Railroad and Metro North to the area. More attention should be paid to major improvements, including a new Staten Island Ferry Terminal and a new headquarters for the New York Stock Exchange, which is getting restless because of its cramped and obsolete quarters. New York City cannot retain its pre-eminence in financial services simply by bribing companies one at a time.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Loyal Opposition on How to Fix America

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:

REASON TO BELIEVE
By Mario Cuomo
191 pages. Simon & Schuster. $21. 
 Seasoned by experience and not noticeably chastened by defeat, the former Governor of New York announces in "Reason to Believe" that he and liberalism are alive and that at least one of them is well. His loyal exposition of the liberal faith and his peppy attacks on the Republican Contract With America are a call to action at a time when the action all seems to be on the other side.
Writing as one who was "capsized by the Republican tide of 1994," Mario Cuomo, who can now be heard on radio when he is not delivering for his law firm, sees the current political course, or the "New Harshness," as heading "backward toward our nation's first century," when exploitation was the rule. He traces his own political faith to the reformist impulses of the early 1900's, which put restraints on corporations, and to the New Deal and the Great Society, which wove a safety net for the needy.
If that sounds like a conventional campaign biography, so be it. But this is campaign season, and Mr. Cuomo's vigor may act as a restorative for the spirits of the beaten-down liberals to whom his book is plainly addressed. The Gingrichian "plastic populism," he argues, is evading the nation's problems or offering inadequate solutions, trading instead on whipping up outrage, "distilling the bitterest juices from the people's anger, bottling them as legislation and then offering it all back as a magic elixir."
His preferred elixir is "a new sense of community," a recognition that "we're all in this together, like a family, interconnected and interdependent," instead of being tempted into "isolation, insularity and indifference to our opportunities in the wider world and our obligations to one another."
Often this short book, which could benefit from being shorter, sounds like a speech, with many points being made more than once and applause lines along the way. When he calls for progress "through integration and not disintegration, through synergism not cynicism, through inclusion not exclusion," he seems to be borrowing from the Rev. Jesse Jackson. It can be wearing on a reader. Just eliminating the tributes to Momma Cuomo, which give some passages the flavor of an Academy Award acceptance speech, would have a bracing effect.
Despite those bad habits of the career politician and a certain amount of recycling, "Reason to Believe" makes a strong, clear appeal to the national impulses that brought about such Democratic-inspired measures as welfare and affirmative action, which are now under heavy assault. While acknowledging some overreaching and underachieving, Mr. Cuomo is not ashamed to call on America to remember the C word, compassion.
He notes, in one of the book's funnier lines, that in the Reagan era of supply-side benefits for the wealthy, "the average American didn't experience any 'trickle-down' benefits; many, in fact, got trickled upon." And he warns that the Republican promise of a balanced budget along with tax cuts bodes ill for investment in the future, "things like children who can read, bridges that stand up, and new breakthroughs in energy efficiency and environmentally sound technology."
It also means, he writes, "the most draconian reductions in worthwhile services for Americans that the nation has ever seen." As a non-candidate, Mr. Cuomo is free to come out against both a balanced-budget amendment and any plan to eliminate the Federal deficit within a given number of years, lest it strangle Government investment that would stimulate the economy and help the needy. Instead, he favors a gradual slowing in the growth of the national debt. The former Governor predicts, on the basis of hard experience, that reducing the income tax will involve steep increases in sales taxes and property taxes.
He concedes that a call for attention to the nation's infrastructure is not a vote-grabber ("No one ever comes up to you starry-eyed and says, 'Oh, Governor, you really know how to structure the infra.' ") but he is persuasive about the importance of spending to keep bridges and roads in good repair. If the Republicans want to cut something, he suggests, they should cut military spending and business subsidies. When it comes to cuts in Medicare, his language is less pointed than usual as he expresses support for "modifying payments to health providers."
He presses the unresolved question about the drive toward "workfare": Where are the jobs? For workfare to work, he notes, there have to be decently paying jobs that the recipient can handle, and he does not find much concern for that detail in the Gingrichian contract. He points out that welfare reform is not, in the short term, a money-saver and doubts that the Republicans are inclined to pay the price in day care, training and job creation.
Mr. Cuomo knows that his preachments here are running against the prevailing mood. At a time of celebrated distrust of Washington, which is still being fueled by his colleagues in the talk-radio industry, he calls for a reassertion of a sense of community through government, in particular the Federal Government. The man who declined to run for President cautions against the rush to "devolution," the popular notion of returning power to states and localities.
Responding to the mantra of the less government the better, he asks, "Were we a better nation without Social Security for the elderly, without civil rights for minorities, without financial aid for college students, without rules regulating pollution?"
Toward the end of his book, he draws on his experiences in Albany to offer some recommendations for reforming welfare, improving the public schools, dealing with drugs and crime, and so forth. For all the partisan shots, the call here is for a national effort to take on intractable problems, be they street violence or television violence, in a spirit of togetherness. He would, I surmise, be enthusiastic about current calls for a bipartisan Presidential commission on race.
Granted, a commandment like "we should insist on all the government we need but only the government we need" doesn't get one very far. Yet the line between Mr. Cuomo's vision of community and the Contract With America becomes sharp enough. He is saying there is plenty that only Washington can do and should be doing to give Americans things they really need and properly expect.
