HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: CASTRO;
Castro Back In Fatigues, And Harlem

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

 BODY:
After a restrained day of diplomacy, clad in a dark business suit, President Fidel Castro of Cuba changed back into fatigues last night to spend the evening before an adulatory audience at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem.
Standing at a podium before 1,300 admirers, Mr. Castro held forth as if he were on a balcony overlooking a plaza in Havana, drinking in the cheers and applause that greeted his nearly every remark. 
 While he had been somber and succinct at the United Nations in the morning, looking more like a well-suited executive than a scruffy revolutionary, he turned back into a firebrand in his visit uptown.
As Mr. Castro spoke, 35 years after his first trip to Harlem made headlines, most other world leaders were attending President Clinton's cocktail party at the New York Public Library. Mr. Castro was not invited; he is being excluded from nearly every social event outside the United Nations.
"This is the 35th anniversary of my first visit to this neighborhood," he said at the church. "And the incredible thing is, I am still expelled. I am still being left out of the dinners, as if nothing had changed in all these years, as if we were still in the days of the cold war."
On his first full day in the United States in 16 years, Mr. Castro picked up where he had left off so long ago, lobbying for the Cuban revolution. This time, though, he seemed particularly to relish taking his campaign to end the embargo against Cuba into enemy territory, emboldened by a shift against it by some American business leaders and members of Congress.
After leaving the Cuban Mission, where he is staying, Mr. Castro began his whirlwind day with a six-minute speech at the United Nations and then went to the studios of the Cable News Network for an interview. In the first part of the day, he traded his familiar crusade against imperialism for a more tempered, but not less controversial, call for social justice.
At the United Nations, Mr. Castro, who drew more applause than President Clinton, spoke out against wealthy nations who have neglected their poorer neighbors, and against weapons of "mass extermination."
His finger jabbing the air for emphasis, Mr. Castro spoke most vehemently against the United States embargo, eliciting rousing applause from the General Assembly and other world leaders.
"We lay claim to a world without ruthless blockades that cause the death of men, women and children, youths and elders, like noiseless atom bombs," he said. "We lay claim to a world of peace, justice and dignity where everyone, without exception, has the right to well-being and life."
Just after his speech and before lunch, Mr. Castro walked over to the leader of the country that was his onetime benefactor, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. The two embraced warmly, stepped apart, embraced again, then stood together,hands clasped in a series of grips. They spoke animatedly through an interpreter. Then Mr. Castro abruptly left the building.
Outside the United Nations, Mr. Castro's presence prompted a less effusive, if no less passsionate, response.
Turning out for one of the largest protests of the day, hundreds of Cuban-Americans chanted for his death.
One woman carried a poster bearing the pictures of Hitler, Stalin and Mr. Castro, stating "What's the difference?" On the East River, a pro-Castro flotilla and an anti-Castro flotilla moved at crosscurrents.
In Miami, watching Mr. Castro's appearance at the United Nations on television, many Cuban exiles said they were chilled by the warm reception he received.
"His duplicity was transparent," said Rafael Penalver, president of the San Carlos Institute, a Cuban cultural center in Miami. "He is the man who ruled Cuba without an election for 37 years, calling for the democratization of the United Nations."
In his interview on CNN, Mr. Castro spoke of his keen interest in Gen. Colin L. Powell's autobiography, of his belief that Jimmy Carter would not be able to mediate between the United States and Cuba, and of his refusal to extradite Robert Vesco, the fugitive financier.
But he refused to discuss the presence of his daughter, Alina Fernandez Revuelta, among the protesters outside the United Nations.
"Look, Bernie," Mr. Castro said to Bernard Shaw, who was interviewing him. "You have raised a question about a personal subject. A very delicate question. And it seems to me that I should not touch upon this subject publicly. I wouldn't be acting like a gentleman if I did."
Mr. Castro did mention the brief moment of eye contact he believes he struck with Mr. Clinton at the United Nations in the morning.
"I received an atom of President Clinton's sight when he looked at everybody and was in the crowd," he said.
Early in the evening, about 1,300 people sat shoulder to shoulder in the pews of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, waiting for Mr. Castro. A diverse crowd, including whites, blacks and Hispanic people, had spent hours on line for the ticketed event. Many said they were there to show support for Mr. Castro's efforts to derail the Helms-Burton bill in Congress, which seeks to tighten the economic embargo. Many blacks, in particular, said they admired him because they believed he had created harmony between the races in Cuba.
"I was here the last time when he came to the Theresa Hotel" in Harlem, said David Brothers, 76. "I felt I had to come again. He's a principled man and he doesn't bow down. He did a whole lot for Africans."
Asked whether he expected to see a firebrand mellowed with age, Mr. Brothers said: "He's still the revolutionary. The suit don't make the man."
Mr. Castro entered the church at about 7:45 to roars of "Fidel! Fidel! Fidel!" The crowd chanted, "Cuba, si, bloqueo, no." Mr. Castro strode to the podium, relishing the boisterous show of support, which lasted for 10 minutes.
He smiled and nodded at the politicans and leaders seated in the balcony above, among them Representative Charles Rangel, Representative Nydia M. Velasquez, Representative Jose Serrano and Angela Davis, the 1970's black radical who is now a professor of philosophy at the University of California at Santa Cruz. Ms. Davis smiled at him and gave him a fisted salute.
Mr. Castro immediately warmed to his audience, reassuring his supporters that while his clothes might have changed, he had not. To the hoots and hollers of his audience, Mr. Castro made himself the butt of his own jokes as he recounted his sartorial transformation. His new suit of clothes -- forced upon him by the diplomatic community, he said -- has made him an "honorable gentleman." But, he added, "if the last time I went to Harlem in fatigues, how can I go to Harlem in a business suit?"
He also took delight in recounting the many snubs he has received since his arrival, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's failure to include him in a Saturday night banquet. "The Mayor said I was a demon and the demon wouldn't be invited to dinner," Mr. Castro said. "I'm going hungry on my first day in New York."
Late in his speech, Mr. Castro touched on what he characterized as Cuba's bold role in the struggle against apartheid, illiteracy and poverty, again evoking cheers.
"We have shed our blood to fights against colonialism," he said.
Despite his social exclusion, Mr. Castro told admirers that more Americans supported his struggle now. And he pointed to the crowd in Harlem, who obtained tickets through churches, black groups and social advocacy groups, as proof that the real people are on his side, even if the politicians remain hostile.
"Others might change because they are not in the right," he said. "We won't because we are right. The best evidence is your presence here."

Elombe Brathm, master of ceremonies, is at left front and Juanita Vera, Mr. Castro's interpreter, is at center. (Associated Press) (pg. A11)

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 597 words

HEADLINE: Save Sterling Forest

 BODY:
Sterling Forest, a nearly pristine area straddling the New York-New Jersey border, is a privately owned preserve the size of Manhattan in an area undergoing an economic boom. The Sterling Forest Corporation, which is part of the Home Insurance Company, is sitting on a parcel of land that, if developed, could bring the company some much-needed revenue.
The forest is also a unique piece of wild country near the nation's largest urban area that conservationists and an increasing number of politicians are trying to preserve in its natural state. The key is to put together the needed funding and persuade Western members of Congress who oppose the creation of more public lands to allow the necessary legislation to pass. 
 The 18,000 acres of forest include sources of drinking water for most of northern New Jersey and provide a stretch of undeveloped land big enough to allow species like the black bear to thrive. The Appalachian Trail passes through it. The forest has already been encroached on by several corporate headquarters and is home to a 160-acre fairground. That is plenty of development. The need for open space in this area far exceeds the need for thousands of housing units and millions of square feet of commercial and industrial space. The rest of this valuable and irreplaceable area should be preserved.
A vocal coalition, including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, Gov. George Pataki of New York and members of Congress from both parties in both states, has mobilized to try to save the forest. Governor Whitman has pledged $10 million to help acquire land in New York, and New York has a $2 billion bond issue on the ballot in next month's election, of which $800 million is to be used for land acquisition, including Sterling Forest. But assembling the whole rescue package is proving very tricky. It involves a combination of Federal and state funding, with the necessary Federal authorizing legislation, and negotiation of a deal with the Sterling Forest Corporation.
Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey has attached a provision to an Alaskan land bill that would authorize $17.5 million to help acquire the forest and add it to the holdings of the Palisades Interstate Commission. The provision passed the Senate. The same bill, without the Sterling Forest provision, passed in the House, and the version with the Sterling Forest authorization is being held at the Speaker's desk. Two key Western Congressmen -- Don Young of Alaska, the chairman of the House Resources Committee, and James Hansen of Utah, the chairman of the National Parks, Forests and Lands Subcommittee -- are longtime enemies of public land ownership who are fighting to divest the Government of many of its holdings.
The Sterling Forest Corporation needs to realize that development of the land has a dubious political future. Any development plan (and there are four under consideration at the moment) would require the combined permission of three municipalities and two state governments, and would have to contend with the opposition of conservation and local citizens' groups. Even with that approval, challenges would no doubt delay any proposed development for years. The company is much more likely to see some real money if it can agree to an arrangement to allow public acquisition of the land.
The region's Republicans in the House, meanwhile, have made heroic efforts on behalf of the forest, especially Benjamin Gilman of New York and Marge Roukema of New Jersey. They need to keep pushing to get the measure through the House this week.


CORRECTION-DATE: October 26, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial on Monday headlined "Save Sterling Forest" said incorrectly that a $2 billion bond issue would be decided in next month's New York State balloting. No such measure will appear.

HEADLINE: Foreign Stocks Drop, Setting the Stage for U.S. Market Losses

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market slumped yesterday, as both the dollar and bond prices dropped, making stocks relatively less attractive to investors.
Before trading opened in the United States, overseas stock markets tumbled, so analysts were well prepared for the decline in domestic equities. The DAX index of German stocks fell 2.91 percent, the CAC-40 index of French stocks fell 1.12 percent and the FT-SE index of British stocks slipped six-tenths of 1 percent. 
 The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond declined 18/32 , and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.39 percent from 6.36 percent on Friday. Higher bond yields are a negative for stocks, since they increase both corporate and consumer borrowing costs.
"The stock market opened lackluster and remained lackluster through the session," said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president of Fahnestock & Company. "There is concern over the outcome of the battle of the budget, and last week's buyers became this week's sellers."
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 39.38 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 4,755.48 -- near its low for the day.
Among the broader averages, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.40 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 585.06 and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.61 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,036.92.
There were almost twice as many declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange as advancing ones, with 1,537 lower and 772 higher. Big Board volume was 330.8 million shares, down from 396.7 million shares on Friday.
Retail stocks were off during the session amid concern about consumer buying during the coming holiday season. Kmart slipped 3/4, to 9 1/8, after Moody's cut the rating on its long-term debt. Sears, Roebuck and Company fell 7/8, to 35 1/8.
Paper issues were down, under pressure from a slowing economy. The Union Camp Corporation declined 7/8, to 51 1/4; the International Paper Company dropped 1, to 36 1/2, and the Weyerhaeuser Company fell 3/4, to 46.
Some airline companies were weak, as traders cited concern over fare discounts. AMR, the holding company for American Airlines, closed at 64 3/8, down 1/2; Delta Air Lines closed at 65, down 3/4, and Southwest Airlines closed at 20 3/4, down 3/8.
On the other hand, the technology sector had a pocket of stocks that finished on the upside. International Business Machines gained 3 5/8, to 99, and the Digital Equipment Corporation, which is scheduled to report its earnings today, advanced 3/4, to 52 1/2. Advanced Micro Devices, which agreed to acquire Nexgen late last Friday, increased 1 3/8, to 27 1/2, while Nexgen rose 1/2, to 21 3/4.
Both the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation advanced as Wall Street indicated its belief that fees would not be imposed on the debt and mortgage-backed securities issued by the two companies. Federal National Mortgage closed at 103 7/8, up 7/8, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage closed at 69 1/2, up 7/8.
Summit Technology climbed 1 7/8, to 42 1/2, after the company's excimer laser treatment to correct nearsightedness was approved by the Food and Drug Administration. A rival, Visx Inc., whose laser is expected to win approval by next March, was up 1 1/2, to 22 1/2.

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: AROUND TOWN;
On the Streets, Shopping Spree and Gridlock

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Her husband was tied up in meetings yesterday, so Naina Yeltsin took care of some of her own business.
"Any concerns about your skin?" the cosmetologist at Estee Lauder asked Mrs. Yeltsin. 
 "It's all right," the first lady of Russia responded.
"Is it oily or dry?"
"Normal."
"How often do you have oily blemishes?"
War and peace and everything in between were on the official United Nations agenda, but in the city outside, it was a day of shopping and dining for the world leaders' spouses, and gridlock and grumbling for New Yorkers. More than a few of the motorcades screeching through the city, holding up traffic, were carrying Very Important Purchasers, shuttling between shops and official luncheons, political fund-raisers and the evening's performance of Beethoven's Ninth at Avery Fisher Hall.
On Fifth Avenue, a small security force waited patiently outside the Salvatore Ferragamo boutique while Amelita Ramos, the wife of President Fidel V. Ramos of the Philippines, was shopping for shoes. As Mrs. Ramos sat in a cushy chair, a salesman settled on his haunches, showing her a parade of pumps and presumably refraining from Imelda Marcos jokes.
And at Tiffany's, Sumanee Guma-Kasem, wife of an adviser to the Prime Minister of Thailand, surveyed the jewlery. "I've been everywhere: Bergdorf's, Lord & Taylor and The Forgotten Woman," she said.
City officials estimate that the world leaders and their delegations will have spent between $28.5 million and $39.5 million in five days by the time they return to their homelands on Wednesday. Starting Saturday, the city's hotel rooms were virtually all booked, making it "a weekend unlike any other weekend in our history," said Jeanine Moss, a spokeswoman for the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Broadway shows were reporting heavy diplomatic interest; "Smoky Joe's Cafe" was expecting both Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway and President Carlos S. Menem of Argentina .
And restaurants, particularly expensive ones with hot reputations, were jammed. Secretary of State Warren Christopher was initially turned down for a reservation at Nobu, the downtown Japanese restaurant, but was squeezed in last night. "Someone from Australia or Austria" called, said Demethress Gordon, the restaurant's reservation manger. "They said, 'The President wants to come here,' and we are trying to get him in."
Some visitors actually ventured out of Manhattan. Ortwin Windmuller, the general manager of Peter Luger's Steak House in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, seated the president of El Salvador over the weekend. "And we had a few here today for lunch, from Brazil or something," Mr. Windmuller said.
Tim Zagat, publisher of the Zagat restaurant guides and chairman of NY 95, a partnership devoted to increasing tourism, compared the United Nations event to the 1992 Democratic Party convention at Madison Square Garden, generally thought to be a watershed event for New York tourism in the 1990's.
"But anybody who thinks this is about how much business we do in these four days just doesn't get it," Mr. Zagat said. "It's the image that New York gets to present around the world -- that it's pretty, that it's nice, that it's hospitable, that it's clean, that it's safe."
The city was playing the constant host. At noon yesterday, Donna Hanover Giuliani threw a luncheon for 400 spouses of world leaders inside the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The guests sat at 50 tables in the reconstructed Egyptian temple. Waiting on each of their chairs was a gift of a star-shaped crystal ornament from Baccarat.
As the spouses dined on grilled salmon fillet and roasted breast of chicken, Mrs. Giuliani, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barbara Walters delivered remarks.The recurring if unofficial theme of celebrating womanhood resounded in a room whose profound imbalance by sex was proof positive that, globally at least, women are hardly on an equal footing with men.
"I feel duty-bound to point out that there are some male spouses in the room," Mrs. Clinton said. In truth, though, there were fewer than a half dozen men among the guests.
Making note of the spouses' contributions to the state of world affairs, Mrs. Clinton said, "Thank you for what each of you do every day." And then, in a sort of winking reference to the difficulty of living with powerful men, she said, "Thank you for what each of you puts up with every day."
There was plenty of unplanned time for the spouses and stores from Tiffany's to F.A.O. Schwarz reported a stream of foreign customers.
Linda Buckley, the public relations manager for Tiffany's, said, "There are people who are coming in today by appointment or just stopping in." But like spokesmen at other stores, Ms. Buckley refused to reveal the names of customers.
Mrs. Yeltsin's visit to the Estee Lauder was not a shopping trip but rather a visit to the company's headquarters in the General Motors building, meant to recognize her work in breast cancer awareness and also to highlight the company's operations in Russia, where a second store in Moscow is set to open next week. Mrs. Yeltsin was greeted lavishly by the Lauder family as here motorcade pulled up yesterday morning.
But whatever hospitality Mrs. Yeltsin and the other guests were feeling, more than a few New Yorkers said they had enough of the traffic tumult caused by the diplomatic invasion, coming just two weeks after the visit of Pope John Paul II.
Carol Cooper, who lives on the Upper East Side, stopped a police officer on the Fifth Avenue sidewalk yesterday as another motorcade went by. "If they're so security conscious why do they announce where they're going with 18 cars, with horns and sirens and clearing streets?" she asked. "It's crazy."
The officer, Robert Giannetta, gently told her he really did not know.
"I think they're all on an ego trip," Mrs. Cooper said.
"Ma'am," the officer said, "you won't have to worry about it for another fifty years."

HEADLINE: Michigan Puts Poor to Work But Gains Appear Precarious

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich.

 BODY:
An axiom of the welfare debate holds that the way out of poverty is a job, and no state has put more of its poor into jobs than Michigan.
Three years after the Governor, John Engler, began recasting the welfare system in his conservative Republican vision, his program is being cited as a model by Congressional Republicans, who are putting the final touches on legislation that would upend Federal antipoverty policy. Governor Engler and his social services director, Gerald H. Miller, were influential lobbyists to Congress in shaping the legislation, which would slash up to $100 billion of Federal aid for the poor and give states block grants to run welfare programs of their own design. 
 Here in Michigan, nearly 30 percent of welfare clients earn a paycheck, more than three times the national average. Today's welfare caseload of 190,000 is the lowest in 21 years. The State Department of Social Services says it is spending $100 million less for welfare than it would if so many people did not have jobs.
State officials proudly say that the program, besides saving money, helps keep families together. Built on carrots and increasingly punitive sticks, the revisions allow more working fathers to live with their families without disqualifying the household from welfare.
But if Michigan gleams as an example of what a state can accomplish without Federal regulation, it also offers cautionary lessons. For all its innovation, the state's welfare system has made only limited and precarious gains, say economists and sociologists and officials from other states who have come here by the dozens to study the system.
Moreover, Michigan has come up against the same economic reality that confronts the nation's work force. For more than 20 years, as inflation has nibbled away at wages, employers have not made up the loss. So a working wage today is often not a living wage, and the idea of a job as an antidote to welfare is no longer assured.
"It has certainly worked," Alan Werner of Abt Associates, a consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass., said of the Michigan welfare program. "It doesn't look like clients are suffering. It doesn't look like poor people are getting poorer."
Mr. Werner, whose firm was hired by the State of Michigan to monitor the program, said it had "increased employment and earnings and reduced welfare dependence -- but only by a few percentage points."
"The scale of change is quite small," he added.
Both the House and the Senate versions of the welfare bill, whose differences are to be reconciled by a conference committee that is to meet today, require that states have 50 percent of their welfare recipients working by the year 2000.
In his original effort to get people off welfare through working, Governor Engler, who was elected in 1990, at first encouraged schooling and training that could lead to well-paid, durable jobs. But the state welfare bill, in part because of job-training costs, remained stubbornly high -- about $7 billion a year.
Last year Mr. Engler ordered most welfare recipients to look for work immediately, and now 55,000 people are working, double the number before he took over. The trouble is that most of the jobs available pay so little that they cannot lift a family out of poverty and to the point where it no longer needs state aid.
In this way, experts say, Michigan's welfare-to-work system shows signs of hooking the working poor to the dole, much as the Federal welfare system is accused of hooking generations of the nonworking poor to the dole.
Even these gains are fragile, analysts add, because they come on the wings of Michigan's soaring economy, the nation's most volatile. Over the last two decades the state's unemployment rate has seesawed from less than 5 percent now to more than 15 percent.
A recession could flood the welfare rolls, said Stephen Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany. "You can see they're not going to have enough money," Mr. Gold said. "They will say, 'Well, we can't raise taxes, so we will have to cut spending more.' They're sowing the seeds of further cuts in social spending."
State officials say Congress, too, threatens their success through a provision in the welfare bill, supported by President Clinton, that would set a cap of perhaps five years on how long states can use their block grants to support a welfare family. The measure would rob the Michigan program of what state officials say is a crucial feature: its assurance that welfare clients can collect benefit checks indefinitely until they make a living wage.
"No awful caps!" said Mr. Miller, the social services director. "The issue is getting people to work and getting people out of poverty."
Sandra K. Danziger, an associate professor of social work at the University of Michigan and an authority on the state's welfare system, said, "A lot of people do seem to be combining work and welfare, and that is really in stark contrast to the rest of the states." She praised the program's accountability and added, "The program for families is very constructive."
But she criticized the Governor for financing the family welfare program, along with a general tax cut, by shutting down a general assistance program for 83,000 indigent single men and women. Since ending the program four years ago, she said, shelters for the homeless have been flooded with new clients.
"He changed the rules," she said of Mr. Engler. And changing the rules last year to compel welfare clients to take low-wage jobs, she added, "is short-sighted."
 
The Program
Some Incentives And Exemptions
In October 1992, when the Governor began revamping the state's welfare system, he told the poor that welfare was not a right. But pull an oar to help yourself, he said, and the state will pull the other.
He introduced a voluntary "social contract," an innovation in welfare policy under which clients would give the community 20 hours a week. They could take paying jobs or do volunteer work, or enroll in school, job training or drug treatment programs. He assured everyone free health care under Medicaid, the insurance program for the poor, and subsidies for child care.
With waivers in the Federal welfare regulations, he added special incentives for workers. They could keep $200 of their monthly earnings without any reduction of their check for Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the principal Federal welfare program.
At that point their welfare benefits would start to decline, but they could still keep 20 percent of their earnings above the $200. By the time a typical family of three was earning about $775 a month, it would be weaned from its welfare check but it could keep Medicaid for the children and some food stamps for another year.
The arrangement still leaves no one particularly well off. The $775 in monthly income, or $9,300 a year, comes to 77 percent of the income a family of three needs to break through the poverty threshhold for three of $12,112. Without working, the typical nonworking family would be receiving about $800 less a year.
Michigan waived other Federal rules to help families. A 100-hour limit on the hours parents could work each month was removed. Welfare experts blame the restriction for chasing fathers from the home and contributing to the proliferation of impoverished families headed by women.
The changes help bond couples like Tonja Kimmel, 21, and Eric Boylan, also 21. They reported here recently to the Ingham County office of the State Department of Social Services so that Mr. Boylan, the father of their 19-month-old son, could be added to Ms. Kimmel's case.
Under the previous system, the state would have docked Ms. Kimmel's welfare payment by some of Mr. Boylan's earnings when they moved in together. Now they can keep much of what Mr. Boylan earns in addition to their $489 monthly check through Aid to Dependent Children. But their prospects for earning enough to escape welfare are dim. Both are high school dropouts and are unemployed.
"It don't bother me to work," Ms. Kimmel said. "I can't find any. Unless you have a good education, it's hard to find a good job."
 
The Push to Work
Emphasis on Jobs, Not Education
Job training might help Ms. Kimmel and Mr. Boylen, but that's pretty much out these days.
A year ago, Mr. Engler started a "work first" program to steer welfare applicants to the job market. Only a few clients -- primarily women with infants at home or people under 24 who have not completed high school -- are deferred.
The social contract, with the new emphasis on finding paid work, became mandatory. Most training is confined to learning how to get a job. Clients are assigned to "job clubs," classes at nonprofit private agencies, on contract with the state, to learn how to handle job interviews, write resumes and comb the help-wanted ads.
Many find work within a month, said Janet L. Strope, director of the Ingham County social services office. She added that the college and skill training that the state used to encourage was too costly and rarely led to good jobs.
But many people balked at taking low-wage jobs, so in April the state introduced sanctions. "If they don't cooperate, if they don't show up for job clubs, if they don't follow up on job leads, if they don't have a cause," Ms. Strope said, "they lose 25 percent of their grant and sometimes 25 percent of their food stamps."
That shoe falls within two or three months after a client applies for welfare. A year later "they lose the whole grant," Ms. Strope said.
So far, of its caseload of 5,300, her office has docked the 25 percent from 350 cases. Ms. Strope said she believed many could absorb the cut because they were earning unreported wages in the cash economy.
But she wonders about the bigger penalties that will not be leveled until next summer. "When we sanction people 100 percent," she asked, "what happens to their children?"
 
The Cutting Edge
Many Problems; Little Enthusiasm
The Cristo Rey Community Center is one of six nonprofit organizations that the Ingham County social services office has hired to help put welfare families on their feet and send them to work.
Along with the health center, there is a Head Start school, a food pantry, an elementary and middle school for children with behavioral problems and classrooms where clients learn to look for jobs.
It is hard to find much enthusiasm for the Engler welfare program among the clients or the staff members here, who say the emphasis on immediate work is stingy and shortsighted.
Robin Ripley, 32, was in the health center with her sneezing 2-year-old daughter, Emily, who gets Medicaid. Ms. Ripley and her husband, David, 37, collect about $100 a month in food stamps.
Ms. Ripley said they first ended up on welfare when she had a high-risk pregnancy and spent three months in the hospital. "I had the baby but in seven days he died," she said. "I lost the A.D.C. two weeks later."
They requalified for welfare when she became pregnant with Christopher, who is now 4, and got off again two months ago when Ms. Ripley took a full-time, $5.20-an-hour job with a telephone answering service, working from 3 P.M. to 11 P.M.
The Ripleys are among thousands of Michigan residents who have worked their way off welfare, but they feel neither rich nor heroic. Their income still leaves them about 20 percent below the $15,520 poverty line for a family of four.
Ms. Ripley said she needs more training to do better. "They would rather have me working at Burger King than get an education and have enough skill to support my family," she said. "What's the point of that?"
Many other people who stream through Cristo Rey do not easily fit Michigan's welfare-to-work program. Indeed, most of them -- the 70 percent who have not gone to work -- do not fit.
Three generations of one family straggle into the health center for a well-baby checkup. "We walk here," said Louise Creller, who is 44, wan and spaghetti-thin. "Takes us about an hour." She and Mary Person, 15, looking adult and purposeful, have brought a stroller with a 2-month-old baby. Two little boys, 2 and 4, accompany them.
The baby is Ms. Person's. Ms. Person is one of Ms. Creller's five children, who range in age from 10 to 21, and lives with her mother. The boys are the sons of Ms. Creller's oldest child, a daughter getting settled in Detroit where she recently found a job stuffing inserts in newspapers.
Ms. Creller, whose husband is "somewhere down South," said she collects about $800 a month in food stamps and Aid to Families With Dependent Children, and her rent is $500 a month.
Deferred from the Governor's work requirement, she has become, instead, a one-woman alternative to his welfare-to-work program.
By not working, she helps steer another generation from welfare to work. "I baby-sit him until 3:30," she said of the baby, until Mary, a tenth grader, comes home. Until the older daughter can take on the boys, she said, "I baby-sit them all day."

But the Ripleys' annual income still leaves them below the poverty level for a family of four. (Peter Yates for The New York Times) (pg. A20)

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: GENERAL ASSEMBLY;
Money on Their Minds, Leaders Tell U.N. to Trim Down

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Beset by economic uncertainties at home and preoccupied by the shadow of bankruptcy looming over the United Nations, world leaders speaking here today could not avoid the subject of money.
The financial predicament has added urgency to calls for reform of the United Nations and may make it easier for the United States and other industrial nations to curtail their support sharply and possibly to force the United Nations to close about half a dozen agencies. This would be the most extensive shrinking and restructuring of the organization in its half-century of existence. 
 Today Prime Minister John Major of Britain used the toughest language heard so far in calling for a smaller, more efficient organization.
"Is the U.N. spread too wide?" he asked. "I believe it is."
"Is too much time and energy spent on ritual verbal battles, brilliantly interpreted into six languages and printed on the world's highest paper mountain?" he said. "Of course it is."
Officials traveling with Mr. Major say that he has a number of United Nations agencies in mind for reduction or elimination. The list is the same one from which the Clinton Administration is working as it tries to negotiate with Congress over a reform plan.
Until the Administration can make some concessions to Congress on foreign spending issues, money to pay more than $1.2 billion in overdue American assessments to the United Nations will not be forthcoming. Today both Britain and France joined a host of other nations in publicly deploring deadbeats.
American officials acknowledge that the agencies now under the most severe scrutiny are the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, which the Administration says has been made redundant by other agencies, and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, whose functions may be overtaken by the new World Trade Organization.
In addition, United States officials say, a plan to rejoin Unesco, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, from which the United States withdrew in 1984, has all but been abandoned for the foreseeable future, and there are serious doubts about continued support for the Food and Agricultural Organization and the International Labor Organization.
The agencies and organizations have also been criticized by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and by other Republican leaders. The Clinton Administration appears ready to sacrifice American membership or support for the agencies if doing so will unlock money, votes on treaties and the confirmation of diplomats, all of which are being held up by the Republicans.
Today Mr. Major and President Jacques Chirac of France -- each saying his country had contributed the largest number of peacekeeping troops to the United Nations -- both spoke more concretely about reforming the United Nations than President Clinton did in his speech to more than 140 world leaders on Sunday.
Mr. Chirac proposed the appointment of a new Under Secretary General to oversee all development work and to be the "strong-arm executor" coordinating various agencies.
Fears that development assistance may fall off played a part in the drafting of a strong set of speeches from African leaders -- delivered by chance on the same day.
Presidents Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Brig. Gen. Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo of Equatorial Guinea, and Foreign Minister Destin Tsaty-Boungou of the Republic of the Congo were among those who asked that the world not turn away from poor nations, especially in Africa, which is falling further and further behind other developing regions in standards of living. Several African leaders blamed the heritage of colonialism for continuing poverty and social stress.
President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana, saying with some passion that "we feel the hunger in the midst of plenty," added that for his continent, "the next 50 years will be even more crucial than the past 50 years."
He added, "We cannot help being struck by the fact that the international community is willing to spend $5 million a day on U.N. peacekeeping operations in Bosnia-Herzegovina, and we would not begrudge those noble people such international solidarity.
"But when we have asked for a sum that represents 10 to 15 days of that bill to help those of us in Africa making every possible effort to assist ourselves with our meager resources, there is deafening silence."
Behind the scenes today, more than 70 private meetings took place between leaders in dozens of instant conference rooms created by temporarily partitioning areas of the first and second floors of the United Nations headquarters. More conversations took place at lunches or over coffee in the basement Viennese coffee shop.
Although they do not get the attention of a Clinton-Yeltsin summit, the large number of usually unpublicized, off-camera meetings between other leaders is evidence of the extensive use of the United Nations as a one-stop diplomatic hub. Visiting leaders not only met each other but also lobbied heads of United Nations agencies.
Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt, on his way to meet King Hussein of Jordan after sessions with the Prime Minister of Morocco and the President of Azerbaijan, said that he had been trying to activate some Islamic opinion on Bosnia as he went from meeting to meeting within the building.
"That saves time and effort," he said. "You don't even have to cross the street."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Utula Utoc Samana, Papua New Guinea's representative at the United Nations, and his wife, Fungkec, right, took pictures of people taking pictures yesterday on the floor of the General Assembly. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Labor's Love Not Lost

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
Whatever anger organized labor has sometimes felt toward the White House was indiscernible last night, when President Clinton spoke for 45 minutes to 1,020 friendly delegates of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., whose four-day convention began yesterday in midtown Manhattan.
American labor unions were once furious with the President over his endorsement of the North American Free Trade Agreement, or Nafta, and many promised to campaign against anyone in Congress, Democrat or Republican, who voted for it. 
 Yet yesterday, as the President reached the dais at the Sheraton New York Hotel, the delegates chanted "Four more years!" and "We want Bill!"
"Whose side is Bill Clinton on?" asked Thomas R. Donahue, the federation president, introducing him. "Make no mistake about it. He's on your side."
And the President responded, "Whatever you do, I intend to be with you every step of the way."
The President ran down the list of policies and programs under attack in Congress and important to labor: occupational safety, Medicare, Medicaid, college scholarships, and the earned-income tax credit, which allows low-wage workers to keep more of their earnings.
One of labor unions' biggest issues is the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage, and the President emphatically reiterated his support for an increase.
"It is high time we raised the minimum wage," Mr. Clinton said to a standing ovation. Citing Republican arguments against an increase of 50 or 75 cents, he said, "There is no evidence that a modest increase in the minimum wage will cause unemployment."
He also repeated other promises, like tax deductions for education after high school and fighting trading partners, like Japan, whom he accuses of thwarting imports of American goods. His only reference to Nafta was an allusion to occasional disagreements over trade.

HEADLINE: Polaroid Picks An Outsider As New Chief

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23

 BODY:
The Polaroid Corporation, under pressure to increase its share price and develop new products to spur sales, named the Black & Decker Corporation's No. 2 executive, Gary T. DiCamillo, chairman and chief executive.
Mr. DiCamillo, the first outsider ever to head Polaroid, is a marketer who increased profits and sales during his nine years at Black & Decker. 
 That is the kind of experience Polaroid, a maker of instant cameras and imaging products, wants.
"This is a guy with good marketing experience, who has been able to improve profitability," said Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Mr. DiCamillo, 44, is scheduled to take the helm on Dec. 1, ending a search begun in March to replace Polaroid chairman and chief executive I. Mac Allister Booth, 63, who will retire.
Wall Street was apparently disappointed that Polaroid did not appoint a more proven cost-cutter. Polaroid shares fell $1.125 to close at $40.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. DiCamillo gave few hints about what he planned for Polaroid, whose woes began when consumer enthusiasm for instant photography waned. At the same time, its forays into new technologies such as medical imaging did not pan out.
"I've got to get into the company, and do more homework," Mr. DiCamillo said. He said he would focus both on the instant-photography consumer business and its new arenas of digital and medical imaging, which use computers to manipulate images.
The company's photographic business "clearly can grow through global expansion," he said, noting Polaroid's efforts for the last few years to increase sales by getting its products into emerging economies such as Russia.
Mr. Rosenzweig of Salomon agreed that Mr. DiCamillo must "boost consumer demand" for instant cameras and film in major United States and European markets, while investing in emerging businesses.
At Black & Decker, Mr. DiCamillo lifted sales and profits at the power tools business he headed. He said that "some cuts and refocusing" had been necessary. The $1.8 billion power tools business accounted for about one-third of the company sales of $5.2 billion in 1994.
"He's a good, basic block-and-tackle operating guy," said Susan Gallagher, a Natwest Securities Corporation analyst who follows Black & Decker.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gary T. DiCamillo has been named chief executive of Polaroid. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Proffitt's to Buy Younkers in Retail Merger

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Proffitt's Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Younkers Inc. in a stock swap valued at $253 million, succeeding where Carson Pirie Scott & Company failed in a yearlong hostile takeover bid.
The deal would create one of the nation's largest regional department-store retailers, with combined revenue of $1.3 billion and 107 stores in 16 states in the Midwest and South. 
 "The big guys already went through consolidation," said Peter Schaeffer, an analyst with Dillon Read & Company. "It has to happen for the regional department-store chains."
While the deal appears to thwart Carson Pirie Scott's $170 million bid for control of Younkers, a lawsuit is still pending in the takeover battle.
Carson Pirie Scott, which has an 11.7 percent stake in Younkers, declined to comment on the proposed merger and said that it had not determined what action, if any, it would take.
Investors, however, appeared to like the deal, sending the shares of Younkers up $3.1875, to $22.25. But the stock of Proffitt's fell $5.125, to $23.375. The shares of Carson Pirie Scott rose 12.5 cents, to $19.50.
Under the agreement, Younkers shareholders would get 0.98 share of Proffitt's common stock for each Younkers share. Proffitt's would issue about 8.8 million shares in the transaction, or about $253 million of stock, based on Friday's closing price of $28.75.
There would be unspecified one-time charges related to the merger and restructuring of operations, the companies said. The boards of both companies have approved the deal.
Through the merger, the companies would create a retailer slightly larger than their Midwest rival, Carson Pirie Scott, which is based in Milwaukee. Carson Pirie Scott has 51 stores and had revenue last year of $1.16 billion.
"This makes sense," said Philip Abbenhaus, an analyst with Stifel Nicolaus & Company. "There is no overlap of markets, and there are clearly opportunities for economies of scale."
Proffitt's, based in Alcoa, Tenn., had revenue last year of $698 million. It operates two divisions. The Proffitt's division has 26 stores, in Tennessee, Virginia, Georgia, Kentucky and North Carolina. The McRae's division has 28 stores, in Alabama, Mississippi, Florida and Louisiana. The stores sell fashion apparel, shoes, accessories, cosmetics and decorative home furnishings.
Younkers, with revenue of $605 million, has 53 stores, in Iowa, Wisconsin, Nebraska, Michigan, Illinois, Minnesota and South Dakota. The stores sell clothes for men, women and children, as well as cosmetics and fragrances.
Younkers would operate as a separate division of Proffitt's, maintaining its headquarters in Des Moines.
Younkers has been battling the hostile takeover attempt by Carson Pirie Scott since October 1994. Younkers rebuffed Carson Pirie Scott's $19-a-share offer as inadequate, saying it was not for sale at such a low price. Carson Pirie Scott offered to raise its offer by $1, but Younkers said it was not interested.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 371 words

HEADLINE: CNN Rejects an Ad

 BODY:
Cable News Network and its owner, Turner Broadcasting, support the House and Senate telecommunications bills. AT&T opposes the bills. AT&T, along with other long-distance telephone companies, wanted to voice its opposition by paying CNN to run commercials. CNN said no, in part because the ads posed a "conflict of interest."
That will not cause grievous harm to the public. After all, Turner Broadcasting is only one of many media companies -- including newspapers, radio stations, television stations and phone companies -- that service communities and can carry advocacy messages. Yet the incident exposes a large danger to the free flow of information that is posed by the very telecommunications bills that AT&T's ads were designed to defeat. 
 The House and Senate bills, which might go to conference this week, could make it possible in a given area for the same corporation to control the major newspaper, television stations, radio stations and cable company. If that happens, a decision to quash an ad or a news story would effectively quash the public's right to know.
CNN was under no legal compulsion to carry AT&T's ad. Nor is it compelled to run advocacy ads at all. The television networks do not. In the past, CNN has even run ads opposed to telecommunications legislation that it supported.
Turner Broadcasting changed its mind this time, it says, because AT&T's ads were "misleading" as well as contrary to Turner's corporate interest. CNN executives also said that the pending takeover of Turner by Time Warner -- which owns a huge cable company -- changed the situation, although a conflict of interest would exist even without a merger.
The telecommunications bills would rely on the antitrust laws to protect the public from undue concentration of media companies. But the antitrust laws are insufficient protection. They are designed to prevent undue economic power -- the threat that consumers will be charged high prices -- rather than to prevent an ominous narrowing of information and opinion.
The law should not tell CNN which commercials to run. But the law should make sure that consumers have enough sources of information that they need not care what decisions CNN makes.

HEADLINE: The Spirit of Hyde Park

 BODY:
The White House picked Hyde Park as the site of yesterday's meeting between Boris Yeltsin and Bill Clinton because the Roosevelt homestead is a symbol of the wartime alliance between Moscow and Washington. The more relevant symbolism of the Hudson River estate might have been Franklin Roosevelt's acute instinct for balancing politics and diplomacy. It is a commodity that will be much needed in the months ahead as Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin try to guide the volatile relationship between their countries through the heat of Presidential elections in both the United States and Russia.
The domestic political pressures already bearing down on both men were evident at Hyde Park, where much of the discussion dealt with Russia's role in a Bosnian peacekeeping force that would follow a Balkan peace agreement. The two leaders reported they made some progress, and Mr. Yeltsin said Russian troops would participate. 
 But despite a giddy news conference, where Mr. Yeltsin's admonishment of the press left Mr. Clinton oddly convulsed by laughter, they resolved none of the hard questions about Russian involvement. Mr. Yeltsin, eager to show that Russian prerogatives cannot be ignored, has refused to contribute troops if the peacekeeping force is under NATO command. Mr. Clinton has rejected Mr. Yeltsin's proposal of United Nations control.
The spirit of Hyde Park suggests a compromise that can satisfy the two Presidents' political concerns without undermining their principles. Russia must be represented in any peacekeeping mission lest the force appear tilted against the Bosnian Serbs and their allies in Belgrade. Without Serbian cooperation there can be no peace in Bosnia.
But Russia does not have to be an equal participant with the United States, Britain, France and other countries. The value of a Russian role can be preserved if Russian troops play a support role and do not take part in combat operations that might be required to keep the peace. That way NATO command can be maintained, which is essential to avoiding the blurred lines of authority that crippled U.N. peacekeepers in Bosnia.
The Bosnian mission should not be freighted with the highly charged issue of NATO expansion. Some Clinton aides mistakenly see Russian participation in Bosnia as a first step toward enlarging the alliance, and some of Mr. Yeltsin's advisers just as mistakenly see a Russian role there as capitulation to NATO. Peacekeeping in Bosnia is not a test case for NATO expansion. It is still far from clear that expansion of a cold-war military alliance is necessary to consolidate democracy and market economics in central Europe today.
For Washington to push expansion now, and make it integral to the Bosnian case, seems not only gratuitous but self-defeating. The surest way for Washington to encourage nationalism and rearmament in Moscow is to push NATO expansion as Russia turns toward parliamentary elections in December and presidential balloting next June.
Franklin Roosevelt held the World War II Allies together with shrewd leadership and a subtle sense for the mix of politics and foreign policy. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin should follow his example.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Large Layoffs Are Planned At Daimler Aerospace Unit

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Announcing one of Germany's biggest layoff programs of the year, the giant aerospace unit of the Daimler-Benz group said today that by 1998 it would cut almost 9,000 jobs, or more than 15 percent of its work force, and would close or sell as many as five plants.
The planned cuts are a stark example of German industry's struggle to remain competitive in the face of soaring labor costs and a rising German mark that drives up export prices, which reduces the country's international competitiveness. 
 Daimler-Benz Aerospace A.G., also known as Dasa, was particularly hard hit because in addition to competing in an industry priced principally in dollars, it has also faced a worldwide recession in the aerospace business.
"This is the only way in which this industry can operate efficiently in the private sector in Germany," Manfred Bischoff, the chief executive of Dasa, said in a statement today.
In the last year, Germany has seen a flight of industrial jobs, as manufacturers have sought to locate plants in regions with lower costs. Dasa's sister company, Mercedes-Benz, has announced a series of new plant openings overseas.
Dasa is Europe's largest aerospace concern, with a 37.9 percent stake in Airbus industries; a 51 percent holding in Fokker, the Dutch aircraft maker, and a one-third stake in the Eurofighter consortium. It also operates Eurocopter Deutschland.
Dasa said it was restructuring operations so that under an exchange rate of 1.35 marks to the dollar, the company would still be profitable. This was regarded as a grim sign by analysts, who noted that companies are increasingly resigned to accepting that in the long term, the dollar will not move much higher than its current levels. The dollar settled at 1.3882 German marks today in New York.
In the summer, traders hoped that with strong backing by the seven leading industrial countries, the dollar would climb back to exchange levels seen in early 1994, of 1.55 to 1.60 German marks.
The job losses mean that by 1998, Dasa will have a work force of some 40,000, less than half its peak of 87,000 in 1993. Even so, the cuts fell far short of analyst expectations and raised concerns that the German Government might be forced to subsidize jobs or that the company might not be restructuring aggressively enough.
Earlier in the year, the company let it be known that under its restructuring plan, it was considering eliminating as many as 15,000 jobs. It now has almost 57,000 employees.
"Our analysis is that if you compare Dasa to some of its competitors, such as British Aerospace, one might have thought that the number of people to be cut would be much higher than 15,000," said Stephen Reitmann, European autos analyst for UBS Global Research in London.
Glen Liddy, German equities analyst at Kleinwort Benson in London, added that "the German Government may want to do this to limit the number of job losses."
Dasa's losses have been enormous, dragging the parent group into the red. Daimler-Benz earned almost $750 million in 1994, according to American generally accepted accounting practices, but the strength of the German mark threw the group into a net loss for the first six months of this year of $1.13 billion, including an operating loss at Dasa of $1.15 billion.
Mr. Reitman predicted that the company would post a loss for the full year of $1.95 billion.
The planned cuts will be felt most deeply at the company's aircraft group, which is to lose 8,046 jobs; 800 jobs will be lost at other divisions.
The restructuring also involves plans to sell three sites in western Germany. In addition, two plants Dasa took over in eastern Germany after the fall of Communism may be sold.
Yet, even if these cuts fix some of Dasa's problems, there are still more troubles ahead that make success far from certain, analysts said. Its Fokker subsidiary, the unit that builds commuter aircraft, is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy and is negotiating with the Dutch Government for a bailout that could exceed $2 billion. Any reductions of workers at Fokker would be in addition to the job losses announced today.
"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
4 Big Brokers In Japan Lift Profits From Lows of '94

 BODY:
Japan's four biggest securities firms, rebounding from their worst year ever, reported sharp improvements in earnings for the first half of the fiscal year yesterday, aided by a rally on the Japanese bond market.
Officials at the four companies said they expected profit to continue to rise, but analysts said the projections were too optimistic. They said the brokerage industry, especially smaller companies, would continue to grapple with high costs and an uncertain revenue outlook. 
 The three largest brokerage houses -- Nomura Securities Company, Nikko Securities Company and the Daiwa Securities Company (which is not related to the Daiwa Bank Ltd.) -- posted gains in pretax profit as great as 995 percent for the half-year ending on Sept. 30. The fourth-largest broker, the Yamaichi Securities Company, swung to a pretax profit in the half from a loss in the corresponding period a year ago.
Reflecting the contrasting performances of the big and small securities houses, however, 9 of the 10 second-tier firms reported losses for the first half, although some of the losses were smaller than expected.
All the results reflected business conducted by the parent companies only. The companies will post consolidated results, reflecting business carried out by all the operations in each business group, later.
The results were in contrast to those for the fiscal year that ended on March 31, when Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi each recorded their largest pretax losses ever. Nomura was profitable, although its earnings fell sharply.
Over all, the 20 brokerage houses listed on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange reported combined losses of more than 254 billion yen, or $2.5 billion, for the fiscal year, making the year the industry's worst in more than three decades.
Since then, however, Japanese bond prices have rallied, lifting the profit the firms make from trading bonds for their own accounts and the commissions they receive on bond trades for their customers.
Bond yields, which move in the opposite direction of prices, fell to their lowest levels after the Japanese central bank cut its discount rate to one-half of 1 percent, also a record low, on Sept. 8. A rally in the United States Treasury bond market also aided the Japanese brokers.
With interest rates about as low as they can go, however, analysts said they did not expect the firms to continue to receive such a big boost from the bond market. "These bond profits are unsustainably high," said Elizabeth Daniels, a banking and financial-industry analyst at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd., as quoted by Dow Jones news service.
Commissions from trading Japanese stocks remained weak in the first half. Average daily volume on the Tokyo exchange's first section fell nearly 10 percent from the similar period a year before. Volume was weakest in the first three months of the half; toward the end of the period, daily turnover improved as the dollar's rise against the yen led to a rally in stock prices. Volume has slowed since then.
Nomura said pretax profit rose to 32.16 billion yen, or $322 million, in the half, up 43 percent from 22.50 billion yen a year earlier. Net income gained 61 percent, to 16.37 billion yen from 10.19 billion yen, and revenue rose 4.8 percent, to 200.07 billion yen from 190.93 billion yen.
Daiwa's pretax profit jumped to 27.53 billion yen from 7.28 billion yen, while net income soared to 20.20 billion yen from 3.23 billion yen. Revenue increased 15 percent, to 143.94 billion yen from 124.92 billion yen.
At Nikko, pretax profit was 25.53 billion yen, more than 10 times the 2.33 billion yen profit in the 1994 period. Net income rose to 18.86 billion yen from 1.97 billion yen. Revenue increased 19 percent, to 139.04 billion yen from 116.78 billion yen.
Yamaichi swung to a pretax profit of 5.21 billion yen from a loss of 8.72 billion yen a year ago. It reported net income of 2.35 billion yen, in contrast to a net loss of 6.59 billion yen in the 1994 period. Revenue rose 10 percent, to 110.76 billion yen from 100.36 billion yen.

HEADLINE: Italy's Political Turmoil Hurts European Stocks and the Dollar

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Political uncertainties in Italy infected financial markets across Europe today, sending the dollar sharply lower and driving down stock and bond prices.
Investors, jittery about the economic outlook in Italy if the current Government fails to survive a vote of confidence in Parliament this week, sold Italian lire and purchased German marks. The mark, a traditional safe haven for European investors, then strengthened against other currencies, including the dollar. 
 Canadian markets were also shaken by political forces today. Stock and bond prices plummeted after a poll showed Quebec separatists gaining an upper hand in a referendum next week. [Page D6.] United States stock prices also fell after the declines in Europe. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 39.38 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 4,755.48. [Page D16.]
The rise in the mark raised fears in Germany that exporters, already hit hard by the strong currency in recent months, would see their profits come under more intense pressure. A strong mark makes German goods more expensive abroad. German stock prices fell sharply, with the DAX index of 30 shares ending the day down 63.07 points, or 2.9 percent, at 2,107.42.
Similar patterns were seen in other European markets. In Paris, the CAC-40 index fell 19.58 points, to 1,721.14. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares fell 19.9 points, to 3,531.5.
In Milan, Italian equities suffered from the nation's continuing political problems, with the Mibtel index hitting a new low of 8,878 during the day before closing at 8,912, down 1.82 percent. The lira slid to 1,160 to the mark from 1,145 on Friday.
Analysts said the dollar, rather than suffering from any new fundamental problem, simply became caught in the European crossfire and was driven down as traders bought marks and sold lire, French francs and other European currencies. Some of those transactions also involve the dollar; a trader, for example, may sell lire for dollars and then sell the dollars to buy marks.
The dollar also fell against the Japanese yen in European trading. The dollar was at 99.60 yen late in the day, down from 100.18 on Friday.
Late in the day, the dollar was trading at 1.3821 marks, down from 1.3975 on Friday. The dollar traded as low as 1.3816 marks during the day, its lowest level in nearly three months.
Later in New York, the dollar recovered a bit, trading at 99.96 yen and 1.3882 marks. But the dollar was still down from Friday's levels in New York, when it was trading at 100.35 yen and 1.3977 marks.
The rocky performance of the markets today came against a background of political and economic problems across Europe.
The Italian Government of Prime Minister Lamberto Dini appeared likely to lose a vote of confidence in the lower house of Parliament on Thursday. If the Government falls, its budget proposals would probably be doomed.
At the same time, the French Government is struggling with the value of the franc while trying to address a stubborn unemployment problem. And doubts are growing in many countries about the ability of the European Union to meet its goal of a single currency by the end of the decade.
"The key thing today is the shift from the French issues that had been dominating the market to what's going on in Italy," said Michael Pratten, senior bond and currency analyst at Paine Webber in London.
In that atmosphere, the mark has proved even more attractive than usual. The trend was strengthened last week by higher-than-expected money supply figures for September that cast some doubt on the ability of the Bundesbank, the central bank of Germany, to cut interest rates anytime soon.
"Political uncertainties have added to European stresses and those in Italy are foremost," said Kermit L. Schoenholz, an economist at Salomon Brothers in London.
The currency markets were also unsettled by reports in France that prosecutors had been asked to investigate whether President Jacques Chirac had used his influence while Mayor of Paris to insure that he could keep living in an apartment he rented from a city-subsidized real estate company. The French currency plunged briefly after the report and then recovered somewhat.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Political uncertainty in Italy is roiling European markets. A trader at the Milan Stock Exchange rested yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Slain Girl Implicated in Family Deaths in Harlem

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
When a mother and her two children were found shot to death in their Harlem apartment early Friday, the crime seemed to be the horrifying work of cold-blooded robbers. When the police said yesterday that they had arrested two suspects, the horror was compounded.
Detectives said that one of the children, a teen-age girl, was actually an accomplice who let the killers into the apartment at 631 West 152d and then became a victim. The police said that she was bitterly angry at her domineering father and that she had hired the men to kill him. 
 Charged with murder, robbery and weapons possession were Lamar Sanchez, 18, of 3675 Broadway, and Jose Rodriguez, 24, of 3692 Broadway. Investigators said Mr. Sanchez was a former boyfriend of the girl, Arelis Batista, a senior at Mother Cabrini High School in Washington Heights, who had chafed under the discipline of her father, William Batista.
Investigators recovered more than $22,000 stolen from the victims' apartment and seized a .22-caliber, silencer-equipped rifle used in the execution-style slayings, said Charles Reuther, the New York Police Chief of Detectives.
The suspects were picked up early yesterday, one at his home and the other on a street, the authorities said. They said the rifle had been found in Riverside Park near 152d Street. The police declined to be specific on where the money had been recovered.
The announcement by the police, made even as mourners were gathering at St. Catherine of Genoa Roman Catholic Church on 153d Street near Amsterdam Avenue to honor the dead, seemed to numb those who thought they knew what had appeared to be a close-knit, religious family.
When William Batista arrived home early Saturday from his night-shift custodial job at a midtown hotel to find his wife, Marian; his son, William Jr., and his daughter dead, all signs pointed to robbery. The motive seemed obvious: someone knew that Mr. Batista, a 40-year-old immigrant from the Dominican Republic, distrusted American banks so much that he kept more than $20,000 in the family apartment near Riverside Drive.
But the investigation soon led to Mr. Sanchez, and then to Mr. Rodriguez -- in part, the police said, because Arelis Batista had disappeared for three days last February and then returned home to tell her father of being kidnapped and sexually assaulted.
Chief Reuther said the police determined in February that the young woman's story was untrue and that she had gone to the police only under orders from her father. As the police were dissecting her story last winter, Mr. Sanchez's name surfaced, though Chief Reuther declined yesterday to say exactly how.
Chief Reuther said investigators believe that Ms. Batista let Mr. Sanchez into the apartment through her bedroom window about 1:30 A.M. on Friday, and that he let in Mr. Rodriguez through the front door. The original plan was for the two men, both unemployed, to wait for Mr. Batista to come home from his night job and then kill him, Mr. Reuther said.
Instead, the chief said, the two men decided to kill the people already in the apartment, and then they apparently fled around 5 A.M. with roughly $25,000 and a handgun, both found in a closet. Chief Reuther said investigators believe Mr. Sanchez first shot Arelis Batista with the rifle, then gave it to Mr. Rodriguez, who killed Mrs. Batista, 41, and her 15-year-old son as they slept.
Chief Reuther said Mr. Sanchez had no prior record and that Mr. Rodriguez had been arrested once before, for burglary and possession of a weapon. The disposition of those charges was not known yesterday.
The suspects were picked up by Detective Elpidio DeLeon of the 30th Precinct, Chief Reuther said.
The chief said Ms. Batista had longstanding grievances with her father, whom he described as "a strong parent with a very tight rein on his family." Jacqueline Gill, a 20-year-old cousin of Arelis Batista, said Mr. Batista did not want his daughter to date until she was 19 and that he even disapproved of makeup for teen-age girls.
But Ms. Gill said she could not believe that her cousin had plotted to kill her father. "It was just a normal strict-parent kind of relationship," Ms. Gill said. "That's why he sent her to an all-girls Catholic school."
After the slayings, the Rev. Robert Ritchie of St. Catherine of Genoa Church said that Mr. Batista's strong control was a reflection of his deep, religion-based love and his determination to shield his family from the everyday dangers of a rough neighborhood.
Last night, Father Ritchie said the suspects had sent flower arrangements -- one in the form of a heart, the other a mixed basket -- to the wake. It was not clear whether the flowers were sent as a macabre joke or contrition or both, but detectives took them away yesterday before about 150 mourners gathered at the church.
Later, Father Ritchie gathered with immediate relatives for a private prayer service. Late last night, the bodies were transported to Kennedy International Airport. Father Ritchie, Mr. Batista and other relatives were to accompany them to the Dominican Republic today for burial.
Residents of the neighborhood said Mr. Rodriguez was known as a troublemaker. "He carried a knife, a screwdriver, anything," said Carlos Romero, who said he had known the suspect for a long time. "You're not going to hear anything nice about him."

Czechs Get $140 Million From Stratton Venture

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Lottery for the Arts: Over the Rainbow Or Under a Cloud?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Imagine a world in which Government support for the arts added not a penny to the deficit, one in which profits from a wildly popular form of entertainment produced a torrent of cash for dance, theater and music. No, it's not some culture vulture's idea of what lies beyond the pearly gates. It's Britain today, where 5 percent of the revenue from the new national lottery -- roughly $10 million a week -- is dedicated to fine arts.
Could a lottery do for the United States what it is doing for hundreds of British arts organizations ranging from the Sydenham School of Dance ($450) to the Covent Garden Opera House ($75 million)? Getting from here to there would take a remarkable job of political salesmanship in a country where 36 states, dozens of Indian tribes and Donald Trump are already scrapping over the last morsels from legal gambling. 
 But with the National Endowment for the Arts slated to lose 40 percent of its appropriation next year and the squeeze already showing in cuts that will halve the endowment's personnel by the end of the 1995, the idea is beginning to stir interest. "It's one of a handful of ideas we're mulling to take arts funding out of budget politics," explained a Clinton Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Special tax incentives for private donations to the arts have been discussed, as has the notion of allowing arts groups to issue bonds whose interest would be exempt from Federal taxation. But both are potential revenue-losers, with little support in Congress. Another idea, initially raised by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, is to auction off extended copyright privileges. But powerful interests, notably the film studios, are on the verge of persuading Congress to extend the current copyright protection of life-plus-50 years to match the new European Community standard, life-plus-70 years. And they have no wish to share the windfall with arts groups.
That leaves the lottery, which at least on first look would appear to be a gold mine.
Britain has long countenanced legal gambling but kept it low key. So last fall, when the country's Conservative leaders finally blessed a weekly televised lottery with the odds of winning set at 1 in 14 million, it hit a gusher of untapped demand. "The Government was shocked by how popular the lottery was," said William Eadington, director of the University of Nevada's Institute for the Study of Gambling.
Half the proceeds go back to bettors tax free as lump-sum prizes. A bit less than a quarter goes to the private corporation called Camelot, which manages the monopoly and the retail vendors that sell the 1 tickets. The rest is divided among five funds dedicated to organized charity, promotion of sports, preservation of historic sites, celebration of the millennium and, of course, subsidies to arts groups.
Since the lottery is doing better than expected, so are the arts. Government spending, which was already $300 million a year, generous by comparison with the United States, may reach double that this year. And while the arts world, or some of it, is apparently embarrassed about the source, it is not about to turn down the riches. John Mortimer, the novelist and creator of "Rumpole," called the lottery "the final, typical nail in the coffin of this horrible regime," then retracted when he was reminded that, as chairman of the Royal Court Theater, he had applied for a lottery grant.
If Congress chose to emulate Britain, says Petert would no doubt draw billions of dollars in revenue. "The big prizes would be irresistible," he argues.
A national lottery could probably operate with lower costs than existing state lotteries. The latest technology would permit direct sale by telephone, bypassing small stores that now punch out state lottery tickets. "If L. L. Bean can sell hiking boots by phone, you can sell lottery tickets by phone," said Charles Clotfelter, an economist at Duke University.
But the mechanics would be the least of the worries of those seeking to operate a high-stakes national lottery in the name of high culture. One big problem is that states have grown increasingly dependent on lottery revenue and rightly fear they would be cannibalized. Last year, the 36 states with lotteries raised 3.2 percent of their total revenues from "painless" lottery wagering. Massachusetts and the District of Columbia both topped $100 in profit per resident. South Dakota, which prides itself on low taxes and ubiquitous gambling opportunities, raised 11 percent of all state revenue from the lottery. "There would be bitter opposition from the states," Mr. Eadington, the Nevada researcher, concluded.
Then, too, there is the issue of principled opposition. While most states have succumbed to the lure of legal gambling, conspicuous holdouts include Utah and most of the rural South. Add to that opposition from those secular humanists who see lotteries as both an unfair tax on the poor and an incitement to compulsive gambling.
Even if fans of a national lottery overwhelm their opponents, supporters of the arts would still have to scramble for a share of the booty. In 1949, the last time a national lottery was seriously proposed, the proceeds were supposed to be dedicated to veterans benefits. This time, a dozen causes from AIDS research to the homeless would doubtless compete.
In Britain, the Arts Council's decision to pour millions of pounds of lottery proceeds into the Royal Opera House drew scathing commentary from politicians and press. "This is a strange country," Jeremy Isaacs, the director of the Opera House, told The Guardian. "People don't understand that it's by a kind of miracle that the curtain goes up here every night."
Americans may not be as primed for class warfare as the British, but they are surely even readier to do battle over icons of cultural identity such as religion, the flag and four-letter words. Hence disposition of the profits from a Government-run monopoly would draw scrutiny from conservative lawmakers like Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, even though the money never showed up in the Federal budget.
Britain's experience suggests another reason for caution. While the arts have been a clear financial winner in the lotteries, directors of the brand-name charities are still holding their breaths. They worry that the millions guaranteed from the lottery will undermine private giving. By the same token, it would not take a very large decline in private philanthropy to offset the gains to the arts from a national lottery in America. After all, any conceivable amount funneled from some future lottery would be small compared to the gifts from foundations, corporations and individuals that now support the arts.
All this suggests that a national lottery for the arts would be a hard sell, even to champions of the Federal support for the arts, like Representative Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois. "I'm intrigued," Mr. Yates allowed, "but I'm opposed."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 4, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article on Oct. 24 about a proposed arts lottery in the United States misstated the fee received by the company that manages the British one. The company, Camelot, splits 25 percent of the proceeds with the Government; it does not receive slightly less than 25 percent.
