HEADLINE: Labor Adopts a Symbol: The Sun (a Rising One)

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Wherever delegates to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention go around their midtown Manhattan hotel this week, they are surrounded by the bright yellow rays of the rising sun, emblazoned on T-shirts, silk-screened onto placards and printed on campaign literature.
The rays have been adopted as the campaign symbol of John J. Sweeney, the president of the Service Employees International Union, who promises to rejuvenate the labor movement if he wins the presidency of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in balloting today. 
 To many of the 1,020 delegates, the rays have become the embodiment of their outlook for the movement itself, a signal that the federation appears to be waking from a long slumber during which it hardly raised a finger as unions were bulldozed by management and whipsawed by economic change.
"There is a sense of change in the air," Ray M. Figueroa, president of the Southern Arizona Central Labor Council, said during a recess at the convention, the first in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s history that has ever featured a contested presidential election. "It's history in the making."
Regardless of whether Mr. Sweeney or his opponent, Thomas R. Donahue, the federation's interim president, wins the election, their hard-fought campaign has injected some new energy and focus into the languishing movement. Mr. Sweeney has vowed to shake up the 13-million-member federation and turn it into an aggressive vehicle for organizing, and Mr. Donahue, notwithstanding his 16 years as the federation's No. 2 official, vows to do likewise.
"Now we're expecting new movement in the labor movement," said Ken Moss, a 6-foot-5-inch union official from Minnesota with shoulder-length blond hair. It was lunchtime, and he was standing outside the Sheraton New York Hotel, the site of the convention, along with dozens of other delegates, basking in unusually warm autumn weather.
Many union members fear that unless the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new head makes good on promises to build a more aggressive federation, the sun's rays will come to symbolize not a rising sun but a setting one. But this time around, union officials insist, the lofty oratory about recharging the movement will not prove empty. They promise to follow up with action, acknowledging that the debate between the Sweeney and Donahue camps has provided some healthy self-criticism.
Mary Lyons, a delegate from Oregon representing the United Food and Commercial Workers, has no illusions that labor's task will be easy. "We're going to have the same big problems as before," she said. "We still have to deal with American corporations and American politicians who aren't taking care of working people."
Sitting in the convention hall yesterday waiting for a Donahue-Sweeney debate to begin, Ms. Lyons was wearing a white shirt with Mr. Donahue's name in big letters. The shirt appeared lonely: it was engulfed in a sea of hundreds of red T-shirts proclaiming support for Mr. Sweeney.
Given all his years in the labor federation, Mr. Donahue is supposed to have plenty of expertise in organizing. But it has been clear this week that the Sweeney forces out-organized him hands down. In addition to their catchy red T-shirts, saying "A New Voice for American Workers," the Sweeney backers carried hundreds of orange campaign placards and wore orange windbreakers with the word "Change" on the back.
Adrift in a sea of Sweeney red, Ms. Lyons and other pro-Donahue delegates appeared all but beaten, although Mr. Donahue's campaign aides insisted that he could still pull a rabbit out of his hat to win.
From the jeers on the convention floor and the arguments in the hall, there was no denying that the presidential campaign had driven a wedge, at least for the time being, into any notion of labor solidarity.
Assuming their traditional role as eternal optimists, many union leaders said they were confident that once the election was over, solidarity would reign once more.
"Things are extremely tense right now," said Edward J. Tynes, who represented the Southwest Georgia Labor Council and wore a "Boot Newt" button. "But once we get outside of this convention hall, solidarity will be there."
Not everyone was so sure. Having invested so much energy and resources into one candidate or the other, many national union leaders accustomed to getting their way will no doubt be fuming come Wednesday.
"There are going to be some deep wounds on the national level," Ms. Lyons said. "There's going to have to be a lot of healing."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS TO OPEN BUDGET BILL VOTES FOR 1996 SPENDING

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Starting Wednesday, Congress will begin voting on the huge budget bills that will give Republicans the chance to prove they mean their promises to change the way Government works -- most of all by balancing the Federal budget by the year 2002.
Until this week, action on the budget has consisted of high-sounding resolutions, the defeat of a constitutional amendment requiring balance and energetic but inconclusive efforts to reduce the level of spending in the annual bills that finance Government agencies. Only 3 of those 13 measures have made their way to the White House. 
 But the big budget reconciliation bills -- 1,949 pages in the Senate version and 1,754 in the House -- promise a balanced budget with curbs on spending for programs available to all those entitled and thus hard to control, like Medicare, Medicaid, student loans and farm programs. The total package is sweetened by a $245 billion tax cut.
Speaker Newt Gingrich said the measure would put the nation "back on the right moral track."
"In peacetime," he continued, "you shouldn't borrow your children's money," adding in a brief interview that the legislation was "an important trust-building step" because the Republicans had promised the public a balanced budget, "and we're going to give it to them."
Mr. Gingrich said the budget votes would also establish that "Washington has to live within its means, set priorities and actually manage its resources." Moreover, he said, there would be a "balanced budget dividend" from the lower interest rates that would result, for individuals, in savings of as much as $37,000 in mortgage interest on a typical house or $700 on a new car loan.
But before debate and votes can begin on Wednesday in the Senate and on Thursday in the House, those huge bills remain subject to last-minute tinkering on everything from Medicaid formulas to milk subsidies.
Those efforts were intended to solidify Republican majorities. Republicans can afford to lose no more than 3 of their 53 senators and 16 of their 233 Representatives for the final votes, which are planned for Thursday in the House and Friday in the Senate.
But there was also a tentative air about this week's votes. Once passed, these bills will amount to a Republican statement. Nothing voted on this week can become law without agreement from the Clinton Administration, which has regularly issued veto threats. Ultimately some sort of negotiation must take place.
Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, focused on that goal today when he said that a Democratic amendment to preserve Medicaid, the health program for the poor, the disabled and the elderly in nursing homes, would be defeated this week, but "The principal contribution of this will be in Round 2 -- after the veto."
Instead of turning the Federal-state program over to the states as a block grant and curbing spending by $182 million over seven years, as the Republican bills would do, the Democratic plan would merely slow its rate of growth by about $60 billion.
There was also a familiar note in the promise to balance the budget -- something that has not been accomplished since 1969. Congress has tried before, but Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Senate Budget Committee, heatedly told reporters that this year's budget reconciliation bills were different because they took on the entitlement programs with their intense political constituencies.
"In this reconciliation bill, the major entitlements are changed by law," he said. Referring to a 1985 Congressional effort to curb spending and get on a path to a balanced budget, he said: "Gramm-Rudman was a process. This is actually a law."
The Medicare plan, voted on separately by the House last week, is included in this bill. So are the House and Senate versions of the welfare bill, on which a House-Senate conference began today. Reublicans would rather pass the welfare bill on its own, but it is included in the filibuster-proof reconciliation bill as insurance.
Democrats do not dream of defeating either the House or Senate versions of the bill. But the Senate amendments can either influence a final settlement, or at least, form the basis for television advertisements with which to accuse particular Republicans who vote against the amendments of hard-heartedness. The Democrats also offered general denunciations today. On all sides, they complained about reductions in the Earned Income Tax Credit, a benefit for the working poor.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, said the Republican bill was suitable for the Halloween season. "The wealthy get treated to huge tax cuts they don't even need," he said, "while middle-class families get tricked out of hundreds of dollars they desperately need to survive."
Senator Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate minority leader, ridiculed the title of the bill, saying "The term 'reconciliation' is bit of a misnomer this year because the only differences being reconciled are between the far-right and the farther-right." He complained that Democrats had been "locked out" of the effort to draft a bill.
When the House considers the bill on Thursday, the only amendment likely to be in order will be a substitute proposed by a group of 22 conservative and moderate Democrats who style themselves "the Coalition."
They would also reach a balanced budget, but their plan includes no tax cut, reduces the growth of Medicare by $170 billion over seven years instead of by $270 billion, shaves $84 billiion instead of $182 billion from Medicaid and reduces the Consumer Price Index by half a percentage point in order to slow the growth of cost of living allowances.
Their symbolic proposal will not command solid Democratic support. Mr. Gephardt said today he would vote against it.
If the Senate meets its schedule and passes the bill by the weekend, it is still likely to take at least two weeks for a House-Senate conference to reach a deal between Republicans in the two houses. That would leave final passage, a veto by President Clinton and any negotiations that follow all to be accomplished by mid-November, when legislation authorizing the current national debt level expires.
The only talk of negotiations today came when Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said at a news conference that he and Mr. Gingrich hoped that Mr. Clinton would follow through on last week's statement that balancing the budget in seven years was now acceptable to him and send them a proposal.
In New York, Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said, "I think the President would prefer that the majority leader and the Speaker get to work on the budget, rather than hold constant press conferences."

HEADLINE: Stocks Stage a Comeback, With the Dow Rising 28.18 Points

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Major stock averages rose yesterday for the first time in three days, with large-capitalization and transportation issues sharing the spotlight.
"It was primarily a fairly impressive performance by the blue chips," said Ricky Harrington, senior vice president at Interstate/Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C. "First there was a bond market rally, and then stocks followed." 
 Bonds climbed after comments by Alan S. Blinder, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated that the Fed might cut interest rates soon. The 30-year Treasury bond jumped almost a full percentage point, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.32 percent from 6.39 percent on Monday.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.18 points, to 4,783.66, erasing more than half of Monday's fall. In addition, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 1.50 points, to 586.56, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.32 points, to 1,039.24.
The Dow Jones transportation index soared 45.99 points, to 1,949.08. The 2.4 percent gain was its largest one-day spurt since the middle of July. A surge in the third-quarter profits of UAL, the parent company for United Airlines, led the way, and the stock gained 4 1/4, to 175.
But in contrast to the recent pattern where better-than-expected earnings reports have generally affected the issuing company, but not its sector, the euphoria over UAL spilled over to other transportation stocks.
The recently merged Burlington Northern Santa Fe, the nation's largest railway, surged 5 7/8, to 82 3/4, after it announced that its revenue growth would exceed the growth in the economy. Other railroads also gained. CSX rose 1 3/4, to 83 1/2; Norfolk Southern increased 2 1/4, to 77 7/8, and Union Pacific advanced 5/8, to 66 1/4.
Airborne Freight reported a profit dip, but its earnings were still stronger than analysts had expected and the stock surged 2 1/8, to 26 1/4.
Declines narrowly topped advances on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,165 to 1,110. Volume on the Big Board spurted to 415.5 million shares from 330.8 million shares Monday.
"It is unusual that there were more declining stocks than advancing stocks on a day when bonds were so strong," Mr. Harrington said. "This shows the continuing divergence between the averages and the market breadth."
Bargain-hunters were selective yesterday in picking their stocks and chose many of the issues in the Dow. The biggest contributors to the gain in the index were Procter & Gamble, up 2 7/8, to 88 3/4; Aluminum Company of America, up 2, to 50 3/8, and Eastman Kodak, up 2, to 63 7/8.
Others included Caterpillar, up 1 1/2, to 54 3/8; International Paper, up 5/8, to 37 1/8, and Boeing, up3/8 to 66 7/8.
Drug shares also turned higher after Pfizer said that it expected new drugs to help its earnings growth through the year 2000. Pfizer closed at 60 7/8, up 1 3/8; Merck closed at 60 3/8, up 7/8; and Schering-Plough closed at 54 3/4, up 1 3/8.
In yesterday's choppy market environment, however, bank stocks, which had been moving up on merger activity and speculation, were subjected to profit-taking. Chase Manhattan fell 2 3/8, to 58 3/8; Chemical Banking dropped 2 3/8, to 57; BankAmerica declined 1 3/8, to 62 3/4, and Nationsbank slipped 1 3/8, to 69 3/8.
Some technology stocks, a group that had long been a market leader, were weak. I.B.M., which announced after the close plans to sell $750 million of bonds, closed at 98, down 1. Texas Instruments closed at 70 1/8, down 1 1/8, and Micron Technology closed at 71 1/4, down 2 3/8.
Also finishing on the downside were some tobacco stocks, after RJR Nabisco told analysts in a conference call that its earnings for the 1995 fourth quarter and 1996 were expected to be below estimates. RJR declined 2 5/8, to 29 1/4, and American Brands dropped 1/8, to 41 1/4.

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: UP CLOSE;
A Wistful Little Land Savors World Stage

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Just outside the fanfare that surrounded the United Nations with a womb of security on Sunday, the Foreign Minister from the tiny nation of Bhutan sat unnoticed at a booth in a coffee shop at 48th Street and First Avenue. He had a cup of Lipton tea and no armed guard.
Dawa Tsering, the Foreign Minister and the official representative of the world's last remaining Himalayan Buddhist kingdom, said he had not been able to meditate much during the weekend. Because King Jigme Singye Wangchuck, Precious Ruler of the Dragon People, had not made the trip to the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, the 60-year-old official had taken part in all the ceremonies and receptions and handshake lines. 
 Now, Mr. Tsering was silently refining his speech to the United Nations General Assembly. That he was 171st in a line of 178 national representatives scheduled to speak late yesterday evening didn't embarrass him. That the anniversary would be essentially over and the United Nations all but empty did not trouble him. For Bhutan, the world stage was fine anytime.
"The big nations of the world could do without the United Nations," Mr. Tsering said. "But without the United Nations, Bhutan would have no voice. Bhutan today exists on the razor's edge. Our culture is at risk. We could disappear. The speech is serious."
When it was Mr. Tsering's turn to address the General Assembly last night, he followed leaders from other small, developing nations and actually spoke before a surprisingly large crowd. He called for the broadening of the Security Council to represent more than just the "privileged few." For Mr. Tsering, his speech was the final act in the dramatic experience of an obscure country caught up in the spectacle of sober geopolitics and smiling photo ops amid suffocating security and state dinners. Certainly, Mr. Tsering cut his own distinctive figure in the mix of egos and agendas and armored motorcades.
Often dressed in his country's traditional clothing -- a kimono-like knee-length wrap called a kho -- Mr. Tsering moved through the three days modestly and without concern about security or traffic. He spent his nights at a colleague's apartment on 34th Street, often walked to the United Nations, and chose to ride courtesy buses through Manhattan when attending the functions hosted by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or President Clinton. Sometimes, he opted for a dark suit, including when he made his speech last night, and with his eyeglasses and moustache he could easily have been mistaken for a professor from Columbia who had wandered downtown.
"Sometimes people gawk at my traditional clothes," said Mr. Tsering. "We don't like to be made a spectacle of."
Inside the institutional politics of the United Nations, Bhutan has gained notice and rank. Ugyen Tshering, Bhutan's representative to the United Nations, is chairman of the General Assembly's committee for human rights and social programs.
More importantly, programs financed by the United Nations's health, education and economic branches have been vital to the country of 600,000 that is pinched between China and India. In Bhutan, where tantric Tibetan Buddhism is the official religion, the King is attempting the delicate trick of transforming a medieval monarchy into a more democratic government without disrupting tradition or creating chaos. As part of that, the country has become a laboratory for experts helping build a money economy from scratch.
And so in a country once sealed from the rest of the world, one that 30 years ago didn't have roads or schools or currency, Mr. Tsering said the United Nations is the reason 90 percent of the children are immunized, and thousands of students have gone abroad. He said the United Nations could be critical in assisting Bhutan with the growing problem of illegal immigration and ethnic unrest among the Nepalese population in the country's south.
"Cultures throughout the world are being watered down," said Mr. Tsering. "Without our identity, we cease to exist."
For the international media and many of the world's political bigshots, Bhutan existed this weekend as a name on a list. That didn't trouble Mr. Tsering. Mr. Tsering, who was educated by Jesuit missionaries in India, attended the dinner at the World Financial Center on Saturday night, meeting the President of the Maldives and the Vice President of Uruguay.
"I found out Uruguay had three million people and 10 million cows," Mr. Tsering said after dashing across Fifth Avenue in his kho late Saturday night. "It was very educational."
It wasn't painless, though.
"Speeches are the price we pay for events like this," he said. "In that sense, there are no free dinners."
Mr. Tsering made it safely to the group photo of world leaders taken Sunday, tucked in the second to last row, but dead center. Later that day, he held several private meetings with leaders from South Korea and other Asian nations. He said he found President Clinton's speech "ordinary," but Fidel Castro's "passionate."
"Castro is a real folk hero, maybe the last one left," he said.
Sunday night, Mr. Tsering waited for hours at the Carlyle Hotel before his bus set off for Mr. Clinton's cocktail party at the New York Public Library.
"I got to the moment when I shook hands with the President and the First Lady, and I suppose I was supposed to just move on," said Mr. Tsering. "But I figured -- why not? -- to try and engage them in conversation. It had been a long wait. I asked the First Lady if she had seen the Bhutanese fabric exhibit that had been at the Smithsonian Institution. She said she hadn't. That was it."
The Foreign Minister never did find much time for meditating. He did stop by to see the Tibetan hunger strikers at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza. He took in Nelson Mandela's address. And always, he was thinking of his speech, rewriting it in his head.
"The ability to revise is one of the benefits of going so close to last," said Mr. Tsering.
Later, he smiled about it all.
"Look, we don't have global issues, and we don't lose sight of our position in the world," he said. "But we don't feel left out, either. For Bhutan, the United Nations is alot more than window dressing. There was an air of history about these days."

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: REPORTERS NOTEBOOK;
Clinton Has Dinner And Cars Go Missing

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
This wasn't exactly LAX being shut down for the Presidential coif aboard Air Force One, but some residents of the Upper West Side awoke yesterday morning to feel the aftereffects of President Clinton's dinner on Monday night.
To make the area around Cafe des Artistes safe for the First Eater, cars were towed from legal parking spaces on 67th Street near Central Park West and parked elsewhere in the neighborhood. The street was heavily secured before the President's arrival, and residents who wanted to go home had to show identification containing their address or be escorted to their apartments by police officers. Shortly before the President arrived, a city street sweeper cleaned 67th Street. 
 When residents found that their cars were gone yesterday morning, they were directed to a police barricade near Central Park where they were directed to their cars.
Mike Tarr, a Secret Service spokesman, said yesterday that his agency had asked the police to move "several" cars "to facilitate the arrival of the Presidential motorcade," adding that if it caused any inconvenience, "we certainly apologize."
Neither the police nor transportation officials could say how many cars were towed, but a resident of the block said the tow trucks were working for hours.
Oh yes, the dinner. Mr. Clinton dined with nine other people, including Susan Thomases, a family friend; Bruce Lindsay, the deputy White House counsel, and Harold Ickes, the deputy White House chief of staff. Mr. Clinton had dined at the restaurant when he visited New York as Governor of Arkansas, but he had never eaten there as President, according to the restaurant's owner, George Lang.
The President order grilled quail served on a bed of caramelized apples macerated in Calvados. He was seen using pumpernickel bread to sop up the juice. (Who could blame him?)
But Mr. Clinton was out yesterday morning running it off in Central Park. Regular joggers there found him and his security detail running around the Reservoir and joined in. Mary Fortuna, an East Side resident, was about to begin her morning run when "all of a sudden I saw Bill Clinton running by me, and a man said, 'Come on, you want to run with the President?' "
Mr. Clinton, it seems, was such a fast runner that Ms. Fortuna could not keep up with him.
 
 
Hunger Striker Hospitalized
 On Oct. 14, six Tibetans began a hunger strike across from the United Nations, vowing to refrain from eating until the international bodies recognized that Tibet is occupied by China and took steps to return Tibet to control by the Dalai Lama. They said that if they died, other Tibetans were ready to take their places.
Late yesterday afternoon, one of the strikers was taken to Bellevue Hospital after doctors determined that she was seriously ill and unable to decide for herself whether she needed treatment, said Heidi Melz, a program director with the Office of Tibet, which represents the Dalai Lama in the Americas. The striker was identified only as Yiga, 35, a Minneapolis woman.
The protesters have been lying on futons in Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, at 47th Street and First Avenue, wearing wool caps and covered with blankets. Yesterday, other Tibetans were chanting slogans like "Free Tibet" and "China Out Of Tibet" behind the strikers, and monks prayed over them.
Ms. Melz said there had been no response to the hunger strike by United Nations officials or world leaders attending the General Assembly session.
 
 
Castro-Watching
 For those stargazers who get their kicks by spotting big-time political leaders, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has been a hot item this week.
But the Fatigued One had his own bout of celebrity fever Monday night, when he went to Jimmy's Bronx Cafe to speak to some Puerto Rican business leaders, many of whom favor lifting the economic embargo against Cuba. When Mr. Castro arrived at the banquet room, he was seated at a side table out of the view of the audience. At the next table he spotted Willie Colon, the internationally known salsa musician who lives in Westchester County.
"Willie!" Mr. Castro said with the fervor of a fan at a rock concert, and broke into a wide smile. The two embraced in a bear hug.
Mr. Castro continued making his rounds yesterday. He was given a lunch by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the Daily News publisher, who said he had made several trips to Cuba in the last year and had held almost 50 hours of conversations with the Cuban President. The lunch, at Mr. Zuckerman's Fifth Avenue apartment, was attended by other media notables like Mike Wallace, Peter Jennings, William Safire and Barbara Walters.
Answering questions through a translator, Mr. Castro said that he was not afraid of facing an opponent in an election, but that such elections were not part of his country's political system. He described Cuba as "an Athenian democracy but without plebeians and without slaves."
He said he considered President Jimmy Carter "a courageous" man, though he said he was not having the same experience with Mr. Clinton. But he added: "I look at Clinton with respect, and I tell you that sincerely. He seems to be a good person."
He said his greatest accomplishment was "survival" in the face of "the greatest power in the world." He described Cuba's relationship with the United States in David-and-Goliath terms -- except, he said, "we do not have a slingshot."
He held out little hope of improved relations. He said that given the demands being made by the United States, "we have no steps to take except to give up." He said he wondered why the United States could not have ties with Cuba when it has relations with Vietnam and China.
At one point in the lunch, Mr. Castro, who is known for his long speeches, was being questioned by John McLaughlin, the rapid-fire talk show host. "You're a journalist," Mr. Castro scolded. "But you don't let me speak."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Fees for guests who check out of their rooms early may become standard for the hotel industry.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
CORPORATE travel departments are not going to like it, but Westin and Hyatt hotels have decided to charge guests who check out one or more days ahead of schedule.
Hyatt's policy, with a $50 fee limit, is expected to be in effect by the end of the year at all 103 of its hotels in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean, a Hyatt spokeswoman said, and is already in effect at some properties, including those in Denver; Kansas City, Mo.; Milwaukee; Minneapolis; New Orleans, and Orlando, Fla., as well as the Grand Hyatt Washington. 
 Beginning Jan. 1, Westin will impose a $50 fee at about 40 of the 80 properties that bear its name and that it manages. It has been experimenting with various fees at hotels in Boston; Orlando; Houston; Hilton Head, S.C., and Mission Hills, Calif. Until the end of the year, its Peachtree Plaza hotel in Atlanta and Cypress Creek hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., will continue to charge a full day's rate for an early departure.
Hilton Hotels, ITT Sheraton, the Carlson Corporation's Radisson, and Marriott said they had no plans to charge for early departures.
"Market conditions are improving," said Don Welsh, vice president of sales and marketing for Westin, "and we're prepared to say there's a two-way relationship between the hotel and its guests."
Other hoteliers agree that with occupancy running at record levels in New York, Phoenix and elsewhere, guests who check out before the agreed-upon date of departure make it difficult if not impossible to sell their room. (While every hotel has some walkup traffic, most rooms are booked days in advance.)
Mr. Welsh and other hoteliers liken early departures to airline no-shows. And a hotelier, whose company does not charge a checkout fee, predicted that if early departure fees succeeded they would become the industry standard.
Meanwhile, business and leisure travelers alike may wonder whether the economic health of the hotel industry isn't improving partly at their expense. Rates are beginning to inch up. And whereas many hotels have for months imposed fees for failure to cancel guaranteed reservations at least 72 hours before arrival, they are now starting to cancel nonguaranteed reservations unless guests check in by 4 P.M., instead of the usual 6 P.M. deadline.
 
Frequent-Flier Update
Sabena and El Al Israel are the latest two airlines to join the American Express frequent-flier program, together with Hertz, Budget and National rental cars. At the same time, the program -- which awards one "point" or mile for every dollar charged to American Express and Optima cards -- added 16 shopping and 9 food partners. These include Nordic Track, Waldenbooks and Saks Fifth Avenue, along with K-Paul's Louisiana Mail Order and Windsor Vineyards. To reflect the broadened focus, American Express has changed the program's name from Membership Miles to Membership Rewards.
Still, frequent-flier miles remain the heart of the American Express program, whose other airlines partners are Delta, USAir, Continental, Southwest, Austrian, Aeromexico and Mexicana.
While a free round trip between the United States and Brussels on Sabena requires 80,000 "points," and between the United States and Tel Aviv on El Al requires 98,000, spokeswomen for both carriers said the real advantage of their affiliation with American Express was not necessarily to accumulate enough points to earn a free round-trip ticket. More likely, they say, it is to enable Membership Rewards travelers to transfer their points into Sabena's and El Al's own frequent-flier programs to earn upgrades or to get the remaining miles necessary to qualify for a free flight.
Moreover, Sabena, which is also a member of the Delta and USAir awards programs, said it expected that some people would buy tickets to fly between the United States and Brussels, and then, for example, use the 16,000 Membership Rewards points necessary to fly between Brussels and London or Paris.
For El Al, there is another dimension. "We have no other partners in our frequent-flier program," said Sheryl Stein of El Al, "so this represents an important expansion for our passengers and our airline."
 
Food for Thought
Flying over Chincoteague, Va., last Thursday evening, the pilot of Continental Airlines flight 693 from Newark to Orlando, Fla., not only pointed out the island to passengers but expounded at some length on the annual wild horse auction for which the island is famed. He ended by recommending "Misty of Chincoteague," the 1947 novel by Marguerite Henry, "even though it's a children's book."
At the conclusion of the travelogue-cum-book-review, a middle-aged passenger in economy class looked up from his Forbes magazine and -- in apparent reference to the snack served on what in times past would have been a dinner flight -- said to his seat mate, "Airlines no longer feed you, but at least on this flight you get food for thought."

HEADLINE: Governments Bypassing Banks to Pool Money in Fund

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Francie M. Heller was a school administrator in Ossining, N.Y., in the mid-1980's when she realized that school districts like hers might be better off pooling their spare cash with other districts rather than following the traditional paths of buying securities on their own or relying on local banks.
But rather than trying to promote the idea from within her school district, Ms. Heller decided to peddle her proposal to Wall Street on her own. In 1987, she landed at Bear Stearns, which sold her new business four years later to MBIA Inc., the municipal bond insurance company in Armonk, N.Y. 
 "A lot of people thought I was nuts to give up the security of the school district job," she said, "but I just knew that I couldn't get this idea off the ground working within the school system."
Today, Ms. Heller manages $1.2 billion for 371 local government entities in New York, from tiny fire departments to large counties. And her business at MBIA is thriving to such an extent that bankers, who are accustomed to handling nearly all the $10 billion to $15 billion that local governments in New York hold at any one time in short-term investments, are pushing for new state laws that would eliminate competition from people like Ms. Heller.
Her idea was to create a new kind of mutual fund for local governments, using state rules that allow these government units to form a cooperative for making investments, in much the same way as they cooperate in buying everything from school supplies to insurance.
Like millions of individuals and businesses who now keep $746 billion in money market funds rather than in bank accounts or other investments, many local governments and school districts are finding that this mutual-fund approach suits their needs. The government clients of MBIA have earned a higher interest rate than on bank deposits -- a difference of $25 million last year, MBIA said. And they avoided nearly $13 million in transaction fees, according to the MBIA Investor Service Corporation, which runs the fund. MBIA charges an annual fee of four-tenths of a percentage point, but still managed to offer a rate of more than 6 percent in recent months, compared with barely more than 2 percent available from most banks on interest-bearing checking accounts.
"I have a responsibility to our taxpayers to earn as much as I can on our investments, and most of the time the fund pays more than the banks," said Kenneth F. Smith, assistant superintendent in the Briarcliff Manor Free School District. Frances G. Wills, superintendent at Briarcliff, noted that without the $230,000 of interest earned last year from the investment pool, the district's local property tax bills would have been 2 percent higher.
In the wake of the debacle in Orange County, Calif., where $1.7 billion was lost by an investment fund run by county officials, local governments have taken a second look at how they handle their temporary investments. But MBIA invests in short-term securities -- either Treasuries or others backed by the full faith and credit of the Federal Government.
Local bankers acknowledge that Ms. Heller, like other money market managers, pays a higher interest rate than banks, but they point out that banks provide a host of financial services not available elsewhere.
"Local governments have some horrendous problems on the budget side, so they need to look at every source of revenue," said Charles V. Wait, chief executive at the Adirondack Trust Company in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. "But they need to remember that when they move their deposits somewhere else, I have that much less money available to lend on a new car or a mortgage."
Indeed, Mr. Wait, like many other bankers in New York, is supporting legislation proposed by State Senator William J. Larkin Jr., a Republican from New Windsor, to curb competitors like MBIA. Hearings are scheduled today in Newburgh for both sides to air their views.
Beyond their complaint that banks no longer have as much money to lend locally, bankers argue that funds like MBIA's enjoy an unfair advantage. They are allowed to pool investments in Government securities, while banks are at a disadvantage because they are required to back each local government deposit with specific securities worth 100 percent or more of the deposit.
"It is a case where a very mature industry, banking, is being bypassed through an investment vehicle that is not what the law contemplated," said Michael Smith, executive director of the New York State Bankers Association. Mr. Smith said the bankers had tried to level the playing field by asking lawmakers to allow them to pool their securities used as backing for local government deposits. But failing that, they are now seeking to curb the MBIA fund by not allowing pooling of its investments.
Some banking companies, however, have found a way to join MBIA rather than trying to beat it. Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I., has started to offer its own investment fund -- apart from the deposits its banks handle -- in Maine, Connecticut and Rhode Island, and it plans to expand into New York.
"We sympathize with the bankers' complaints about unfair competition," said John B. Robinson, a managing director at Fleet, "but realistically it will be difficult to change things because local governments like the MBIA product and the extra interest they are earning with it."

HEADLINE: Outline of the Republican Proposals on the Budget

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

 BODY:
The mammoth budget bills before the Senate and the House of Representatives this week follow the same themes, although they differ somewhat on the margins. These are the main elements:
TAXES Taxes would be reduced by $245 billion over seven years. Most families would get a tax cut of $500 a child. The tax rate on capital gains would be lowered, eligibility for individual retirement accounts would be expanded, the marriage tax penalty would be lessened and a tax credit would be allowed to offset some adoption expenses. The Senate would allow a tax credit for part of the interest on student loans. The House would abolish the alternative minimum tax. 
 MEDICARE Spending for the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled would be $270 billion less over the next seven years than it would be without the changes. Payments to hospitals and doctors would be reduced, monthly premiums would be raised and inducements offered to encourage beneficiaries to move from the Government program into private insurance coverage.
MEDICAID To save $182 billion over seven years, the measures would give the states a reduced sum of money annually for health coverage for the poor and allow each state to decide what benefits to offer. Federal standards for nursing homes would be eliminated. The Senate and House use different formulas to decide how the money would be allotted among the states. The Senate, but not the House, would require states to cover pregnant women, children 12 and under and poor disabled people.
WELFARE The 60-year-old Federal commitment to provide subsistence payments to poor children and their parents would be ended. The program of Aid to Families With Dependent Children would be turned over to the states along with a reduced appropriation. Each state would decide how much the benefits would be and who would get them. Most recipients would be required to work within two years of going on welfare, and families would generally become ineligible for welfare after five years. Child care programs would also be administered by the states. Food stamps would continue as a Federal program, but benefits would be reduced. The House would deny funds to unwed teen-age mothers and children born to welfare recipients. The Senate would allow the states to withhold benefits from those people.
EARNED-INCOME TAX CREDIT Eligibility for this program, which lowers the taxes of low-income workers and in some cases gives them cash benefits, would be tightened, and benefits would be reduced. The cuts in the Senate bill are much deeper than those in the House.
STUDENT LOANS The interest subsidy students can get for the first six months after graduation would be abolished. The interest rate on loans to parents would be raised. The House would abolish and the Senate would limit direct loans by the Government. The Senate would require schools to pay a fee for each student with a Federally guaranteed loans.
ENVIRONMENT The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska would be opened to oil exploration, and mining would be expanded on Federal lands. The House would raise the fee ranchers pay for grazing on Federal land. The Senate would increase the entrance fees at national parks.
AGRICULTURE The House bill would overhaul the basic farm programs that have been in existence since the Depression, and replace them with large, slowly declining cash payments regardless of what farmers grow. The Senate bill would retain the basic structure of the Federal programs but would reduce to 70 percent from 85 percent the amount of a farm's acreage on which subsidies would be paid.
MISCELLANEOUS A fee would be imposed on savings and loan institutions to shore up the fund that insures their deposits. The House, but not the Senate, would abolish Federally chartered savings institutions by 1998. Various Federal assets like oil from the strategic petroleum reserve would be sold to raise money. Modest reductions would be made in veterans' benefits. The House, but not the Senate, would abolish the Commerce Department. The House, but not the Senate, would also fold the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency into the State Department. Federal employees would have to contribute more toward their pensions. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

HEADLINE: U.N. Warns Against Delay in Cutting Carbon Dioxide Emissions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
Delaying action to rein in emissions of heat-trapping atmospheric gases like carbon dioxide could increase the rate and magnitude of future climatic changes and make the world more vulnerable to costly and possibly irreversible damages, a United Nations scientific panel says in a new report.
Some economists have argued that the only cost-effective way to reduce emissions is to put the reduction off as long as possible, while others insist that doing so would merely push the burden onto future generations. 
 The new report, made public yesterday in Washington by a working group of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, says that while future technological advances might lower the cost of emissions reduction if action is delayed, deeper emissions cuts would be required in the end. Moreover, the scientists say that a delay in action could boost the damage from climate change and increase the cost of adapting to it.
And they say that if existing technologies for cutting fossil-fuel energy use are aggressively exploited through strong governmental policies, substantial emissions reductions can be achieved without big changes in life styles.
The report comes at a time when 142 countries that are parties to the 1992 climate treaty signed in Rio de Janeiro are negotiating reductions in carbon dioxide emissions and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases. The emissions come mainly from the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil. The industrialized countries of the world have already pledged, as a first step, to cap the emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000.
The report also comes as Republicans in Congress are seeking to reduce by as much as 40 percent the funds for the Clinton Administration's program to reach the 1990 cap.
The role of the intergovernmental panel, which consists of about 2,500 experts around the world, is to advise the treaty parties. An economics working group reported in Montreal 11 days ago that earlier action to cut emissions might relieve the burden on future generations by giving them more flexibility. The new report, from another working group, says that loss of this flexibility would force deeper emission cuts later on.
An average increase in global temperature of 1.5 to 6.3 degrees by the year 2100, predicted by a third working group, would cause a sea level rise of 6 to 37 inches by then and more in the following centuries, according to the report issued yesterday. Many low-lying coastal areas around the world could be inundated, the scientists say. An average rise of about 39 inches, they say, could place 70 million people at risk.
The panel also said climate change could produce, among other things, these consequences:
*Bring an increase in heat waves, floods, droughts, fires and pest outbreaks in some regions.
*Lead to the disappearance of entire forest types.
*Make desert climates more extreme.
*Cause a rise in the number of heat-related deaths and illnesses.
*Increase the range of vector-borne infectious diseases like malaria, yellow fever, dengue fever and viral encephalitis.
The report says that if existing technology were applied strictly, energy savings of about 25 percent could be achieved in homes, businesses and industrial plants during the next 30 years, and that greenhouse-gas reductions could be even larger.
It said energy use by motor vehicles could be cut by about a third during the same period by using efficient drive trains, light-weight materials and low-air-resistance design. Further reductions could come if vehicles were made smaller.

HEADLINE: Matsushita's Profits Climb For Half-Year

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that its half-year profits rose because of aggressive cost-cutting and despite a small decline in sales.
The company's chief financial officer, Motoi Matsuda, said lower manufacturing costs and better management efficiency helped the company shrug off fierce competition and appreciation of the yen, which shaved some 16 billion yen, or about $160 million, from the value of overseas sales. 
 "Business is starting to look slightly better, but the overall environment remains tough," Mr. Matsuda said at the company's headquarters here today.
Matsushita manufactures electronic equipment under such brands as National, Panasonic and Technics.
The company said its current profits rose 10 percent, to 41.22 billion yen ($412 million) in the half-year that ended on Sept. 30 from 37.41 billion a year earlier.
Current profit is a pretax profit that includes gains and losses made on investments and other nonoperating activities. But sales fell to 2.16 trillion yen, or about $21.6 billion, from 2.20 trillion.
Matsushita said sales were strong in Asia, where economic growth remained brisk, and relatively weak in Europe, the United States and Japan, where growth was sluggish or faltering.
Sales in Japan rose 2 percent, to 1.42 trillion yen ($14.2 billion), helped by marketing of new products and strengthened sales organizations, Matsushita said. But exports dropped 9 percent, to 739.4 billion yen ($7.39 billion).
Video equipment sales fell 17 percent and audio equipment sales dropped 8 percent, largely because of lower exports and a shift in consumer demand to lower-priced models, despite higher sales of wide-screen televisions, Mr. Matsuda said.
Electronic component sales surged 11 percent, while sales of communications and industrial equipment stayed steady overall. Sales of mobile communications equipment, including mobile telephones, rose strongly in Japan, he said.
Sales of home appliances rose in Japan because of the introduction of new models.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Renewed Hope for Rate Cut Sends Bond Prices Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Yields on Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, with the market getting plenty of mileage out of renewed hopes for an interest-rate cut in the near future, thanks to comments by Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.
The only problem with that positive news for the market was that it played havoc by blowing out short positions usually set up ahead of a government auction, disrupting normal dealer positioning. 
 Mr. Blinder's comments, reported yesterday morning by the Market News Service, indicated that a soft economic landing was likely without further cuts in short-term interest rates. Still, Mr. Blinder said, real rates are too high for the long run, so the Fed should begin to lower them, but not necessarily "imminently." He said he favored a "sizable" rate cut, depending on the outcome of Federal budget talks.
Mr. Blinder indicated that these were his opinions, not necessarily those of the Fed, but he said he had support from others. Analysts said the remarks gave the market a strong lift.
By late in the day, the 30-year Treasury bond was up 31/32, to a price of 107 13/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, was 6.32 percent, down from 6.39 percent on Monday.
As trading opened, the index of retail chain-store sales compiled by Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. and Schroder Wertheim & Company showed a hefty 1 percent increase for the week ended Oct. 21. Many economists saw the gain as a catch-up after poor sales reports in the previous three weeks, and they said seasonal considerations, like cooler weather and the approach of Halloween, had bolstered sales. But they noted that the index was up an impressive 5.2 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier.
The strong retail report, indicating a robust economy, erased the market's modest overnight gains. But traders managed to remain focused on buying on price declines.
In futures trading, the December bond contract did not even reach the Monday low of 116 5/32 before buyers stepped in yesterday morning. Yesterday's low was 116 6/32, with the high at 117 12/32 and the close at 117 8/32.
"If you're selling in this market, keep it conservative," said Robin Mesch, a fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research of Boston. "We view a break to the 115 20/32 price level as an important area to buy, and over all we view breaks as buying opportunities."
By afternoon, the Johnson Redbook retail chain-store sales index helped lift the market even higher. The index declined 1.9 percent for the first three weeks of October.
Yesterday's $17.75 billion auction of two-year notes went better than expected. "The aggressive bid on the two-year note suggests that investors see a good chance of a near-term rate cut," said James Hale, fixed-income analyst at MMS International, San Francisco. The high yield at auction was 5.705 percent, the lowest since June 27, 1995, when it was 5.690 percent.
"We'll have to give Mr. Blinder some credit for the auction's success," Mr. Hale said. "His comments more than compensated for the disruption of the normal auction setup where dealers start discounting the price of securities ahead of the auction to make those securities that much more attractive at auction."
Mr. Hale said the market was also watching the Federal budget talks, "with bonds not likely to get below 6.25 percent until an accord is reached." Today, the Government will report data on existing home sales for September, with analysts expecting a decline. "Our own forecasts call for a decline of 5 percent," Mr. Hale said. "But these are volatile numbers anyway, and it is not unusual to see large fluctuations."
Mr. Hale said investors who tried to set up short positions for today's five-year note auction might have a difficult time, especially after so many were chased out of the market early yesterday.
Joel Marver, chief technical analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the budget negotiations were backing up the market in the sense that participants love talk of a balanced budget. "It doesn't matter that prior stirring for a balanced budget has always resulted in disappointment," he said. "This is the type of market condition where investors have done well by holding positions."

HEADLINE: Has This War Been Won?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Remember WIN buttons?
Those relics of the mid-1970's, with their "Whip Inflation Now" slogan avidly promoted by President Gerald R. Ford, are collector items today, reminders of a misty past that apparently shows no signs of returning. Indeed, the United States has just gone through five consecutive years of the lowest level of consumer price inflation since the economy's golden run in the mid-1960's. 
 But if inflation -- now at less than 3 percent a year -- is down, it may not yet be time to count it out. A hot debate has erupted between those who contend that the economy has changed so fundamentally that inflation is no longer a serious threat and those who worry that efforts to stimulate the economy beyond its natural capacity could again stir the beast from its slumber.
On one side are politicians of both the right and left, much of the labor movement and a growing number of business leaders. They argue that the Federal Reserve, because of an outdated fear of inflation, has suppressed growth by keeping interest rates too high and credit too tight.
"There's no sign of pricing pressure anywhere," John Welch, the chief executive of the General Electric Company, said at a meeting of the Business Council in Williamsburg, Va., earlier this month. "This economy can grow more than 2 or 2 1/2 percent," he asserted, "and we ought to let it do it."
But Mr. Welch's optimism is not shared by many on Wall Street and much of the economics establishment. While economists are intrigued by fragmentary evidence that fierce competition and corporate revampings have caged both price and wage increases, they remain skeptical whether the underlying forces have been tamed.
"It's much too early to declare victory," argued Robert Gordon, a leading economist at Northwestern University. "The relationship between unemployment and inflation has held for two decades and is one of the best-documented linkages."
What worries many experts is that inflation has stayed unexpectedly low so far in the 1990's only because of special factors that are unlikely to be repeated. If the economy continues to advance and the jobless rate creeps lower, they say, it is only a matter of time before prices begin to rise at an accelerating pace.
Those thoughts were echoed by the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, at a speech last week to the Economic Club of Chicago. "We have to be careful not to lull ourselves into the presumption that somehow the institutional structure of the American economy and its increasing globalization is permanently suppressing inflation," he said.
Mr. Greenspan added that workers, still insecure in their jobs after years of layoffs and corporate downsizing, have not pressed for higher wages out of fear of losing their jobs. But there will eventually come a point, Mr. Greenspan said, "when workers will perceive that it no longer makes sense to trade off wage progress for incremental gains in expected job security."
So who's right? No one can say for sure, but the next year or so is likely to test the economy's sensitivity to inflation. For all its vows of vigilance, the Fed is under political pressure to push interest rates lower even though unemployment, at 5.5 percent, is already less than the level of roughly 6 percent that has tended to lead to higher prices in the past.
That will be particularly true if the White House and Congress manage to agree on a plan to eliminate the budget deficit over the next several years. Squeezing from one side is President Clinton, who wants a strong economy to aid his re-election bid. From the other, Congressional Republicans need more rapid growth to generate the tax revenues to meet their budget goals.
Nobody on either side of the debate is predicting a return to the double-digit inflation rates of the 1970's. In the oil shocks of that decade, Washington was inclined to avoid recessions at all cost, accommodating higher energy prices by sharply expanding the money supply.
But that same path was not pursued after the spike in oil prices following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990. Indeed, the Fed accepted a recession as the cost of emphasizing the point that price stability was Job One. "Alan Greenspan deserves a lot of credit for reining in inflationary expectations," George Perry, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said.
Still, that does not mean that prices won't start to creep up again. Most economists believe joblessness and inflation rates are closely linked. A variety of factors -- from the level of the minimum wage and the strength of the safety net for the jobless to the mobility of the work force -- determine a core non-inflationary rate of unemployment.
When unemployment is driven below this "natural" rate, bidding for scarce skills tends to push wages up faster than productivity is advancing. That, in turn, eventually pushes up the price of a range of goods and services. By contrast, when unemployment rises above the rate, the cost of labor tends to fall, bringing inflation down with it.
Since the late 1970's, estimates of the natural unemployment rate, which has always been hard to pin down, have bunched around 6 percent. But unemployment of less than 6 percent has peacefully coexisted with low inflation since late 1993, leading some people to speculate that the natural rate has fallen to 5.5 percent or even lower.
There is no shortage of plausible reasons why this might be true. The least controversial is tied to demographics. John Taylor, an economist at Stanford University who advised President George Bush, points out that young, inexperienced workers always represent a disproportionate percentage of the unemployed. Thus, the aging of baby boomers should have lowered the number of unproductive, hard-to-employ individuals at the margins of the work force.
Then there is corporate restructuring. While its actual impact on job tenure is still being debated, the sense that jobs are easier to lose than to find is strong. More companies are prepared to replace striking workers and more seem willing to move production elsewhere to escape high wages. The key issue in the current strike at the Boeing Company, for example, is how much freedom the aircraft maker should have to subcontract the building of certain components to China.
The openness of the American economy to imports has also reduced the bargaining power of the once-omnipotent unions in the auto, steel, rubber and construction-equipment industries. "Both labor and product markets are far more competitive," Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said.
Perhaps most striking, Lawrence Katz, an economist at Harvard University, argued, is that "recessions have become more democratic."
In the 1991-92 slump, college-educated workers proved to be highly vulnerable to layoffs, if still not as much as their blue-collar counterparts. An unprecedented 43 percent of the white-collar workers who lost jobs in that period eventually had to settle for lower pay, according to the Labor Department. That's a good reason why skilled workers, whose scarcity spurred wage increases in past booms, might now be reluctant to demand higher pay.
But there are holes in what at first glance seems an air-tight case for concluding that wage-driven inflation is yesterday's problem. Professor Gordon at Northwestern notes that the failure of total labor compensation to keep pace with productivity as the economy strengthened in the early 1990's can be largely attributed to the taming of health insurance and workers' compensation premiums paid by employers. Looking only at wages rather than total labor costs, he says, there is no convincing proof that workers have been frightened into docility.
Mr. Gordon called the good news on health and workers' compensation premiums "a favorable supply shock -- the opposite of, say, an increase in the price of oil." But even if health care inflation does not rebound to the high rates of the 1980's, there is no reason to believe this will translate into a permanent reduction in the natural rate of unemployment. Once workers get the point that employers are pocketing the savings on health care, they can be expected to demand part of the windfall.
The other reason for caution in predicting the demise of inflation is the inherent difficulty of assaying trends in a $7 trillion economy.
According to Benjamin Friedman, another Harvard economist, the best research from the 1980's suggests that operating the economy at a full percentage point of unemployment less than the natural rate for a full year adds just half a percentage point to inflation.
Thus, running at 5.5 percent unemployment even if the natural rate was still closer to 6 percent would add only a quarter percentage point a year to the inflation rate. That is too little to distinguish from blips in the prices of fuel, food, housing and autos -- at least not yet.
But if unemployment falls a little further, analysts will be in a better position to determine if the natural rate has really taken a permanent nosedive. And some -- even those who are skeptical of the claim that inflation is nothing to worry about any more -- would love to find out, in hopes that the economy can offer more opportunities to the unemployed and underemployed. "I'd like to slip into the 5 to 5 1/2 percent unemployment range," Mr. Gordon said, "and see what happens."
 
Photos: President Nixon tried a wage and price freeze; President Ford tride WIN buttons. But it took Paul Volcker, President Carter's cigar-smoking choice for Fed chairman (George Tames/The New York Times), to halt the runaway inflation that was brought on by two 1970's oil shocks with high interest rates and a deep recession. Now some think inflation is so thoroughly beaten that the economy can grow faster with stable prices. (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: Applause for Castro? Why?

BYLINE: By Robert G. Torricelli; Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, is a member of the House of Representatives from New Jersey.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is hard to know what is more disturbing the thought of business leaders like David Rockefeller sitting down to a lunch with Fidel Castro or the sight of hundreds of people at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem cheering the fatigue-wearing Cuban revolutionary.
These meetings this week were more than incongruous. They undermine our Government's efforts to restore freedom to the Cuban people. 
Of all things, a civil rights leader, Representative Charles Rangel, who once led the fight for economic sanctions against the apartheid regime in South Africa, put himself on the church dais with a dictator who has jailed more political dissidents than any other leader in this hemisphere.
Fidel Castro has consistently prevented Amnesty International from entering Cuba to investigate human rights abuses, has silenced independent journalists and has expelled political opponents.
If American business, perhaps the most practical and competitive in the world, is not deterred by politics, then it should consider the high risks of dealing with Cuba. Investor Magazine ranks only North Korea as a less attractive country in which to invest, and Cuba has only a small quantity of foreign currency reserves. In a galling move, Mr. Castro is selling off confiscated property owned by American citizens and corporations to raise hard currency to buy a little more time for his regime.
The Harlem rally and the lunch meeting at the Council on Foreign Relations attended by the business leaders may send mixed messages, but United States policy could not be clearer. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 is aimed at trying to bring about political freedom. It authorizes telephone and other means of communication with Cuba in order to promote the exchange of ideas. It denies Mr. Castro the opportunity to support his security forces by earning hard currency through trade with the United States. It challenges him to begin democratization and offers calibrated American responses.
The power to end the embargo lies in Fidel Castro's hands. He can exercise it by simply permitting free expression and holding free elections. His Government's fall is inevitable. When the prisons are opened and the political prisoners' horror stories are more fully told, I wonder if those who cheered Fidel Castro and sat down with him will be proud of themselves.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Journal;
Million Man Stall

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
"I met Jesse, strangely enough, through Ross Perot," said Felix Rohatyn this week, recalling the "Six Degrees of Separation" coincidence that led him into an unexpected alliance with Jesse Jackson.
Mr. Rohatyn, the investment banker who masterminded New York City's fiscal comeback in the mid-1970's, was on the phone with Mr. Perot, talking about building schools. Mr. Jackson, who was in Mr. Perot's office, conveyed his desire to meet with Mr. Rohatyn about the crisis in America's cities. Next thing you know Mr. Jackson and Mr. Rohatyn had joined forces on a plan called "Rebuild America," to raise $500 billion for investment in generating jobs and repairing the infrastructure in the nation's rotting urban core. 
 That was in 1992. In 1995, one week after the Million Man March and counting, the rebuilding of urban America not only remains a dream deferred but a dream hardly talked about by politicians of either party. Speaking with both Mr. Jackson and Mr. Rohatyn in separate interviews since the march, I was struck once again by how much of official Washington's post-march babble is, by contrast, beside the point.
The two men go their own ways and, unsurprisingly, part company on one crucial matter in the march's aftermath. Mr. Rohatyn -- like many others, myself among them -- was "very disappointed" by Mr. Jackson's decision "to put himself squarely on the side of separatism" by appearing on the podium with Louis Farrakhan. "If Jesse really wanted to do something symbolic, he should have stood with the black marchers and said nothing," Mr. Rohatyn added. "The marchers, with great unity and dignity, reminded the country we have a problem. That was the message, not what was happening on the podium."
Mr. Jackson's lukewarm rationale for Mr. Farrakhan -- as a potentially positive force for voter registration and black-Jewish dialogue -- remains unpersuasive. But his definition of the marchers' message parallels Mr. Rohatyn's and can hardly be dismissed. As Mr. Jackson speaks of the need for devising a "bipartisan national urban policy" that goes beyond either the current welfare debate or the Farrakhan slogans of self-help, so Mr. Rohatyn elaborates that the cancer of race begins in the cities, with black despair and white flight: "If we don't deal with it in the cities, we can't deal with it at all. Clinton, Gingrich and Dole must stand up and say we're going to jointly deal with urban problems, in ways that meet the objectives of white communities and taxpayers as well as of minorities who are dying in cities with no school system worthy of the name, no jobs, no medical care and no hope of entering the 21st century."
None of this will be easy, of course, or cheap. When Mr. Rohatyn had to negotiate the New York City bailout, he told the various factions: "There are no alternatives that involve pleasure and pain, there are only alternatives that involve pain and agony. The ideal is to avoid agony. You can't avoid pain."
Today's politicians do not like to talk in public about policy alternatives that involve pain. And so no one in political office offers any scheme to rebuild America, whether a variation of Mr. Rohatyn's dormant idea or something new. Bill Clinton delivers a fine speech on racism the morning of the march -- without venturing concrete policy prescriptions. Republicans conveniently embrace the spirituality of the march as its principal message -- as if the marchers' pride and dignity will rebuild America all by themselves. Well-meaning Congressmen of both parties, white and black, call for a new Kerner Commission to redefine the problem -- an idea rightly dismissed by Mr. Jackson as well as by Mr. Rohatyn ("We don't need a new commission to study whether we have a racial problem -- we know we have a race problem.").
All the while, our cities continue on an apocalyptic spiral that Mr. Rohatyn sees as "close to irreversible." As the likes of Mr. Farrakhan, Benjamin Chavis and their white extremist counterparts scheme to exploit the crisis, we wait and wait for some leader in Washington who might regard the Million Man March as an urgent cue to action, however painful, rather than as merely a cost-free political opportunity to pat the marchers on the head.

HEADLINE: U.S. Doesn't Really Want Iraqi Leader to Go

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Iraqi Sanctions: No End in Sight" (editorial, Oct. 19): For the past four years your editorial page has challenged the legality, morality and wisdom of the United States' interpretation of the United Nations embargo on Iraq. It is dismaying to see you abandon your position although little in the situation has changed. 
 Under Resolution 687, the United Nations Security Council pledges to end the embargo once Iraq respects its neighbors' borders and eliminates its weapons of mass destruction. The Bush and Clinton Administrations, however, have repeatedly made it clear that we intend to maintain the embargo as long as Saddam Hussein is in power.
It has been an open secret that we hope to use the embargo to bring about a coup in Iraq. Yet policy makers also have serious worries about the possible result. If Mr. Hussein, a blustering nationalist, is replaced by an Islamic fundamentalist, it would be a dubious triumph. If Iraq fragments into Yugoslav-style civil war, it might provoke Iranian invasion on one side and destabilize our ally Turkey on another.
Privately, American policy makers prefer the status quo, which justifies the deployment of American troops and, by shutting Iraq out of the oil market, maintains high revenues the Saudis and Kuwaitis need to pay for American arms purchases.
The only coup we really want is "Saddamism without Saddam" -- an equally authoritarian leader who would be our ally. The United States was euphoric when Mr. Hussein's son-in-law Gen. Kamel Hassan defected to Jordan on Aug. 8. But his long participation in the corrupt and brutal Baghdad regime discredited him among true dissidents and civilian populations in Iraq and the Arab world.
Meanwhile, with no end in sight of either Mr. Hussein or the embargo, the people of Iraq are the victim. Witnesses such as the Harvard Medical School team and Unicef report hospitals without anesthetic, malnourished children and people succumbing to normally curable disease. The United States disclaims responsibility because we have offered to let Iraq sell limited amounts of oil to buy food and medicine.
But we knew that the humiliation in such offers would bring rejection from Mr. Hussein who, like not a few world leaders, derives his power from machismo. The offers were designed to wash our hands of responsibility, not to feed Iraqis.
A new policy by President Clinton -- a commitment to end the embargo when Iraq destroys its weapons -- would show humanity and courage rather than simulations of toughness.
 
DAVID KEPPEL
Essex, Conn., Oct. 20, 1995

HEADLINE: BOXING

BYLINE: By King's Accuser Testifies That He Created Fake ExpensesBy RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The key witness in the wire-fraud case against Don King testified yesterday that the promoter directed him to create $350,000 in training expenses to justify an insurance claim for a Julio Cesar Chavez-Harold Brazier fight that was canceled.
Chavez owed King, his longtime promoter, $736,000, and King allegedly wanted to recover a portion of it by attributing $350,000 of it to training expenses, said Joseph Maffia, the former controller of Don King Productions. 
 King is charged with altering Chavez's contract to include a rider that would allow him to collect $350,000 in nonrefundable training expenses from the boxer. Last week, Chavez testified that he had never seen the contract that King filed in his successful insurance claim to Lloyd's of London.
Maffia said that during telephone conversations King escalated the amount he wanted to claim to Lloyd's. "He said, 'Put down $150,000, $200,000, $250,000,' I don't remember the exact figure," he said.
The final figure, Maffia testified, was $350,000.
"He instructed me to deem a portion of the $736,000 check for training expenses," Maffia said. King had written the check, an advance against Chavez's $2 million purse to fight Brazier, in March 1991.
But there were not enough expenses to justify the $350,000, Maffia said. The accountant, who spoke in a quiet monotone, said he could find only $130,000 to $150,000 in claimable expenses. King, he said, told him to pad the expenses.
"He suggested I look at the Mirage Hotel for Spanish production costs, and Spanish advertising done through Western Media, Gladys Rosa's bill" and legal bills, Maffia said. Rosa, a King employee, is Chavez's translator.
Maffia's cooperation with the United States Attorney, which began in May 1992, is crucial to the case against King. During direct examination by Paul Gardephe, an assistant United States Attorney, Maffia was almost unflappable.
Before King's legal team could impugn Maffia as an angry former employee, Gardephe's questioning opened the door to that issue.
Maffia said that after being forced to resign in September 1991, King disputed his unemployment insurance claim, sought to have his license as a certified public accountant revoked and sued him to repay an outstanding loan.
Maffia said he called King in May 1992 and vowed revenge against him. "Have you said you hate Don King and want to hurt him?" Gardephe asked.
"Yes," Maffia said.
"Do you feel the same way now?" Gardephe asked.
"No," Maffia said. "I dislike him."
The exchange brought chuckles from King.
Under cross-examination, Peter Fleming Jr., King's lawyer, focused on whether Maffia asked King or other co-workers for a copy of Chavez's contract and why he did not secure one when Gagliardi Brothers, King's retail insurance broker, asked for it. "Did you advise Gagliardi that you were unable to find a copy of the contract?" Fleming asked.
"No," Maffia said.
"They asked for it," Fleming said.
"Yes," Maffia replied.
Months after Maffia's resignation, Richard Hummers, King's vice president of finance, filed the insurance claim.
Maffia was often vague about details of his cooperation with the Government. He admitted to telling his lawyer that he felt the United States Attorney's office was "threatening" him in September 1993.
"You were worried that having cooperated, you'd be indicted," Fleming said. Maffia said he was concerned at the slow pace of the case, whether it would actually go to trial. "I wanted to go on with my life," he said.
"Do you remember saying you'd rather go to jail for a year?" Fleming asked.
"Yes, I do," Maffia said quietly, without elaboration.
