HEADLINE: Personal Health;
The forgotten child in treating pain is the child.

SERIES: First of two columns on pain
in children.

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
CHILDREN'S aspirin has been on the market for decades, joined more recently by children's acetaminophen. Both are mild pain relievers, although mainly used to reduce fevers. But when it comes to quelling severe pain, the kind, for example, associated with sampling bone marrow, setting a broken arm or sewing up a bad cut, children have long been therapeutic orphans.
Drug companies feel that the pediatric market does not offer enough economic incentive to warrant the costly testing and approval process required to license pain medication in a form suitable for small children. Most potent painkillers are administered by injections that are themselves painful and frightening for children. 
 And when doctors want to reduce anxiety in children undergoing painful medical procedures, they are often forced to reformulate into an oral preparation a drug called Versed that is marketed only in an intravenous form.
The drug companies' reluctance to develop pediatric analgesics has been tacitly supported by doctors who have long harbored many myths about pain in children, including the notions that they do not feel pain as much as adults, that they do not remember their pain and that they might become drug addicts if given narcotics. Such beliefs account for the longstanding failure of doctors to use painkillers when circumcising newborn boys.
Too often, instead of being given pharmacological or other forms of relief, frightened children about to undergo painful procedures are simply restrained physically, a practice pain specialists call barbaric.
Intensity of Pain
Infants may be unable to verbalize pain and small children may be afraid to, but there is no longer any doubt that children suffer as much as adults, and it is clear from their response to repeated procedures that they remember the pains of the past all too well.
In fact, as noted by Dr. Lynda J. Means, an anesthesiologist at James Whitcomb Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis, "infants may actually have a heightened response to pain because inhibitory mechanisms, while present, have not fully matured."
Dr. Kathleen M. Foley, chief of the pain service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, said pain in children might be worse than pain in adults because children are often unable to understand that "the pain may be short-lived, that relief is possible or that the pain associated with treatment or diagnostic procedures can have long-term benefits." Dr. Foley added, "Some children, especially those with chronic disease, become desperately afraid of needles and those who wield them."
Furthermore, anxiety and unrelieved pain can complicate recovery, prolong hospitalization and even increase the risk of dying from a medical procedure, said Dr. Myron Yaster, a pediatric anesthesiologist at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
The nervous system circuitry for feeling pain is present in fetuses from 30 weeks of gestation onward. There are several ways to measure the pain of children too young to describe accurately how they feel. Pain profiles have been developed for infants based on such physical symptoms as breathing and heart rate, skin color and facial expression. Babies as young as 18 months can express pain and tell where they hurt.
For preschoolers there are facial scales, like the "Oucher" Scale, that allow them to point to a picture that best describes how much they hurt. Other scales use poker chips or colors that help young children indicate the intensity of pain.
 
New Techniques
Last year a small company, the Anesta Corporation in Salt Lake City, won approval for the first potent analgesic specifically designed for and tested in children. The drug, fentanyl, an opiate, acts fast but is short-lived, making it an ideal medication for providing relief during painful medical procedures. It has the added virtue of being absorbable through the mucous membranes in the mouth and so could be formulated in a "lollipop" that makes it easy and painless and not frightening to administer. This form also enables doctors to remove the remaining drug from the child's mouth when a sufficient dose has been absorbed.
But Fentanyl Oralet, as the analgesic lollipop is called, has yet to be used for most of the procedures for which it is intended. That is not because it is unsafe or ineffective, but because some outspoken doctors have raised concerns about possible subsequent drug abuse by patients who receive it, as well as objections to the link it establishes between candy and opiates and its potential for abuse as a street drug.
Dr. Yaster maintains that these are empty arguments that simply deprive children of the kind of comfort readily provided to adults undergoing painful medical procedures. In an editorial in the journal Pediatrics earlier this year, he pointed out, for example, that "most orally administered medications are made palatable for children so that they can be better tolerated -- 'a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down.' " He also noted that addiction and drug abuse do not result from "the judicious use of analgesics" and that the frightening situations under which children would be given the opiate lollipop "are not the type of life experiences that children will want to voluntarily repeat."
There is another new medication to reduce the pain and resulting fear of needle injections and other external procedures for adults as well as for children. It is topical anesthetic called EMLA Cream, manufactured by Astra Pharmaceutical Products Inc. of Westborough, Mass. It combines two local anesthetics, lidocaine and prilocaine, and rather than being injected, it is first smeared on the skin; the area is then covered for one to two hours until the drug is absorbed. It temporarily deadens nerve endings, providing pain relief for several hours after the cream is removed. It has been shown to reduce pain significantly in children undergoing insertion of an intravenous line, a spinal tap or aspiration of bone marrow. It may also help to diminish the distress associated with immunizations and circumcision.
For children 6 and older who are experiencing chronic or prolonged pain, there is now also the option of using patient-controlled analgesia. Patients give themselves medication by triggering a microprocessor-controlled infusion pump that is designed to prevent overdosages. This technique allows drug doses to be individualized, prevents anxiety-inducing delays in relieving pain and gives children a sense of involvement in and control over their own care.
Experts in pediatric pain urge parents to be aggressive in assuring that their children do not suffer unnecessary pain during medical treatment. They say that children's complaints of pain should always be taken seriously and treated with the same respect and care that an adult would receive.
Next: Nondrug treatments for children's pain.

HEADLINE: Prospective Labor Leaders Set to Turn to Confrontation

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
Frustrated by declining wages and an erosion of political power, the nation's labor movement is expected to turn today to a new corps of leaders who say they are willing to adopt the tactics of civil disobedience and confrontation, largely abandoned in the 1960's.
In recent decades, even as union membership has shrunk along with inflation-adjusted pay, labor's leadership has tended to rely on politics and negotiation to carry the case of workers. 
 But today more than 1,000 delegates of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, gathered in New York for their weeklong national convention, are set to elect as president John J. Sweeney, who shut down the bridges to Washington last summer in a campaign to organize janitors. Given the way Mr. Sweeney's forces have held together on a number of resolution votes this week, his victory in the election, over Thomas R. Donahue, the federation's longtime No. 2 official and now its interim president, seemed assured yesterday, with a majority of at least 55 percent.
There are abundant indications that Mr. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union, and his allies are prepared to follow through on their promises of greater militancy.
A Sweeney-prepared convention resolution calling for the training of 1,000 organizers a year, five times the current number, says, "We must first organize despite the law if we are ever to organize with the law."
In a convention talk to his supporters, Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers and the Sweeney slate's candidate for secretary-treasurer, shouted: "Something historic's about to happen! You are about to see corporate America's worst nightmare come true!"
Linda Chavez-Thompson, a vice president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, who is the slate's candidate for executive vice president, told a news conference, "I like to get arrested." And she recently was, while demonstrating on behalf of hotel workers in San Francisco.
The willingness to take a page from labor's legacy of the early 20th century, when warriors like Samuel Gompers helped lift workers into the middle class, reflects a seething frustration with a Congress that labor officials see as indifferent to their members' concerns and with a declining influence of unions generally.
Whether the new approach can change the fortunes of organized labor is a wide-open question. Unions retreated from their earlier strategy of confrontation after a number of them had acquired an image of arrogance, corruption and even violence that the federation's departing leadership celebrates having largely erased. But unions are so small now, with only 15.5 percent of the work force -- half the level of the 1950's -- that mighty corporations can routinely block their organizing drives and chip away at wages with little fear of strikes.
In any case, the voices of caution are fewer and fewer among the union leaders gathered in New York. Just let one more company discharge a worker for trying to bring a union into his plant, warned Richard Bensinger, head of the federation's worker-organizing institute, which is about to be showered with a fivefold increase in funds, to $20 million a year.
"We're going to react against that corporation in a 100-fold, magnified way," Mr. Bensinger said. "We should sit down. Agree to spend a day in jail on behalf of the first worker who is fired. We have to send a message that this is a social movement. We're a moral force in society. It seems to me we should do what is morally right."
One firebrand organizer, Ron Carey, president of the 1.3-million-member International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said civil disobedience required a "very thoughtful decision," but another teamster leader, John P. Morris of Philadelphia, is cranked up to press all the limits of the law. "We're going to take the ports," Mr. Morris said. "That's the whole Philadelphia waterfront."
Indeed, the Sweeney side seems unequivocally committed to a form of activism that the departing regime condemns. "I believe in blocking bridges" on behalf of working families, Mr. Sweeney said in a convention debate with Mr. Donahue yesterday.
Mr. Donahue, recalling labor's long effort to clean its image, takes a dim view. "We have to worry less about blocking bridges and worry more about building bridges," he said in a speech to the convention. "We must enlist the support of the members of the public, not inconvenience as many of them as possible."
But Gary Hubbard, a spokesman for one Sweeney ally, George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers of America, noted "a willingness now" to resort to civil disobedience.
"Becker's prepared and willing to do that," Mr. Hubbard said. "It's something we haven't practiced since the civil rights struggles of the 60's."
Joel Ochoa Perez, a machinists' union organizer from Southern California, said: "This is the first time I see organizing put right at the top of the agenda. For the first time, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is not just talking about organizing but about ways to organize."
These new attitudes have permeated a convention, held every two years, that is very different from those of recent decades. Few delegates are wearing the usual lapel buttons ranting at enemies like corporations that break strikes or Republicans in Congress who stop the labor agenda. Instead, the delegates are turning inward, searching the federation itself for the causes of the unions' failure to grow and win political battles.
They complain of a creaking labor bureaucracy that runs on a budget of $70 million a year. From their headquarters one block from the United States Chamber of Commerce and just across Lafayette Park from the White House, federation leaders have frequently taken on the demeanor of the Cabinet officers, lawmakers and lobbyists with whom they spend most of their time -- all, in terms of labor's agenda in recent years, for naught.
Periodic polls showed that only small minorities of rank-and-file workers in cities beyond Washington could even name Lane Kirkland, the president for 16 years, who this summer dropped out of a run for re-election in the face of an insurgency led by the presidents of two of the biggest unions: Mr. Sweeney, of the Service Employees, and Gerald W. McEntee of the State, County and Municipal Employees.
A leading advocate of the shift toward civil disobedience is the 44-year-old Mr. Bensinger, the federation's top organizing official, who is a close associate of Mr. Sweeney.
"Look at the Christian Coalition," Mr. Bensinger said. "They have $25 million. We have $11 billion" -- the total of all union revenues, mostly from dues. "The Christian Coalition mobilizes around people's anger. They channel anger downward, toward welfare mothers. We can channel anger upwards, toward rich corporations."

HEADLINE: THE U.N. AT 50: CLINTON AND JIANG;
CHINA'S PRESIDENT AND CLINTON MEET TO REPAIR FENCES

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Meeting on the sidelines of the United Nations anniversary celebration, President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China made their best effort yesterday to repair a relationship that has been seriously strained by disagreements over Taiwan and human rights.
No concrete agreements emerged from the two-hour session at Lincoln Center, and there was no public display of unity comparable to Mr. Clinton's joint appearance on Monday with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia at Franklin D. Roosevelt's Hudson Valley estate. 
 But White House officials expressed confidence that the momentum developed at the intense session yesterday would allow the two nations to move forward with further discussions in a range of areas of concern, from arms control to trade relations.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House Press Secretary, said Mr. Clinton described his encounter with Mr. Jiang as a "very good, very positive meeting and the best of three meetings he has held to date" with the Chinese leader.
"He's confident that we have begun a process that will lead to a series of dialogues that will help improve the opportunity for comprehensive engagement with China," Mr. McCurry said.
Chen Jian, the spokesman for President Jiang's delegation, told reporters at a separate briefing that the meeting had been "candid, friendly, positive and useful."
"It will be useful for the improvement and growth of the bilateral relationship," Mr. Chen said.
Clinton Administration officials said the two leaders covered a range of issues including Taiwan, human rights, China's desire to join the World Trade Organization and nonproliferation of nuclear weapons. The officials said Mr. Clinton emphasized that while the two major powers were bound to have their differences, they can manage them better through honest dialogue.
"Neither side would claim that there aren't serious differences remaining," Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord said after the meeting. "There are serious differences."
But he said the relationship had "resumed momentum."
The Administration had hoped to capitalize on Russia's agreement on Monday to halt all nuclear testing in 1996 as a way to persuade China to do the same. But the Administration received only a promise to pursue the issue further. Though China has agreed to pursue a comprehensive test ban in 1996, it is the last of the five major nuclear powers not to sign on to the idea of zero testing.
Mr. Clinton raised the issue of human rights with China, bringing up specific cases as well as the issue of Tibet, which has been under Chinese control since 1950. But at a briefing after the meeting, Mr. Lord refused to identify the specific human rights victims discussed. That was in marked contrast to Mr. Clinton's meeting with Mr. Jiang in Seattle in 1993 where the public announcement of names helped get dissidents freed.
Mr. Clinton deflected questions about human rights issues and Taiwan from reporters who quizzed him and Mr. Jiang at a picture-taking session before their meeting.
"The important thing is that we're going to have this meeting," he said. "These are two great countries that have a real interest in maintaining a constructive dialogue with each other and wherever possible a partnership, and we need to go to work on it.'
Mr. Chen sidestepped a question about whether President Clinton had raised individual human rights cases with President Jiang.
"It is true that both countries have different views" on human rights, Mr. Chen said. "We can have dialogue on it instead of confrontation."
As expected, the Chinese brought up the issue of Taiwan, and Mr. Chen described it as "the most major and sensitive issue affecting the relationship." But American officials said they were gratified that it did not dominate the agenda as it did in the aftermath of the United States' decision to allow the Taiwanese President, Lee Teng-hui, to make a private visit to the United States this spring.
Despite the Administration's insistence that the visit did not constitute a break with Washington's longstanding "one China" policy, Beijing recalled its Ambassador in protest.
Mr. Clinton's aides said that at the meeting today the President reaffirmed that the United States recognized only one China, but that the United States would not promise to ban any visits by Taiwan officials. He said such visits would remain "unofficial, private and rare."
Ever since Mr. Clinton took office the relationship with Beijing has been one of the most difficult to keep on track. With the end of the cold war and the breakup of the Soviet Union, China and the United States no longer have the same pragmatic need to use each other as counterweights against the former adversary. China's leaders have been unsettled by a struggle over who will be the successor to the 91-year-old Deng Xiaoping. And the personal relationship between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang has been cool, Administration officials acknowledge.
The United States has also been concerned about China's arrest and trial of Harry Wu, an American human rights advocate who was jailed in China and convicted of stealing state secrets.
Since then both countries have moved back from the brink. Beijing released Mr. Wu; Hillary Rodham Clinton visited Beijing for a United Nations women's conference, and China announced in late September that it would suspend a contract to sell two nuclear power reactors to Iran.
Still, a successful meeting between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang yesterday was not assured.
At the last moment, the Chinese demanded that the meeting site be changed because the planned venue, the New York Public Library, was featuring an exhibit that included a handbill from the 1989 student democracy movement, which was crushed in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. The exhibit also contains footage of the Chinese military suppression of the demonstrations, in which hundreds were killed.
And just hours before the two world leaders sat down together, Mr. Jiang used his speech at the United Nations celebrations to charge that "certain big powers, often under the cover of freedom, democracy and human rights, set out to encroach upon the sovereignty of other countries, interfere in their internal affairs and undermine their national unity and ethnic harmony."
Mr. Jiang also repeated Beijing's longstanding position that Taiwan remains an "inalienable part of China's territory."
Nonetheless, both the American and Chinese officials were eager yesterday to bring relations back to the point where the two nations could have normal diplomatic exchanges.
Other issues that came up yesterday included joint law enforcement efforts, narcotics enforcement and trade relations. China's admission to the World Trade Organization is one of Beijing's major diplomatic objectives. And Mr. Lord said the President stressed that China needed to make more progress in the area of intellectual rights protection as a step toward its goal.
Mr. Chen said that the two leaders would meet again at the summit conference of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Group in Osaka, Japan, next month. "The Osaka meeting will build on this meeting and move the process forward," he said.

HEADLINE: Crowning the Comeback King

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Though there are still four years to go in the 90's, business and government leaders in New York honored Donald J. Trump yesterday for pulling off what they called "the comeback of the decade."
Mr. Trump, the developer who came to epitomize opulent wealth during the 80's before tumbling into deep financial trouble, has managed to erase much of his debt and is moving ahead with major projects at a time other developers are idling. 
 Judging from the attention showered on him yesterday at the Union League Club, some of New York's civic and business leaders are quite captivated by Mr. Trump, despite the financial uncertainties that still surround some of his properties.
But the operative word at the luncheon was comeback, though Mr. Trump might dispute that he ever went far away. William D. Fugazy, the limousine magnate and chairman of the Forum Club, the group of business and civic leaders that sponsored the luncheon, presented Mr. Trump with a boomerang encased in glass. "You throw it and it always comes back," he said as he handed it over.
In a flattering speech, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey called Mr. Trump "the comeback kid." Charles A. Gargano, who as chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation is himself considered one of the new powers of the state, joked about a Perot-Trump presidential ticket. "He would be the most loved Vice President since Spiro T. Agnew," he said. Mr. Gargano, who heads the state's economic development efforts, added, "Thank you for your tax dollars."
After the collapse of the real estate market of the 1980's, Mr. Trump's company was left holding some $8.8 billion in debt, causing his personal net worth to drop to a low of about $1 billion in the red by 1991.
But since then, his fortunes have changed. He continues to pursue the trademark trophy-style projects he is known for, such as a hotel and condominium project on the southwest corner of Central Park that is expected to open by late 1996.
Indeed, about an hour before the luncheon, Mr. Trump and representatives from a Hong Kong development firm huddled over drawings and models for their planned Riverside South development, a 17-building project at the site of the old Pennsylvania Railroad yard on the West Side.
In addition to his real estate ventures, revenues are strong throughout the casino business, where Mr. Trump is one of the most noteworthy operators, owning three gaming establishments in Atlantic City. "The market is quite vibrant," said N. Bruce Turner, a gaming analyst at Solomon Brothers. "It has lifted Donald Trump's vibrancy. Has he come back along with the market? No question."
To be sure, for all his latest achievements, Mr. Trump is still somewhat at the mercy of the various lenders who granted him concessions on his debt. Also, he has recently proposed another refinancing of his Taj Mahal Casino in Atlantic City, which has never lived up to the huge profits that he predicted.
But at Tuesday's luncheon, with his family by his side, Mr. Trump was in full form, gracefully taking in all the praise, like a preacher gathering up Sunday's collections.
For the guests, who included Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, and the developers Lewis Rudin and Peter Kalikow, he recalled how in 1991, the world was far different.
Outside the room, he proclaimed with no shortness of his characteristic hyperbole, "I'm the biggest in real estate in New York, and I'm the biggest in the gaming industry."

HEADLINE: NYC;
Without a 'Class Card,' This One Will Have to Do

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
DENNIS M. WALCOTT is uncomfortable with "race card," the Age of O. J. expression that is almost as popular, and overworked, as "mother of all" was during the Persian Gulf war.
There is an unpleasant ring to it. So it is understandable that Mr. Walcott, president of the New York Urban League, does not like hearing it applied to his attempt to undo the 25-cent increase in subway and bus fares that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted for last week. "We get too locked into these terms," he said. 
 Now, Mr. Walcott stands justifiably accused of being a thoughtful man. But, his protestations notwithstanding, a race card is exactly what is being played -- right from the top of the deck -- in a Federal civil rights lawsuit that the Urban League and the Straphangers Campaign, a subway advocacy group, have brought against the M.T.A. and New York State.
THEY are saying that the latest fare increases are discriminatory in their impact, that they favor overwhelmingly white suburban commuters over city subway riders, most of them black, Hispanic or Asian, and that this imbalance puts the M.T.A. in violation of the 1964 Civil Rights Act.
No one is arguing that the M.T.A.'s intent was racist, Mr. Walcott says. But that's irrelevant. When black city people are slapped with a painful 20 percent fare rise while white suburbanites are let off with a more tolerable 9 percent, the "disparate impact" violates the law, he argues, the same as if E. Virgil Conway, the M.T.A. chairman, were Bull Connor in a pinstripe suit.
Those are dynamite charges, and not surprisingly state officials are tugging at their shirt collars. Who relishes seeing race surface yet again? Even some of those people who would love to drive a stake through the heart of the $1.50 fare are squeamish about doing so on the basis of race. A common tendency is to wave off the Urban League suit as the legal equivalent of a Hail Mary pass, doomed to failure when a Federal judge in Manhattan takes it up next week.
Mario M. Cuomo, lawyer and former Governor, wishes that this case had stayed in the lawyers' briefcases. "The fare increase doesn't make economic sense," Mr. Cuomo said. "Your best arguments are fiscal, political and economic arguments, not your judicial arguments."
This is no nuisance suit, though, and anything can happen. Last year, a claim of "disparate impact" based on race persuaded a Federal court in Los Angeles to block a fare rise on city buses. In June, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled that the same issue could be legitimately raised to bolster charges of state budgetary discrimination against New York City schools.
And it does not take much imagination to see that a victory in the suit against the M.T.A. could lead to one racial-bias claim after another as Federal, state and city Republicans whack away not only at mass transit and schools but also at hospitals and social programs. One can almost hear the politicians' collective gulp.
It is not yet a deep gulp, however. The M.T.A. reaction is, Piffle! "If this suit prevails, then we might as well do away with elections," a spokesman, John Cunningham, said. "There's a new Republican administration, and it seems clear that they're going to take care of the people who voted for the Governor. That's the way it's been run since at least Andrew Jackson."
That is certainly the way it's being run by Gov. George E. Pataki, who wastes no love on the boroughs that did not vote for him and whose budget cuts are widening a city-suburban chasm that was already bad enough.
"IT'S really insidious," said Robert Paaswell, who has documented the imbalance as director of the University Transportation Research Center at City College. His figures show that each passenger on Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road receives a government subsidy of $4.70. The figure for the city's subway and bus riders is 80 cents. Looked at another way, the average city rider will now be forced to pay for 69 percent of the total cost of his trip, while the suburban commuter pays only 44 percent.
Ah, but does that make the system racist?
Not necessarily, Mr. Walcott acknowledges. But the result, he says, is devastating all the same. It hits poor people hardest, and in this city, they generally belong to minority groups protected by the 1964 act. It would be nice if there were a way to deal head-on with the real issue: class distinctions. But there isn't. In effect, this lawsuit enters through the back door.
Besides, a lawyer for Mr. Walcott insists, if anyone played the "class card" first, it was Mr. Pataki when he slashed mass transit aid. "We're not playing the race card," said the lawyer, Eric Schneiderman, of the Kirkpatrick & Lockhart firm. "We're simply saying, 'Judge, you can't run two transit systems, separate and unequal.' "

HEADLINE: A Jamaican Way Station in the Bronx;
Community of Striving Immigrants Fosters Middle-Class Values

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
There is the odd hole-in-the-wall serving up fiery jerk chicken, or a greengrocer with 10 kinds of exotic yams on his shelves. Cricket matches can be glimpsed in Van Cortlandt Park on summer afternoons. But it is difficult to identify overt signs of West Indian culture among the neatly kept, modest brick houses of Williamsbridge and Wakefield.
Yet these northeastern Bronx neighborhoods are home to one of the largest concentrations of Jamaicans in the city, with Crown Heights and East Flatbush, Brooklyn. And they are the literal descendants of the close-knit, sociable and striving community of Jamaican immigrants in the Bronx that nurtured retired Gen. Colin L. Powell and launched him on his career. 
 Forty years after the Powells hit the numbers and left for Queens, the Bronx's role in the ascent of Jamaican immigrants is strikingly similar to what it was when the general was a child. For while Brooklyn remains the great magnet for the bulk of Jamaican immigrants, the Bronx is the more distinct way station on their road to middle-class solidity.
In Williamsbridge and Wakefield, more than 70 percent of all immigrants are from the island, more than 14,000 Jamaicans in all, according to an analysis of census data for The New York Times by Dr. Andrew Beveridge, a sociologist at Queens College. And Jamaicans there are wealthier, better educated, more likely to own homes, and have more stable families than those in Brooklyn.
Precisely why this is so is unclear, but several experts pointed to the housing pattern in the neighborhoods at the northern edge of the city: street after street of plain but solid single-family brick houses, attractive to strivers looking to own rather than rent.
"The Bronx plays the same role for Jamaicans as it once did for Jews," said Philip Kasinitz, an expert on Caribbean immigration at Hunter College. "It's basically stable, middle-class neighborhoods."
The Bronx Jamaican community today is a recognizable echo of the world fondly evoked in Mr. Powell's autobiography -- a world of curried goat, calypso music and strong families. Ethnic pride is distinct but discrete, flourishing in tight family circles, behind the closed doors of these blocks of well-kept dwellings.
Before Arnold Anderson, a 71-year-old former mathematics teacher, left Jamaica 30 years ago, "we were poor," he said simply. Today, all seven of his children have college degrees, and all are homeowners. Several sat around their parents' cluttered living room recently, discussing why they had made good.
Karlene Anderson, 39, an X-ray technician with a degree in sociology from Lehman College, pointed to her mother, Kathleen, a retired nurse. "Mother was the doorkeep, the gatekeeper," she said. We weren't free to go out and date other kids." Her parents made sacrifices.
"Everything we earned went into their education," Mrs. Anderson said.
The children discussed a less palpable reason for their success: their sense of Jamaicanness.
"You're Jamaican," Karlene Anderson said. "You're not going to take stuff sitting down.
Her sister, Christine Anderson Lewis, 33, said, "The longer I'm here, the more I realize how important it is to hang to who I am."
Joyce James, a Jamaican who directs the Susan E. Wagner Child Care Center in the Bronx, said of the neighborhood: "It's very cohesive. They've been here for a while. They're not necessarily comfortable flaunting the fact that they're Jamaicans."
It is a working community: among groups in the Bronx, employment rates are higher for Jamaicans than for Dominicans, Koreans and white people born in the United States. Posses, the feared Jamaican drug gangs that made headlines in the 1980's, were a Brooklyn phenomenon.
To be sure, this is a different Bronx than the one of General Powell's youth: Jamaicans, like others, fled up the borough as the South Bronx crumbled in the late 1950's, a precipitate exodus during which, General Powell wrote, he remembers hearing people ask each other, "When you getting out?"
Shifting neighborhoods in the borough was a way of holding on to the achievements of the two initial waves of migration from Jamaica, in the first decades of the century, and from the late 1930's to 1965: houses, solid jobs, mostly in service industries, and strong family ties.
Mr. Kasinitz noted that while, in Mr. Powell's era and before, immigrants from the island tended not to be from the poorest classes, in the third great wave of Jamaican migration, which began in 1965 and continues today, "everybody now leaves Jamaica." And yet today, Jamaicans within the Bronx itself show the same unmistakable signs of upward mobility as did many in Mr. Powell's youth, particularly compared to other leading immigrant groups there.
They have lower poverty rates than Asians, Dominicans, and Puerto Ricans in the borough, far greater concentrations of households in upper-income categories, and a higher percentage of people reporting a 40- to 45-hour work week than any other group, including American-born whites, according to an analysis of Bronx census data by Prof. William Bosworth of Lehman College.
"The Bronx became the first suburb for West Indians," said Karl Rodney, publisher of The New York Carib News, speaking from personal experience. Mr. Rodney, himself of Jamaican origin, bought his first house in the United States in Williamsbridge, before moving to Westchester in 1969, a common migration of the last several decades.
Mr. Powell wrote in his autobiography of a "degree of clannishness among West Indians, Jamaicans included." This remains a distinctive feature of the quiet Jamaican presence in the Bronx today. Typical is the Wembley Athletic Club, described by many as one of the few expressions of Jamaican associational life in the borough.
The explanation for this paucity is characteristic: "There is some, but because they work so hard, they don't want to sacrifice the time to do these things," said Jackie Nkrumah, who owns Jackie's West Indian Bakery on East 233d Street, and works the evening shift herself to ensure the freshness of the coconut gizzardas, or sweet cakes.
On a Friday night, the Wembley A.C., as members call it, rocks with nothing louder than a lively game of dominoes.
Many of the members have been in America for decades -- the club president is a retired I.B.M. account manager, and friends gathered around included a skilled electrician, an insurance agent, a manager in the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, and a retired Transit Authority supervisor. They are thoroughly integrated into American economic life.
Yet this plain, two-story brick building, tucked away on a quiet corner in Wakefield, remains their chosen spot: the members are all West Indian, and mostly Jamaican.
The sense of ethnic identification is strong. Equally strong is the conviction that ethnicity played a vital role in what the men regarded as lives of reasonable success. General Powell's upward trajectory is no mystery to them.
"We're all proud of him as Jamaicans," said John Lyn, the president of the Wembley Club, who came to the Bronx in the days when Mr. Powell's family still lived on Kelly Street in Mott Haven. "That pride, that unwillingness to back down, is probably what got him where he is. If his parents were parents like the ones we had, they would not forgive him if he denied his manhood. In Jamaica, if you allow yourself to lose your dignity ----"
"You'll be thrashed," cut in Leslie Stephenson, an insurance broker who immigrated 28 years ago. "We, as best as we could, kept our Jamaican ways," Mr. Stephenson said.

HEADLINE: Fearing Bankruptcy, 2 SUNY Hospitals Are Seeking to Go Private

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The State University of New York is seeking permission to set up private, nonprofit corporations to run two of its three teaching hospitals, where for decades students who would not otherwise have been able to afford a medical education have trained as physicians and nurses.
The hospitals, in Brooklyn and Syracuse, have fallen behind in the race to enroll patients in managed-care organizations, largely because they are hamstrung by state regulations that make it difficult to enter contracts with doctors' groups or other hospitals. They complain that they cannot reinvest budget surpluses, but rather must return the money to the state. And they complain of red tape that delays the purchase of up-to-date medical equipment, like the latest mammography machine. 
 Both hospitals say that without legislation to give them more flexibility, they will face bankruptcy within the next three years.
"If we do not have this legislation, we would be facing some very serious questions in three years, the most important of which would be whether or not we could afford to continue to operate University Hospital," said Stephen Villano, the vice president for university affairs at the SUNY Health Science Center in Brooklyn.
If the SUNY hospitals were to fail, the economic impact in their communities could be grave. But if they succeed in gaining more flexibility, they will be new, large entrants in the managed health-care field, providing new competition for other hospitals in their areas and new options for patients.
The move by SUNY officials follows similar efforts by public universities across the country. Since the early 1980's, a dozen university systems from Florida to Wisconsin have transformed their hospitals into nonprofit corporations, hospital authorities or separate state agencies or turned them over to private companies to manage them.
At SUNY, such a transformation needs legislative approval -- far from certain, since the chairman of the Assembly's Higher Education Committee, among others, opposes it at this point, saying neither he nor constituents who would be affected by the change were consulted before the SUNY trustees approved a proposal last week to seek the change.
Hospital officials say a bill giving them more flexibility while keeping them part of SUNY will help, but only wholesale changes -- which they say are impossible if the hospitals remain state entities -- will keep them afloat.
Unlike New York City, which wants to sell some of its public hospitals to other hospitals or medical schools, SUNY officials want to create individual nonprofit corporations to run each hospital. These corporations would be led primarily by the existing administration.
While the change might appear a technicality -- not nearly as dramatic as the sale of a hospital -- SUNY officials say the impact would be dramatic. The nonprofit hospitals could then join existing managed-care companies, and physicians, no longer state employees, could create their own cooperative managed-care services, as well as remain staff members of the hospital. The hospital officials say the added freedom would permit them to negotiate directly with unions, bypass cumbersome purchasing requirements and make capital improvements more quickly, saving money and making them more competitive.
SUNY contends that allowing the private corporations to run the hospitals will help the state save money in a time of budget stress. The state now spends $74 million a year to subsidize the fringe benefits for the SUNY hospitals' employees, whose salaries are paid from patient revenues. SUNY officials expect to see a budget cut of $130 million to $150 million this year and project continuing financial strain in the future.
Even though they would lose the fringe-benefits subsidy, hospital officials say the greater freedom to compete in the managed-health-care market would more than make up the gap.
Under the resolution, the university hospitals in Brooklyn and Syracuse, commonly called Downstate and Upstate, would be run by nonprofit corporations, separate from the SUNY bureaucracy. The rest of the health science centers in those two locations, with their medical schools, nursing schools and graduate centers, would remain SUNY campuses. The hospitals would still be affiliated with the schools, training students and sharing resources for research. And existing medical school affiliations with other hospitals, like Downstate's agreement to send physicians in training and their supervisors to Kings County Medical Center, would remain intact.
"There are lots of models for academic programs being conducted in clinical settings other than university-owned hospitals," said Thomas A. Bartlett, Chancellor of SUNY. "More and more around the country, academic health centers are releasing their hospitals. Their hospitals are becoming independent entities. And that seems to work."
The SUNY system's hospital on the campus of the State University at Stony Brook is not seeking a separation from the university system, although officials say they also need more freedom to cooperate with other hospitals and with managed-care companies.
Dr. Nancy H. Nielsen, a Buffalo-area physician who is the SUNY trustee who proposed the resolution at the trustees' meeting last week, said she had not been sure that privatization was the answer until she saw the numbers showing how serious the hospitals' conditions were.
"It's not that we don't have good managers," Dr. Nielsen said. "It's just that they can't manage because the rules don't allow them to."
"You have three choices," she said. "Either you can increase state subsidies to keep the hospitals afloat, or they will close. Or we can try to change the rules and make them into something viable."
Assemblyman Edward C. Sullivan, chairman of the Assembly's Higher Education Committee, said he has serious reservations about turning the hospitals into private corporations. He said that he had not been consulted and that he considered the board's resolution "frivolous" because the board had not discussed its plans with local officials, students or union leaders.
"We're not about to roll over dead and allow them to kill the State University, either in medical education or in any other branch of the university system," he said.
The president of the Health Science Center in Syracuse, Dr. Gregory L. Eastwood, said he had tried to assure his faculty members that the hospital, Upstate, and the professional schools would continue training students and sharing resources.
But William E. Scheuerman, the president of the United University Professions, the union that represents 7,000 physicians, technicians and nurses working in the SUNY hospitals, said that his members were still concerned.
"To whom is the group that runs the hospital accountable?" Mr. Scheuerman asked. "What happens to existing obligations that don't make money, like care for children and the indigent?"
"This could be another attempt to downsize the university and keep the public out of the public university," he said. "This time, it's not in the classroom, it's in the hospital, which the public uses."
In most states, the legislation turning hospitals over to private hands has specified that they must remain allied with the medical schools and continue to treat poor patients in the community. And in most cases, the medical schools have benefited because the hospitals' economic position has improved, according to Robert Dickler, the senior vice president for health care affairs at the American Association of Medical Colleges.
"The experience at all the hospitals that have separated is that it has helped strengthen the academic program because the hospital has been stronger," Mr. Dickler said. "In some ways, the mission has remained unchanged while the legal structure has changed."
The SUNY trustees voted for a two-step measure. First, the Legislature would consider a bill in its next session, beginning in January, to free all three SUNY hospitals from some of the constraints they now operate under. Then, SUNY would seek to remove the Brooklyn and Syracuse hospitals from SUNY control. The first measure, sought by SUNY since 1993, is expected to pass both houses by the end of January, according to State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, Republican of Suffolk, the Senate higher-education committee chairman.
To sweeten any flexibility deal this time around, the three hospitals have agreed that if the bill passes, they will give back some of the state subsidy -- $24 million next year.
Mr. LaValle said he opposes the privatization of the Stony Brook hospital, which is just outside his district. He said he wants to see whether Stony Brook can form a health care network with other hospitals on Long Island and still remain part of SUNY.
Dr. Michael Maffetone, the director and chief executive officer of the hospital at Stony Brook, said that right now he believes he can join a regional network if the flexibility legislation is passed. Stony Brook does not face the same competition as the other two hospitals because it is the most advanced trauma center in Suffolk County.
"We don't have the urgency that they feel right now," Dr. Maffetone said of Syracuse and Brooklyn. "But the environment can change very quickly, and we may need to reexamine that at some future time."

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Mary B. W. Tabor 

 BODY:

From George Sand
When George Sand submitted "Horace" to her French publisher in 1841, he returned it, demanding that she tone it down. Set in Paris during the 1832 student rebellion, "Horace" offered vivid portraits of bohemian students, political rebels, a jaded aristocracy and a fallen woman who lives happily ever after: sure fodder for scandal, argued Francois Buloz, the editor of the journal Revue des Deux Mondes.
Outraged by his proposed changes, Sand rebuked Buloz in a letter dated Sept. 15, 1841. "Your ideas and your instincts have no business in my prose," she wrote. "Please leave my brain and my ink alone." To tone down her portraits was "to remove the marrow from the bone," she continued. "And I'm not so rich in talent that I can make do without the truth." 
 She took her novel elsewhere, and "Horace" was eventually published in serial form in the Revue Independante, and later as a book. But unlike most of Sand's other works, "Horace" was never published in English.
"At that time, it just didn't fit into the world view of the English-speaking world," said Zack Rogow, an award-winning translator. But now, "Horace" may have a better chance. This month, Mercury House, based in San Francisco, published what appears to be the first English edition of "Horace," which has been translated by Mr. Rogow. The book, a paperback, has a list price of $15.95.
It has already drawn support from reviewers and scholars.
" 'Horace' is one of George Sand's most interesting novels, politically speaking," said Prof. Lucienne Frappier-Mazur, a professor of French literature at the University of Pennsylvania who has read "Horace" in French. "It has a lot to do with the dignity of the woman and her freedom of choice and the fact that she becomes economically self-sufficient."
Sand had struggled to support herself through her writing, Professor Frappier-Mazur noted. Sand was known for her love affair with Chopin and her penchant for wearing men's clothes and smoking cigars. When she left her husband in the 1830's, she lost much of her inherited wealth. Like Marthe, the heroine in "Horace," Sand needed financial independence to support her two children.
 
Agent for John Grisham
 Ever since the death of John Grisham's literary agent, Jay Garon, two months ago, publishing circles have buzzed with speculation about who would emerge to take Mr. Garon's lucrative management job.
Though Mr. Grisham is under a multi-book contract at Doubleday and Dell, whoever becomes his literary agent could reap hefty commissions from potential future works and ancillary deals. These days, fingers have been pointing at David Gernert, Mr. Grisham's editor at Doubleday.
A report last week in Variety, the industry's trade paper, named Mr. Gernert as a possible heir to the Grisham representation. And yesterday morning, Mr. Gernert flew with Mr. Grisham, who pilots his own plane, to watch the filming of "A Time to Kill," on location in Mississippi, and to discuss his next book, "The Runaway Jury," which Doubleday is to publish in the spring.
Executives at Bantam Doubleday Dell said Mr. Gernert had laughed off questions about the reports.
 
Men, a March, a Book
 The men marched in Washington, and now Crown Books is running to publish a commemorative book of photographs from the Million Man March for Christmas. The book, "Million Man March," a collection of more than 125 images taken by 20 photographers, is to be put together by Deborah Willis, the curator of exhibitions for the Smithsonian Institution's national African-American museum project.
The text is to be written by Michael Cottman, a journalist and a host for "Flashpoint" on PBS.
 
Endnotes
 *Helene Atwan, who was a marketing executive of Pocket Books, has been named the new director, or publisher, of Beacon Press.
*Stephen Fraser, a vice president of HarperCollins since 1991, has been named executive editor of Houghton Mifflin's adult trade and reference division.

HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: Jonathan Kozol;
Listening to the South Bronx

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
MY friends tell me: 'You look worn out, Jonathan. I'm worried about you,' " said Jonathan Kozol, perched on a battered counter stool, its cover worn to the wood, at B&V pizza and doughnuts in the South Bronx.
"They take me to fancy restaurants in midtown Manhattan, but I lose my appetite. It just seems strange. I'd rather be here. My digestion is better. I mean this $2.35 tuna sandwich tastes good to me, and I don't have to think which fork to use." 
 For almost three decades, Mr. Kozol has been plumbing the depths of poor inner-city neighborhoods and the children who live there, first as an idealistic young teacher in the Roxbury section of Boston, then as a celebrated advocate for the poor and forgotten, now as what even he takes to be something of a relic of an earlier age of urban optimism.
His labors have won him widespread acclaim and awards, as well as some degree of skepticism from critics who contend that he walks a fine line between crusading reporting about the urban poor and pious moralizing that is short on solutions.
Like or dislike his books, it is hard not to see the descending arc of urban policy and the worsening plight of the inner-city poor in Mr. Kozol's evolution, from the crusading optimism of his first book, "Death at an Early Age," to the angry pessimism and tentative, weary spirituality of his most recent work, "Amazing Grace: The Lives of Children and the Conscience of a Nation" (Crown Books, 1995), a depiction of Mott Haven in the South Bronx.
"I wrote the first book, and I thought people would say: 'Separate and unequal schools in the City of Boston? I didn't know that. Let's go out and fix it,' " he said at the B&V, a small eatery at St. Ann's Avenue and East 138th Street.
"I thought then the problem was lack of knowledge," he continued. "Now I think it's lack of will. Now, I don't expect what I write to change things. I think I write now simply as a witness. This is how it is. This is what we have done. This is what we have permitted."
Mr. Kozol's odyssey began in 1964, when he returned to Boston after graduating from Harvard University, studying at Oxford University as a Rhodes scholar and spending four years as an aspiring writer in Paris.
Amid the excitement of the civil-rights era, he began teaching black children in Roxbury, first in a summer freedom school, then as a fourth-grade substitute teacher. He was dismissed for teaching unauthorized texts, specifically the poetry of Langston Hughes.
His journal from the 1964-65 school year was turned into "Death at an Early Age," which won a National Book Award and is often ranked with books like Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring," Ralph Nader's "Unsafe at Any Speed" and Michael Harrington's "Other America" as an influential work that both reflected and shaped the conscience of its time.
Since then he has written about "Illiterate America" (1985), about homelessness in "Rachel and Her Children" (1988) and about the disastrous state of urban education in "Savage Inequalities" (1991).
Publisher's Weekly, for the first time in its history, endorsed "Savage Inequalities" on its cover, imploring President George Bush to read it. The book went on to become a best seller.
On the other hand, some critics have found some of his books hectoring and self-righteous, as Christopher Lehmann-Haupt did in The New York Times. In his review of "Illiterate America," he wrote: "Eventually, one begins to wonder who precisely Mr. Kozol means to be whipping with the sodden lettuce leaves of his incessant piety."
Mr. Kozol, who is 59 and divorced (he has no children), speaks in soft, precise, professorial inflections. Although he admitted that his brand of consuming liberal angst was utterly out of fashion, he said that this says more about the times than about him.
"I talk to people, and they grow impatient," he said. "They say: 'Well, of course, we know all that. Tell us something new.' There's this kind of urbane equanimity about it, spiced with irony, like a cultivated kind of weariness. It's like you can't speak of this without incurring the charges of self-righteousness. But to me the central fact of life in New York City is the terrible sin hidden in the center of the city's romance."
To him, that sin is the racial segregation and crushing poverty in places like the South Bronx, where he spent the better part of the last two years while researching and writing "Amazing Grace." He writes of mothers with AIDS shuttled between unfeeling bureaucracies, of the children who make their way through an urban wilderness of crime, drugs and abandonment and of the children who die young there. A postscript lists 23 children who died while he was working on the book.
He was asked if some of his concerns, like his discomfort at being at parties where the food is served and the cleaning up is done by black maids, just as it was when he was a boy a half century ago, might come across merely as liberal guilt. This discomfort can also apply to other aspects of his life. In Byfield, Mass., a picturesque New England town where he lives in a 200-year-old farmhouse, "the golden retrievers have a nicer place to play than the children do in the South Bronx," he said.
"I'd say there's a lot to be guilty about," he continued. "A culture in which guilt is automatically assumed to be neurotic and unhealthy has devised a remarkably clever way of protecting its self-interest. I mean, what I've seen in this neighborhood and in similar neighborhoods for 30 years isn't a misfortune that happened by mistake. This is an injustice. This is an artfully created lazaretto, and I think those powerful people who created it have a lot to be guilty about and ought to be condemned. And the people in this book frequently do condemn them."
We left the restaurant and walked around the neigborhood, two white men in suits lost in conversation amid the bodegas, Caribbean music and crowds of young black and brown men on street corners.
There were so many deaths during the two years he was in Mott Haven that he stopped constantly to explain who died, when and how and in which building, becoming more intense as we walked along.
When I stopped and stooped to tie a shoelace in front of Public School 65, one of the 16 most troubled schools in the city that the new New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, put under his direct control last week, he squatted down with me and kept talking without missing a beat.
"What's the newest slogan?" he asked. "Let's make it a 'site-based school,' a 'restructured school'? The solution for a bad ghetto school is to have a site-based ghetto school or a ghetto school with ghetto choices for ghetto children. But in New York and America no one asks why we still have ghetto schools a quarter century after Dr. King's death and why it isn't even questioned now."
As we walked down from P.S. 65, two officers in a police car eyed us warily, then cruised by and stopped.
"Do you know where you are?" the officer behind the wheel asked Mr. Kozol. "What are you doing here?"
Mr. Kozol explained that he was a writer. The officer looked at him as if he were crazy and encouraged him to get off the streets.
"You stand out like a sore thumb," he said. "I'm not going to tell you what to do, but you stay out long enough, and like on 'Monty Python,' you're going to have a 60-pound weight fall from the sky onto your head."
As Mr. Kozol turned a corner past the school, a hollow-eyed beggar in rags walked toward him, his hand out in a halfhearted begging gesture in a part of the city where the pickings must be exceedingly slim.
Instead of avoiding him, Mr. Kozol quickened his step as if he had fortuitously happened upon an old friend, dug his right hand into his pocket, pulled out a $5 bill and pressed it into the stunned man's hand.
After his two years in the South Bronx, Mr. Kozol said he had lost 30 pounds and had begun suffering from asthma, like so many of the people who live there. To some of his friends, these signs are just more evidence that he has gotten more involved in his story than is healthy, personally and perhaps journalistically.
He faces no such criticism from the people he has gotten to know in the South Bronx, like Alice Washington, a sharp-witted woman with AIDS who is a main character in the book. Or Dale Prentice, who works in the after-school program at St. Ann's Episcopal Church. Or the Rev. Martha Overall, the church's pastor. Or Aurea Picart, grandmother of Bernardo Rodriquez, an 8-year-old who fell to his death down the shaft of a faulty, bullet-riddled elevator in 1994. Mr. Kozol established a memorial fund called Remembering Bernardo, which he hopes to finance with proceeds from the book and with donations.
He lingered for a while at St. Ann's, an island of peace amid the turmoil of Mott Haven, and then walked me down to the Brook Avenue subway station.
"I have an enormous sense of having failed in life," he said, as the northbound train stopped and then clattered away. "If I had succeeded in everything I had tried to write, starting in 1965, there wouldn't be a neighborhood like this. Now there are more, and they're worse than ever before. I feel, in the end, as if everything I've done has been a failure."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 28, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A profile in The Living Section on Wednesday about Jonathan Kozol, a writer who has been chronicling urban poverty for several decades, misstated the name of the publisher of his new book, "Amazing Grace: The Lives of Children and the Conscience of a Nation." It is Crown Publishers, not Crown Books.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 880 words

HEADLINE: The Risks of Lettting Russia Disengage

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is vice president for Russian and Eurasian affairs at the Carnegie Endowment.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The meager results of this week's lunch-hour summit between President Clinton and President Boris Yeltsin will strengthen skeptics in both countries who say we should stop pretending to be "partners."
Zbigniew Brzezinski has called Russia "irrelevant," and this sneering term enjoys a minor vogue even at the State Department. In Moscow, Anatoly Adamishin, Ambassador to Britain and among the most likely successors to Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev, expresses a surprisingly similar view. Although he has for years been one of his country's most pro-Western diplomats, Mr. Adamishin now calls on Russia to "step to the sidelines." There's no need for all-out hostility toward the West, he wrote recently, but for the foreseeable future Russia will be too weak to be taken seriously by the United States and its allies. Better, then, to stand alone. 
 To date, both Governments have rejected the case for disengagement, as they should. Yet the rhetoric of "partnership" has grown perfunctory, and the reason is simple: neither side has taken the idea seriously enough to give it any real meaning.
Today Russian-American relations are a textbook case of how not to build lasting cooperation between great powers. It can't be built on charity (in any case, our aid to Russia is too small to affect large decisions). Nor can it be built on blackmail -- on fear of what the Russians might do if we don't stay on good terms with them.
Earlier this year Russian and American diplomats thought they might give the relationship a boost by reaching a special "understanding" between Russia and NATO. But the Russians reject anything that legitimizes NATO expansion, and the Americans fear a Russian droit de regard over Eastern Europe. Right now, neither side can gain from grand but empty agreements.
The idea of sending Russian and American peacekeepers to Bosnia is also turning out to be a loser. Cooperating on a job that neither side's military really wants to do, and that has little support in either country, may sink relations, not salvage them.
As a last resort, advocates of Russian-American partnership fall back on the "tens of thousands of nuclear weapons" defense. The two sides, it's said, have to work together to shrink their arsenals. True, and yet the enterprise is decidedly backward-looking. The need to mop up after the cold war is a weak basis for future cooperation.
If Russian-American relations stay on their present course, the case for "irrelevance," (or worse) will carry the day in both countries. "Partnership" will seem a serious undertaking only if it is connected to the real concerns that are likely to dominate each side's foreign policy over the next decade or so.
Start with nuclear weapons. For the first time since the beginning of the nuclear age, the big problem that Russia and America have to address is not how to deter an attack by the other. It's how to deal with new nuclear powers, especially so-called rogue states with access to high technology.
To deal with this emerging threat, both former superpowers are going to take a greater interest in building defenses against ballistic missiles. They can do so without threatening each other (and in fact their common interest is strong enough to justify joint research and development). But this won't happen automatically: If Russian-American relations worsen, it will be easy to ignite the Star Wars controversies of a decade ago, and the whole effort could bog down.
Across the board, our ability to deal with future security problems will be less if we have to cope simultaneously with problems of the past. Yet our policies rarely recognize this fact. Vast amounts of geopolitical pundit-time go into thinking about how to deal with the looming emergence of China as a military and economic colossus. Russian-American relations, strangely, are almost never treated as part of the equation.
This is a mistake. Isn't it obvious that, if we ever had to organize a broad coalition to contain China, Russia's orientation would be crucial? For that matter, aren't we less likely ever to need to organize such a coalition if China sees that the other major powers enjoy good relations that would make it easy for them to unite?
In other regions, Moscow will play a crucial role in determining the success or failure of American diplomacy. Russia has, in fact, helped to strengthen Ukraine, which many regard as a fulcrum of peace and security in Eastern Europe. Its policy toward Iran, by contrast, is damaging.
But whether we agree or disagree with Russian policy is not the issue; it's how to advance our interests. It will be far harder to offer meaningful support for Ukraine if Russian-American relations deteriorate. By the same token, it will be far easier to turn off Moscow's nuclear deliveries to Iran if relations improve.
In the shadow of the Russian-American dispute over NATO expansion, it may seem hopeless to address the problems sketched here. But they should not be left for later. What both sides need now is help in gauging the real costs of a break over NATO. They need a clearer sense of whether partnership will pay off in the future, or remain a matter of rhetoric. Not finding out means accepting "irrelevance," and paying its price.

HEADLINE: For the Debate On Debt Limit, No Usual Script

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
By anybody's standards, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is plenty rich. But even his staff blanched a bit when one of his predecessors, James A. Baker 3d, suggested recently that a quirk of Federal law would make Mr. Rubin personally liable for any Federal debt incurred after the Government hits a $4.9 trillion ceiling on borrowing sometime in the next two weeks.
The good news for Mr. Rubin is that the Treasury Department's lawyers think Mr. Baker was probably wrong. The fortune the Treasury Secretary accumulated on Wall Street -- roughly $100 million, or enough to keep the Government running for about 33 minutes -- is safe. 
 The bad news for Mr. Rubin is that he is already caught, politically if not financially, at the center of what has become a giant game of chicken in which both the White House and the Congressional leadership blame the other for pushing the country to the brink of default. And he is playing with two equally unpredictable opponents, Congress and the markets.
On Capitol Hill, the freshman class of Republicans have called the shots on this issue so far, using tactics President Clinton today characterized as "economic blackmail, pure and simple." On Wall Street wary traders are wondering whether the risk of lending money to the Government may be about to rise sharply.
The two are playing off each other and that combination has turned what was once a fairly simple political contest into a financial one with enormously high stakes.
Many in Washington and Wall Street say wearily that they have seen all this before. And they have. Time after time, Congress has threatened to hold an increase in the debt limit hostage -- preventing the Government from raising money it needs both to operate and to pay off Treasury bonds -- unless it gets its way on the budget. Democrats have made the threats in years past, and so have Republicans. After predictable histrionics, it has always ended without disaster.
But this time, a growing number of Democrats and Republicans say, an overreliance on history could be misleading.
The freshman and sophomore classes of House Republicans have made clear that they have no intention of sheathing their most potent weapon against President Clinton. They have yanked their Speaker, Newt Gingrich, back in line whenever he has seemed on the verge of suggesting a way to separate the budget debate from the authorization to borrow more money.
And President Clinton, after weighing the politics of it all, sounds like a man who thinks that Congress -- rather than the White House -- will end up taking the rap for sending financial markets into chaos if the United States flirts with failing to pay investors. He said as much today.
"For all their loose talk," Mr. Clinton said, "the Congressional leaders know that if they were to allow us to go into default, this would have a severe impact on our economy, on financial markets, and on the interest rates paid" by government, business and homeowners.
But in the next breath, Mr. Clinton said he would not let that risk force him to sign a budget he hates. "If they send me a budget that says simply, 'You take our cuts or we'll let the country go into default,' I will veto it," he concluded.
The problem, Mr. Clinton and his advisers know, is that it does not take an actual default to shake the markets. A credible threat of it can send interest rates up, especially if foreign investors are so spooked that they are tempted to invest their cash elsewhere -- say, in German marks.
The fear is that if this goes on, the Government might be faced with paying an "America premium," a slight increase in the interest rate demanded by investors for putting their money into Treasury securities. The phrase is drawn from the "Japan premium" that Japanese banks are now paying investors -- in the form of higher borrowing rates -- for the risk of investing in the tottering Japanese banking system.
"I think that this has already influenced the cost to the U.S. Government, and perhaps the value of the dollar," David DeRosa, a senior trader at the Swiss Bank Corporation, said.
 Other traders say it is impossible to tell if the argument over the debt limit is nearing the point at which it starts to exact a cost. Government bonds are now trading at their lowest levels since early 1994, indicating that the Government's borrowing costs are lower than they could be.
Still, warnings about upsetting the markets are usually all it takes to bring bickering politicians in line. But in the past few days the usual logic has worked in reverse. Mr. Gingrich said recently that he thinks the White House is using the potential reaction in the markets as a lever to win its way. Mr. Rubin, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company who spent years overseeing trading in government securities, has found his expertise more hindrance than help.
"Bob Rubin goes up to the Hill and talks about the signals to the markets, and they look at him like he's speaking Swahili," an official close to the Treasury Secretary said the other day. "This generation of Republicans doesn't know about the markets, doesn't care about the markets and enjoys making that clear to Bob at every turn."
But Mr. Rubin's expertise could come in handy. Given the political stakes, Mr. Rubin does not go into much detail about the wide spectrum of options he has to keep the United States from actually defaulting while the budget arguments play out. There are alternatives to a straight default -- in which the Government simply refuses to meet its obligations to existing bondholders -- but each, he said, has "serious and unresolved legal and policy issues," and all of them might cost a lot of money.
For example, he could stop the ordinary practice of putting cash held in Social Security or Medicare trust funds into Treasury securities. That would create more room for the Government to borrow money to pay its bills. But it would also deny the Social Security fund a safe way to earn interest on its holdings. In the current political environment, that would probably open the White House to charges that it was playing with senior citizens' money to win its way on the budget.
The debt debate continued to build this week. On Tuesday, Mr. Gingrich charged that Mr. Rubin was manipulating the date when the United States would run out of borrowing authority. The real deadline kept shifting, he complained, from Nov. 15 to Oct. 30 to Nov. 6. "We're waiting to see," Mr. Gingrich said. "Secretary Rubin has now changed by a week in a week."
Mr. Rubin said that he has been clear and consistent. The Republicans, he said, "don't want to hear the facts."
Postponing a coming debt auction to raise $100 billion or attempting makeshift ways to raise the money would affect rates, he said, "and on $100 billion, even a small increase in the interest rate can cost you a lot."

HEADLINE: Purchase for Preservation Fills a Gap in Putnam County

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: PHILIPSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Capping a four-year effort to preserve one of the last unspoiled tracts of woodlands and pasture in the lower Hudson River Valley, a private conservation group has purchased Glynwood Farm, a 957-acre estate here.
More than 700 of those acres are to be added to a surrounding 3,700-acre arc of forest already bought by the same group, the Open Space Institute. If New York State finds the funds, all that property is to be added to the adjacent Clarence Fahnestock Memorial State Park. 
 "We've finally plugged the hole in the doughnut," said Kim Elliman, president of the Open Space Institute. He said the $6.25 million purchase completed an effort by the institute to expand the protected lands in the Hudson Highlands, a mountain range bisected by the Hudson River 50 miles north of New York City.
The purchase, which was completed on Tuesday, was made with a grant from the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for the Hudson Highlands, a trust set up in 1983 by the founders of Reader's Digest to preserve unspoiled parts of the Hudson Valley.
In 1991, the surrounding forest was also bought with Wallace Fund money by the institute. It is already being managed by the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation as an annex to the park, which is visited by about 220,000 people a year.
The parks office will now also manage the new 727-acre tract, which filled a vulnerable gap in the map of protected lands in western Putnam County. "This is a parcel we've been very interested in for a very long time," said Julia Stokes, a deputy commissioner for operations in the parks office.
The land will also be used by thousands of schoolchildren from New York City who each summer visit the adjacent Taconic Outdoor Education Center, which is also operated by the parks office, she said.
The core of the estate, 230 acres of cow pastures, ponds and farm buildings, will remain a working farm and will also house a newly formed nonprofit group, the Glynwood Center, that will study ways to mesh local economic growth with preservation of natural resources, said Judith LaBelle, the group's president.
Ms. LaBelle said the Glynwood Center planned to work with Putnam County and Philipstown officials to find ways to expand the local economy while preserving the rural landscape that gives the region its appeal.
The Glynwood Center will operate as an affiliate of the Countryside Institute, an existing private group that has done similar work with communities as far afield as Prince Edward Island, Canada, and Spring Hill, Tenn., Ms. LaBelle said.
Glynwood Farm was bought from the heirs of George W. Perkins, a financier who at the turn of the century was a partner of J. Pierpont Morgan, the industrialist and financier. Mr. Perkins, a noted conservationist, was one of the creators of the Palisades Interstate Park system, a chain of preserves west of the Hudson River.
For many years, the family had opened the farm to visits by schoolchildren, and that tradition would be expanded at the new center, Ms. LaBelle said.
Today, as patches of sunlight slid across the orange woods and green fields, Ms. LaBelle greeted visitors from the St. Agnes Children's Rehabilitation Center in Carmel, who were petting several Black Angus calves. Eight severely disabled children, accompanied by teachers and parents, reached through a fence toward several calves.
As Brian Desatnick wheeled his 4-year-old son, Lloyd, in a stroller along the edge of a pasture, he surveyed the corrugated ranges of fall-flamed hills and said, "It's terrific that this won't be developed."
