HEADLINE: Emil Jonassaint, 82, Ex-Haiti President, Dies

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

 BODY:
Emil Jonassaint, the jurist who served last year as the puppet President of the military junta that overthrew President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, died on Tuesday at his home in Port-au-Prince. He was 82.
Officials said Mr. Jonassaint died of natural causes. Several high-ranking military officers associated with the military junta have been killed recently in suspicious circumstances. 
 A former Supreme Court justice, Mr. Jonassaint was appointed President on May 11, 1994, by a rump Parliament to fill the vacuum left by the ouster of Mr. Aristide in a coup on Sept. 30, 1991.
But four months later he and Jimmy Carter signed an agreement that led to the departure of the military junta dominated by Gen. Raoul Cedras and to the return of Mr. Aristide.
Initially, the United States had shunned all contact with Mr. Jonassaint, describing him as nothing more than the nominal head of an illegal Government recognized by no other nation. But in a last-ditch effort to avoid an American invasion, Mr. Jonassaint was allowed to join other Haitian officials in two days of increasingly tense negotiations in Port-au-Prince with an unofficial American delegation headed by the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell; Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and Mr. Carter, the former President.
The resulting agreement, signed on Sept. 18, 1994, with American troops already in the air on their way to Haiti, called for General Cedras and other military leaders to give up power and allow Mr. Aristide's return to office in exchange for a lifting of economic sanctions and passage of an amnesty. One day later, 20,000 American troops began landing in Haiti, meeting no resistance and incurring no casualties.
Mr. Jonassaint's brief tenure was marked by widespread violations of human rights, the suspension of basic constitutional guarantees and frequent accusations that he had betrayed the principles of the legal profession in his zeal to serve the military rulers of Haiti. He imposed a state of emergency, and also expelled a United Nations-Organization of American States Mission that had been monitoring human rights abuses, giving them only hours to leave the country.
During his five months in office, Mr. Jonassaint became known for his habit of scheduling his most important official pronouncements at odd hours of the night, sometimes as late as 2 A.M. American officials mocked that custom, saying he was afraid to face his own people, but Haitians merely assumed he had selected that hour after consulting voodoo priests.
Mr. Jonaissant was, in fact, an ardent believer not only in voodoo, but also in astrology, numerology and other schools of mysticism, all of which affected his policies and governing style. He was said by friends and other government officials to believe that Haiti was the last remnant of the lost continent of Atlantis, and that the United States coveted the country in order to locate and then steal the magic Philosophers' Stone.
Before the American troops landed, Mr. Jonassaint also boasted that voodoo spells would protect Haiti from enemy aircraft and predicted that an army of invisible voodoo warriors would arise to defeat any foreign troops foolish enough to attack. He urged Haitians to "mobilize all the resources and strategies of our ancestors" in resisting an American invasion.
A native of the northern city of Port-de-Paix, Mr. Jonassaint began his political career in the early 1950's, serving as a Senator in the military dictatorship of Gen. Paul Magloire. During the 30-year dictatorship of the Duvalier family, which ended in 1986, he withdrew from politics, however, and limited himself to practicing law and perfecting his knowledge of ancient Greek and Latin.
When a constituent assembly was organized to draft a new constitution in 1986, Mr. Jonassaint was chosen as its president. He served on the Supreme Court until 1991, when Mr. Aristide ordered him to step down because of his age, but he was restored to that position after the military seized power.
Once American troops landed, Mr. Jonassaint complained that the agreement bearing his name and Mr. Carter's was not being properly implemented, and showed reluctance to leave the National Palace. But with the disintegration of the armed forces that had been his only source of support, there was little he could do, and he finally left office quietly, just days before Mr. Aristide returned from exile in the United States.
After Mr. Aristide's restoration a year ago this month, Mr. Jonassaint dropped out of public life and spent much of his time, friends and associates said, rummaging through his extensive personal library, which included many law books and esoteric texts.
Family members, reached by telephone in Port-au-Prince, declined to disclose the names of survivors.

HEADLINE: Man in the News: John Joseph Sweeney;
New Fire for Labor

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
John J. Sweeney, the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., was not playing by Marquis of Queensbury rules when he told the Los Angeles Board of Supervisors in July that if it pushed through a plan to cut 18,000 workers from its payroll, his union would conduct "a massive campaign of resistance and retribution."
Mr. Sweeney, who has spent 15 years as president of the Service Employees International Union, warned the Los Angeles officials that instead of forcing labor to accept their plan, they had better show workers some respect and sit down with union leaders to discuss less-painful ways to make budget cuts. 
 And to show that he had some muscle to back up his threat, 3,000 members of his employees union were demonstrating outside. In a move that raised the ante, 20 protesters were arrested after they sat down and blocked traffic.
Just minutes after he was elected the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president yesterday, Mr. Sweeney told all who would listen to expect many more such confrontations. He said he was dead serious about jettisoning the federation's gentlemanly ways and about transforming it into an aggressive, often confrontational, voice for American workers.
"As your president, I will never forget that our movement grows by addition and multiplication, and not by division and subtraction," he said to the cheering delegates.
Mr. Sweeney also told reporters that he would visit President Clinton the moment he was invited so he can go over the issues important to labor. And inside the federation, he said he would conduct a review of all functions and immediately start changing the federation's ways.
In campaigning against Thomas R. Donahue, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s interim president, Mr. Sweeney made clear that he thought the federation had let labor become a patsy repeatedly victimized by management. In a debate on Tuesday at the federation's convention at the Sheraton New York hotel in midtown Manhattan, he told the union leaders that he deserved their support "if you are tired of being treated like so much road kill on the highway of American life."
Despite the vinegar of his words, Mr. Sweeney, who is 61, will never be mistaken for firebrand union leaders like the mine workers' John L. Lewis. Mr. Sweeney is soft-spoken and slow to anger, inspiring workers not through emotional speeches, but by talking to them in a heart-to-heart way showing that he knows their problems.
Judging from his years at the helm of the 1.1-million member Service Employees Union, experts predict he will lead the 13 million-member federation in several new directions at once. He promises to increase spending on union organizing more than fivefold, something he become known for at the service employees union, which spends 30 percent of its budget on organizing, compared with 5 percent for most unions. Under his leadership, his union has nearly doubled in size even as union membership nationwide remained flat.
He also promises to try to bring more women and minority members into unions, and particularly into leadership positions. He revamped his union's board so that 20 of its 57 members are female, black or Hispanic.
"If it hadn't been for Sweeney, people like myself never would have been on the executive board," said Eliseo Medina, head of the service workers' San Diego local, whose membership has jumped fivefold since 1985.
While the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has a reputation for focusing on protecting the best-paid workers, Mr. Sweeney plans to focus more on organizing and helping low-paid workers, like the 20,000 home health aides his union has organized.
At the debate on Tuesday, Mr. Donahue attacked Mr. Sweeney's plans to change the federation's direction: making it more combative. Mr. Donahue criticized a tactic by Mr. Sweeney's union to block traffic on bridges in September in Washington to draw attention to its continuing campaign to organize janitors. Unions should be building bridges, not blocking them, Mr. Donahue said.
But Mr. Sweeney says labor must be ready to engage in civil disobedience to command respect. "I believe in building bridges, whenever the shelling lets up long enough for us to put up steel and pour concrete. We need to be a full partner with our employers," he said. "But I believe in blocking bridges whenever these employers and those communities turn a deaf ear to the working families that we represent."
John Joseph Sweeney was born in the Bronx on May 5, 1934, to parents who had emigrated from Ireland. His mother, Tricia, was a cleaning woman, and his father, John, was a city bus driver who often took his son to meetings of the Transport Workers Union.
He attended parochial school, graduating from Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx and from Iona College in New Rochelle, where he majored in economics. He first joined a labor union while working as a grave digger during college. His first job after college was at I.B.M., but he was happy to drop that and take a job at two-thirds the pay as a researcher for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
"John always wanted to be with labor unions," said his wife, the former Maureen Power. "Social justice is what motivates him. He has never forgotten where he came from." The Sweeneys have two children, Tricia, 23, who works for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s housing investment fund, and John, 26, who is studying to be a chef.
Mr. Donahue, who used to work for New York-based Local 32B of the service employees union, recruited Mr. Sweeney for a job in the union in 1960. Mr. Sweeney climbed the ladder at Local 32B, beginning as contract director, then becoming assistant to the president and, in 1976, president. At the local, which represents janitors, doormen and elevator operators, he led two citywide strikes of apartment workers.
In 1980, he moved to Washington to head the Service Employees International, where he developed a reputation as a rabble-rouser who wanted to shake up the labor movement.
"He would say that he wants labor-management cooperation, but he says it has to come when unions are in a position of strength," said Sandy Felder, head of a service employees local in Boston. "He says unions should be treated with respect. If they reach out their hand, and management pushes it aside, then he believes that hand should turn into a fist."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Turn Over Troops Accused of Murder or Rape to Japan

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Hoping to settle growing anger at crime by American soldiers in Japan, the United States agreed today to hand over troops accused of murder or rape.
The American concession is intended to defuse the passions provoked by the kidnapping and rape of a 12-year-old Japanese girl in Okinawa last month, in which three American servicemen were accused of the crimes. 
 The three young men accused in the rape, who have not yet entered pleas, have perhaps affected Japanese-American relations more than anyone else this year.
That incident has provoked a broad rage and a growing campaign against American military bases.
Both the Japanese and American Governments are desperately trying to calm the fury before President Clinton arrives in Japan in the middle of next month for a summit meeting. The centerpiece of the meeting is supposed to be an agreement on the importance of the American-Japanese security relationship, but the public mood toward military cooperation has turned sour since the rape.
Today's agreement may not immediately diminish the demands for an American pullout from its bases in Japan, but it perhaps will go part-way toward easing the furor that has arisen since the rape in Okinawa. To many Japanese, it seemed galling that the American suspects were kept on an American base until their indictment, when they were handed over to the Japanese authorities.
Still, today's concession by the United States raises concerns about the legal protections afforded to American soldiers accused of crimes abroad. Japanese interrogators sometimes rough up suspects, or soften them up by depriving them of sleep, and that is why the United States in the past had not wanted to hand over American troops.
In addition, South Korea has already been demanding that the United States revise its procedures for handing over any troops suspected of crimes. Now Seoul is sure to press its demands even more.
Today's agreement is based on the "status of forces agreement," or the Sofa, a document that stipulates the rights and obligations of the 60,000 American forces in Japan. The Sofa now states that in most cases American troops suspected of crimes will be handed over to the Japanese authorities upon indictment.
The agreement today adds that that the United States "will give sympathetic consideration" if Japan requests custody of servicemen who are suspected of murder or rape but have not yet been indicted.
The clause is similar to one in the Sofa that covers American troops in Germany. But there the clause is almost never exercised, and American servicemen are normally handed over to German authorities only after conviction of a crime.
Although the Governments of both Japan and the United States want to maintain the existing bases in Japan, public opinion in Japan is ambivalent. In a recent poll by the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, an economic newspaper, almost as many Japanese opposed the United States-Japan security treaty as favored it.
The poll showed that 40 percent said that the treaty should be abolished, while 44 percent supported it. The United States has gradually given up its claims to jurisdiction. In 1957, for example, there was a huge uproar when an American soldier shot and killed a Japanese woman.
There was a debate the in the United States about whether an American soldier could be tried in a Japanese court, but eventually the United States handed the suspect over and he was convicted. The soldier was never sent to prison, but was released and returned to the United States.

HEADLINE: A Budget Democrats Should Vote For

 BODY:
The House is scheduled to vote today on a remarkably sensible, though tough, budget plan sponsored by Democrats, mostly conservative. The plan will not pass, but the vote still matters. President Clinton is likely to veto the initial budget that the Republican-controlled Congress puts on his desk. His negotiating strength will flow from today's vote. If Democrats line up behind their colleagues' plan, then Mr. Clinton can pull the G.O.P. toward its provisions. But if the Democrats flee, then he is left with no option to fight for.
The Democrats' plan meets the stringent Republican test of balancing the budget within seven years. But the Democrats would more fairly spread the burden. Gone is the G.O.P.'s $245 billion tax cut that largely benefits upper-income families. That allows the Democrats to propose spending cuts 25 percent less severe than the harsh reductions proposed by the Republicans. Gone is the G.O.P.'s tax hike on the earnings of low-paid workers and the reduction in student loans. Also gone are Republican proposals to eliminate 60-year-old Federal entitlements for health insurance and cash assistance. 
 Attempting to be both fair and fiscally responsible, the Democrats would trim Medicare costs, in part by charging upper-income enrollees higher premiums, but they would take out about $100 billion less than the Republicans. Medicaid, the program of health insurance for the poor, would survive at lower levels and with a spending cap that adjusts for inflation and enrollment. The Republican plan calls for much larger Federal Medicaid cuts and takes no account of future enrollment and inflation surprises. The Democrats propose reducing cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other Federal benefits, but they cleverly design the system so that poor families should not suffer.
The plan has flaws, beginning with the Democrats' decision to match the G.O.P.'s goal of reaching a balanced budget on an arbitrary timetable of seven years. The goals and the timetable will require huge cuts in valuable public investments, including research, education and job training.
Indeed, discretionary spending under the Democratic plan could well drop as calamitously as it would under the Republican plan and, contrary to current law, the Democrats would no longer raise discretionary spending to offset inflation. Their proposed trims in agriculture subsidies -- one place where larger cuts would be fully justified -- are smaller than the Republicans'. The Democrats propose to tax the poor on the value of food stamps and on their disability insurance. They would also cap malpractice awards.
Still, the plan suggests the budget can be balanced by 2002 without pummeling the poor or Medicare. Liberals will not be pleased. But if the Democrats cannot back something like the budget their conservative colleagues have put forward, they will severely limit the President's bargaining leverage.
Correction
An editorial on Monday headlined "Save Sterling Forest" said incorrectly that a $2 billion bond issue would be decided in next month's New York State balloting. No such measure will appear.

HEADLINE: Labor Wakes Up

 BODY:
John Sweeney's victory over Thomas Donahue in the first contested election for the leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. yesterday reflected the labor federation's recognition that it must change or continue to shrivel. But the campaign raised the possibility that Mr. Sweeney will waste his fresh start on convulsive organizing tactics when the federation needs not just energy but more sophisticated understanding of the global economy and the changing workplace to which it must adapt.
It is understandable, of course, that the delegates to the national convention in New York City this week want to shake off the lethargy that settled over the union movement during Lane Kirkland's tenure. Union membership in the United States has been shrinking drastically even though the value of ordinary workers' wages and their job security have been atrophying. But the campaign speeches about blocking bridges and getting arrested seemed oddly dated. Instead the new regime needs to start with an analysis of whether coal-mine and steel-mill tactics are the best way to win the loyalty of high-tech workers and the respect of corporations exploring new schemes of cooperative management. 
 To be sure, the awareness that something new was needed drove this election. Challenged by Mr. Sweeney's insurgent movement, Mr. Kirkland stepped aside last year and handed the leadership to his deputy, Mr. Donahue. But Mr. Donahue was shackled by the old craft-union legacy and came across as representing a failed status quo.
Mr. Sweeney, on the other hand, heads a union -- the Service Employees International Union -- that has almost doubled in size at a time when union membership in the nation has shrunk to 15.5 percent of the work force, its lowest level since the 1930's. Mr. Sweeney's most significant victories have come from his willingness to take on the classic, grinding and time-consuming task of the labor movement: organizing. He has done this by paying attention to those the labor establishment has most egregiously ignored: the low-paid, the non-white, the women.
He promises to continue and expand this commitment, spending more of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s considerable resources on organizing and political work and introducing a resolution to insure the diversity of its executive council. He promises to finance a political training institute, targeting vulnerable freshman Republicans in the next Congressional elections. He also wants to underwrite a labor-oriented think tank to answer the influential and ubiquitous messages of conservative organizations such as the Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institute.
Mr. Sweeney and others on his team have also expressed an understanding that to win public acceptance, the union movement must shake off the shadow of corruption and police itself vigilantly. He introduced a successful resolution to the convention to amend the federation's constitution by adopting an ethical practices code that includes possible suspension of corrupt unions.
All these steps will be needed to rejuvenate the labor movement, but Mr. Sweeney and his followers will need more than enthusiasm, commitment and honesty. They will need to develop a new, sophisticated understanding of the economic forces that have contributed to the weakened position of American workers. Demonizing corporations, while emotionally satisfying, will not deliver the new skills and productivity increases needed to give American workers more jobs at higher wages.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Let the Loser Lose

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
In a tie and suit, Fidel Castro, describing himself as a politician, flattered the media biggies gathered for lunch in Mort Zuckerman's Fifth Avenue apartment with: "You are the cream of the crop."
A dollop of sour cream came from this corner: If you claim to be a politician, why have you been unwilling for 36 years to face an opponent in a democratic election? 
 The Cuban dictator downmouthed elections as "a popularity competition between political personalities" engaged in by "speakers good at theatrics, demagogues and liars. I don't want to get involved in that kind of competition."
Fidel, the non-demagogue, is above all that. He took pains to remind us he won a law school election 180 to 33, and had perfected the techniques of organization and direct mail "even before your Christian right."
Then why not let the Cuban people vote? "I am not afraid, but we do not have presidential elections in our country." Later, he compared his selection to that of the Pope, elected by a ballot of cardinals.
All this nonsense is being peddled by the only totalitarian ruler in our hemisphere; his secret police informers, trained by the Stasi spies of East Germany, permeate every Cuban village and walk of life. Amnesty International counts 600 prisoners rotting in Cuban jails for daring to oppose the dictator's rule; the Stasi and the old K.G.B. would be proud of their pupil.
Castro, who rules by fear, avoids free elections because he is afraid he would lose. That should not be surprising because he is one of the great losers of our time.
After seizing power, he lost his revolutionary soul by taking Cuba down the Communist road to repression. He lost all chance for Cuban prosperity by burdening the people with 3.2 million government workers and a huge standing army to protect his regime from any need for elections. He lost Cuba's independence by making it a vassal of the Soviet Union, addicted to Soviet subsidies, renting out Cuban youth as mercenaries in Moscow's failed African adventures; and when that blood money dried up, Cubans suffered as never before.
Despite that record of colossal failure, he gets the loudest applause of all speakers at the United Nations. Why? Not for anything he has done for Cubans, nor for his necrophiliac love for a dead doctrine. His popularity in the striped-pants set is rooted solely in his four-decade defiance of the United States and his contempt for American democracy.
Every U.N. diplomat who envies and resents U.S. power gets a kick out of cheering Castro, who has clung to unelected power during nine elected U.S. Presidencies. (As the dictator denounced us, only the Israelis sat on their hands.) Turning biblical righteousness on its head, he is playing David to our Goliath, a strategy aimed at snatching one final, personal victory.
That is why he told the luncheon guests that "the U.S. is so astonishingly powerful that not even the Romans, Napoleon, the Germans in both world wars can compare. Your economic and political influence has no parallel." In the face of such power, unlike David, "we don't even have a slingshot."
This is the plaintive we're-no-longer-a-threat plea. End your embargo; send us your tourists; subsidize my regime with your investment money; help me adopt capitalism without freedom and rule for life with an iron fist; let me enjoy the last laugh at the exiles in Miami and the Colossus of the North.
This from the man who stunted Cuba's growth and jailed or exiled many of its patriots. To obscure his failure, the Communist who victimized his people is posing as the victim of a U.S. that he claims seeks "hegemony in a unipolar world."
Some U.S. business executives comfortable with state-monopoly deals help him sell this line; they're the same ones who assured us that trade would bring an end to repression in China. President Clinton cannot admit it publicly for fear of losing Florida in 1996, but if re-elected, I suspect he would end all pressure to bring down Castro, trotting out the same vague reason he used to embrace Vietnam: "It's time."
It will only be "time" when Dictator Castro quits or submits to free elections. Communism is tyranny that is bound to fail. Let the loser lose.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Tape at King Fraud Trial Reveals Threat by Accuser

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Don King's lawyer continued yesterday to question the credibility of a crucial Government witness in the promoter's Federal mail fraud trial.
Joseph Maffia, King's former controller, has testified in United States District Court in Manhattan that King told him to falsify training expenses for Julio Cesar Chavez in order to make an allegedly fraudulent $350,000 insurance claim when an injury to Chavez forced the cancellation of his fight against Harold Brazier on June 28, 1991. 
 Maffia said King directed him to pad the claim in order to recover part of a $736,000 advance the promoter made to Chavez on March 18, 1991.
Peter Fleming Jr., King's lawyer, played a tape of a telephone call Maffia made to King in May 1992, eight months after being forced to resign.
The call began with the usually low-key Maffia loudly threatening physical violence. "Do you understand this?" he shouted.
King apparently did not recognize Maffia's voice and sounded confused.
"Is this my dear friend?" he said. "My landsman?"
After Maffia repeated his threat, King said, "Landsman? Landsman?"
"Who the hell do you think this is?" Maffia shouted.
"I don't know," King said.
To Fleming, Maffia said: "I just wanted to yell at him."
Maffia told Paul Gardephe, the Assistant United States Attorney, that he was angry at King for challenging his claim for unemployment benefits, seeking to revoke his state accountant's license and for an unspecified personal matter.
One point of great personal contention between the two men, writes Jack Newfield in "Only in America," a new biography of King, was their involvement with the same woman. (Earlier, United States District Court Judge Lawrence McKenna ruled that notes of conversations between Newfield and Maffia revealed "no evidence or impeachment material" that could be used by King's defense team.)
The defense wants to portray Maffia as an unreliable former employee -- one who wanted to be a promoter himself -- who is lashing out at King. Playing the tape was one strategy, but Fleming also tried to impeach him by eliciting vague and contradictory answers from the accountant.
An important element of King's defense is that the $736,000 advance against Chavez's next purse was insured under a $750,000 policy obtained by Maffia.
But Maffia told Fleming that advances were not insurable.
Asked if he had told King that the $736,000 was not insurable under the policy, Maffia said, "No, I did not." He added: "We did not insure the $736,000 so I did not tell him." Maffia said Tuesday that he found only about $150,000 in claimable expenses, including $80,000 for Chavez's training.
Maffia also said that he did not tell the retail broker, Gagliardi Brothers Insurance, the specifics of what he wanted to insure and did not read the insurance binder that was sent to him that laid out the conditions of insurance.
Gardephe scored points when Maffia read from a Don King Productions bookkeeping journal that showed handwritten entries, made after he stopped working for King, for Chavez's training costs of $80,000 and another for $270,000.
Together they add up to the $350,000 in training and "maintenance" costs that King's company fashioned for its insurance claim.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
DU PONT (E. I.) DE NEMOURS & CO. (DD,N)

 BODY:
The shares of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company fell yesterday after the company, the nation's largest maker of chemicals, reported third-quarter earnings that made investors nervous, even though they surpassed analysts' expectations.
At midday, trading was halted for almost an hour because of an order imbalance. The stock traded as low as $60.125, down about 8 percent, after the interruption. It closed at $61.125, down $3.875. 
 After charges and gains, the company's net income was $769 million, or $1.38 a share, up 18.9 percent from $647 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier. And it was higher than the average prediction of $1.34 a share by 15 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Du Pont had 18 percent fewer shares outstanding than it did a year earlier, after its repurchase of shares from the Seagram Company this year.
Revenue rose 3.9 percent, to $10.4 billion from $10 billion, the company, based in Wilmington, Del., said. Some of the increase came from an increased allocation of earnings from its pharmaceuticals joint venture with Merck and Company. Du Pont's chemical shipments were unchanged.
"The quarter was a warning of potential disaster for the fourth quarter, next year and into '97," said Paul Raman, an analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company. The results of Du Pont's core businesses reflected much slower growth in Europe and the United States, he said.
Andrew Cash, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., said that with chemical prices high, customers were tapping inventory rather than buying more chemicals.
Du Pont's president, John A. Krol, said, "The business climate in the third quarter was difficult, as growth in key global economies slowed." (Bloomberg Business News)

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Home Desk 

LENGTH: 979 words

HEADLINE: A Temple of 80's Chic Gets a Corduroy Makeover

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY JACK WARD 

 BODY:
COULD it be true? Could it be that Morgans Hotel -- the harbinger of Eurostyle in New York, the prototype "designer hotel" when it opened in 1984 -- had become tired? Or -- as its French designer, Andree Putman, put it, "use jusqu'a la corde" -- threadbare?
Eleven years, one recession and one Return to Comfort later, it was all too true. Wear and tear aside, all that black and white and gray was no longer cool, just cold. And so last spring the hotel's owner, Ian Schrager (who also owns two other temples of interior chic in New York, the Royalton and Paramount hotels), asked Ms. Putman to return to the project that first propelled her to international fame. 
 Once a monument to designer excess, Morgans, at 237 Madison Avenue (37th Street), has gone soft, warm, vanilla. Well, more caffe latte, really. If the early-80's Morgans was a top-heavy power suit, the new-and-improved Morgans is a slouchy pair of corduroys.
Throughout the hotel, the palette has softened from cool, silvery tones with black-and-white-check accents, to a warmer, subtler mix that ranges from sandy to sandier. It is as if someone had gently fiddled with the little knob that adjusts the color on a television screen.
"These days, the less you see, the better you feel," Ms. Putman said.
The new lobby sets the tone: The sleek but uncomfortable designer-statement armchairs have been replaced by flea-market treasures. There are pairs of weathered caramel-colored leather club chairs that are inviting and familiar. A 19th-century mahogany, teak and rattan planter's chair sprawls by the front door. The three-dimensional design of the carpet is the same, but its new palette makes for a very different effect.
Styles of decorating change just as styles of living do. In 1977, Mr. Schrager could be found glittering the night away at Studio 54, which he owned with Steve Rubell, who died in 1989. But now, at 49, Mr. Schrager looks forward to spending the evening with his wife, Rita Narona-Schrager, and their daughter, Sophia, 2.
Ms. Putman, too, has changed. "I am not a saint, quite the opposite, but my passion now is to change life a little bit, to improve daily life," she said on a visit to New York in early October to supervise the finishing touches of the $1.3 million renovation. "I believe design is redemptive. The new goal is to create things that last."
The recent renovation of her duplex apartment in Paris, on the Left Bank served as a laboratory for Ms. Putman's new ideas. A new understanding of home coincided with the birth of her grandson, Alexandre, now 2. "The reality of my house is scenes spent with the child," she said. "Home exists, to my eyes, for him."
Her list of design dislikes remains the same: "Too much Louis-someone, too big flowers, too much the desire to intimidate. And I do resent the obligation of using lavish materials, pretending to be Versailles. The French have a heavy sense of decor, having never recovered from Louis XIV not being here anymore. But it is a painful and stupid nostalgia."
Ms. Putman seems equally disdainful of those who are obsessed with newness and acquisition. "For all the threatening advertising, and wanting so desperately to be in, suddenly people are realizing that buying things doesn't save" in the redemptive sense, she said, adding: "Design became a kind of show business. That even a teapot should be designed anew by an architect is so depressing, when China or Africa are filled with the most beautiful objects."
The guest rooms at Morgans Hotel were once dressed in sleek black leather, gray flannel and stainless steel and trimmed with a black and white checkerboard frieze. That was replaced by the new warmer palette. To make the small rooms look less cramped, beds and chairs are no higher than 16 inches from the floor. The original framed botanical photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe remain.
The headboards and window seats are now covered with a dove-gray washable synthetic suede. The aggressive right angles of a buffalo-plaid blanket have been replaced by a coffee-colored throw soft enough to wear, as Ms. Putman did during her stay, occasionally draping it around her shoulders.
Most emblematic of what the designer calls her new "obsession for warmth" is the boxy armchair, generously scaled, with a very deep, soft seat. It is covered in thick wide-wale corduroy the color of rich cream. Ms. Putman absently petted it with her fingertips as she mused, "Stroking this chair is a real pleasure."
Throughout the hotel, walls have been given a flecked finish that resembles pink granite. It is a spray-on pointillist concoction of specs in three similar colors. The overall effect is of a slightly taupey speckled eggshell.
But guests at the hotel, who pay $195 to $250 a night for a regular room, can still take a stroll on the wild side: A narrow stairway off the lobby leads down to a dark bar lighted only by quirky candlesticks and votive candles wedged into brick walls. Mr. Schrager asked Calvin Tsao, a New York architect and a protege of I. M. Pei, to create the bar in what had been a storage room.
"I was thinking Cocteau -- a grotto, very dark, mysterious, just a little sinister and surreal," Mr. Schrager said. A glowing translucent marble bar slashes diagonally through the room. On each side of the bar are totem-like wood stools designed by Chris Lehrecke, a Brooklyn artist.
One recent day, Ms. Putman took a break from putting Euroflash out of its misery and watched the people in the compact lobby. Four young men and women, snappily dressed, struggled through the front doors, loaded like pack mules with at least two shopping bags each from Brooks Brothers, Swatch, Banana Republic and the Gap, insignias a-flying.
"It is obscene, isn't it?" she whispered, referring to their trendy haul. "That will not console them, not for a moment."

HEADLINE: Giuliani? He Wouldn't Get Castro's Vote

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

 BODY:
Sitting at a polished oval conference table at The New York Times yesterday, Fidel Castro broke from his characteristic political discourse to make a pronouncement.
"I would not vote for the Mayor," he said of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Yet, despite the glittery galas and concerts that Mr. Castro missed at Mr. Giuliani's behest, it is something more profoundly prosaic that galls him about the Mayor's tenure. 
 "It's not just because he didn't invite me to dinner," the Cuban President said with a grin, "but because on my way into town from the airport there were such enormous potholes."
On his last day of a five-day visit to New York for the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, Mr. Castro met for nearly two hours with the publisher of The New York Times and several editors at the paper's offices.
Speaking through his longtime interpreter, who not only mimicked his expressions but at times ended his sentences, Mr. Castro answered an assortment of questions, touching on his visit to the United Nations, political prisoners in Cuba and the fall of the Soviet Union.
Mr. Castro punctuated his remarks with disarming humor and, at times, long-winded asides. He wore his recently disclosed wardrobe of international diplomacy -- a starched white shirt, gold cuff links, a red tie and comfortable shoes.
The suit and tie, however, were no more than superficial accouterments. As the 69-year-old Mr. Castro tackled the tough questions first, then the more lighthearted, he showed no signs of bending his political will to suit others, defending his rule in Cuba as a form of democracy that enjoys deep public support.
Replying to a question about Cuba's longstanding policy of imprisoning dissidents, Mr. Castro agreed with estimates by Amnesty International that some 600 Cubans are in prison for political reasons.
But he quickly defended the policy, saying he was not alone in jailing those who fight against the state. Mexico does the same, he said, as do Argentina, France, China and a host of other countries.
Showing a keen knowledge of the United States political landscape, he spoke about Ross Perot and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the retired Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but saved his most admiring words for President John F. Kennedy. He described Mr. Kennedy as a formidable opponent in the "positive sense" because he had the courage to stop the attempted invasion of Cuba at the Bay of Pigs. "He is a man for whom I feel respect," he said.
Now, however, it is General Powell who has captured his attention. He said he ordered 46 translators to transcribe the general's recently published autobiography into Spanish, for reading by himself and by senior Cuban officials. His hectic schedule, however, has kept him from any bedtime reading.
On the economic front, Mr. Castro said Cuba was beginning to make headway, citing an increase in foreign investment and the large number of tourists and foreign entrepreneurs visiting the island. This openness, he said, poses a security risk, but one he is willing to take.
Emphasizing a recurring theme of his visit, Mr. Castro said he refused to abandon his principles and Cuba's sovereignty by moving toward democracy just to meet conditions set by the United States for lifting its economic embargo.
"This is not a business deal," he said. "This is not about bargaining."
Mr. Castro called his trip, his first to New York since 1979, successful, saying he tried to accommodate many of the 200 invitations he received to different functions. He went to a church in Harlem, a banquet hall in the South Bronx, a media executive's Fifth Avenue apartment and the homes of millionaire business executives.
He ended the day by meeting for two hours with about 100 religious leaders, overwhelmingly Protestant, at Cuba's United Nations Mission.
Mr. Castro joked about a trick he played in 1957 on a determined Times reporter, Herbert L. Matthews, in the Sierra Maestra, when his small band of guerrillas had been all but written off by the outside world. "We tried to give Matthews the impression that there were more of us," Mr. Castro said, recounting how he ordered the same troop of weary soldiers to parade past the reporter again and again.
Two years after Mr. Matthews interviewed Mr. Castro, his revolutionary movement had grown, and in January 1959 his forces swept into Havana. The visit by The New York Times to his remote encampment, he said, had been "really very helpful."

HEADLINE: Record S.E.C. Settlement by Merrill and Lazard Expected

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
In the largest settlement of its kind in municipal finance, Merrill Lynch & Company and Lazard Freres have each agreed to pay about $10 million to settle charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission over a secret fee-splitting contract that the two firms mantained.
 
 The settlement is expected to be announced by the commission shortly. At the same time, people close to the investigation said, a Federal grand jury in Massachusetts is expected today to indict Mark S. Ferber, a former Lazard partner. Mr. Ferber, a municipal-finance expert, is suspected of having collected more than $1 million a year in secret fees for Lazard from Merrill Lynch for steering business to Merrill from 1989 to 1993.
 The case reflects to new emphasis by the S.E.C. on cleaning up municipal finance, which has long been plagued by political payoffs and other forms of corruption.
 Even so, the arrangement between the two investment firms was highly unusual. Mr. Ferber, who had been hired by municipalities as a financial adviser, would recommend to his clients that Merrill Lynch be selected to conduct lucrative swap transactions. In less than three years, Merrill paid Lazard a total of $2.6 million for Mr. Ferber's recommendations.
 This arrangement was outlined in a contract between the two firms, the terms of which were to have been kept secret. In making the settlement, the two firms are neither admitting nor denying guilt. The S.E.C. settlement comes over charges that the two firms violated Federal securities laws by not disclosing the fee-splitting arrangement to Lazard's financial advisory clients, who were relying on Mr. Ferber's recommendations.
 In addition to settling with the S.E.C., the firms are also settling with the state of Massachusetts and the Massachusetts Water Resources Agency. Mr. Ferber was hired by Massachusetts as an independent adviser to help arrange financing for municipal projects, including the cleanup of Boston Harbor, then one of the largest such projects in the country.
 During the course of the contract, Merrill and Lazard were incolved in six specific fee-splitting deals involving interest-rate swaps recommended by Lazard to its municipal clients and underwritten by Merrill. In nine other deals, Merrill Lynch served as a municipal bond underwriter, and Mr. Ferber was the financial adviser and in a position to recommend the hiring of Merrill.
 Richard Y. Roberts, a former S.E.C. commissioner, praised the impending settlement. "This is a good news to municipal-finance investors," he said after getting a description of the settlement. "And the size of the fine indicates the S.E.C. intends to address the kinds of shenanigans that were once part of the municipal-finance landscape. This is a strong step to restoring integrity to the municipal marketplace."
 The combined penalities of roughly $20 million are by far the largest ever brought by the S.E.C. in a municipal-finance case. Last August, in what was then the largest municipal penalty in S.E.C. history, a St. Louis brokerage firm, Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, paid $1.44 million to settle a fraud case.
 The Merrill-Lazard case is one of a series of enforcement actions being brought by the securities commission in the municipal-finance markets. Currently, the agency is investigating possible fradulent actions in the sale of municipal bonds in Orange County, Calif., which is under bankruptcy protection, and in connection with the building of the new Denver International Airport.
 Merrill Lynch is also being investigated by the S.E.C. over its role in the sale of taxable Orange County bonds, as well as the sale of derivatives to the county's failed investment pool.
 People close to the Massachusetts investigation said the indictments on charges that Mr. Ferber defrauded his clients would be issued today. His lawyer, Catherine Weinman, would not comment on these reports.
 As part fo the settlement, the S.E.C. is delaying taking any civil action against Mr. Ferber, pending the outcome of the exected criminal charges. This delay came at the request of the United States Attorney in Boston, according to people close to the investigation, so that information currently held by the S.E.C. would not be available to Mr. Ferber through the civil discovery process that could be used as part of a criminal defense.
 This would be the second time that Merrill and Lazard paid sizable fines over a fee-splitting arrangement. The two recently paid a total of $3.6 million to the District of Columbia, which had hired Mr. Ferber as its financial adviser. Upon Mr. Ferber's recommendation, Merrill was hired to conduct two interest-rate swaps.
 As part of the settlement, no other restrictions have been placed on the firms by the S.E.C. in the conduct of municipal finance. Merrill Lynch is one of the largest municipal bond underwritters in the country, while Lazared often serves as a municipal-finance adviser to public agencies.

HEADLINE: Placing Bets On a New Medicare

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
When an elderly person breaks a hip, the typical hospital stay is just seven days. That is at least three fewer days than was the case a decade ago, before Medicare switched to a flat payment system for each illness or injury.
 
 But while the payment system was meant to cap Medicare spending, it wound up doing the reverse. Because such patients are hardly ready to dance home after a week, they are transferred to nursing homes for follow-up care. Medicare pays again, often at $400 a day, and it may pay later for therapy in the patient's home. "The Government ended up paying at least twice," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care securities analyst with Sanford C. Berstein & Company.
 In short, Medicare could not stop being a boon to health care providers, producing often-unexpected opportunities financed by an ever-flowing spigot of tax-payer dollars. Nursing homes and home health care companies that were quick to seize these opportunities segued easily into Medicare's services for the elderly and disabled and became Wall Street favorites.
 But now, if the Republican-controlled Congress has its way, it will be time for some of health care's fastest-growing sectors to pay the piper. Over the next seven years, $270 billion will be squeezed out fo projected Medicare payments, under budget-cutting bills now coming through both houses of Congress.
 In part, the latest shift is simply a matter of speeding the process of change spurred by managed care and other cost-containment efforts.
 "The cuts will accelerate a lot of things that are happening already, because employers have become very cost-conscious," said Richard L. Scott, chief executive of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the rapidly growing for-profit hospital chain that already controls close to 10 percent of the hospital business in the country.
 But in their overall impact, the proposed changes - like those instituted a decade ago- would repaint the landscape of the $1 trillion-a-year health care system, producing new peaks and valleys that promise shocks and surprises for patients, investors and employers, not to mention the heatlh care providers themselves. The deep budget cuts are certain to produce pain for some providers, analysts say, but new opportunities, both aniticipated and unanticipated, for others.
 The potential losers, at least among groups, seem obvious. Under the House bill, hospitals would receive almost $78 billion less in Medicare payments over the next seven years, the home health care industry would lose $17 billion and certain nursing homes about $10 billion. Home-oxygen suppliers, whose revenue had been growing by 15 percent a year, would also be reined in.
 But here would be winners, too, within these groups, because providers that have already been adapting to the changing health care market would be in a position to capitalize on the belt-tightening. Hospital chains like Columbia and the Tenet Healthcare Corporation would have new opportunities to grow by acquiring weak nonprofit hospitals pushed under by the cutbacks.
 The cuts would "just push us to be more aggressive in streamlining the delivery process and accelerating the consolidation of excess facilities and capacity," Mr. Scott said. "It will accelerate our growth."
 Columbia, which as 325 hospitals in 36 states and has announced plans to acquire at least 9 more, gets 45 percent of its $17.5 billion of annual revenue from Medicare.
 Wall Street has already been handicapping the prospects of companies throughout the health care industry. In most cases, it expects profits to be squeezed, as the proposals now stand. Nursing home and home health care stocks have been hammered this year. But H.M.O. stocks, after taking their own hits from lowered earnings growth earlier this year, have rebounded, partly on hopes for growth as Medicare pushed the elderly toward manage health care. Meanwhile, companies that make medical devices have also gained, but for a different reason: the Republican campaign to lower Federal regulatory hurdles for new products.
 Among analysts' new favorites, besides hospital chains, are the so-called physician practice management companies like Phycor Inc. Pacific Physician Services and Caremark International. These companies "rent" the services of doctor groups to hospitals and managed care plans.
 Other favorites are a few nursing home companies, like Manor Care Inc., that mainly serve patients who have private insurance.
 Drug companies are not affected by the proposed Medicare cuts, but they are lobbying hard for the chance to raise prices for Medcaid programs for low-income people.
 The planned budget cuts still have to clear several legislative hurdles and the threat of a White House veto. The health care industry will be lobbying for chantes down to the wire, but some version of stiff cuts seems likely. Following is alook at the potential impact fo the cutbacks, sector by sector.
 Hospitals
 Health care experts say the most successful hospitals will be those, like Colmubia's, that build networks of outpatient clinics, groups of regional physicians, nursing homes and home health care services. As a result, they will be able to offer one-stop shopping to H.M.O.'s and big employers. By contrast, hospitals that try to go it alone will face hard times, the experts say.
 The House bill would permit hospitals and doctor groups to compete with local Medicare health maintenance organizations by dealing directly with employer groups. These new provider-sponsored H.M.O.'s might succeed by grabbing customers from the insurance companies, eliminating the middleman. But the new groups could also lose if established H.M.O.'s retaliated by no longer referring patients to them.
 In addition to physician management companies like Phycor, "we might see a new little industry to help doctors and hospitals manage the risks by becoming more efficient," said Kimberly A. Purvis, a securities analyst with Doaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
 Mr. Scott said Columbia would consider establishing its own H.M.O.'s on a market-by-market basis. In cities like Nashville, where columbia is dominant, it has used its power to push for advantageous deals with the H.M.O.'s in town, analysts said.
 Mr. Scott noted that Medicare' rates have not kept pace with inflation since 1993, while payments by employers have actually declined. Even so, Columbia has thrived, he said, by cutting its own costs and increasing the flow of patients into its hospitals and outpatient clinics.
 H.M.O.'s
 For H.M.O.'s and other health insurers, the Medicare legislation is a mixed bag. Both the Senate and House bills encourage beneficiaries to join Medicare H.M.O.'s, which are already growing fast. But there would be sharp cuts in payments for Medicare H.M.O. patients in high cost markets like New York, Miami, Chicago and Los Angeles.
 Analysts said the rate reductions would hurt Humana Inc, which has a big presence in south Florida, and Pacificare Health Systems in California, which gets 56 percent of its revenue from Medicare. In New York, Oxford Health Plans and U.S. Healthcare have been adding Medicare members, but they are a small part of their businesses.
 H.M.O.'s in lower-cost markets like Minneapolis have been promised higher pavments for elderly patients. The increases would alos encourage H.M.O.'s and other managed-care health plans to move into rural areas that they previously shunned, said George C. Havorson, president of Health Partners, a big Minneapolis H.M.O.
 In New York, for example, higher rates might attract companies like Oxford and U.S. Healthcare to expand in upstate counties.
 Nursing Homes
 The outlook for nursing homes is even more complicated. The House bill "is a nightmare for us," said David R. Banks, chief executive of Beverly Enterprises, which operates 700 nursing homes throughout the country.
 The payment squeeze on post-hospital therapy, which the industry calls "subacute care," would affect more than one-fourth of Everly's revenues, which were $834.9 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30. "It would push us back into custodial care," where profit margins are much lower, Mr. Banks said.
 Nursing homes want Congress to adopt a version of the fixed-rate payment system for hospital care to cover the post-hospital care they provide.
 Worried investors have driven down the stock price of nursing-home companies like Integrated Health Services, which runs nursing homes for post-hospital Medicare patients. But Manor Care, a nursing-home chain that gets less than 15 percent of its revenue form Medicare, remains a favorite.
 Home Care
 Home health care companies also face many problems. The House bill cuts $2.5 billion over the seven years from homoe oxygen services, which received only $1.4 billion from Medicare last year. The Senate bill cuts even deeper, $4.5 billion.
 Home oxygen services have grown rapidly as equipment has improved and the population has aged. With Medicare picking up 60 percent of the bills, companies like Lincare Holdings Inc. and a precursor of Apria Healthecare Group went public in the early 1990's and then used stock to acquire smaller companies. But hefty profit margins, exceeding 30 percent, drew the attention of Government officials, who argued that Medicare payments were too high. The companies disagree.
 Now, the cmpanies' patients are sending thousands of letters urging members of Congress to soften the blow of the impending payment cuts.
 Tim Aitken, president of Apria, hinted that his company might move away from providing home oxygen for Medicare patients if the cuts siphoned off profits. Already, he said, the company was able to offer lower costs on other types of high-technology home care to H.M.O.'s in the highly competitive California market.
 Erik Wiberg, a health care analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, said small home health companies that provide health aides and nurses would also be squeezed by the heavy Medicare cuts. Big home-nursing companies like the Olsten Corporation, could also be hurt.
 Labs and Equipment Makers
 The House bill also clamps down on payments for laboratory tests and medical equipment like wheelchairs. Analysts said this business was important to Apria, the Retech Medical Corporation and American Homepatient Inc.
 The bill would cut $6 billion from projected spending increases for clinical laboratories over the seven years. Lab companies like the Laberatory Corporation of America and the Metpath unit of Corniag Inc. would also face competition from doctors who would be freed from restrictions on owning and operating labs.
 "Laboratories have been a tough business for the last several years, and this will just make it that much tougher," Mr. Wiberg said.

HEADLINE: Militant Is Elected Head of A.F.L.-C.I.O., Signaling Sharp Turn for Labor Movement

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

 BODY:
With the election of John J. Sweeney yesterday as the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. the American labor movement took a sharp turn toward militancy, rebuilding union membership, moving women and minorities into the policy-making ranks and tackling in hostile Congress.
 
 Mr. Sweeney, 61, the longtime president of the 1.1 million-mmeber Service Employees International Union, won the votes of delegates representing 56 percent of the 13 million members of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. Individual unions are allocated numbers of delegates in proportion to the size of their membership, so that small unions have just one delegate and the largest have more than 20.
 Mr. Sweeney defeated Thomas R. Donahue, 67, the federation's second highest ranking officer as secretary-treasurer for 16 years and president since August, when Lane Kirkland retired rather than face a Sweeney-led revok against him.
 With the announcement of the results in the convention hall of the New York Sheraton hotel, a man who openly accused the union movement of sliding toward irrelevance was handed Mr. Donahue's gavel, marking an immediate transition of power and the end of the Kirkland regime.
 With little comment beyond thanking his family, his service employees' union and the delegates, Mr. Sweeney then won the unanimous approval of the creation of a new office, executive vice prsident, which the Donahue forces had fought, and the unanimous election of his candidate, Linda Chavez-Thompson, 50, a vice president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
 Ms. Chavez-Thompson joins the other victor on the Sweeney slate, Richard L. Trumka, 45, president of United Mine Workers union. All three members of the new leadership mark an emphatic shift back to the labor movement's militant roots, with promises to blockade the economy and go to jail in promoting the interests of workers, especially those at the bottom of the wage scale.
 In nominating Mr. Sweeney, George J. Kourpias, president of the 448,000-member machinists union, spoke of a "humble and decent man, more a listener than a talker," who "understands there are times when you have to block bridges" and "who will put the movement back into the labor movement." The service employees' organization that Mr. Sweeney led for the last 15 years is one of the few unions that have grown throughout organized labor's decades of decline.
 After the election, Stephen P. Yokich, the new president of the United Automobile Workers, said: "This is the first time in 20 years there's excitement. I heard someone say we have in defend the middel class. Well, that's right. But we've got to defend from the middle class on down."
 Dally Willis, an official of the Communications Workers of America form Austin, said some bitterness over the election remained in the hall. But he said, "I'm just thinking about the job we have to do - go out and fight for workers."
 It was hard to find skepticism among women, who make up a third of all union members, and blacks, who make up a fifth, about the opportunities promised them by an institution that had become one of the nation's few prominent bastions of white male leadership.
 In negotiations between the Donahue and Sweeney sides that continued until early this morning the federation established a new policy making executive council of 54 mostly union president, but including 15 women and minorities, or 27 percent of the total. It succeeds a 35-member council with 6 women and minorities, or 17 percent of the total.
 "If they're not serious, they're getting serious," said Tony Hill, who si black and secretary-treasurer of the federation's Florida affiliate. Bernard Moore, a black New York staff member of Mr. Sweeney's union, said: "He believes in it. His heart is in it.
 Marjorie Taylor, a black delegate from a service employees' local in Baltimore, said, "John Sweeney personally gave me a fair start." He later moved heronto his union's board.
 Jennifer Trudeau, a white woman who is president of an operating engineers local in Jackson, Mich., said, "They're realized that women are part of the labor movement."
 Creating the new council was a feat of intense negotiations to solve two problems: accommodating unions that supported Mr. Donahue, many of them small, and broadening the mix of the membership. Mr. Donahue entered the convention proposing a council of all the federation's 78 union presidents, plus three top officers of the federation.
 Mr. Sweeney wanted to expand the membership to just 45, which would have meant adding unions supporting him, as weel as some women and minorities, who would not have been union leaders.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Using Creative Accounting to Reduce the Federal Deficit

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
WHEN Congress sells an oilfield, should the proceeds count toward reducing the budget deficit? To most economists, such a move is "pure window dressing." in the words of William D. Nordhaus of Yale University.
 Window dressing or not, Washington's latest foray into creative accounting does offer an excuse to examine how far the practice of deficit reduction has drifted from the theory. What started as an effort to increase national savings and investment is now a cause leacking any clear economic rationale.
 To cover budget deficits, Washington routinely sells Government bonds. To cover the deficit over the next few years, members of both political parties have decided to throw in some tangible assets: oil reserves, power plants in Alaska, the air rights to Union Station in Washington. What is the difference between selling bonds and selling of fields?
 None, by the reckoning of economists. Selling either reduces the private savings available for private investment in, say, factories or housing.
 Most elected officials presumably understand this. Even if they do not, they can read the law: order 1987 amendments to the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction act, Congress explicity prohibited the "scoring" - counting - of asset sales as a deficit reducer. Why, then, the new enthusiasm for legislating a few dozen exceptions?
 For some, it seems a golden opportunity to get the government out of businesses in which is has no business. Selling off the Elk Hills Naval Petroleum Reserve in California certainly fits this category. For others, it is a way of locking in constituents' Government perks that may be threatened by future administrations. The sale of hydroelectric dams and irrigation systems at bargain-basement prices to local cooperatives belongs here. For yet others, it is a way of getting past powerful lobbies. Auctioning the oil right in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a sale long fought by environmental groups, fits here.
 But for many - including President Clinton - it is a means of delivering on promises to balance the budget with the least political pain: every dollar "earned" from selling Government assets is one less dollar that has to be cut from Medicare or highway repairs.
 So what else is new? Washington ussually makes policy with generous helpings of indirection. If the goal - maintaining the monentum toward a balanced budget - is a worthy one, why quibble over a few political compromises along the way?
 Robert Eisner, an economist at Northwestern University and a former president of the American economic Assoication, does not think the goal is espeically worthy. Fire sales of assets, he says, "are just one terrible consequence of budget-balancing paranoia." And while Mr. Eisner's convictions on the subject are unusually strong his contention that deficit reduction is no longer anchored in good economics does touch a nerve.
 The point of deficit reduction, most economists agree, is to reduce consumption to make resources - human and physical - available for investment. But the Government budget makes no distinction between investment and consumption. Nor, if Congress has its way, will it distinguish between revenues gained by reducing private consumption and revenues gained by selling productive assets. As a result, the current exercise of budget-balancing may reduce investment or increase it, depending on the composition of the revenues raised and the expenditures reduced.
 The only way to clarify the consequences would be to keep a separate set of books for capital spending. By this reckoning, a balanced budget would be one in which any additions to Government-financed assets like buildings and airplanes.
 And why doesn't the Government keep its books this way? In part, the reasons are that "cash flow" accounting is the way it has always been done and that capital accounting would create ways of cloaking deficit spending. Rudolph G. Penner, an economist at the Barents Group and a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, worries that they gray area between consumption and intangible investment in health and education will be an invitation to expand the definition of investment. "How would the Clinton Administration count children's vaccinations?" he asks.
 It is undeniably true that the possiblities for fudging the books would rise: simply changing the rate at which the Air Force depreciated F-16 fighters or estimated the value of its real estate could change the deficit by $5 billion in a single year. But most state and local governments already use capital budgets, so there is plenty of experience to discipline the process.
 In any case, the clear and present danger of using asset sales to balance the budget and the subtler folly of failing to distinguish between cuts in Government spending and investment suggest that the current accounting system is fatally flawed. "The whole point is to know what you are actually doing." Mr. Nordhaus argues.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germany's Central Bank Moves Spark Little Change in Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Conflicting signals from Germany's central bank confused currency traders yesterday, leaving the dollar little changed.
 
 The president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, "has been making comments left, right and center," said Chris Iggo, an international economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "It seems the Bundesbank is trying to contain some of the moves that happened this week."
 On Monday, Mr. Tietmeyer made comments that the market interpreted to mean that a strong mark was best for Europe, further leaving in doubt whether Germany would join the rest of Europe in a single currency by 1999.
 His remarks also stirred suspicions that Germany might not intervene in the markets on the dollar's behalf as it had this spring. The suspicions led the mark higher. On Tuesday, Mr. Tietmeyer apparently indicated that the Bundesbank might buy dollars.
 But such central bank intervention failed to materialize, and yesterday Mr. Tietmeyer said that cooperation between leading central banks could take several forms, not just inervention.
 In addition, he called recent moves in foreign exchange exaggerated and not reflective of fundamentals.
 "There's not much else going on, so the market is focusing on these views," Mr. Iggo of Chase Manhattan said. "But you have to question how much they are prepared to do. "It's just verbalizing at the moment."
 In New York late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.3923 marks from 1.3944 marks on Tuesday and to 1.1326 Swiss francs from 1.1364 Swiss francs. The British pound edged up to $1.5785 from $1.5784.
 The dollar rose to 101.23 Japanese yen from 100.51 yen. In traditing between the mark and the yen, speculative investors sold the yen, helping the odllar's rise.
 Yesterday, currency traders were also watching several political developments in Europe.
 The Italian Government of Prime Minister Lamberto Dini may collapse today if a no-confidence vote succeeds, which would throw the lira into further turnmoil.
 In Spain, the 1996 budget was voted down yesterday, hurting the peseta and helping the mark.
 In other currency trading the Canadian dollar was fairly stable after seesawing the last several sessions over the possiblity of a separatist vote in Quebec succeeding Monday.
 Traders may be beginning to square their positions ahead of the vote, analysts said. In New York, the Canadian dollar was at 73.03 United States cents yesterday, down slightly from 73.13 cents on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Market Place

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
HISTORY never repeats itself. But that doesn't stop people from looking for historical patterns.
 
 One of the exhibits now being passed around by the dwindling number of stock market bears is the accompanying chart, which shows what happened to the Dow jones industrial average from February 1918 through 1934, and the Nasdaq composite average from February 1984 through the end of last month. The advances are some-what similar: 327 percent for the Dow through September 1927 and 313 percent for the Nasdaq through last month.
 The chart is based on one put together by Walter E. Stone, a Boston technical analyst whose publication, Long-Term Technical Trends, has a following among some institutional investors. He believes a sharp plunge in prices will come.
 Comparing the Dow to the Nasdaq may seem to be a stretch, but the Dow back in the 1920's was not as stodgy an index as it is now. It included Radio Corporation, which could be viewed as the Microsoft of that era. The Nasdaq index has been an especially strong index this year because of its technology components.
 Mr. Stone argues that the widespread belief that stocks will rise, year after year, at about a 10 percent rate "has produced a mutual fund mania that has created a tremendous speculative bubble in the U.S. stock market."
 "Since we are all inside the bubble, it is difficult to appreciate its true scope," he said "Yet, based on our studies, we believe it will ultimately take its place in the financial history books along with the Tulip Mania and the South Sea Bubble."
 Chart comparisons are, of course, a risky business. After the 1987 crash, a number of charts appeared comparing 1967 to 1929. The aftermath has been quite different.
 Still, there is no doubt that this market has its speculative elements. And for those how think past is prologue, it does look a little alarming.

HEADLINE: September Home Sales Reached Highest Rate in Nearly 2 Years

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes jumped to the highest level in 20 months in September as buyers took advantage of falling mortgage rates, a real estate group said today.
 
 Sales of previously owned homes rose seven-tenths of 1 percent - the fifth consecutive monthly increase - to an annual rate of 4.15 million units from a rate of 4.12 million units in August, the group, the National Association of Realtors, said.
 The rate was the highest since annualized sales of 4.17 million units in January 1994, the association said. It stood 7 percent above the rate a year earlier as prices edged back down after rising in August.
 Declining mortgage rates spurred most of the buying, economists said, adding that housing should continue to bolster the economy as rates were likely to remain low.
 "In view of the recent further declines in mortgage rates, we should expect additional gains in home sales in the fourth quarter," said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at the First National Bank of Chicago.
 Regionally, sales rose in the Northeast and Midwest but declined in the South and West.
 "Even though the market is doing well, it is a case where buyers are still demanding some pricing descipline," said Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation.
 The median price of an existing home fell to $115,200 in September from $117,600 in August, the real estate agents' group said.
 Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages fell to 7.64 percent in August and 8.64 percent a year ago, the group said.
 The rebound in housing after sluggishness last spring is spilling over into purchases of furniture, appliances and other furnishings, economists said. It contributed about half a percentage point to economic growth in the third quarter, some analysis estimated. The Government's first report on third-quarter economic growth will be released on Friday.
 "I think the big implication of the existing home sales is more toward consumer spending on durables because there are a lot of things that go into houses like appliances, carpeting and furniture," said William Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. "It basically points to an economy that should be probably a little but stronger than what people expect in the third and fourth quarters."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

House Passes Budget Bill To Balance the Budget
The House approved the foundation of the Republican revolution: a broad-ranging bill that would balance the budget in seven years, cut some taxes and diminish the Federal Government's role.
President Clinton has vowed to veto the bill, so it will be weeks before it is known how many of its elements will become law. [Page A1.]
 
Stocks Tumble in Nervous Day
The Dow Jones industrials fell 49.86 points, and are down 90 points for the week, at 4,703.82, with financial stocks leading the slide.[D8.]
Buying of equity mutual funds has apparently slowed a bit, though overall demand for mutual funds remains strong. [D8.]
 
Kmart Worries Investors
The abrupt departure of a senior executive at Kmart left many investors worried that the discount retailer is in disarray just as it is entering the critical Christmas season. Kmart said that Charles Chinni, an executive vice president, had resigned; one retailing industry expert said Mr. Chinni had been forced out. [D4.]
 
Digital Luring I.B.M. Official
Digital Equipment has reportedly hired Bruce Claflin, a veteran I.B.M. executive who worked on the Thinkpad line, to run its money-losing personal computer division. [D4.]
 
Durable-Goods Orders Jump
Durable-goods orders jumped to a record in September, on strong demand for commercial aircraft. Total orders were up 3 percent, after a 5.1 percent surge in August. [D8.]
 
Saudis Order $6 Billion in Planes
Saudi Arabia ordered 28 jets from Boeing for $4 billion and 33 aircraft from McDonnell Douglas for $2 billion. The order has been in the works since early last year, but the Saudis delayed it because of weak oil revenue. [D4.]
 
Former Lazard Partner Indicted
Mark S. Ferber, a former Lazard Freres partner who was once a powerful municipal finance banker, was indicted on 63 counts in connection with what the Government contends was a scheme to defraud clients. Lazard and Merrill Lynch agreed to pay $20 million to settle related claims. [D2.]
 
Manville Selling Paper Stake
Manville agreed to sell its stake in the paper company, Riverwood, to an investment group for $2.7 billion. Manville also proposed a restructuring of the complicated bankruptcy that settled its asbestos problems. [D6.]
 
Income Gap Worse in U.S.
The gap between rich and poor was wider in the United States during the 1980's than in any other large industrialized country, according to a study for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. [D2.]
 
Leadership Shift at Tandem
Tandem Computers reported a plunge in earnings and realigned its management to improve operations. [D4.]
 
American General Stock Skids
American General, the insurer whose stock has skidded this week, bought up some shares and named a new chief executive. [D7.]
 
Grant Hill Succeeds Off-Court
Grant Hill, the Detroit Pistons guard, has helped Fila broaden its sales in the competitive market of athletic shoes and clothing. Now it is introducing some stylishly low-key television and print advertisements. Hill shoes are said to be the best-selling since Nike's Air Jordans. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
