HEADLINE: New York City Is to Lose Jobs in Pataki Transfer

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Pataki administration is preparing to transfer several hundred state workers from New York City to the Binghamton area, state officials said today.
The move would mark the third time this year that the Republican administration has announced plans to shift state jobs from predominantly Democratic legislative districts to heavily Republican ones. Word of the latest move drew criticism from Democrats and state labor unions. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki is expected to announce a group of job transfers, about 1,350 in all, in a news conference outside Binghamton on Friday. The workers will move from several state-government offices, including some in New York City. They will be transferred to a former I.B.M. office building in Glendale, about 180 miles northwest of Manhattan.
It was not clear today how many of those jobs would come out of New York City. Pataki administration officials have said in the past that about 1,050 of the transfers would be from offices in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Today, they said the number would be signficantly less than that, though they gave no figures.
Administration officials contend that the move will save money by allowing the state to consolidate several operations under one roof.
But Democratic legislative leaders attacked the move as "geographic patronage" intended to bolster the economies of Republican regions at the expense of Democratic areas.
"This is just one more chapter in the shell game they are playing, all under the heading of geographic patronage," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, whose lower Manhattan district could lose as many as 200 of the jobs. "The way to grow the economy is to grow private-sector jobs. You don't grow the economy by taking jobs from one region and moving them to another."
Mr. Silver and Assemblywoman Eileen C. Dugan, whose Brooklyn district is expected to lose most of the jobs, sent a letter today to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani imploring him to fight the transfer. "New York City has enough experience fighting to retain jobs from questionable economic development practices of neighboring states," it said. "Now the state administration is actually joining New Jersey, Connecticut and others to take jobs from the city."
But Robert J. Bellafiore, Mr. Pataki's press secretary, said the move would save the state millions of dollars by consolidating computer operations spread over several sites. "Surely, the Speaker of the Assembly is not suggesting that we should have inefficient, expensive government that doesn't perform for the people of our state."
The administration has already announced two other impending transfers of state jobs from a Democratic stronghold, Albany, to Republican areas. Albany is the only county outside New York City that voted against Mr. Pataki in 1994.
In September, Mr. Pataki said the state will move 800 workers from Albany to a former I.B.M. building in Kingston that the state plans to buy. Fleet Bank also agreed to move 2,650 part-time and 500 full-time employees who process tax returns for the state from Albany to the Kingston site. Kingston is represented by Republicans in both houses of the Legislature.
Several weeks ago, the administration said it would transfer 630 workers from Albany to Troy. Troy is part of the district represented by the state's second most powerful Republican: the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno.
Officials with state labor unions joined with the Democrats lawmakers in branding the planned job transfers a political payoff for loyal Republican areas. "It looks pretty obvious to us to see what they are doing," said Stanley Hornak, a spokesman for the Civil Service Employees Association, which represents 95,000 state workers. "We don't think state workers should be pawns in a political game."

NEW YORK CITY IN AGREEMENT ON WATER
After decades of conflict between New York City and the upstate communities that supply its water, the city has agreed to spend $1 billion to preserve the quality of its water while spurring economic growth in the towns and villages around its 19 reservoirs. [Page A1.]
 
EL SALVADOR OFFERS AID TO ITS REFUGEES 
 The Republic of El Salvador has begun offering a highly unusual service to its refugees: free help in filing claims for political asylum based on El Salvador's own history of persecution. Critics say its real goal is to insure that the flow of money home continues. [A1.]
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
SQUATTERS GIVEN A REPRIEVE
In yet another setback to efforts to pry defiant squatters out of city-owned buildings, a State Supreme Court justice ruled that they could stay put while he considered whether they had the right to remain. [B3.]
 
SURVIVOR OF MASSACRE TESTIFIES
Ann Figueroa is the sole survivor of the Queens killings that came to be known as the College Point massacre, in which six people held hostage were shot in January. In a courtroom crowded with friends of the deceased, Ms. Figueroa told her story. [B8.]
 
SOME SEX SHOPS VOW FIGHT ON ZONING
A City Council decision that drastically restricts the number of neighborhoods open to sex-related businesses has left many pornography merchants with few options. [B8.]
 
MAYOR'S APPROVAL RATE DOWN, POLL SAYS

HEADLINE: Strong Profits Fail to Help Stock Market

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
American corporations are generally reporting better-than-expected profits for the third quarter, continuing a successful string that goes back two and a half years.
But this has not been enough to prevent nervous investors from sending stocks down sharply this week. Some have apparently seized on a few signs of consumer weakness -- notably an indication that more people are having trouble paying their bills. And others could be worried that while earnings are up, the pace of growth slowed in the third quarter and is expected to slow further in the last three months of the year. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average yesterday fell 49.86 points, pushing the average down more than 90 points for the week, with financial stocks leading the way. [Page D8.] Much of the nervousness came from one earnings report, from a home mortgage lender called the Money Store. It reported higher profits, but investors seized on the fact that the number of overdue loans was up sharply. Shares in the Money Store are down 28 percent since the report came out on Wednesday.
Over all, corporate earnings in the third quarter jumped almost 17 percent, the 10th straight quarter in which earnings exceeded expectations and the 14th quarter of double-digit growth in per-share earnings for the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
But investors may focus more on the spottier performance during the summer quarter. Perhaps more important, the rate of profit growth at many of the nation's largest companies slowed significantly from the second quarter, despite what seems to have been a rebound in economic growth.
Worries about the near-term sustainability in the stock market's advance may also help explain an apparent slowing in October sales of mutual funds that invest primarily in stocks. The slowdown followed a three-month runup that made the third quarter the strongest in the history of the mutual fund industry. [Page D8.]
"In the aggregate, third-quarter profits are good," said Thomas McManus, an investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "Some companies continue to provide big, positive surprises. But more companies are starting to trip over the earnings bar than previously. At this time of the year, that raises caution among portfolio managers."
All of the returns are not yet in. But as the list of reporting companies lengthens, it is apparent that the third quarter was a difficult one for cyclical industries like automobile manufacturers and makers of home furnishings, as well as producers of basic materials like paper and steel.
But despite a notable stumble by the International Business Machines Corporation, profits at most other high-flying technology companies stayed high. A fairly benign interest rate environment helped financial service companies. Oil companies posted very strong gains. And an exceptionally warm summer pushed up profits at utilities.
According to Zacks Investment Research, a Chicago-based company that tracks earnings estimates of about 2,500 analysts, earnings at the companies that make up the S.& P. 500 index as of yesterday were up 16.8 percent from last year's third quarter.
That is a strong gain, but it nevertheless represents a slowdown from profit growth in both the first and second quarters, when earnings at the S.& P. 500 companies rose by 24 percent and 23.6 percent, respectively. Ben Zacks, an executive vice president at the research company, said analysts expected earnings growth to slow further in the fourth quarter, to an estimated 13.7 percent. "This is what has everybody concerned," he said.
Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said: "I think the problem starts in the fourth quarter. We are looking for sort of a weak profit level in 1996." In his view, the chances that the economy may fall into recession are about "five in seven," he said.
Still, the reported results have exceeded the expectations of Wall Street analysts, the professionals whose quarterly earnings forecasts can influence the tone of the stock market. The 16.8 percent increase is a full percentage point higher than expected before the reports started to roll in.
Of the roughly 1,950 companies that have reported earnings since the end of September, results at 53.5 percent of them have exceeded expectations, Mr. Zacks said, while 33 percent are below estimate. The 10 consecutive quarters of pleasant surprises is the longest string since 1985, when Zacks began tracking earnings estimates.
As of yesterday, about two-thirds of all companies operating on a calendar year, and roughly 80 percent of those in the S.& P. 500 index, have reported their results for the third quarter.
While an earnings slowdown may furrow some brows, it comes as no surprise. Indeed, given the length of the current expansion, economists and analysts have been impressed with the fact that corporate profits have stayed so strong for so long. As a percentage of gross domestic product, corporate profits are the highest they have been in more than two decades.
"At this point in the business cycle, you would expect profit growth to slow," said Gordon Richards, chief economist at the National Association of Manufacturers in Washington. "The largest gains in profitability often occur early in the cycle."
Even though a slowdown may be expected, few analysts are suggesting that profits in the fourth quarter and into next year are about to go into decline. In large measure, that is because the underlying factors that have generated such big increases over the last few years remain in place. Interest rates are relatively low, keeping a lid on borrowing costs. Wage rates are still under control. And inflation is still fairly tame.
"Profits have been this strong for this long because most of this growth is from the effectiveness of capital, which is replacing people," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University. "The tools we are putting into people's hands are better, and the returns are going to people who make the tools, not to the people who use them."
Barring a recession, or an unexpected spike in inflation or interest rates, some analysts say corporate profits could continue to grow at a healthy clip for some time, in no small measure because of a shift in attitude among executives about their importance.
"It used to be that you looked at the economic environment, did your budgets, and profits were what was left over," said Gale Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board. "Nowadays, profits are not just left to fate. Prolonged periods of declining profits are not acceptable. Profits will still respond to recession. But in a period that could basically be considered to be normal, you will continue to see profits grow."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Peso Dives, as Economy Treads Water

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Although Mexico's major companies posted third-quarter earnings this week that were no worse, and in some cases noticeably better, than had been expected, a spasm of uncertainty sent the peso today into its deepest slide since March. It closed here at 7.2 pesos to the dollar.
In a sign of investors' anxiety, the Mexico City stock market sank this morning along with the peso, then rebounded later in the day to close down eight-tenths of 1 percent. In the last week, the main stock index has lost nearly 7 percent. 
 The Government insists that the worst financial hardship is past, but most Mexicans have yet to feel any relief from the economic plunge that began with the devaluation of the peso in December 1994. And the relatively positive corporate results have not been positive enough to calm widespread queasiness about Mexico's underlying stability or the prospects for overall recovery.
As expected, Mexican companies that are tied to the domestic market or that depend on Government contracts showed dismal results, bBut several leading export-oriented companies were able to exploit thriving markets abroad for this country's now-inexpensive goods. Others lifted their earnings by slashing costs and pushing out local competitors.
"Mexican companies are pretty much holding their own," said Christopher Taylor, an analyst with Interacciones Global Inc., a Mexican broker based in New York. "And since everybody was expecting a really poor third quarter, a little bad news amounts to good news."
On Tuesday, Telefonos de Mexico, the nation's phone monopoly and the stock market's benchmark issue, reported an 11 percent decline in quarterly earnings, mainly because of a lag in Government-fixed prices for telephone service. The stock fell again today, with Telmex's American depository receipts closing in New York at $26.625. down $1.375, on trading of more than 11 million shares.
The construction giant, Grupo Tribasa, which has a big chunk of its business in building highways, reported a 64 percent slide in earnings.
In banking, an industry badly weakened by the devaluation, Banca Serfin reported a drop of 69 percent compared with the third quarter of last year, but Serfin explained that it had used virtually all its third-quarter income to reinforce its reserves.
The glass and container powerhouse Vitro S.A. reported an 18 percent earnings decline in the third quarter, but a 250 percent increase in the first nine months of this year. Vitro's export sales have risen by 22 percent since January.
The steel and petrochemical conglomerate Alfa increased its exports 15 percent in the third quarter, bringing it a 138 percent earnings gain in the first nine months of 1995.
Another surprise came from the auto parts and petrochemical manufacturer Desc, which had a 12 percent increase in operating income in the quarter. Grupo Industrial Maseca, which mills three-quarters of the flour for corn tortillas, and Tamsa, a steel producer, also had modestly favorable quarters.
Government officials argue with increasing conviction that recovery has begun, and that steady growth can be expected starting early in 1996.
"The crisis has touched bottom," Commerce Secretary Herminio Blanco told a group of textile executives on Wednesday. But industry leaders made it clear to Mr. Blanco that they did not share his optimism.
"Most of our companies are struggling to survive amid a collapse of the internal market, fiscal policies that don't encourage productive investment, high costs and tight credit," retorted Victor Manuel Diaz Romero, president of the national industrial association, in a speech following Mr. Blanco's.
Indeed, the economic data could support either view. On the negative side, inflation crept up by 1.1 percent in the first two weeks of this month, for an annual rate of 30 percent, considerably higher than Government projections for the year. To cope with the peso's decline, officials raised interest rates by two percentage points, to 42 percent, on Government securities, making scarce business credit even more expensive.
Yet one indicator that seemed to bolster the Government's optimistic view was a sharp increase in the number of workers enrolling in the Social Security program, a sign that they have started new jobs. More than 28,000 new employees registered with the Government program in the first two weeks of October, compared with less than 2,000 last month.
Foreign investors, Mexican businessmen and everyday workers remain wary, still nursing wounds from the peso debacle.
"The confidence in Mexico has been fragile, and the last couple of weeks have weakened it further," said Jay Pelosky, a Latin America strategist with Morgan, Stanley. He predicted that the skepticism would prevail until at least December, the first anniversary of the devaluation.

HEADLINE: S.&P. Lifts Rating Of Some G.M. Debt

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Standard & Poor's Corporation increased its rating on the General Motors Corporation's senior debt yesterday, citing the auto maker's higher profits, as well as G.M.'s efforts to improve its product line, cut costs and reduce its unfinanced pension liabilities.
G.M.'s rating was raised one notch, to "A-," putting G.M.'s debt at the same level as the Chrysler Corporation's and two notches below the Ford Motor Company's senior debt, which is rated "A+." 
 "Ongoing cost-cutting actions and initiatives to improve product offerings, and the company's efforts to eliminate its unfunded pension liability have reduced G.M.'s vulnerability to future downturns in the U.S. automotive industry," S.& P. said.
G.M. and its units have about $78 billion of debt outstanding.
In the last two years, G.M. cut costs and returned to profitability after posting losses during the recession in the early 1990's. At the same time, it added to its United States pension funds, contributing $18 billion since the end of 1993.
As a result, "even in a severe downturn, the staggering losses generated during the past recession are unlikely to recur," S.& P. said.
In the third quarter, G.M.'s profits rose by 16 percent, to $642 million -- well above expectations -- as the company substantially trimmed its losses in its North American business and increased its United States market share.
The credit rating company raised its rating on the senior debt of G.M. and its General Motors Acceptance Corporation and Hughes Electronics Corporation units to "A-" from "BBB+." It bolstered the rating on G.M.'s preferred stock to "BBB+" from "BBB," and it affirmed its "A-2" rating on GMAC's and Hughes's commercial paper.
The "A" senior debt rating and "A-1" commercial paper rating on the debt of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, G.M.'s computer services unit, remain under review for a possible upgrade, S.& P. said.

HEADLINE: Widest Gap in Incomes? Research Points to U.S.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The income gap between rich and poor was wider in the United States during the 1980's than in any other large industrialized country, according to the most comprehensive international study ever released on income distribution.
Britain, France, Italy and Ireland all had highly paid elites, but the gap between high-paid and low-paid Americans was wider in the mid-1980's than in these countries or in a dozen others included in the study, which was commissioned by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group that aims to coordinate the economic policies of the world's 25 richest nations. 
 The study, scheduled for release on Friday here and in Paris, suggests that the relatively high levels of inequality in the United States persisted into the early 1990's.
Income inequality has become a politically charged topic in recent years. Previous studies, contested by some conservative economists, suggested that the income gap grew in the 1980's.
The new study is considerably more comprehensive than earlier attempts and addresses many criticisms aimed at them. It also lays out a new methodology for analyzing income inequality. The new method has been reviewed by technical experts in more than a dozen industrialized countries.
The study ranked countries in terms of disparity on the income scale. For example, an American adult who barely made it into the top 10 percent in after-tax income earned 5.9 times as much in 1987 as someone who just fell into the bottom 10 percent, according to the study. The ratio in Finland, which had the least inequality, was 2.59.
Inequality rose markedly in the United States, Japan, Australia and Britain, and showed modest rises in five European countries during the 1980's, the study found. But inequality was little changed in five other European countries and Canada, and actually fell in Italy and Portugal. A shortage of reliable data, though, makes it difficult to establish rankings before the mid-1980's.
The rankings depended partly on the criteria. The broadest measure of after-tax income showed that the United States had the highest level of inequality between the top 10 percent and bottom 10 percent of individuals by incomes. But income was slightly more concentrated in the top 5 percent of families in Ireland than in the United States, and income was slightly more concentrated in Ireland when interest payments, dividends and other nonwage income was excluded.
Data for some nations in the study became public last spring, but not the detailed analysis and methodology seen in the full document.
The study avoids conclusions about the causes of the widening income gap, and makes no recommendations on what, if anything, should be done about it. Economists have offered many theories for the growing inequality, including the spread of computers, cutbacks in welfare programs and growing trade with low-wage countries.
The O.E.C.D., leery of political controversy, added a disclaimer to the book-length study, stating that it represented the views of the authors and not necessarily those of the international agency.
Many conservatives have argued that high levels of income inequality may not be bad if the rich invest their savings productively, contributing to faster economic growth.
"The existence of income differences does not necessarily have policy implications," the study concludes. "The importance of the results for policy depend on social judgments, including the trade-off between the level of income and its distribution."
Yet the results seem likely to provoke considerable controversy, as the Clinton Administration and Democrats in Congress have spent the last few weeks accusing Republicans of trying to cut welfare to help finance tax cuts for the wealthy.
Douglas J. Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group, said that while income inequality appeared to be rising in Europe and the United States, comparisons between countries with different economic systems were tricky, even with detailed data.
He also questioned the study's relevance to the current debate on the Federal budget, saying a breakdown of the American family and a rise in the number of unwed mothers had produced more poverty and a wider distribution of income.
Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, took the opposite tack when the report was described to him. "This is not the time to exacerbate the inequalities that may be arising from a whole variety of sources," he said, "and that is precisely what the House Republican budget and Senate Republican budget are doing," he said.
The new study was commissioned in 1991. It was written by three economists using data from the Luxembourg Income Study, a nonprofit group based in Walferdange, Luxembourg, that is financed by the National Science Foundation of the United States and its counterparts in almost two dozen other countries.
The O.E.C.D. circulated the study for extensive review for more than two years by organization officials and economic officials from most of its 25 member governments, who suggested some changes in the way their countries' figures were calculated. The final objections from the Governments of Australia and Ireland, which the study found to have fairly high levels of inequality, were addressed last spring, said a person involved in the study who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The economists who wrote the study are Timothy M. Smeeding, the director of the Luxembourg Income Study; Lee Rainwater, the research director, and Anthony B. Atkinson, the warden at Nuffield College at Oxford University in England.
In defining income, the study included wages, salaries, dividends, interest and private cash transfers like child support and pensions, as well as Government transfers like Social Security. It also included Government benefits like food stamps that are nearly convertible into cash, and took taxes into account.
But it excluded health benefits, like private health insurance, Medicaid and Medicare, as well as free or nearly free Government-provided health care in Europe. And it excluded large investment gains, like those from the sale of a house or stock. While some United States measures include these gains, most foreign countries do not.


GRAPHIC: After four years of analysis, study for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has concluded that the gap between the incomes of the rich and poor is wider in the United States than in 15 other industrial countries. The study used data supplied by governments from various years in the 1980's.
Graph: "Measuring the Gap"
 The authors calculated a median income per person after taxes for each country, adjusted for differences in family size. Then they examined the incomes of rich people at the 90th percentile and poor people at the 10th percential on the income scale -- that is, people whose income exceeded that of precisely 90 percent of their compatriots or precisely 10 percent -- and compared them with the median. The further apart the rich and poor incomes were in percentage terms, the wider the gap.
 Graph charts results of the analysis. (Source: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development)

HEADLINE: RESEVOIR TOWNS AND NEW YORK CITY REACH AGREEMENT

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
After decades of conflict between New York City and the upstate communities that supply its water, the city has agreed to spend $1 billion during the next five years to preserve the quality of its water while spurring economic growth in the towns and villages around its 19 reservoirs.
The deal, brokered by Gov. George E. Pataki and expected to be announced next week, is an alternative to a far more expensive option: building a filtration plant, costing from $4 billion to $8 billion, to keep the water clean. 
 Negotiations were prompted by increasing development and pollution in the hills and valleys draining into the reservoirs. With New York City owning less than 4 percent of the land in its watersheds, Federal officials had threatened to order filtration this year if no plan were developed to protect the water.
Although a few issues remain to be worked out, participants in the talks expressed confidence that they did not threaten the agreement.
Under the plan, the city would upgrade and build sewage treatment plants in the reservoir watersheds, sharply increase monitoring of pollution, and initiate a series of environmental and economic programs to keep the water supply clean without overburdening local economies.
In return, the watershed communities would drop several lawsuits against New York City and agree to abide by a new package of watershed rules, the first revision of the city's water-protection regulations since 1953.
The city's early efforts to write stricter watershed rules were attacked by local communities, which felt their authority was being usurped and their hopes for economic development were being undermined. Given the cost of a filtration plant, Mr. Pataki, who as a state senator represented a portion of the watershed, was pressed to balance the interests of the 200,000 watershed residents against those of the nine million people in New York City and Westchester and Putnam counties who consume the water.
"Governor Pataki was in a unique position to do what he did," one participant in the talks said. "He was able to get the trust of local governments and reach out to environmentalists."
The costs of the program are expected to be borne by the users of the water, probably through a rate increase. But city officials declined to say how much water rates might rise, or if some other financing arrangement was being considered.
In a flurry of daytime, nighttime and weekend meetings during the last two weeks, negotiators representing interests as disparate as Delaware County dairy farmers, the Federal Government and Mayor Rudolph A. Giuliani attacked a final list of issues and whittled it down to a few remaining points of contention, participants say. The seven-month negotiating process was largely spurred by Michael C. Finnegan, Mr. Pataki's counsel.
One person involved in the talks remarked: "I was convinced as recently as two weeks ago that we'd end up with a bunch of unhappy people agreeing to a package of less than optimum alternatives. But the fact is, there's enough stuff in this agreement that everybody can find something to be pleased about."
Ceremonies were being planned in New York City and in the watershed areas to mark what would be the first broad-based accord over how to preserve New York City's century-old system for capturing more than a billion gallons of water a day in the hills of the Catskills and in the Delaware and Hudson Valleys.
But several participants said that, regardless of any announcement, putting a final accord into practice will entail years of work and potential setbacks.
The expected $1 billion agreement will be four-pronged, participants in the talks said, focusing on these areas:
*Increased investment by New York City in infrastructure within the watersheds, including repairing faulty sewage treatment plants, many of which are city owned and operated, and improving maintenance of city-owned bridges and roads, which local communities had for decades complained were being allowed to decay.
*An economic partnership in which money would flow from New York City to upstate towns and villages to offset economic burdens created by watershed regulations.
*City land purchases that would create a buffer to development or preserve wetlands. Several participants in the talks said New York City agreed to allow local communities to have some say over which parcels are bought.
*A revised package of watershed rules and regulations.
Several negotiators said the plan would involve experiments with new methods for protecting water quality, but with sufficient monitoring that if a novel idea was shown to be failing, more stringent rules could be enacted. Negotiators, sworn to secrecy by the Governor's office, would not provide details.
Several people said that an existing program, in which dairy farmers are cutting the flow of manure from pastures and barnyards in unorthodox ways, is an example of what could take place in other spheres.
Environmentalists, who were invited into some of the closed sessions only in the last couple of months, are apparently divided on whether the new rules are adequate to insure that contaminants are kept out of the water supply.
But one member of a private environmental group involved in recent sessions hailed the land-acquisition plan, saying: "It shows respect for local concerns. Condemnation is not going to be used. Taxes are going to be paid. It's a very civilized, almost revolutionary approach."
Many participants in the talks, including city and state officials, said the intensive program for monitoring pollution in the farthest reaches of the watersheds would set a national standard. Currently, most monitoring of water quality takes place once the water is already on its way to New York City.
Negotiators for the Coalition of Watershed Towns, which was formed out of the fiery debate that raged after New York City first proposed watershed rules five years ago, said they were pleased to see an imminent end to the conflict.
The uncertainty over watershed rules had depressed business and real estate activity in the watersheds west of the Hudson River, several upstate negotiators said.
One interested party outside the negotiations seemed to sum up their feelings. Raymond M. Christensen, Chairman of the Delaware County Board of Supervisors, said, "For five years there's been a cloud hanging over Delaware County. Maybe soon we'll see some sunshine."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Tumbles After Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, on a stronger-than-expected Government report of durable goods orders in September, and continuing concern about the effects of drawn-out budget negotiations.
The traders' underlying fear was that a delay in a budget accord would also stall an expected cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve next month, maybe even endanger the chance of a cut at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in December. Few in the market are worried that the Government will default on its debt if an accord is not reached in time. 
 Donald E. Maude, chief fixed-income strategist at Scotia McLeod U.S.A. Inc., predicted that the yield on the Treasury's long bond could fall as low as 6 to 6.25 percent after a budget accord is achieved.
The current issue of the 30-year bond fell 1 1/32 to a price of 106 14/32 to yield 6.39 percent, up from 6.32 percent on Wednesday. It meant that bondholders lost more than $10 for each $1,000 of bonds held.
Orders for goods intended to last at least three years rose 3 percent in September; in contrast, economists were expecting a decline of four-tenths of a percent. Excluding military items, orders rose 3.1 percent; a rise of two-tenths of a percent was expected.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York, a research and analysis firm, said yesterday's selloff could well have reflected a realization by market participants that if a budget accord was delayed long enough, it could jeopardize a rate cut by the Fed. "On top of this, the economic numbers have not been uniformly weak," he said. "After today's durables report came in on the stronger side, there may be some caution in the market ahead of Friday's advance report on third-quarter gross domestic product.
The Labor Department also reported yesterday that the number of people filing first-time unemployment claims last week held steady at 359,000; economists had expected claims to rise to 362,000. The four-week moving average, a less-volatile measure of the labor market, increased to 354,000 last week from 348,000 the previous week.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, in Columbus, Ohio, said that not much of what he heard yesterday could explain the strong drop in prices. But he did note that the volume of trading was par for a regular day.
One thought about a possible source of market weakness was the corporate debt market, which has seen a considerable amount of debt issued recently as treasurers hastened to take advantage of the low rates. Stephen W. Carter, an analyst with MCM CorporateWatch, a new-issues research firm, said that for the month of October, including yesterday, corporations sold $16.3 billion of straight and high-yield debt.
But if corporate supply and budget concerns were the bullets, it was the durable goods report that was the trigger for yesterday's selloff, one trader said. But, Mr. Donne said, "the durable number is notoriously volatile and will be adjusted."
"On balance the information in the last couple of days would indicate that some sectors are still responding to low interest rates."

HEADLINE: Salvador Helps Refugees Filing for Asylum in U.S.

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Three years after its civil war ended, the Republic of El Salvador has begun offering a highly unusual service to its refugees here: free help in filing claims for political asylum based on El Salvador's own history of persecution.
The service is part of a nationwide immigration counseling program that Salvadoran officials insist is motivated by a desire to help refugees. But critics say its real goal is to insure that the flow of money home continues -- a system of informal foreign aid nicknamed dolares pobres, or poor dollars. 
 Salvadoran immigrants, more than a million around the nation who work largely as maids, landscapers and waiters, last year sent almost $1 billion to relatives in El Salvador, according to academics and Government officials, a sum that nearly rivals the nation's export earnings.
With a mandate from El Salvador's President, Armando Calderon Sol, the Salvadoran Government has added counseling services at its consulates and opened immigration offices in San Francisco and in an unpretentious Hempstead storefront squeezed between a camping store and a beauty salon. It has also hired legal staff, set up a telephone hot line and trained its consular employees in the intricacies of United States political asylum applications.
Wary immigrant rights groups say the free advice could lead to a surreal scene -- refugees who have fled persecution turning to the very nation that drove them north with a decadelong legacy of killing and torture.
The leadership of the Government and the right-wing ruling party, Arena, has changed since the worst excesses of that period. And Mr. Calderon Sol has tried to steer a more centrist path for the party, whose founder, Roberto d'Aubuisson, was widely viewed as the organizer of death squads in the 1980's.
But the President's latest effort to reach out to almost 200,000 political refugees living in the United States since 1990 has shocked immigration lawyers.
"I think they were off their rockers when they did this," said Patrick Young, legal director for the Central American Refugee Center in Hempstead, which is just three blocks from El Salvador's new office. "The last place I'm going to send an asylum applicant is to the country that they're fleeing from. It's absolutely outrageous."
Mr. Young and other officials from the center said it appeared that the Government's office has not been attracting many clients. One employee in the office said that most visitors were curious and asking questions but that few were filling out asylum applications.
The planning for the counseling service began last year with a demand from President Sol to "do something" for Salvadoran immigrants, said El Salvador's Ambassador to the United States, Ana Cristina Sol, a distant relative of the President.
She said the President's directive came as anxiety was building among Salvadoran immigrants in California over a successful state initiative limiting services to illegal immigrants. In the meantime, she said, the Salvadoran Embassy in Washington was fielding calls from Salvadorans who complained about the difficulties of applying for asylum.
In January, she said, the embassy started offering immigration counseling. Later, it won permission from the United States Government to expand outside the consulates.
"We're helping them to stay where they want," the Ambassador said, adding that all Salvadorans were still welcome to return to their homeland. "The problem is that there is not enough work to give these people. That's the main problem. If they go to El Salvador they will not be part of the economy."
After 12 years of a civil war that ended in 1992, the Salvadoran immigrants to the United States have settled largely in metropolitan Los Angeles, Houston and Washington and on Long Island. Many fled the small country's conflict between guerrillas and the Government.
Of the more than one million immigrants, about 190,000 are eligible to apply for asylum under a temporary Federal program, which has a Jan. 31 deadline. Those who settled in the United States before 1990 are eligible to apply for asylum.
Many of these immigrants subsidize their families in El Salvador with checks averaging about $150 a month. Their relatives use the money for basic expenses like rent, school tuition or medical care. Others have invested the money, expanding small businesses like bodegas or bakeries.
Some studies show that such support makes up as much as 30 percent of family income in El Salvador, said Roxana Ulloa, a Georgetown University graduate student whose master's thesis studied a small town in eastern El Salvador that depended on cash sent through money courier offices.
"This money is the Salvadoran version of the welfare check," said Oscar Chacon, of Centro Presente, nonprofit group in Cambridge, Mass., that offers asylum counseling. "Salvadorans in the U.S. are of tremendous strategic importance to El Salvador. For every Salvadoran in the United States, there is probably a family in El Salvador getting money. This definitely works as a pressure valve that releases the steam."
It is these immigrants that El Salvador's Government is trying to reach with appeals in Spanish newspapers in New York and Los Angeles and advertisements promoting, "informacion gratis."
The windows of the Government's cramped office in Hempstead are painted with brightly colored appeals to Salvadorans to take advantage of free immigration advice. Somehow, immigrants find the office even though it lacks an official sign and bears the name of a previous tenant, Corfinge, a money courier service.
Last week, Nelson Castillo, 26, a refugee who has already applied for political asylum in the United States, entered the storefront, formally known as the Office of Legal Assistance for Salvadorans, out of curiosity. As he gazed at a portrait of El Salvador's President and a poster of the country's national hymn, he said his memories of death threats and jail were revived.
"It's not really over," said Mr. Castillo, a Hempstead resident and catering worker. "You have flashbacks that come back to you when you enter any Government agency from your country. They did a lot of things that were not good, killing people without reason."
El Salvador's Ambassador insists that refugees have nothing to fear. She said that the guerrillas have disbanded and that most of the refugees seeking asylum fled the country because of a situation that existed up to 15 years ago. "So there is no conflict with the Government," Ms. Sol said, and "they have realized that we have no political intention behind all this."
As part of the immigration process, political refugees must fill out one immigration form detailing examples of persecution or their reasons for fearing repression.
Ms. Sol said the Government's legal offices would not complete this form "because we're not qualified to do that." Instead, the Salvadoran Embassy refers refugees to a Washington-based lawyer hired by the Government who consults by phone, fills out the form and mails back the entire asylum application to the local Salvadoran office. Immigrants then sign the documents with a Government employee as a witness.
"It may be that the Salvadoran Government does not understand the ironies of what they're doing," said Lucas Guttentag, a lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union who filed a successful lawsuit seeking protected refugee status for Salvadorans. "As a general rule, it is not appropriate for a government to be involved in representing or advising or getting information from persons who are fleeing that very government."
Many immigrant groups are already offering political asylum counseling services, charging about $250 to prepare an asylum application, and embassy officials said they would also refer refugees to those agencies.
Ms. Sol said El Salvador decided to offer its own immigration counseling because "a lot of agencies closed their doors because they were having a swarm of people seeking services."
But even with an application deadline looming, most immigrant organizations that have historically served Salvadoran refugees contend that they have not been besieged. In New Jersey, New York, Massachusetts and California, agencies are actually experiencing a lull in application requests.
In Hempstead, where the local refugee center and El Salvador's new office are a short walk apart, Mr. Young of the center said requests for political asylum applications have dropped. The agency, he said, has prepared more than 4,000 such applications, drawing from a growing Salvadoran community that local groups estimate at about 100,000.
Mr. Young said he was concerned that the Government's efforts, however well meaning, could damage a refugee's chance of obtaining political asylum. He advises refugees to say away from the Salvadoran consulates and the new immigration offices.
"It could potentially compromise their case" with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, he said. "How could someone apply at the consulate, claiming persecution from the country they're fleeing from?"
"I think they're out of their mind," he added. "Go to a private lawyer or nonprofit agency. Do not go to the Salvadoran consulate. People are absolutely loony to do this."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
How to Trade With Cuba

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
American businesses eager to do business with Cuba are pushing every pressure point they can to end the U.S. embargo, except the one that might work. They refuse to use their economic influence to pressure Fidel Castro to give Cubans political and human rights.
All these businesses achieved their wealth through the American system: free enterprise with political democracy. Democratic capitalism: the combination has been the key for them and American society. 
 By itself, capitalism can operate in a dictatorship. It did in Nazi Germany, in Imperial Japan and in Saddam's Iraq. Now it is at work in China, overseen by the Communists, and in a dozen other dictatorships.
The business executives involved know this. That's why they busily seek out new markets for capitalism in dictatorships like China, like Cuba.
So some critical questions are at the heart of the push for trade with Cuba. They have been at the heart of every controversy on empowering dictatorships through American economic might.
Once they were debated openly, passionately. Now they are not even raised, not by the business community, not by academics and journalists also trying to end the embargo.
Do U.S. businesses have the moral and political right to transfer the fruits of democratic capitalism, which come from the efforts of the entire American population, workers as well as C.E.O.'s, to strengthen a dictatorship so that it can more efficiently control and persecute its own entire population?
Or do they have the obligation to try to use the lure of capitalist investment to bring some liberty to the people of the dictatorships -- who will be making for Americans any profit they take out?
On Wednesday, President Castro demonstrated at The New York Times the wit and intelligence that so entrance the hundreds of American business leaders who make the pilgrimage to Havana.
Charming -- but not charming enough to erase memory. The man sitting there committed the greatest crime any revolutionary could. He asked for and got the help of Cuba's people to destroy the Batista dictatorship. Then he brought them not freedom but another dictatorship -- fully equipped with firing squads, kangaroo courts, political prisons, intellectual and political suppression. One party, one leader, one mouth.
He uses truth and falsehood not as values in themselves but as conveniences of the moment. He said almost casually that yes, Amnesty International's figures of about 600 political prisoners in Cuba were correct but that once there were thousands.
But for his original movement to be accepted by Cubans as a revolution for freedom he had told them he was not a Communist. He lied for years, until it suited him to reveal himself as part of the international Communist political and military apparatus.
When asked at The Times whether he would agree to an opposition party or press, or a free election, steps that would lead to virtually automatic lifting of the embargo by the U.S., he told his personal truth: Never, a long, polite stick them in your ear.
But he may not be able to hold out against liberties as long as he wishes. As an effective economic weapon, the embargo began just about 1990. Until then, Moscow made up embargo losses with $5 billion in yearly economic aid plus all the arms he could eat. And only in 1992 did Washington close loopholes that allowed American subsidiaries to do $500 million in trade with Cuba.
Cuba's economy is at about 40 percent of what it was a few years ago. The idea that economic pressures do not work is a myth; they did against the Soviet Union, Rhodesia, South Africa, Iraq and Serbia.
Mr. Castro can end Cuban suffering by his own decision to agree to those freedoms he dismisses now.
This is the precise time for American business people who want to trade with Cuba -- and all who pressure Washingon to end the embargo -- to ask Mr. Castro publicly to make it possible by permitting democratic freedom to go with capitalist investment.
He will do no such thing as long as he knows Americans put pressure only on their government, not him. Even so, he may keep refusing out of fear of his own people.
But either way, American businesses will at least and at last be standing up for Cuban freedom, and for the fountainhead of America's power and their own: democracy and capitalism, in combination.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Yields Its Early Gains, Hurt by Mexican Peso Losses

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday as gains made against the German mark eroded after a selloff of the Mexican peso.
The dollar surged early in New York trading on news that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia had been taken to a hospital with heart problems for the second time in recent months. His illness, which comes a few weeks before legislative elections, compounds the political uncertainty surrounding Russia. 
 The mark, which benefits from political turmoil in other countries as a currency of refuge, does not gain from problems in Moscow because of the many ties that German businesses have to Russia. Germany is Moscow's largest European lender.
In early New York trading yesterday, the dollar gained to 1.4100 marks, on speculative buying spurred by rumors that Mr. Yeltsin had died.
But the dollar reversed course after the peso came under speculative attack, knocking it down more than 5 percent in a few hours. The Mexican and American financial systems are closely linked these days, with the North American Free Trade Agreement and the United States-led bailout of Mexico.
Yesterday's peso selling followed reports of weak Mexican corporate earnings, which suggest that the nation's economy might face slower growth along with high inflation.
Adding to panic selling were new concerns about unrest in Mexico's southern state of Chiapas after the Zapatista rebel front threatened to withdraw from peace talks.
There is also some worry about Mexico's ability to repay a $20 billion American loan after the Mexican Government this week rolled over a separate debt of $1.3 billion in short-term credit lines.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.3915 German marks from 1.3923 marks on Wednesday and to 1.1312 Swiss francs from 1.1326 francs. It edged up to 101.43 Japanese yen from 101.23 yen. The dollar rose to 7.2350 Mexican pesos from 6.7850 pesos.
The mark may have also gained against the dollar by events in Italy, where Prime Minister Lamberto Dini's Government survived a confidence vote -- though Mr. Dini gained the required margin of victory by agreeing to leave office before the end of the year.
"The fact that the Dini Government was able to survive, that calms the European fears and is helpful to the Deutsche mark," said Lisa Finstrom, currency analyst at Smith Barney. "It means the European Monetary Union may be going forward, and that left the Deutsche mark in a position to benefit from the peso and dollar-selling."

HEADLINE: Durable-Goods Orders Rise 3% For Month, Surprising Analysts

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Brisk demand for commercial aircraft pushed orders for durable goods to a record in September, the Commerce Department reported today.
Bolstering the economic outlook, total orders rose a surprising 3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $169.03 billion, after an upwardly revised 5.1 percent surge in August -- the biggest monthly gain in a year -- as inventories from the second quarter were depleted. 
 Analysts said the September increase in orders would help manufacturing, and that in turn would lift the slow-growing economy.
"With capital-goods orders on the move and the inventory correction having pretty well played itself out, manufacturing now is moving back into a position of being a mildly positive influence," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Separately, the Labor Department reported that the number of Americans applying for state unemployment benefits was unchanged last week at 359,000.
The Commerce Department, underlining a more robust trend for factory business, said shipments of finished durable goods also rose in September, and backlogs of unfilled orders increased after being flat for two months.
Durable goods are products like cars and refrigerators that are intended to last three years or more and are relatively costly. Economists track orders for these goods to gauge future hiring prospects and to measure the willingness of consumers and business to spend money.
Sung Won Sohn, an economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said the latest evidence of economic firming was likely to help induce the Federal Reserve's key committee not to lower interest rates when it meets on Nov. 15.
Transportation orders were far and away the leading influence on September orders, increasing 10.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted $43.18 billion after a 17.1 percent surge in August.
The Commerce Department does not separate the value of aircraft orders from those for autos, although it said demand for aircraft and parts led the increase in transportation. Excluding transportation, orders rose a relatively slight six-tenths of a percent in September after a 1.8 percent gain in August.
Separately, the White House announced the $6 billion sale today of 61 planes to Saudi Arabia -- an order that will take six to seven years to fill and support thousands of jobs.

HEADLINE: The Sound Of New York: Ska. Ska? Yes, Ska.

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
THE hunt for thriving regional music scenes has become an important one in the record business. Music labels in New York regularly send talent scouts to places like San Diego and Louisville, Ky., to make deals with new cadres of bands hoping to replicate the success of the Seattle grunge scene that spawned Nirvana and Soundgarden and the Berkeley, Calif., punk scene that produced Green Day and Rancid. What most record companies do not consider, however, is that for a dozen years a scene has slowly been expanding right on their doorstep, and it is close to exploding. It is perhaps the only underground musical movement that New York can now call its own. T-shirts in record stores and cover artwork on compact disks proudly proclaim it in large letters: NYC SKA.
Ska is an odd-looking word: short, punchy, almost funny. So is the music at times, a light, bouncy, horn-infused grandfather of reggae. (The word itself comes from the sound a guitar makes.) Ska has arrived in three musical waves, beginning in Jamaica in the 1950's and 60's as a home-grown version of rhythm-and-blues performed by collectives of former jazz musicians like the Skatalites. The music traveled to England along with Jamaican blue-collar laborers, quickening its tempo as it mixed with punk and working-class youth sounds in the 1970's. A second wave of interracial ska bands, including the Specials, the Selecter and the English Beat, first appeared on England's Two-Tone label, registering in America as a quick spark on the pop charts. But that spark slowly ignited an international fire as New Yorkers like Rob (Bucket) Hingley (a veteran of the English movement) and Jeff Baker not only started bands like the Toasters and the Boilers, but also helped to establish a solid underground network, connecting ska groups in New York with ones in Brazil, Japan, Germany, Hawaii and elsewhere through newsletters, fan magazines and record labels. 
 "It was New York that galvanized the national scene with bands like the Toasters touring," said Mr. Hingley, who runs Moon, the premier ska label in the United States, in addition to playing guitar and singing in the 12-year-old Toasters. "The music really hooks people once they finally hear it. First you meet a kid at a concert, next they have a band, then they're opening up for you and the next thing you know, you're putting out a record of theirs."
Five years ago, ska concerts in Manhattan were strictly underground events, where green-haired punks, skinheads and stylish ska fans known as rude boys danced to the holy triumvirate of New York ska bands: the Toasters, the Scofflaws and the N.Y. Citizens. Now there are concerts every weekend at downtown clubs like Wetlands, New Music Cafe, the Cooler and Coney Island High, and the audience is a broad, multi-racial mix, where hippies meet skinheads and college jocks dance with rude boys.
"You used to know everybody in the scene in New York, if not personally, at least by face," said Mr. Baker, a former member of the hardcore band Murphy's Law who now plays in the ska bands Skinnerbox and the Stubborn All-Stars. "Now I look around, and I see almost no one I know. It's not exclusively a rude boy and skinhead thing now. There are people from 15 to 50 at the shows. And I know why: it's the only music that makes me dance without thinking about it."
 
Bands and More Bands
 Chris Zahn, who books concerts at Wetlands in TriBeCa, said he had noticed not only an expanding audience for ska, but also an increasing number of people playing the music.
"What we have to do is package the ska shows, turn them into multi-band nights with five or six groups," Mr. Zahn said. "There just seem to be bands coming out of nowhere. I'm getting tapes from all over the coast that even people involved in the ska community have never heard of. I had a ska band from Venezuela here the other night dropping off their tape, and there's an Argentine band interested in playing here."
"But as popular as ska is getting, it's still surprising how many people don't know it," he added. "On a typical Friday, we get tons of phone calls about what's playing. When we say it's a ska show, there's always a pause and then we hear: 'Ska? What is ska?' We've gone so far as to say, 'Think of it as Jewish reggae: imagine 'Hava Nagilah' and then put some island rhythms in there.' "
Not every club in New York has such an open attitude toward ska. "I don't book ska shows anymore," said the manager of one club, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "If there aren't fights inside, you have nearby restaurants and neighbors complaining about skinheads loitering around with 40-ounce beer bottles in their hands."
But other club bookers and concertgoers say that fighting at ska shows is becoming a rarity. The attitude of ska music has always been one of having fun in the face of oppression, as encapsulated in a warning made famous by the Jamaican legend Prince Buster: "Enjoy yourself. It's later than you think."
At Wetlands this month, when the New York band the Slackers opened for the English Two-Tone band the Selecter, the scene was peaceful and friendly. With fast, shuffling guitar strumming, infectious drumming on the offbeat and a horn section worthy of a 60's soul revue, the music had even the most awkward of club denizens skanking, or bouncing from leg to leg and swinging their arms.
Where most rock bands get by with three or four members, ska bands may have as many as a dozen. In addition to guitars, bass and drums, they often have an entire horn section. These groups sometimes find older players from the jazz or Latin music worlds; other times they recruit young people who have just graduated from their high school jazz band. Either way, it makes for eclectic music. At 11 members, the Slackers are among the more diverse and unpredictable bands in New York.
There are many different styles of ska being played today, but the main schism is between the bands that try to blend it with punk and hardcore music and the traditionalists who look back to Jamaica for a purer sound.
It is this first style that fans and record executives alike predict will make ska part of the fabric of popular music. The Mighty Mighty Bosstones, from Boston, performed this summer on Lollapalooza, the alternative-rock package tour, exposing new audiences to high-energy ska-core, as the group's hard, fast hybrid is sometimes called. More recently, the California punk band Rancid (which was formed from the ashes of Operation Ivy, a ska-influenced band) put out a ska single called "Time Bomb," which has been played heavily on MTV and pop radio.
But the Slackers have their own dream of a slower, rootsier ska finding success. "The more modern stuff is what they're expecting to break through in the wake of Rancid," said Marcus Geard, who plays bass in the Slackers at night and delivers trees during the day. "But I think the VH1 audience is a perfect traditional ska audience. I think they dig the groove and the vibe more; they're more sophisticated and don't get put off by Latin and jazz influences. The beat's infectious, and then the other influences make it more interesting."
 
Investing in a Genre
 Profile Records in New York has become one of the biggest American record labels to make an investment in New York ska. Its rock division, Another Planet, recently signed the Stubborn All-Stars, a rotating New York supergroup with an old-time sound featuring members of the Slackers, the Toasters, the Insteps and Skinnerbox, along with the tenor saxophonist from the original Skatalites. The label has also signed the Insteps, and is courting one of the New York ska scene's brightest hopes, Mephiskapheles.
"Ska is probably the biggest underground network going right now,"said Fred Feldman, the general manager of Another Planet records. "Moon Records has a 15,000-name direct-marketing list, and the Toasters are selling at least 25,000 to 30,000 records now, most of it through nontraditional retail outlets. I think the bigger labels are still waiting to see what happens with this Rancid song and to see how Green Day does with the ska band it signed to its 510 label, the Dancehall Crashers. If any of it becomes huge, then you'll see a feeding frenzy."
Many bands, however, remain skeptical. For a long time, some musical pundits have written off ska as creatively defunct without ever having listened to the stylistic extremes of the music, which range from the swing- and be-bop-influenced instrumentals of the New York Ska-Jazz Ensemble to the industrial electronic ska of World Service. As Mr. Baker said, "One of the strengths of ska is that the foundation is so simple but so effective that it can endure a lot of changes but still maintain a relationship to the original style."
Nonetheless, Mikal Reich of Mephiskapheles added: "Ska is almost the marketing kiss of death. We've been talking to record labels, and they're always telling us they don't know how to market ska; they don't know who to sell it to. I used to think people in the record industry were barracudas and would jump on anything. Here you've got Rancid with a ska single in MTV's 'Buzz Bin,' and I still have to spell ska to people over the phone."
Steve Shafer, who is in charge of promotion at Moon, speculates that one reason for ska's obscurity is that it is stereotyped as a revival. "What happened with ska was that the Two-Tone revival was labeled as a rehash of the Jamaican sound, and critics couldn't see it as a re-examination and reinvention of that kind of music," he said. "There was punk and anger and frustration in it. And now it's still growing and going off in different directions: ska punk, ska-core, rootsy stuff that sounds like it came out of the 60's. We have our 'Spawn of Skarmageddon' compilation coming out, and there are 43 bands on it from all over the U.S., and none of them sound the same."
 
Beyond the Clubs
 Ska is not just a club event in Manhattan anymore. In February, Moon Records opened a store in the East Village selling records, T-shirts and books. It also serves as a general clearinghouse for information on concerts and on ska lore, usually courtesy of a counterman, Noah Wildman, who is working on a book on ska.
And for more than a decade, rude boys up and down the East Coast have been buying their Doc Marten boots and Fred Perry shirts at 99X, also in the East Village. Rude boys were originally unemployed youths-turned-gangsters from Jamaica's shantytowns who dressed in the latest clean-cut fashions to intimidate and impress.
Their narrow-brimmed porkpie hats, close-shaven haircuts, wraparound sunglasses, skinny ties and sharkskin suits with tapered legs have survived in ska wear today, as have the checkerboard patterns (symbolizing black and white unity) of England's Two-Tone look.
"Whenever there's a big show in New York, the store gets packed because all these people come into town from all over," said Alex Pietropinto, who works at 99X. "Their style hasn't changed. You can look at pictures of people 30 years ago, and see a rude boy now and they look the same."
Another factor that has helped ska endure is the word itself. The word "ska" can be combined with almost anything. There have been Skalapalooza tours and Skampilation records; this weekend, there's a Skalloween concert in the East Village, and in December New York is to have its first Skanukkah concert. "We thought we'd exhausted all the variations we could come up with on the word ska," Mr. Zahn of Wetlands said. "But then last week we booked a Skanksgiving show."

Skanking Away
Here is a sampling of ska concerts this weekend in Manhattan and places that specialize in ska merchandise:

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Talks at Historical Society
Don't be fooled by the seemingly quiet mood at the New-York Historical Society: interesting behind-the-scenes negotiations are in progress.
Merger talks have begun again between the society and the Museum of the City of New York. The last time the idea surfaced was in 1992, but those talks led nowhere. Neither institution would discuss what's going on, but those close to City Hall say Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is taking a personal interest in trying to make the merger happen.
Colleen Roche, the Mayor's press secretary, said: "Discussions to see whether a merger would be beneficial are very preliminary. At the request of the Mayor and John Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, Schuyler Chapin has been made available to participate in discussions." Mr. Chapin is the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.
A report to the board of the Museum of the City of New York said that the Mayor had "asked the museum to take a leadership role in seeking a permanent solution to the society's chronic problems."
While the two institutions have similar missions -- to celebrate the city's rich cultural history -- each is in a period of flux. The Museum of the City of New York is involved in a capital campaign to start a $36 million renovation, expansion and reorganization of its 1932 Neo-Georgian building at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. The city, which owns the building, is paying for half the project.
The Historical Society had its own facelift and reopened its doors in May after having been closed for two years. Despite its spiffier premises, it is struggling to pull itself out of serious financial problems. The city and New York State have provided $12.6 million and the State Attorney General's office, which oversees nonprofit institutions, allowed the society to sell a selection of Old Master paintings and Americana to raise money.
Most of the art and objects were sold at Sotheby's in New York in January in a sale that made $17.6 million. Fifteen marine paintings that were part of the original consignment sanctioned by the Attorney General's office were sold at Sotheby's on Sunday, and the Historical Society is $611,300 richer for it. The paintings were by the 19th-century New York artist James Bard.
Sotheby's sold 26 Bards in January and decided it was dangerous to try to sell them all then. "Under normal circumstances, we usually see two or three Bards a season, and we were worried about flooding the market," said Nancy Druckman, head of Sotheby's department of American Folk Art. "So we saved this core group until now."
Among the top sellers were "Steamboat Thomas P. Way" (1859), estimated to sell for $25,000 to $35,000; it sold to an unidentified collector for $112,500. Under the society's original agreement with the Attorney General's office, other New York State institutions can exercise a right of first refusal for any work at auction, and have a week after the sale to act. If something sells for its high estimate, the society gives the pre-empting institution a graduated discount. A Sotheby's spokesman said no institutions had pre-empted any of Sunday's Bard sales.
 
For Korean Art
 Two Korean foundations, the Korea Foundation and the Samsung Foundation, have given the Metropolitan Museum of Art a $5 million grant to develop a Korean arts program and a new gallery devoted to the arts of Korea. "This will encourage the development of our collections in this area, from the ceramics we now display to a well-rounded collection that represents the spectrum of artistic achievements of this rich culture," Philippe de Montebello, the Metropolitan's director, said.
The new gallery is expected to open at the end of 1997. The Korean Foundation will pay for the gallery's construction, while the Samsung Foundation will support the program, including displaying the art and educational programs.
 
Christie's Campaign
 Christie's latest marketing effort has gone beyond fancy shopping bags or scarfs or chocolates.
Fifty-five thousand subscribers to Christie's International Magazine received a special all-color brochure about the auction house's 19th- and 20th-century picture departments. But the art wasn't what Christie's seemed to be selling. The message was all about the "youth and experience" of its staff.
The lavishly produced, 13-page brochure was shot by Derry Moore, the English photographer known for his glamorous interior photographs in Architectural Digest. Each Christie's expert is posed on a separate page with a painting offered for sale this fall. Each expert either wears an outfit color-coordinated with the painting or poses in a manner similar to a figure in the work, sort of an artsy version of the way real estate agents and new car salesmen sell themselves these days.
"We were deliberately breaking new ground here," said John Lumley, the international head of Christie's 19th- and 20th-century paintings department, who masterminded the brochure. Mr. Lumley (the only expert not pictured) said he believed it was important to "sell the people concerned," adding, "They are stars in their world."
About half the experts have held their jobs less than a year, but Mr. Lumley said that had nothing to do with the concept. "These experts form an important part of our international network," he said. "We were not ignoring the works of art; it's the whole package that's important."
 
A Contemporary Arrival
 The long-awaited Jeffrey Deitch gallery, which has been hovering in the art world's imagination for nine months, has finally touched down. Mr. Deitch, a leading contemporary art dealer and adviser, has teamed up with Jeanne Greenberg, who has worked with him for about two years as director of his art advisory service. They have formed a joint enterprise called Deitch Greenberg Projects.
Its new home is the former Joe Fawbush Gallery, which closed this month after Mr. Fawbush's death in June. It is a modest but unusually beautiful space at 76 Grand Street in SoHo, which Mr. Deitch and Ms. Greenberg are planning to use as a project space for emerging and established artists. "We're planning to invite artists to do special installations," Ms. Greenberg said.
The gallery will open temporarily in November. Then the space will close for renovations in December and reopen in January.

HEADLINE: Mayor Offers 3 Hospitals For Lease

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration formally offered yesterday to turn over three public hospitals to private health care organizations. It also strongly suggested that the city would try to release the new operators from the terms of current labor contracts.
In two detailed plans, one for Coney Island Hospital and one for both Elmhurst Hospital Center and Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, the city is offering to sign long-term leases with nonprofit companies that meet the city's requirements for delivering health care to the poor. 
 Although the city took pains to describe the offerings as leasing arrangements, they are in many ways tantamount to actual sales.
The two documents, which were prepared by the J. P. Morgan investment firm, read in places like upbeat real estate brochures, praising, for example, easy access by car and ambulance to Coney Island in Brooklyn, as well as the relatively low unemployment rates in the neighborhoods surrounding the Elmhurst and Queens hospitals.
"The transfer of these hospitals to not-for-profit entities can help the city insure access to quality health care services and meet the new demand of the communities, with the provision of increased primary care services and much needed capital improvements," Maria K. Mitchell, the Mayor's special adviser on health policy, said in a prepared statement.
But even before the documents were made public yesterday afternoon, board members of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the public hospital system, angrily denounced the privatization plan, saying that it would damage the health care system for poor people and that it was also probably illegal.
"I oppose these resolutions because they violate the law and are directly inconsistent with our obligations under the law," said David R. Jones, a longtime board member. "These actions will result in a fragmentation of the delivery of health services that the corporation was created to provide."
The suggestions in the offerings that the city is willing to revise its labor contracts with hospital unions is also certain to alarm hospital union leaders. Job security for hospital workers has been a thorny issue in the current contract negotiations between the city and District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said one city official.
Stanley Hill, president of District Council 37, expressed skepticism of the plan.
"We have always said that selling hospitals will increase the city's health costs and will not help the service," he said. "We're also concerned about our own interests, such as collective bargaining rights and benefits. We don't know the impact, who the buyer will be, so there's a big concern here."
The release of the formal offerings is the first concrete step the city has taken toward privatizing its public hospitals since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani first announced his intention to sell several hospitals shortly after taking office last year. In recent months, he has expressed hope of turning additional hospitals over to private companies, perhaps dismantling the system entirely.
The offerings make few specific demands on potential bidders, although the Queens plan stipulates that a new Queens Hospital Center must be built to replace the aging structure.
Beyond that, the plans simply insist that the organization that takes over any hospital must satisfy the city that it can provide a high quality of care to the city's indigent and uninsured.
The plans also leave considerable flexibility about how prospective purchasers will deal with the public hospital's powerful unions, whose rules have often been blamed for the system's inefficiencies. The plans suggest that the city will allow union contracts to be abrogated or at least significantly reworked.
While the city insists that the privatization plan will make the public hospital system more economical, others disagree. Just last week, Standard and Poor's dropped the hospital agency's bond rating, citing in part uncertainties created by the privatization plans.
"Not knowing what will or will not remain under H.H.C.'s umbrella or how such decisions will be made is a significant operational handicap," Standard and Poor's wrote.
Mr. Jones, a corporation board member, also raised questions about whether the city has the legal authority to transfer public hospitals without state legislative action, since the system was created by legislative act in 1969.
Beyond that, the State Department of Health must be asked to approve all transfers in hospital ownership or managerial responsibility. Lois Utley, a spokeswoman for the department, said that it had not received a copy of the offering plans, but noted that "the state would be concerned about continued methods for taking care of the patients who depend upon the hospital, particularly the indigent."
And then there is the question of whether there are any takers, particularly since the Medicare bill under consideration in Congress would take millions of dollars in Federal financing away from each hospital now on the sale block.
Mr. Jones said: "I think there must be oil under one or more of these hospitals, because we are supposedly going to generate so much money by getting rid of them."
