HEADLINE: South Africa's Rulers Ask, 'How're We Doin'? '

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: VOSLOORUS, South Africa, Oct. 24

 BODY:
With eight days until the second most important election in South African history, Max Sisulu might have been expected to be frantically pressing the flesh, kissing babies and doing everything he could to make sure his party's candidates win their races.
Instead, Mr. Sisulu, a legislator from Soweto and son of Walter Sisulu, lion of the African National Congress, was touring a tough township that does not contain a single one of his constituents, trying to determine whether his party's platform, issued two years ago, is on track. 
 The platform is the much-vaunted Reconstruction and Development Plan, the African National Congress's book-length outline for rebuilding South Africa.
Crime, housing, and how much power Zulu chiefs will retain under the Constitution are big issues in the Nov. 1 voting, which will elect city councils and ward committees across the nation. But one thing the ruling African National Congress's opponents have unfailingly bashed it with is the charge that "the A.N.C. has failed to deliver on the R.D.P.," as everyone calls it in the most acronym-mad milieu this side of the United States Army.
That's why Mr. Sisulu was here. "The A.N.C. has to deliver on its promises," he said. "If we do that, we'll win all the elections."
Not that he seemed worried. "We got 64 percent of the vote last time and we're hardly likely to lose this time," he said.
Unreleased polls bear out Mr. Sisulu's confidence. Markinor, a polling operation here, predicts that the Congress will again get nearly 65 percent of the vote.
Stan Greenberg, an American polling expert under contract to the Congress said, "The elites and the press keep looking for signs of voter impatience, but it doesn't show in the polls." He said the party could even make gains among mixed-raced voters, called coloreds,' who supported the opposition National Party in the last election.
Another fertile field for A.N.C. inroads, he said, was among people of Indian descent in the Durban area, frustrated with the continuing violence under the Inkatha Freedom Party, which rules their province. But elections there have been delayed by a court challenge.
President Nelson Mandela is not stumping; he has been visiting the United States. Of course, the big newspaper photos of him sitting with President Clinton do not hurt his party's image.
Saki Macozoma, chairman of the Congress's elections commission and a principal strategist, denied that the party is complacent, saying its national leaders will campaign hard this weekend. They did little before, he said, because his research showed voters were more interested in the local candidates.
The campaign has been short. The 15,000 candidates for city councils and ward committees were not even chosen until Sept. 22, and the first posters went up less than a month ago. That was deliberate; England's brief campaigns are South Africa's political model. Also, there was fear that a long, heated campaign would spark further killings.
But brevity was also a product of confusion and time pressure. It took months to raise voter registration to the current level of 76 percent of those eligible and to pick candidates for 701 separate elections. And there have been endless court challenges.
"I've never seen an election where the voters understood all the issues," Mr. Macozoma said. "But they know that whether or not they get resources in their neighborhoods depends on the outcome."
Mr. Sisulu's eyes are firmly on the number of houses built, jobs created, promises kept. As the chairman of the Parliament committee overseeing the Reconstruction and Development Plan, he is especially stung by the campaign criticisms. Asked how he would treat Jay Naidoo, the quick-witted, fast-talking Cabinet minister who is in charge of running the plan, if he suspected foot-dragging, he replied, "I'll hammer him."
But after touring Vosloorus, Mr. Sisulu was not reaching for the hammer.
In this zone, which also includes the townships of Katlehong and Thokoza, the Reconstruction and Development Plan seems to be changing the way life is lived. The army, the police, engineers, project managers and social workers of all races seem to be working together.
Murders and other "serious incidents," to use a South African colonel's classification, are down from a high of 580 in August 1990 to 18 last month. Hostels controlled by the Congress's bitterest opponents, Zulus of the Inkatha Party, are being painted and electrified, with the Zulus who live in them getting the jobs. Tracts of $5,138 houses -- two cinderblock rooms with a fiber-cement roof, two windows, an inside toilet and a coat of paint -- are being built, and the occupants own them. Nineteen police stations -- truck bodies with no toilets or water -- are in place. Squatter camps are getting water standpipes, brick outhouses and one vandal-resistant telephone every few hundred yards on which they can call for police, an ambulance or even sewer repair.
Mr. Sisulu talked to people at every stop -- most of them women washing clothes in buckets or men employed to paint houses. Invariably, they said they are grateful to the Congress for the houses and have even chased pamphleteers for the rival Pan Africanist Congress away. A landslide for the Congress seems certain here.
"But jobs is the real issue," Mr. Sisulu said. "Giving them houses is nice, but without economic development, nothing will happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a Johannesburg township, residents put an addition on a house, partly financed by the Government's Reconstruction and Development program. (Greg Marinovich/Matrix, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Philippine Leader Says He'll Leave in '98; Foes Have Doubts

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: MANILA, Oct. 26

 BODY:
When asked his plans after his term as President of the Philippines ends in 1998, Fidel V. Ramos tends to smile playfully and say something about spending the rest of his life on a golf course.
But his political adversaries suspect that the President's mind is actually far from the 18th hole. They assert that a recent campaign to replace this nation's American-style presidential system of government with a parliamentary system is part of a scheme by Mr. Ramos to remain in power indefinitely -- as Prime Minister instead of President. 
 Mr. Ramos insists publicly that he does not want to see the system of government changed during his presidency and that, regardless of what happens, he will step down in 1998, as is required by the current Philippine Constitution, which allows a President only one six-year term.
"I have no wish nor design to perpetuate myself in office," the 67-year-old President said a few weeks ago. "I will step down at the end of my term."
But still the suspicions have been raised, and apparently with good reason. The politician who has led the call for a constitutional change is Jose de Venecia, the Speaker of the House and a close political ally of the President. And in August, Mr. Ramos's supporters in the Senate engineered the ouster of the Senate President, a champion of term limits.
Opinion polls suggest that a switch to a parliamentary system and an end to term limits would be unpopular with the public -- term limits are as popular with voters here as they are in the United States -- and several prominent Filipinos have stated their opposition to constitutional changes, including Mr. Ramos's predecessor, Corazon C. Aquino.
Mrs. Aquino, who stepped down at the end of her term in 1992 and endorsed Mr. Ramos, said this month that "we have enough serious problems to address without putting forth issues which no doubt will divide Filipinos people at this time."
Mr. Ramos's political opponents are quick to point out that the last Philippine leader to seek a change to a parliamentary system was Ferdinand E. Marcos, who sought the change in the early 1970's in a transparent effort to remain in power.
When it was clear that a parliamentary system would not be adopted, President Marcos declared martial law in 1972 and held onto power until 1986, when he was forced out in an popular uprising led by Mrs. Aquino and Mr. Ramos.
Still, there are many other powerful Filipinos who would like to find some way of keeping Mr. Ramos in office, given his success in reviving the economy of a nation of 67 million people that was long seen as the economic laggard in Asia.
The economy is expected to grow this year by nearly 5 percent -- a growth rate that is modest by the standards of booming Southeast Asia, but is a near-miracle for the Philippines.
The wariness about Mr. Ramos's intentions grew after his political coalition engineered the ouster of the Senate President, Edgardo Angara, even though Mr. Angara was a party stalwart who had shepherded legislation on Mr. Ramos's behalf.
Mr. Angara's personal popularity had been rising, and he was increasingly seen as a viable presidential candidate in the next elections. He has accused Mr. Ramos of orchestrating his removal.
"There is no doubt what he is up to," Mr. Angara said in an interview. "Ramos may say that he does not want to stay in power, but his words are contradicted by the actions of his lieutenants. They wouldn't do anything without his approval."

HEADLINE: A Big Job For Labor

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
With words of militancy, the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is promising the third big surge of labor organizing in the nation's history, hoping to add millions of workers to union rolls just as the movement did during the Depression and after World War II.
American unions tripled their membership in the six years before 1941, thanks to the passage in 1935 of the Wagner Act, which set pro-labor ground rules for organizing Depression-era workers hungry for better wages. And after World War II, unions scooped up millions of more workers, fed up with wage controls. 
 Can they do so again?
In his acceptance speech yesterday, the day after delegates to the national convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations had elected him president, John J. Sweeney made clear that he was setting his sights high.
"The most important thing we can do, starting right now today, is to organize every working woman and man who needs a better deal and a new voice," he said. "As long as we speak for scarcely one-sixth of the work force, we will never be able to win what we deserve at the bargaining table or in the legislative process. That is why we're going to pour resources into organizing at a pace and scale that is unprecedented."
Mr. Sweeney's heartfelt vow to get the union movement running on all cylinders notwithstanding, he will find it hard to repeat the successes of yesteryear, because unions now face a constellation of forces that did not exist in labor's heyday: fierce economic competition from abroad, a Republican-controlled Congress hostile to organized labor, technological changes that are sweeping away factory jobs, and corporations that have honed sophisticated strategies to outflank unions.
"Changing the vigor with which they pursue new members doesn't change any of the enemies they have," said Ronald Seeber, a professor at the Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations. "They still face a global economy which is sending their job base overseas. They still face a hostile political environment in Washington and most state capitals. And they face a public indifferent to the cause of unions."
And that is not all. In the 60 years since the Wagner Act was adopted, Congress, the courts and the National Labor Relations Board have chipped away at that landmark legislation, making it less friendly to unions. And in the last 15 years, employment in manufacturing, the most heavily unionized sector of the economy, has shrunk by a sixth, while employment in the harder-to-organize service sector has nearly doubled.
Another problem is that Mr. Sweeney is inheriting a federation suffering from bureaucratic sclerosis: his predecessors' policy was that attracting new workers was the business of individual unions and not of the 13-million-member federation.
Despite so hostile an environment, Mr. Sweeney and the other insurgents who won control of the federation at this convention, in midtown Manhattan, are confident that they can reverse labor's slide. Before them they see huge swaths of territory fertile for organizing -- areas where wages are low and management largely unsympathetic, areas that Mr. Sweeney's predecessors all but ignored. Mr. Sweeney and his aides talk of organizing hospitals, nursing homes, discount stores and textile factories, and of focusing on the South in particular.
Mr. Sweeney, a 61-year-old Bronx native who has headed the Service Employees International Union for 15 years, is promising nothing less than the reversal of a four-decade-old trend in which union membership plunged to 15.5 percent of the work force in 1994, from 34.7 percent in 1954. At the once-mighty United Automobile Workers, membership has plummeted to 800,000, from 1.5 million in 1979; at the United Steelworkers, it has slid to 140,000 from 380,000 during the same period.
Mr. Sweeney and his aides have adopted the attitude that it is always darkest before the dawn. They say the time is ripe to woo workers to the unions because labor dissatisfaction is bubbling over during an era in which wages have badly trailed inflation and in which management, through constant "downsizing," has left workers feeling profoundly insecure.
Whether Sweeney & Company can tap this worker discontent remains to be seen. During the 16-year reign of Lane Kirkland, who stepped down as president in August in the face of a Sweeney-led challenge, it seemed that the federation had forgotten how to carry on a dialogue with American workers, more than 100 million of them, who do not belong to unions.
From the moment he was elected on Wednesday, Mr. Sweeney has sought to jump-start that dialogue. Addressing himself to all American workers, he said: "Our problem is your stagnant wages -- America needs a raise. The solution is a bigger, stronger labor movement."
But American workers may continue to tune out big labor's message, Professor Seeber said.
"The fundamental message of trade unionism still resonates with most American workers," he said. "They would like someone arguing on their economic behalf in the workplace; that's almost a universal truth. But when you attach the word 'union' to it, that turns a lot of people off. Unions will have to go back to core fundamentals to figure out how to reach these people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After promising convention delegates a labor renaissance, John J. Sweeney, center, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president, joined them yesterday in a midtown Manhattan march to a rally at Eighth Avenue and 38th Street. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
HOUSE PASSES BUDGET BILL, BEDROCK OF G.O.P. AGENDA; MUCH BARGAINING REMAINS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today approved the foundation of the Republican revolution: a mammoth bill that would balance the Federal budget in seven years, cut the taxes of most families and significantly diminish the place of the Federal Government in the lives of Americans.
President Clinton has vowed to veto the legislation, so it will be weeks before it is known how many of its elements will become law. But its approval today underscored the willingness of the members of the new Republican majority to cast difficult votes in areas that have proved politically risky in the past. 
 Spending on Medicare, the popular health program for the elderly and disabled, would be strictly limited, and the program would be changed so fundamentally that no one can predict with confidence what the consequences would be.
The 60-year-old commitment of Washington to provide subsistence for the poorest in the society would be ended, with that responsibility shifted to the states.
The money for Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program, and Medicaid, the health care program for the poor, would be much less than it would be without changes in the law. In both cases, the states alone would be allowed to decide who would receive benefits and how much they would get. Most Federal standards for nursing homes would be abandoned. [Page D20.]
"In seven years," declared Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the Republican chairman of the Budget Committee, "we will balance the budget and save the country and save the next generation."
The sweeping legislation, called a budget reconciliation bill, was passed on a party-line vote of 227 to 203. Four Democrats crossed party lines to vote for the measure. Ten Republicans voted against it.
Earlier, a Democratic alternative that would have continued Federal commitments to the poor, allowed more money for Medicare and abandoned the notion of a tax cut was solidly rejected, 356 to 72.
The Senate, meanwhile, began voting on amendments to a companion measure, rejecting by nearly straight party-line votes Democratic attempts to restore money for Medicare, Medicaid, the earned-income tax credit, student loans and other social programs and to reduce the size of the tax cut. The Senate bill, expected to be adopted Friday, differs on the margins from the one the House approved today, but the themes are the same.
After blocking votes all day on Wednesday, Republican senators permitted them today in return for a promise from Democrats to limit the number of amendments they offered.
Many niggling details will have to be worked out by a House-Senate conference committee, on matters like how Medicaid money would be apportioned among the states and exactly who would be entitled to tax breaks.
But whatever comes out of the conference, no one doubts that a veto will follow. Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, criticized the budget bill, saying, "It will severely harm Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment, and raise taxes for working families while providing huge new tax breaks for the wealthy."
He added that the President "will continue to insist that Congress pass a balanced budget that protects seniors and working families."
Since Republicans do not have the votes in Congress to override a veto, the final budget can be written only after negotiations between the President and Republican Congressional leaders.
Rarely are the philosophical lines between the two parties drawn as starkly as they were in the debate in the House today.
For example, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, declared, "We believe the strength of America lies not with the Government but with each of us as individuals."
Over the last 30 years, Mr. Archer asserted, the Government "spent over $5 trillion on the war on poverty, only to lose the war."
But Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, the Democrat who previously led the committee, took an entirely different stance. The Republicans, he declared, intend to take "$450 billion out of children, out of sick people, out of nursing home people."
"This," he said, "is a travesty on the American people."
Representative Martin Olav Sabo, Democrat of Minnesota, accused Republicans of harboring "a vision that rewards the wealthiest and most powerful interests in our society at the expense of the most vulnerable Americans."
The Democratic whip, Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, said, "This budget doesn't reward the best in us. It appeals to the worst in us. It doesn't reward our best instincts. It tramples our most basic values."
But Republican leaders were adamant that their direction was the right one for the country.
"We don't have a right to tell the next generation that we can't stop ourselves from spending that extra trillion," said Mr. Kasich, the legislator more responsible than any other for putting together the package that was approved today.
"We're going to look over all the swamp, and all the muck and all the nasty rhetoric," said Mr. Kasich, his hand over his brow like the lookout in the crow's nest of a sailing ship. "We're going to look beyond that. We're going to look to the next generation. We're going to get this done for our precious nation."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, would have none of that. Wrapping up the Democratic side of the debate on the budget, he said, "It's wrong. It's morally wrong. It's economically wrong. It's the wrong thing for our country."
Much of the debate in the House and Senate today was over Medicare, the health program depended on by 37 million elderly and disabled Americans. The bills would spend $270 billion less on Medicare over the next seven years than would be spent without changes in the law. The saving would be accomplished primarily by reducing payments to doctors and hospitals, raising monthly premiums and providing inducements to encourage beneficiaries to move from the Government program into private insurance coverage.
Republicans said they were doing this to protect the program from bankruptcy and preserve it for the next generation of retirees. Democrats accused them of decimating the popular program to raise money to offset tax cuts.
In addition to welfare and Medicaid, the House bill would also restrain spending on other Federal programs for the poor, including the earned-income tax credit, child-care assistance, food stamps, school lunches, nutrition aid for pregnant women and help for low-income disabled children.
The Republican view is that these programs, mainly the products of the Democratic New Deal and the Great Society, have been allowed to grow out of control, to a point where taxpayers can no longer afford them.
Student loans would be restricted. But other entitlement programs with middle-class constituencies, like farm-price supports and veterans benefits, would see more modest reductions.
The cornerstone of the part of the bill dealing with taxes is a tax cut for all but the richest and poorest families, based on the number of children. For technical reasons, the bill approved today would put the tax credit at $365 per child. No one doubts that the conferees will approve $500 per child, the figure in the Senate bill and the one approved by the House in April. The only question is exactly which taxpayers would be eligible for the credit.
The measure would also lower the tax on capital gains (the profits from the sale of investments), expand eligibility for individual retirement accounts, reduce the marriage penalty for working couples, allow tax credits to offset some of the expenses of adopting a child and caring for an elderly relative at home, abolish the alternative minimum tax for corporations with large tax write-offs, increase the size of the estates that would be exempt from inheritance taxes, reduce the amount of Social Security benefits subject to taxation and permit companies to withdraw excess money from their pension funds.
Before taking up the overall bill today, the House approved a nonbinding resolution promising to vote later in the year on a separate measure that would increase the amount of money people over 65 could earn without having their Social Security benefits reduced.

HEADLINE: Fearing G.I. Occupiers, Japan Urgesd Women Into Brothels

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Governments have made plenty of outrageous requests of their citizens, but few are as remarkable as what the Japanese Government secretly requested of tens of thousands of Japanese women 50 years ago.
Six days after Japan's surrender in World War II, the Cabinet met in the Prime Minister's residence to discuss "urgent measures" that had nothing to do with the atomic bombings or the millions of homeless people or similar national crises. Instead, the Cabinet struggled with how to sate the libido of American "sex-starved soldiers." 
 Fearing that the Americans occupying Japan would behave as Japanese troops sometimes had overseas, raping any woman in sight, the Government quietly set up a front organization to establish brothels, and asked patriotic Japanese women to sacrifice themselves as "comfort women" for the Americans.
"We were told that our mission was to be a sexual dike to protect the chastity of Japanese women," remembers Tatsugoro Suzuki, who was then the 25-year-old manager of a fine restaurant. After two frantic weeks, using Government help to obtain futons, scarce in war-devastated Tokyo, Mr. Suzuki had turned the restaurant into a brothel with 30 women supplied by the Government.
The charge to the soldier (only Americans were admitted) was the equivalent of eight cents, and that included a bottle of beer. Half the take went to the woman and half to the house.
"The Americans didn't know this was a Government operation," Mr. Suzuki said. "That was a secret."
The 50th anniversary of the beginning of the American occupation has stimulated renewed interest in that chapter of Japanese history, and a television program has raised awareness and eyebrows with its fictionalized version of the life of Japan's own wartime prostitutes.
Internal documents of the front organization, the Recreation and Amusement Association, show that 55,000 women served in it. The figure includes some office workers, but the great majority worked as prostitutes.
"This really was necessary at the time, because we didn't know what kind of soldiers would come," said Tsunenori Ono, then a 29-year-old police official detailed to oversee the brothels. "It really seemed crucial to build this sexual dike."
The American military authorities nominally banned prostitution, but made few efforts to enforce the ban. The Americans became agitated only when venereal disease rates soared, leading them to declare the Recreation Association brothels off-limits in March 1946.
As a result, the association decided to close down. Other brothels, privately owned, did a booming business, but the Japanese Government's role as a procurer ended after seven months.
In the last few years the world has learned a bit about the Korean, Chinese and even Dutch "comfort women" who were forced to provide sex for the Japanese Army abroad. Yet the Japanese Government's efforts to gather Japanese prostitutes on behalf of American soldiers is much less known.
There is, of course, an enormous difference in that the overseas "comfort women" were mostly Korean teen-agers who were dragged away from their homes and forced into front-line brothels. The Japanese women mostly volunteered, albeit out of economic desperation, and they were paid several times the going rate in ordinary brothels.
Especially at the beginning, the Japanese women were primarily working prostitutes. Later, war widows and other women signed up because they had no other way to feed their families.
To read the yellowing internal documents of the Recreation Association is to peek through a window into a different time. Japan was then not only traumatized by defeat but also terrified at the prospect of the arrival of American troops.
Many families sent young women to the countryside, and one neighborhood association even distributed potassium cyanide capsules with the recommendation that women kill themselves rather than risk disgrace at the hands of savages. Government officials emphasized that the brothels were the best way to "protect the purity of Japanese blood," and they were particularly worried about what they saw as defilement by black American soldiers.
The Recreation Association officially was launched on Aug. 28, 1945, two weeks after the Japanese surrender. Its officials gathered in front of the Imperial Palace and swore an oath acknowledging that "this project is a cornerstone in protecting the chastity of Japanese women." The association's internal documents, gathered by a Japanese writer named Akira Murase, who has written a book about the brothels, refer to the prostitutes as "Okichi."
It is a term laden with sacrifice and sadness, for Okichi was a 16-year-old girl sent by the authorities in 1857 to be the mistress of the first American consul in Japan. Okichi was reviled by Japanese for her intimacy with an American, and so in despair she drowned herself.
Although in 1945 the Government was worried that Japanese prostitutes would not want to stoop so low as to have sex with "satans and savages," economic circumstances were so desperate that many applied. And despite Okichi's misfortunes, apparently the women were not scorned more than other prostitutes.
"They were even envied a bit by ordinary people, because they could earn lots of money," said Mr. Ono, the former police official, whose salary then was equivalent to 46 cents a month. "People were obsessed not with race but with how to make a living."
The first "comfort station," the Komachien, a huge wooden traditional building in a Tokyo suburb, opened with 150 kimono-clad women. One woman had 47 American customers the first day, thereby earning almost $2 for herself.
The prostitutes, who then ranged mostly between 18 and 25, have long since disappeared. They apparently mostly left Tokyo by the 1950's, never spoke of what they had done, and in many cases died early of the effects of venereal disease or other ailments.
The Government role in setting up brothels was less surprising in Japan than it would be in the United States, in that until 1958 Japan permitted prostitution in officially permitted and defined red-light districts.
Despite their theoretical ban on prostitution, the American military authorities in at least one area apparently asked the Government to set up a brothel.
"A month after the troops landed, an American general came to me and said, 'I need your help,' " remembered Yasuhiro Komatsu, then a 25-year-old liaison officer between the American and Japanese forces in the city of Moji. Mr. Komatsu says that the American general demanded that Japan set up a brothel for his men.
As it happened, the Japanese Navy had been running a brothel in one of its buildings in Moji for its own servicemen until the end of the war. So Mr. Komatsu asked the women if they would be willing to have sex with Americans.
"They said, "We're scared of the Americans,' " Mr. Komatsu recalled. "But they also said, 'We have no other job so we'll do it.' "
So the brothel quickly opened, charging much less than the Tokyo rates. Americans lined up, leaving their shoes at the door, and paying just over a penny per visit.
In a few cases, the authorities may have forced Japanese women to work in the brothels. One Japanese book asserts that female factory workers in the city of Kawasaki were trucked to a brothel for Americans and given a speech by a man who said he was from the Interior Ministry.
"You should be proud to be given this mission," he reportedly told the women, who had been told only that they would work in the tourism business. When one woman tried to escape, she is said to have been beaten and her right eye gouged out.
In another case, a women's corps affiliated with the army in Saitama Prefecture is said to have received an order on Sept. 9, 1945, dispatching the members to four brothels in Tokyo. The order, from the Interior Ministry, reportedly said: "You should bear the unbearable and be a shield for all Japanese women."
The Recreation Association followed Japanese tradition by setting up separate brothels for American officers, so they would not have to share women with enlisted men, but some officers declined to take part.
In Nagasaki, seven prostitutes complained formally to the American commander, Lieut. Col. Victor Delnore, that they should not have to pay an "entertainment tax," since they did not find their work entertaining. Colonel Delnore mentioned the issue to the Finance Ministry, and it granted a tax abatement to the brothel.
When the grateful prostitutes then presented Colonel Delnore with free passes, he declined them.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE SCENE
CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;
The G.O.P.'s Wild Card Over at the White House

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Once President Clinton had explicitly vowed to veto the Republicans' ambitious seven-year budget bill, the grand two-house debate today over the measure began to take on the air of another day at the office. Lawmakers grappled across the debating mat, but looked beyond passage toward some future, more melodramatic showdown focused on the constancy of the President and his promises.
"Given the President's recent comments on taxes, how can I know what he will do?" Speaker Newt Gingrich remarked even before the day's debate. Almost merrily, he was relishing the cynical suspicion that had to be left unstated by Democrats that the President has proved to be their uncertain ally. 
 Most recently, Mr. Clinton recanted some of his own enthusiasm for the 1993 tax increase that he had the Democratic Congress pass, leaving his Capitol colleagues feeling hung out to dry and uneasy as they thundered against the Republicans into the night.
Mr. Gingrich exploited their unease over the President's latest promise Wednesday to stand fast. "He's now trying to make the left feel happy, having repudiated them last week on taxes," the Georgia Republican declared at a news conference, describing the President as off on his own "Kabuki theater" of re-election posturing.
Mr. Clinton's resoluteness became a sub-theme of the day's debate. First thing this morning, a House Republican, J. D. Hayworth of Arizona, offered another tired play on the David Letterman top 10 list, including still another unoriginal allusion to Halloween ("Trick the people, then treat Big Government"). But at the top, he listed the Democrats' "secret fear that the President will flip-flop again and refuse to veto."
Mr. Hayworth left the microphone grinning broadly, feeling he had struck home. He strutted past the front-row morning lineup of representatives waiting to speak before the main debate. They sat like bike messengers ready to leap up and deliver disjointed one-minute commentaries before the C-Span cameras that make a practiced lawmaker seem fully engaged even when the House is as empty as a bus terminal at midnight.
In the Senate, Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, stood early to debate another nearly empty chamber. He railed, as if before a crowd, against the Republicans' plan to cut the income tax credits that help the working poor stay off welfare. "This is one of those moments that is so clearly defining that it is even reachable by my own rhetorical skills," Mr. Bradley declared, resorting to mocking his own rather wooden way with words to measure his bitterness.
As all manner of speech mounted like slag across the day, Republicans reflected the implacability built into majority status. They often left the Democrats unchallenged on their many warnings. Still, there was an occasional confirmation that some opposing lawmakers heard one another.
"Let's reject the Civil War the Republicans are trying to wage," counseled Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, Democrat of Rhode Island, contending that the Republicans will trigger a "states rights" rush to deepen Federal cuts in the dole.
Across the aisle, Representative Charlie Norwood, a Georgia Republican with an ear for Confederacy politics, cautioned Mr. Kennedy in the gentlest drawl: "Everybody knows it wasn't 'the Civil War,' it was the 'War Between the States.' " He went on resolute as Stonewall Jackson in decrying the "Chicken Little Democrats" and their warnings of hardships to flow from Republican budgeting.
In their attempts to make these warnings graphic as Dickens, the leaders of the Democratic minority once more arrayed some of the poor, the elderly and the afflicted outside the Capitol's east staircase for a news conference of complaint. "They ought to be ashamed of themselves," declared a tourist who paused momentarily and felt offended at the sight of a brain-damaged boy displayed in a wheelchair as an example of who would suffer from home-care economies in Medicaid.
The Democrats were unapologetic. "The extreme right will have their victory," conceded Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, counting on the President to fulfill his veto vow.
One of the bipartisan anomalies of all the day's politicking -- the cross-barrage of increasingly severe warnings directed at a shrinking, often inert electorate -- seemed personified by Barbara Greenwell, a 67-year-old woman who said at the news conference that she was too poor to ever retire and could not afford to get ill.
"I haven't voted in years," she said rather brightly without apology to Democrat or Republican. "You know what? I'm going to register."
Up the steps and inside the House, the Republicans moved forward with the majority strength that accrued from the last elections.
"The Seven-Year Balanced Budget Reconciliation Act of 1995: Oh how that rings in my ears!" exulted Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, New York Republican and chairman of the Rules Committee. He was ready to move it ahead, if only to a short-term Presidential veto and the deal-making negotiations with the White House that might follow.
"Where's my easel?" asked Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio and the Budget Committee chairman, rushing to the floor and sounding like a master late for his own chef-d'oeuvre. The easel appeared, filled with charts that made the Republicans' case gleam. The majority moved forward. The Democrats clung to the President's vow.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET;
Excerpts From Debates in House and Senate on Budget Bills

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by lawmakers today during the House and Senate budget debates, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times. 

IN THE HOUSE
 
David E. Bonior
Democrat of Michigan and minority whip
We may not have the votes to beat this rule, the votes to beat this budget, but we do have the votes to sustain a Presidential veto.I urge my colleagues to stop this tax increase on families, stop the destruction of Medicare, stop this war on kids and say no to this shameful budget.
 
John R. Kasich
Republican of Ohio
You know what the fight is about in this chamber? You know what the fight is all about in this whole capital, Washington, D.C., area? Whether we can go from $9.5 trillion to $12.1 trillion or whether we should increase that to $13.3 trillion.
The question you have to ask the American people is, Can we save a trillion dollars for the next generation? Nothing is more tragic than to go to the settling of an estate and have the children sit in the room and have it told to them by the lawyers that your mother and father put you in debt. We would consider that to be not a good thing to do, a bad thing to do, to tell your children that they have big bills. . . .
The same is true with the Federal budget. We don't have a right to tell the next generation that we can't stop ourselves from spending that extra trillion.
We're going to look over all the swamp, and all the muck, and all the nasty rhetoric and the shrill rhetoric that exists on both sides. We're going to look beyond that. We're going to look to the next generation. We're going to get this done for our precious nation. Support the reconciliation bill.
 
Gerald B.H. Solomon
Republican of New York
I've heard speaker after speaker after speaker after speaker stand up and say we need to spend more money here, we need to spend more money there. Well, ladies and gentlemen, we've been spending more money here and more money there for years and years and we have just about ruined this country.
 
Kweisi Mfume
Democrat of Maryland
Mr. Chairman I obviously rise in opposition to this legislation. It is bad for America, and in my opinion, it is bad policy.
Supporters of the bill before us are likely to argue and make talk about the future and they will say that over the six or seven years this bill will lead us to the balanced budget and that they are doing it for our future and for our children's future. The real question becomes, however, What kind of future will these generations be inheriting?
Many of us believe that they will be living in a future among seniors that do not receive adequate medical care or enough income to survive despite having worked all their lives. We believe they will be surrounded by undereducated people who were brought up in the public school system that was plagued by drugs and violence and out-of-date books. And that those same people will also be relegated then to menial jobs in this new future because they cannot afford a college education and because their Government has turned their back on them.
And everywhere we look in this new future there will be whole families without adequate housing and without adequate health. Entire communities will be decimated by crime, by the lack of viable businesses that no longer have incentive and by abject poverty.
And so many of us believe, Mr. Speaker, that this bill is not good, it is not good for the working poor, it is not good for the middle class of this country, the elderly, and it is certainly not good for the children of this nation who will feel the brunt of this bill's damage. . . .
With this bill we are saying that the Congress has new priorities in that future, and that in that future, under this bill, American people are not one of those priorities.
 
Sam M. Gibbons
Democrat of Florida
Listen to me, Mr. Solomon, when you vote for this bill today you are voting to end Medicare. You're voting to end Medicare. Don't be hoodwinked, it's in your proposal. It is in there in the fail-safe device. That will put an end to Medicare and the Gingrich-Dole plan to end Medicare is in this vote today.
This is a serious, serious matter. This is not just about balancing the budget. This is putting an end, this is the proposal that Dole and Gingrich have cooked up to get rid of Medicare.
 
Christopher Shays
Republican of Connecticut
We need to get our financial house in order and we need to balance our Federal budget. We need to save our trust funds, particularly Medicare, and we need to transform our social and corporate welfare state into an opportunity to society.
The bottom line and the most difficult part is saving our trust funds. We know what the board of trustees, the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, has said. They said that in basically seven years the Medicare Part A trust fund literally goes bankrupt, but nobody on that side of the aisle even wanted to address it until a few weeks ago.
We are addressing that fund, we're making sure that $333 billion is benefited to the Medicare Part A trust fund and $137 billion benefits the Medicare Part B trust fund. We have extended its insolvency and its ultimate bankruptcy from the year 2002 to the year 2010.
Now what's so important about the year 2010? That's when the baby boomers start to get into this fund, and at that point we have the baby boomers from the year 2010 to the year 2030. By the year 2030 baby boomers from the age 65 to 85 will be in the fund. What does that mean? We have workers right now, three and a half workers are working for each individual in the trust fund. Right now three and a third workers work for every person in the social security trust fund. By the year 2030, 35 years from now, there'll only be two workers.
We're talking about what has happened over the last 40 years, in particular the last 25. Our Congress and regretfully our Presidents have mortgaged the farm and now we're trying to buy it back for our kids.
 
Bill Archer
Republican of Texas
The great social experiment of the last 30 years has led to an unparalleled expansion of the Federal Government. Sadly it has failed to solve our nation's most difficult problems.
Nowhere is that more the case than in our miserable and unfortunate welfare system, where in the last 30 years we have spent over $5 trillion in the war on poverty, only to lose the war. . . .
Government cannot take the tax dollars that are earned by one citizen, hand them over to another and then believe that they have improved the life of either citizen. Yet for 30 years, Government tried that. It's called tax and spend.
Mr. Chairman, the time has come to admit that tax and spend has failed. It's time to reduce the size of Government and to give the tax dollars back to the people who earn them. And I say to my colleagues across the aisle -- it ain't your money.
 
Edward J. Markey
Democrat of Massachusetts
You know, back in the 1960's our political leaders asked us not what our country could do for us, but what we could do for our country.
Well, in 1995 the Republicans' motto is, Ask not what your country can do for you, but ask what you can do for the country club. This is a contract with the country club. This takes money out of the pockets of senior elderly, out of students, piles it up and then gives tens of billions of dollars of tax cuts to the wealthy in our country. The wealthy aren't asked to sacrifice.
You know, back in the Civil War, because the wealthy could buy their way out of the war, they said it was a rich man's war but a poor man's fight.
Well, here in this reconciliation battle in 1995, it's a rich man's war but it's a poor man's fight. The rich men get tremendous tens of thousands of dollars in tax breaks and the poor seniors have their Medicare premiums go up. The poor students and working class families have their student loan payments go up. And yet the Republicans stand here and tell us that they care about the working people in this country.
This is a wrong vote for America, just plain wrong.
 
Richard A. Gephardt
Democrat of Missouri and minority leader
This budget that we're about to vote on decreases the Earned Income Credit for families struggling to get into the middle class. In other words, it increases taxes on people that are struggling to get in the middle class, people earning $25,000 and $30,000 a year. And in the same budget we have a tax cut, a massive tax cut, for people at the top.
It takes my breath away. I cannot believe that someone seriously, in 1995, at the same time could make those two suggestions, simultaneously. It is wrong. It is morally wrong, it is economically wrong, it is the wrong thing for our country. . . .
But finally, let me say that I think this budget, more than anything that we've dealt with, presents a very clear and different vision between these two parties. This budget really presents a different vision for America.
A very prominent member in the other body said yesterday, "I was there fighting the fight, voting against Medicare, because we knew it would not work in 1965." My party, the Democratic Party, fought for and enacted Medicare in 1965. We believe that Medicare has helped the American people probably more than anything we as a people have ever done. And I believe the rhetoric we heard yesterday is really the real debate that we ought to be having.
If extremes in your party really do want to get rid of Medicare and to change it so dramatically that its emasculated, than let's have that debate, let's be proud to bring that difference to the American people. And if the extremes in your party really believe that the right thing to do is to raise taxes on the middle class, and lower taxes dramatically on the wealthiest people in this country, than let's have that debate between now and 1996.
Ladies and gentlemen of the House, in conclusion let me say, this budget and these next 14 or 15 months are about real differences and a difference in vision of where this country should go. Let the American people decide and I believe they will decide for Medicare and for the middle class of this country, not the wealthiest of this country.
 
IN THE SENATE
 
Jon Kyl
Republican of Arizona
If there's a single vote on which the American people will judge the success or the failure of this Congress, if there is a single vote this session that will change the course of American history, it will be the vote on the Balanced Budget Reconciliation Act which is before us today.
This single vote will determine whether we finally face up to the grim reality of a national debt that is $4.9 trillion and growing daily, a debt that now amounts to $18,500 for every man, woman and child in this country. Or whether we continue this spending spree that we've been on for the last 20 years at the expense of our children and grandchildren.
This single vote is more important than the votes on the balanced budget amendment and the line item veto. Those were the tools that will help us balance the budget and keep it there.
This bill actually balances the budget.
This single vote will determine whether we keep the promises we made to the American people last fall that we would balance the budget and provide badly-needed tax relief.
Or whether it's business as usual. Promises out the door as soon as it's time to make the final decisions, the difficult decisions.
 
Tom Harkin
Democrat of Iowa
One of the obligations we have is to insure that future generations have the ability to get a decent, sound education so that they can raise their families and they can compete in the world marketplace. That also is a moral obligation, and what this reconciliation bill does is pull the rug out from underneath that obligation that we have for future generations.
Mr. President, we hear a lot of talk about the tax breaks that are in this bill. And those of us on this side have been talking about the $245 billion tax breaks for the wealthy at the expense of the elderly and Medicare cuts. Well, there is an $11 billion cut in student aid here, the largest cut in student aid in our history.
But what we're not hearing about are the hidden taxes that the Republicans have in this bill: the stealth taxes. . . .
This budget adds about $700 to $2,500 of debt per student. So that's a hidden tax on our students. Adds up to $5,000 in additional cost for families who use the PLUS loan program, another tax on students and their families. And then it imposes a direct Federal tax of .85 percent on colleges and universities participating in the student loan programs, a direct tax on colleges. And of course they're going to have to pass that on to their students. And last, of course, it forces schools out of the direct-loan program that has been so successful.
We hear about the tax breaks of the wealthy, we don't hear about the stealth taxes -- that it's in the Republicans' bills, and mainly it falls on students. . . .
And who does it hit? It hits moderate and low-income families the hardest. That's why we have to defeat this reconciliation bill and make sure that these students can get a decent education.
 
Larry E. Craig
Republican of Idaho
The future of our children, Mr. President, and our grandchildren, does not depend on a student loan. It depends on the economy of this country, and the vitality of that economy that produces the student loans, that creates the jobs, that offers the future, and the opportunity. . . .
I find it absolutely amazing that this President will argue a $200 billion deficit and a debt that heads toward $5 trillion and say that that's growth and that's opportunity and that's going to create a productive economy.
Let me tell you what that kind of $200 billion deficit does to the average child of today, the college student of tomorrow, the job seeker in the future. The average child today will pay $5,000 additional taxes over their lifetime with that $200 billion defecit. The Clinton budget projects deficits of that range out through the year 2000 and that alone adds up to an additional tax burden of $40,000 in the lifetime of that child.
 
Don Nickles
Republican of Oklahoma
Many of the allegations and the statements that are made are certainly not taking a look at the overall big picture. I want to help students too, and I understand that there may be a leadership amendment that's going to make some modifications into proposals that are being discussed, and I think I'll wait for the discussions on the specifics until that amendment is offered. . . .
But I will tell you the best news that we could give my kids who are going college is to balance the budget. And we only have one proposal before us to balance the budget. And that is the proposal that the Republicans have put forth that will give us a balanced budget.
I remember going to a town meeting not too long ago and somebody that was about 23 years old raised her hand and said, "Senator, will I ever see balanced budget in my lifetime?" And they were just as serious as they could possibly be.
Well, later today or maybe tomorrow we're going to be voting on a balanced budget, but there's only one. President Clinton doesn't have a balanced budget. We do.
 
Charles S. Robb
Democrat of Virginia
I have long believed that it would take courage and wisdom to develop and implement a plan that would lead to a balance budget. Without the courage to make tough choices and the wisdom to place budget policy above partisan politics, our ability to develop an equitable plan that can stand the test of time and public opinion is severely limited. And while I give our Republican friends credit for bringing this package to the floor, I must say that a certain element of this plan does not reflect courage, wisdom or equity.
A particular concern to me are the tax breaks which you've been included in the bill. Mr. President, it does not take courage to cut taxes. That's one of the easiest votes a legislature can cast. What takes courage is to resist politically popular tax cuts at a time we have a nearly $5 billion, $5 trillion debt.
And even a unified balanced budget is at least seven years away if we get there at all. And for all the talk about fiscal responsibility recently, how can we endorse a $245 billion tax cut that makes balancing the budget much more difficult and adds to the debt over the next seven years? . . .
It's not courageous, it's not wise, it's not equitable and I would implore my colleagues to reject the proposition that we should have tax cuts before we have a balanced budget.
 
Bob Graham
Democrat of Florida
This reconciliation proposal is filled with risks: risk of the unknown, risks that have consequences that are beyond our ability to forecast. There is no area in this entire legislation that has a greater risk to the people of this country than the proposals in Medicaid.
We are proposing to cut Medicaid by $187 billion. I repeat, a program last year which had a total Federal expenditure of $89 billion, we're going to cut, over seven years, by $187 billion. It is at risk because we are proposing, for those funds that are left, to place them in an inflexible block grant without Federal participation in terms of dealing with unexpected circumstances, and we are freezing in many of the inequities that have made this program inappropriate in the past.
 
Pete V. Domenici
Republican of New Mexico
Mr. President, speaking of risks, the biggest risk our nation faces is that we not balance our budget and that we continue to spend our children's and grandchildren's money to pay for programs we cannot afford. Obviously, this program is growing so fast, it's unsustainable. But anyone that thinks it is being cut is just not reading the facts. We're going to increase this program to more than $94 billion next year, $124 billion in 2002, and over the entire period of time, this program will increase at a rather healthy rate while most programs in the national Government are either frozen or reduced.
It's time we reformed this system so we can deliver on what we promised. But we also have to deliver on a promise to get interest rates down, to have growth and jobs for our children, and we cannot have the status quo and do that also.

CITY: WASHINGTON, DC, USA (53%);

HEADLINE: U.S. Inquiry Begins on Price For Newsprint

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Justice Department said today that it had begun a significant investigation into possible anticompetitive pricing practices in the newsprint industry.
A spokeswoman at the Justice Department, Gina Talamona, announced the antitrust investigation but declined to identify which companies or individuals had been under scrutiny, or to say how far the investigation had progressed or when it could lead to possible legal action. 
 The announcement followed a series of complaints from newspaper publishers this year about the sharply escalating prices of newsprint. The increases have been cutting into newspaper profits, leading to layoffs, newsstand price increases and reductions in the space allotted for news.
Newsprint typically accounts for 20 percent or more of a newspaper's costs and is the second-largest expense, after salaries.
The rise of newsprint prices has been cited as a reason for the closing of The Houston Post and the consolidations at the Times-Mirror Company, as well as the merger of The Milwaukee Journal and The Sentinel.
Three dozen companies produce most of the newsprint consumed in the United States. Antitrust laws bar producers from collaborating on price increases, and suppliers have cited rising prices for pulp and a tight worldwide market for all grades of paper as the reason for the price increases.
An official of a paper industry organization said tonight that he knew nothing of the investigation. The official, Richard E. Storat, a vice president of the American Forest and Paper Association, said when reached at a meeting in Palm Beach, Fla., "This is something we have no knowledge of."
Newsprint is sold by the metric ton, or 2,204 pounds, and large newspapers use hundreds of thousands of metric tons of newsprint annually. For instance, it takes roughly 300,000 metric tons of newsprint to produce The New York Times every year. The price of newsprint has risen steadily in recent years, from $469 a metric ton in 1994 to $675 this spring.
Financial analysts and experts in the newsprint and newspaper industries say the explanation for the speed of the price climb is the law of supply and demand, which has had a sharp effect because an unusual combination of factors has exaggerated the price swings typical of commodity markets.
After suffering huge losses in recent years, when newsprint prices were at their lows, the newsprint industry has been trying to catch up. At the same time, the costs of raw materials used to make newsprint have climbed sharply.
Moreover, demand for newsprint has been up worldwide. As newspapers recover from the recession, they are selling more advertising and printing more pages. But supply has not been keeping up because mills have been running near capacity for years and virtually no new mills have been built in North America. 
 "An official of a paper industry organization said tonight that he knew nothing of the investigation. The official, Richard E. Storat, a vice president of the American Forest and Paper Association, said when reached at a meeting in Palm Beach, Fla., 'This is something we have no knowledge of.' "

CORRECTION-DATE: October 28, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a Justice Department investigation of pricing in the newsprint industry referred imprecisely to the price of paper. Newsprint cost about $675 a metric ton last spring; it is now $730 to $750 and is expected to be around $800 early next year.
In addition, because of a production error, the continuation of the article included a scrambled passage in some copies. The passage should have read:

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall Amid Worries Over Earnings

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market tumbled again yesterday as traders and investors continued to find signs of consumer weakness in corporate earnings reports.
More disappointing earnings results yesterday fueled the market's nervousness. A durable goods report that was stronger than expected also revived worries that the Federal Reserve would not cut short-term interest rates again this year. A rate cut would mean lower borrowing costs for companies, thus improving the prospects for earnings growth. 
 "It doesn't take much to get a decline in stock prices going these days," said Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. "If anything is bothering investors, it's the volatility in the market. So if you are looking for a reason to sell, you can find it everywhere."
The Dow Jones industrial average, which at one point during the session fell more 80 points for its largest one-day decline in more than three months, partly recovered late in the day to close at 4,703.82, down 49.86 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.75 points, to 576.72, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 8.90 points, to 1,017.57.
A drop of more than 50 points in the Dow industrials at 2:27 P.M. set off the New York Stock Exchange's "collar," an effort to stabilize the market by curbing computer-guided trading programs. There were four such sell programs and one buy program yesterday, which accounted for 82 percent of the final decline in the average.
"This is an edgy market, but it's not the end of the world," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst for Birinyi Associates. "This is not the correction."
Declining issues on the Big Board overwhelmed the advancers, 1,727 to 664. A total of 467.7 million shares changed hands, compared with 433.6 million shares Wednesday.
A Commerce Department report that durable-goods orders surged unexpectedly by 3 percent last month was interpreted by analysts as an indication of faster economic growth that might cause the Federal Reserve to hold off on lowering interest rates. As a result, bond prices plummeted. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.39 percent, from 6.32 percent on Wednesday.
Among the companies that announced weak earnings yesterday were Xerox, Browning-Ferris and Philips Electronics. Xerox dropped 3 5/8, to 131; Browning-Ferris declined 2 3/4, to 28, and Philips Electronics fell 5, to 36 7/8.
Drug stocks, which have had run-ups recently, slid as signs developed that their earnings growth had peaked. Johnson & Johnson declined 1 5/8, to 80 3/8; American Home Products was down 1 1/8, to 89 1/2, and Upjohn fell 7/8, to 48 3/4.
Money-center banks were under pressure for the seventh day in the last eight, with more and more questions arising over the quality of their consumer credit-card loan portfolios. BankAmerica closed at 58 5/8, down 1 1/4; Chase closed at 56 1/2, down 1/8, and J.P. Morgan closed at 76 1/2, down 1/2.
Petroleum producers and refiners also fell, following a downgrading by Merrill Lynch of its investment opinion on Exxon -- partially because of fears that oil prices may get lower. Exxon dropped 1 1/2, to 75; Texaco fell 1, to 67 1/4; Amoco declined 5/8, to 64 1/2, and Mobil was down 1 5/8, to 100.
 Another article in Business Day on Oct. 27, about the previous day's stock trading, described Xerox's earnings incorrectly. Xerox's net income, which rose 27 percent, came in slightly higher than Wall Street analysts had forecast.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 6, 1995, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report by Reuters in Business Day on Oct. 27 about the financial results of the Xerox Corporation referred to one figure incorrectly. Xerox's property and casualty insurance company, Talegen Holdings Inc., lost $20 million in the third quarter; it did not take a charge of that amount. The article also misstated the ownership of Talegen. It remains a unit of Xerox.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 693 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy Grew in Summer At Surprisingly Brisk Pace
 
The economy rebounded vigorously over the summer, growing at a 4.2 percent pace that surpassed nearly all expectations, the Commerce Department reported, while inflation, already low, subsided still further. "We're on the right track," President Clinton declared, trying to take advantage of the sunny report for his budget negotiations with the Congress. [Page 1.]
 
Stock prices rebounded after Thursday's selloff as money managers took heart that inflation appeared to be under control. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 37.93 points, to 4,741.75. Bank stocks and technology issues were strong. [37.]
 
Bond prices swung widely as traders first feared that the strong economy would keep the Fed from lowering interest rates further, then tempered their reaction, seeing hope for a budget accord. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.35. [36.]
 
Allied Signal to Cut 3,100 Jobs
 
Allied Signal reported a 15 percent rise in third-quarter net income but said profit in its automotive parts unit was off. The company said it would cut 3,100 jobs in that division, or about 3.7 percent of its total work force, and quit the car anti-lock brakes business. Allied's shares rose $2, to $43.375. [35.]
 
Aetna Earnings Jump 42%
 
Aetna Life reported an unexpectedly large 42 percent gain in third-quarter earnings from operations, to $212.6 million, citing reduced costs for pollution cleanup. [35.]
 
Look Out Coke, Arizona Is Coming
 
The small but feisty Arizona iced tea company is entering the cola wars. It is now making three flavored colas and a root beer. The line is being watched closely because of Arizona's record for smart product innovations. [35.]
 
Oil Partners Press Moscow
 
Kazakhstan and its partner Chevron are trying to win Russia's agreement to ship more oil from their Tengiz fields. They are also planning to build a pipeline to connect to the Black Sea. If successful, Chevron could finally cash in on its $1 billion investment. [34.]
 
Airbags Tied to Childrens' Deaths
 
Eight children may have been killed by airbags, according to a Government official, who said a redesign may be needed. [6.]
 
For TV Industry, a Cut-Rate Sale
 
Buried in the budget bill is a plan to sell off a chunk of the nation's airwaves over the next seven years for an estimated $14 billion. It would give broadcasters licenses for "advanced television service," such as high-definition or interactive television, that Government economists say could be worth $70 billion. [9.]
 
The Senate veered away from the House in approving several changes to the bill to balance the Federal budget by 2002. It killed a provision to let corporations withdraw billions of dollars in surplus assets from their pension funds, retained the Federal guarantee of Medicaid coverage for a variety of poor people and kept regulations on nursing homes. [1.]
 
Tougher Limits on Lobbyists
 
House Republicans plan a vote in November on tighter registration rules for lobbyists and on banning gifts to representatives and their staffs. The Senate adopted similar measures during the summer. [8.]
 
No Comment to the Japanese
 
In an unusually tart exchange, the State Department told the Japanese Ambassador that it would not explain or confirm reports that the C.I.A. spied on Japanese negotiators during tense economic talks this year. [4.]
Japanese regulators accused Merrill Lynch Japan of violating a rule meant to prevent brokerage firms from manipulating stocks during new-securities sales. Some analysts saw the move as a retaliation for American criticism of the big loss at Daiwa Bank. [34.]
 
Smaller Awards in Implant Case
 
The judge presiding over the silicone breast implant case disclosed details of a proposed
settlement, including proposals that would further reduce awards to claimants. [10.]

Dollar Gains, Aided by Peso
 
The dollar gained, benefiting from recoveries in the Mexican peso and French franc. It rose to 1.4090 German marks and 101.93 yen. [46.]

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET;
White House Gets Specific on New Debt Ceiling

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
In the Administration's latest entreaty to Congress to avoid hitting the national debt ceiling in coming days, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has asked for a temporary increase of $85 billion, which he said should keep the Government running until mid-January.
Until today, Mr. Rubin and Speaker Newt Gingrich had parried over the debt limit, and the White House had declined to specify how large a temporary increase it would find acceptable. But with only days left before the current $4.9 trillion limit on borrowing is reached, Mr. Rubin made his first specific appeal in a letter to Mr. Gingrich. 
 The Administration's chances of getting that large an increase are almost nil. Congressional Republicans have not committed to any short-term increase, and they say that any permanent increase in the limit would be included in the spending bill they send to President Clinton. Mr. Clinton has repeatedly vowed to veto that bill, and said he would not submit to "economic blackmail" by signing it simply to achieve an increase in the debt limit.
Earlier this week Mr. Rubin said that unless an agreement was reached by Nov. 1, the Treasury would have to put off a $100 billion quarterly re-funding of its debt, a step that could have considerable cost. He has said repeatedly that the Republicans would have to bear the responsibility for driving the United States to the edge of default; the Republicans have said that he has manufactured the crisis.

HEADLINE: Georgia Neese Clark Gray, 95, First Woman as U.S. Treasurer

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Georgia Neese Clark Gray, whose signature -- as Georgia Neese Clark -- appeared on some $30 billion in paper money while she was the first woman to serve as Treasurer of the United States, died on Thursday at the Brewster Place retirement community in Topeka, Kan. She was 95.
President Harry S. Truman chose Mrs. Gray to be Treasurer in 1949, a year the Democratic Party promised a New Deal for women aspiring to high office. She had been a small-town Kansas banker and a Democratic National Committeewoman since 1936. Her confirmation by the Senate was unanimous. 
 As the nation's 29th Treasurer, she was in charge of all the bills and coins along with Government securities held in the vaults in Washington. The office is a division of the Treasury Department. When Dwight D. Eisenhower became President in 1953 he selected another woman to succeed her, Ivy Baker Priest, a Utah Republican.
Mrs. Gray was a highly visible figure in Democratic Party affairs, including its national conventions. She was an associate of Eleanor Roosevelt, with whom she often shared the speakers' platform.
After serving as a National Committeewoman for 28 years, Mrs. Gray resigned in 1964 to devote herself full time to banking and other business and farming interests.
Georgia Neese was born in Richland, a rural community of about 200 people 15 miles southeast of Topeka, where her father, Albert, had founded the Richland State Bank in 1892.
She received a bachelor's degree in economics from what is now Washburn University of Topeka in 1921. She then studied acting in New York and toured the country with stock companies for 10 years.
Her stage career ended when her father's health faltered and the arrival of talking pictures diminished the appeal of traveling stage troupes. By then she had married George M. Clark, her manager. They were divorced in the mid-1940's.
At her father's death in 1937 she became president of the bank; in 1964 she moved it to Topeka and renamed it the Capital City State Bank.
Her friend and mentor, Harry Truman, helped to dedicate the new bank. "Mrs. Gray is the only United States Treasurer since the Civil War who really worked at her job," he told the crowd. "She knows money affairs as well as any man, and anyone who brings their money here will know it is in charge of someone who knows how to take care of it."
Mrs. Gray was remarried in 1953 to Andrew J. Gray, a former New York and Washington newspaperman and press agent. He died last year. She is survived by a nephew, Ward Keller of Manhattan.
